column2: Broadway has its first commercial failure of the 2010-11 season: David Mamet's play "A Life in the Theater," which stars stage and television star Patrick Stewart and the former "Grey's Anatomy" actor T.R. Knight, will close on Nov. 28, five weeks ahead of the originally scheduled end of the run.

It's just like the N.H.L. to pat itself on the back and trumpet its great accomplishments, then turn around and stab itself in the back, or at least shoot itself in the foot. It's a pathology the league has exhibited repeatedly when it comes to changes designed to improve the game.

Queens has the highest retail vacancy rate in New York City - at 13.7 percent, it is nearly double the rate that Manhattan had in the second quarter of this year. But if there's one spot where empty storefronts are a rare commodity, it is on Roosevelt Avenue, between roughly 72nd Street and 84th Street, a bustling commercial district on the edge of Jackson Heights.

Some people think it's a scourge on neighborhoods. Bloggers devote Web sites to mocking its worst examples. While vinyl siding may seem like a material that simply protects homes from the elements, it draws every element of opinion about its appearance and presence in neighborhoods.

Amateur astronomers in this city don't have it easy. The brightest lights in New York's nighttime burn from Broadway marquees and skyscraper windows, obscuring Orion, Gemini and the Dippers from their rightful place in our sky.

The College Board recently released its latest report on college costs, and it is chock-full of nutritious charts and graphs. One takeaway is that while sticker prices for college tuition may be rising,  for the typical student out-of-pocket higher education costs have actually fallen in recent years, thanks to more generous financial aid.

Updated, Tuesday, Nov. 9, 11:05 a.m. |The mini-spike in murders that has pushed the homicide rate up 15 percent so far this year continued with three more killings this morning, following four on Saturday night and Sunday. Through Sunday, there were 459 murders this year, compared with 399 at this time last year, the police said this morning. Here are the seven new killings:

When I dropped off a rental car recently in New York City after visiting my daughter at her college's parents weekend, I suffered a severe case of sticker shock. I had been cursing myself for forgetting to refuel the midsize car in New Jersey before re-entering New York. Now I would be stuck paying New York gas prices.

Horse racing let us down a lot last weekend. We saw a disgraceful and indefensible jockey fight in the winner's circle; a perplexing series of events that led to Life At Ten jogging around the track at Churchill Downs under the lights; a fatal injury to Rough Sailing in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile Turf.

Jane Birkin may be best known for her namesake Hermès bag and her scandalous duet with Serge Gainsbourg on 'Je T'aime Moi Non Plus," but these are only specks of sequins in her glittery 45-year career. At 64 years young, Birkin has recorded more than 20 albums, acted in more than 65 films, worked as a designer, a model and a muse, and actively supported a slew of humanitarian causes. Along the way she even picked up an Order of the British Empire title.

The marathon world-record holder Haile Gebrselassie announced his spur-of-the-moment decision to retire from the sport after he dropped out of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, but his fellow Ethiopian athletes and fans, and others close to him, believe he may reconsider the decision.

In addition to depriving the Democratic Party its House majority, this political season has cost us the services of three of the country's most prominent "centrists" - Evan Bayh, the Indiana Democrat who grew so tired of the Senate that he declined to run for re-election; Charlie Crist, the Florida governor and Senate hopeful who left the G.O.P. to run, and lose, as an independent against Marco Rubio; and Arlen Specter, who was defeated in Pennsylvania's Democratic primary after he switched parties to avoid a primary challenge. I've written critically about each of these figures before (Specter here, Crist here and here, Bayh here), but I think it's worth pausing a moment, amid all the midterm analysis, to emphasize what they represented and why they won't be missed.

First operas, then ballets and now, increasingly, orchestras. The Los Angeles Philharmonic has joined the movement to transmit performances live to movie theaters. The orchestra announced Monday that it would beam three performances conducted by Gustavo Dudamel later this season, reaching 450 theaters in the United States and Canada.

You put Michael Jackson's name on a record, you'd think it's a given that Jackson is somehow involved in the material it contains. But the Epic Records division of Sony Music now finds itself in the unusual position of having to reaffirm that the King of Pop really did provide the vocals for a new release being put out under Jackson's name - and to make clear that Prince is not connected to the album.

Ever since the diminutive mezcalería La Bótica opened in Mexico City's fashionable Condesa neighborhood on Cinco de Mayo 2005, mezcal has steadily risen from hipster novelty to ubiquity in restaurants, neighborhood pubs and classic cantinas alike. Savvy chilangos have reappraised the country's rich alco-history, looking beyond tequila - and lately even mezcal - for new sources of national pride and connoisseurship.

One of the hallmarks of great puzzles is that when you encounter them for the first time, you get the feeling that they are impossible. Like Alex, our hustled victim, and the way he felt about the pizza puzzle a few weeks ago, you think: "That just can't be. There must be some mistake." In the very best puzzles, some residue of this feeling remains even after you know the answer. Today's puzzle is of this type. It concerns a historical scenario very similar to that of the prisoners and light bulb puzzle a couple of months ago.

Red Bull Racing clinched its first ever Formula One constructors' championship at the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, but the landmark moment was overshadowed by the team's decision not to institute team orders to give its driver Mark Webber a better shot at the drivers' title.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Fans of the short-lived ABC drama "Eli Stone'' were surely happy to see its star, Jonny Lee Miller, turn up on "Dexter'' on Sunday night. I know I was. Mr. Miller aces just-shy-of-sleazy charm, though here he is a full-on sleaze and psychopath: a motivational speaker named Jordan Chase who seems to appeal to sexually disenfranchised average Joes. It's a guy not unlike the one Tom Cruise played in "Magnolia,'' if that character had led a band of deranged torturers, which Chase seems to be doing.

Updated | 1:57 p.m. In a new video message posted on a jihadist Web forum on Monday, Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born cleric based in Yemen whose most inflammatory sermons were withdrawn from YouTube last week, said that the killing of Americans by Muslims requires no special sanction.

Some readers have asked about the graphs that show up in some posts; many of them come from FRED, the terrific data site of the St. Louis Fed. FRED lets you both create and customize charts of US data, and lets you create permalinks to the charts too -- a significant convenience in my case, because for technical reasons creating a non-FRED chart requires me to move back and forth between the Times and Princeton VPNs.

--A page one story by Landon Thomas Jr. on Monday looks at Irish debt, and what it portends for Europe. John Bruton, former prime minister of that embattled nation, assures us via Bloomberg that a default is unthinkable -- short-sellers, beware. The ever astute Morgan Kelly, however, warns that while bad loans to developers have caused great grief so far, greater grief awaits the Irish when their long recession finally causes a wave of mortgage defaults. And finally, looking back to 2006, what do you want to bet that Malcolm Gladwell wants to revise this analysis. Toward the end of the Irish expansion, growth was built on cheap debt, a real estate bubble and a smattering of fraud.

Texas officials step up their efforts to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its authority to regulate the state's carbon dioxide emissions, the highest in the nation. How did technology become both my new BFF and my arch-enemy? I find myself lusting for any iGadget that I can afford, wouldn't think of going on vacation without my Kindle, and tell students how lucky they are to be able to Google their college searches. Life is good and clean and quick and secure when it's online.

There are those performers whose outgoing characters are the polar opposites of their shy, retreating selves, and then there is Molly Shannon. In her six seasons at "Saturday Night Live," Ms. Shannon embodied tireless, talkative creations like Sally O'Malley, the 50-year-old dancer; Jeannie Darcy, the hopeless stand-up comedian; and, of course, Mary Katherine Gallagher, the Catholic schoolgirl with dreams of superstardom. Many of those same qualities are on display in Ms. Shannon's performance in the Broadway musical "Promises, Promises," in which she plays Marge MacDougall (a role she took over from the Tony winner Katie Finneran), a barfly who lands in the lap of Chuck Baxter (played by Sean Hayes) on the worst possible night. And they are all characters with which she shares a thing or two, if a recent telephone interview with the enthusiastic, impassioned, occasionally out-of-breath Ms. Shannon is anything to go by.

When Andrew M. Cuomo takes over as governor on Jan. 1, he will bring a management style that is demanding and focused, insistent on results and disinclined to entertain dissent. In interviews with more than 50 former aides and colleagues, The Times found a picture of his leadership emerging: He sets his sights on a few priorities, frequently to underscore his political goals, plots several steps ahead and is fixated on avoiding mistakes.

President Obama gave a fine speech this morning to the Indian parliament -- and to China and Pakistan, which clearly were intended audiences as well. That emphasis on how democracy isn't an impediment for a developing country seeking economic growth was all about China. Likewise the stress on the links between two great democracies amounted to a studied contrast with Sino-U.S. relations, especially in the aftermath of the Liu Xiaobo Nobel Peace Prize.

Though it can be difficult to get excited for Halloween-themed television programs a week after the holiday, the producers of "The Simpsons" did their best to get over that roadblock by resorting to some good old-fashioned star power. For a segment called "Tweenlight" that at least began as a parody of the "Twilight" books and movies, the show recruited as the voice of its hunky young vampire none other than the white-hot British heartthrob at the center of a money-minting fantasy film franchise: Daniel Radcliffe, the "Harry Potter" star. The Palais de Tokyo, which has hosted its share of underground art, is headed underground in an entirely different way. The museum has inaugurated a new 97,000-square-foot basement space that links it to the adjacent Musée d'Art Moderne. Initially created in 1937 for the the World Expo, the space had been sealed up for years. It is now to be reconverted into a contemporary art space by 2012 -- but in the meantime, the derelict environment is serving as an inspiration to one artist.

Edison Pena could be forgiven for having to slow to a walk at times during the New York City Marathon on Sunday. But after fighting through knee pain to jog across the finish line in under six hours, Pena wanted to clear something up.

HERAT, Afghanistan -- Even the poorest families in Afghanistan have matches and cooking fuel. The combination usually sustains life. But it also can be the makings of a horrifying escape: from poverty, from forced marriages, from the abuse and despondency that can be the fate of Afghan women. The night before she burned herself, Gul Zada took her children to her sister's for a family party. All seemed well. Later it emerged that she had not brought a present, and a relative had chided her for it, said her son Juma Gul.

It is an old strategy among parcel delivery drivers in New York City: Leave a parking summons tucked on your windshield and hope the ticket agent walks right past your illegally parked truck, believing it has already been ticketed. ''That trick never works,'' said John P. Lopez, a FedEx deliveryman with a route in West Harlem. ''Everyone knows it. The agents walk right up, read the old ticket you got earlier at some other location, and they write a new one. Now you got two.''

The yearly dance between retailers trying to drive fourth-quarter sales and consumers waiting for big discounts has begun. According to Thomson Reuters, the increase in sales in October at 28 large retailers (excluding Wal-Mart) was only 1.6 percent. Some retailers are moving up their big sales usually reserved for the day after Thanksgiving, amid 9.6 percent unemployment. Consumers are casting a critical eye. Among the top 25 retailers whose scores rose the most from September to October, no retailer had an overall value score over 50, out of a maximum of 100 points. SHELLY FREIERMAN

LONDON -- When interest rates soared last week on Irish government bonds, it served as a grim warning to other indebted nations of how difficult and even politically ruinous it could be to roll back decades of public sector largess. An Irish bond market already in free fall plunged further after Irelandannounced on Thursday that it planned to nearly double its package of spending cuts and tax increases to try to rein in its huge deficit. Investors took it not as a sign of resolve but rather of Ireland's desperation and uncertainty about the true extent of its problems.

WASHINGTON -- American authorities sent David C. Headley, a small-time drug dealer and sometime informant, to work for them in Pakistan months after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical Islamic groups, according to court records and interviews. Not long after Mr. Headley arrived there, he began training with terrorists, eventually playing a key role in the 2008 attacks that left 164 people dead in Mumbai. The October 2001 warning was dismissed, the authorities said, as the ire of a jilted girlfriend and for lack of proof. Less than a month later, those concerns did not come up when a federal court in New York granted Mr. Headley an early release from probation so that he could be sent to work for the United States Drug Enforcement Administration in Pakistan. It is unclear what Mr. Headley was supposed to do in Pakistan for the Americans.

LOS ANGELES - With little fanfare, Hollywood's movie and television production companies and its principal actors unions early on Sunday morning said they had agreed tentatively to a new three-year contract that provides a 6 percent increase in wages over three years, and increases health and benefits contributions by the companies. The agreement comes well in advance of the current contract's expiration, in June 2011, and follows weeks of closed-door bargaining between the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers and both the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists. The early settlement points to a new mood in Hollywood labor relations, which have become less confrontational as both companies and unions try to cope with softer economic conditions. In late 2007, movie and television writers began a three-month strike, then members of the Screen Actors Guild worked for months without a contract during a contentious bargaining period. This time around, the actors guild bargained in tandem with a sister guild, the federation, and reached a tentative deal in a relatively trouble-free process. The new contract, which also provides for expanded coverage in the new media area, is subject to approval by members of the two unions. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

VERRETT--Shirley. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the great American singer Shirley Verrett. Acclaimed both in mezzo-soprano and soprano roles, she sang 126 performances with the company between 1968 and 1990. Verrett made her Met debut in the title role of Carmen and earned accolades for her unique artistry in a wide range of roles that included Eboli, Azucena, Tosca, and Dalila. Her versatility allowed her to make Met history by singing both Adalgisa and Norma in Bellini's Norma in the same season. In the Met premiere of Berlioz's Les Troyens, she was heard as both Cassandra and Dido in one evening. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

A group of about 30 people gathered on Saturday afternoon in front of the Lyceum Theater to protest a matinee of the new Broadway musical ''The Scottsboro Boys,'' which retells the story of nine African-Americans between 12 and 19 who were falsely convicted of raping two white women in Alabama in 1931. The show, written by the celebrated team of John Kander and the late Fred Ebb and directed by the Tony-winning director Susan Stroman, uses the minstrel tradition to tell the story of how racism infected the judicial system. The protesters, organized by the Freedom Party, argued that the use of minstrelsy and blackface were racist. Ms. Stroman said she was disappointed that people who probably had not seen the musical misunderstood that the creators were not celebrating the minstrel tradition but rather using it to reveal the evils of the system.

As the men or women's elite runners jostled their way through Brooklyn, a sprint to the finish was under way in Central Park in the wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon. David Weir of Britain held off Masazumi Soejima of Japan in an exciting uphill battle through the park in one of the closest finishes in the 11-year history of the race. Weir finished at 1 hour 37 minutes 29 seconds, Soejima at 1:37:31. The two-second gap topped the three-second differential set in 2004. Last year's race ended in a dead heat.

Pittsburgh Steelers (5-2) at Cincinnati Bengals (2-5)8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Steelers by 5 1/2 Cincinnati has the statistical profile of a team with a 4-3 record. The Bengals have outgained their opponents, 2,488 yards to 2,394; they hold a 16-12 turnover advantage; and they do not have huge disadvantages in penalty or special-teams yardage. The Bengals keep losing because they make lots of little mistakes. They have the worst short-yardage defense in the N.F.L., with opponents churning out first downs or goal-line touchdowns against them 94 percent of the time. On offense, they have fallen in love with play-action passing on third-and-short, but they are awful at it. If the Bengals could have stopped one more drive and sustained one more of their own, they might have beaten the Browns, the Buccaneers and the Dolphins. Pick: Bengals.

Harvey Fierstein's two Tony Awards for best actor resulted from his signature talent playing women, as the drag artist Arnold Beckwith in his play "Torch Song Trilogy" (1982) and as house frau Edna Turnblad in the musical "Hairspray" (2002). He also won a Tony in 1984 for writing the book of the musical "La Cage aux Folles," which centered on the drag performer Albin, a role that won Tonys for George Hearn in the original "La Cage" and for Douglas Hodge in the current Broadway revival.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art plans to undertake a multiyear redesign and renovation of its plaza on Fifth Avenue and said it had selected a landscape architecture firm, OLIN, to lead the project. In a telephone interview the Met's director, Thomas P. Campbell, said that the need to replace the museum's two fountains, which have been turned off for several years, led to a broader discussion of the plaza's layout. "Obviously the front steps are one of the great gathering points in New York, but the rest of the space is perhaps less successful," he said. Apart from the steps, he said, the rest of the space, including the fountains, would be completely rethought. He would not specify a budget but said, "Obviously, it's going to be an expensive undertaking." A museum trustee, David H. Koch, has pledged $10 million for the project. The Met expects to complete the renovation by 2015.

The multi-talented Alexander Cowings brought together several forms of performance in his explosive show at the Producer's Club in midtown Manhattan. Joined by the dancer Calvin Booker, the two performed the seldom-seen art of hip hop tap, championed by Savion Glover in the 1990's with the hit show "Bring In Da Noise, Bring In Da Funk." Cowings crooned a number of original R&B diddies, backed by a live band of drums, electric guitar, and stand-up bass, marking intervals in the music with furious bursts of tap dancing. The evening ended with a powerful performance by Cowings's mother, Kim Kalesti, and an open tap jam.

The International Herald Tribune is hosting its 10th annual luxury conference today and tomorrow. In keeping with previous conferences, the IHT has chosen a theme that captures the fashion mood of the moment. This time round, the focus is on heritage and, not surprisingly, the event is being held in London. Suzy Menkes, the IHT fashion editor for the past 22 years, is grilling speakers like Alber Elbaz, Karl Lagerfeld, David Lauren and Christopher Bailey on far-ranging topics, including whether luxury brands need a history to have a future and how quality and craftsmanship can be meaningful in the era of fast fashion. In the video above, Elbaz reveals how his own heritage is defined by something his mother once told him: be big in work but small in life.

On Monday, Melissa Clark (@goodappetite) posted a question on Twitter about whether or not cookbooks should contain pictures. Matt Armendariz (@mattarmendariz), a food blogger and photographer, took a poll on the matter.  I weighed in wondering if the opinions I shared with Times readers in an article I wrote on this very issue five years ago should be revised.  I asked if, with the increase of people taking pictures of their prepared food, cookbook authors would be  wise to include pictures to provide reference for budding shutterbugs.  Since many of you come here to learn about taking better food pictures, I would love to know what you all think. Should cookbooks always include photography or not?  Please post your thoughts here.

Gant, the ne plus ultra of preppy attire, is going back to its roots and setting up shop in one of New Haven's most historic buildings. Opening on Nov. 22, the Gant Campus Store - set in the site of the former Langrock Fine Clothes men's department store -- will house a selection of Gant, Gant Rugger and Gant by Michael Bastian. The Gant brand is also working with Yale for a spring re-release of the defunct Yale Co-op shirt collection, which was manufactured during the 1960s. (Every card-carrying Yalie owned at least one of these Co-op shirts back in the day.) The Moment caught up with the Gant president and chief executive, Ari Hoffman, to find out more about the homecoming.

Democrats who support Nancy Pelosi's bid to remain her party's leader in the House - over the objection of more conservative Democrats - have been pointing to a historical precedent. The legendary Sam Rayburn of Texas did stay on as minority leader after Democrats lost control of the House in 1946 and again in 1952, and no Democratic speaker has faced a similar dilemma since. (Tom Foley of Washington had the job in 1994 when Democrats were turned out and he lost his bid for a 15th term.)

It used to be much simpler to earn your environmental stripes, but these days anything short of brewing your own biodiesel gets you dirty looks in yoga class. At least Hertz is making things a little easier. Beginning in late December, customers in New York, Washington, D.C., and San Francisco, and on select college campuses, will be able to rent a Nissan Leaf, the first mass-market, zero-emissions electric car. The Leaf can go about 100 miles on a full charge, so if you're planning on roving into the wilderness of no charging stations (Hertz is working on building an infrastructure of stations nationwide), you're better off with the slightly less saintly hybrids, like Priuses and Volts, also available. Rest assured, for those vacationing without a vegan or a sense of environmental outrage, there is still fun to be had: Mustangs, Sebrings and Caddies galore. Go to hertz.com.

If you ask the Spanish pastry chef and chocolatier Oriol Balaguer what he did before he opened his Chocolate & Confectionary Studio in Barcelona eight years ago - launching his eponymous brand a year later - he'll tell you he was a "sweets chef" at a restaurant for seven years. It just so happens that restaurant is El Bulli. Because Balaguer's a humble sort of genius, it's not until you see his compositions or bite into one of his violet-cassis-filled dark-chocolate pods that you realize you're in the presence of a dessert deity. For those who can't access his freestanding boutiques in Barcelona, Madrid or Tokyo, New York's Borne Confections stocks the chocolate products (and, for the holiday season, the panettone). That's where T caught up with him while he was in town for a certain event that celebrates his favorite things: design, architecture and, yes, gastronomy.

The At War blog is well past one year old now, and one of the most gratifying results of its brief but busy life has been the level of engagement it has drawn from readers. Material posted here, seemingly small or not prominently displayed (at least compared to a front-page treatment in the newspaper), routinely generates heavy e-mail feedback in addition to the comments visible under each post. For the staff that makes At War possible, reader feedback has produced many news and investigative tips, led to new sources and helped some of us learn new things.

INTERNATIONAL A subheading on Saturday with an article about the presidential elections in Tanzania misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the incumbent, who was re-elected. He is Jakaya Kikwete, not Kikweke. (Go to Article)

ESPN ended its 20-year association with Jon Miller and Joe Morgan as the voices of ''Sunday Night Baseball'' on Monday. They declined to renew Morgan's contract and have asked Miller if he wants to stay on as the radio voice of the Sunday night games. Discussions are ongoing. ''We've decided to make a change and introduce new voices and new perspective,'' said Norby Williamson, an executive vice president of ESPN. He added: ''Twenty one years is an eternity in this business. And today is about acknowledging the contributions they made to the franchise.''
International SUPPORT GROWS FOR TREATY

The Hall of Fame announced Monday that George Steinbrenner, the longtime Yankees owner who died in July, was one of 12 candidates who will appear on the ballot of the latest incarnation of the veterans committee, which meets at the winter meetings in December. The 16-person committee now consists of eight Hall of Famers, four executives and four writers, and candidates need 12 votes - or 75 percent - to be elected. This round of candidates is from the era beginning in 1973, the year Steinbrenner bought the Yankees.

Joshua Roberts/Bloomberg NewsThe Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters.Has the Securities and Exchange Commission bungled its disclosure rules? That's the question being whispered around Wall Street trading floors after a series of company disclosures in recent weeks from the likes of Microsoft and Google that appear to have created an awful lot of confusion, potentially giving some savvy investors an edge while potentially putting the rest of us at a disadvantage.

8 P.M. (ESPN) THE BEST THAT NEVER WAS In 1981 the nature of college sports recruiting shifted as a dozen top-tier football programs waited for Marcus Dupree, a high school running back from Mississippi, to make his decision. After Mr. Dupree (left, in 1982) committed to the University of Oklahoma, his career faltered as conflict, injury and the burden of expectation took their toll. In this ''30 for 30'' documentary, Jonathan Hock explores why the star of Mr. Dupree, now a part-time truck driver, fell to earth and how he ultimately returned to football for redemption. 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE The series explores bullying, particularly when gay students are the victims. Kurt (Chris Colfer) finally stands up to his football team tormenters after meeting another gay student (Darren Criss) who sings for the competition.

DARBY--G. Harrison. January 24, 1942 to November 2, 2010. The partners and staff of Jackson Lewis LLP mourn the loss of our partner and cherished friend Harrison Darby. During his 38 year career Harrison led our firm's expansion to the west coast in 1977 and established a reputation as an outstanding management side labor law practitioner. His colleagues and clients will miss his friendship and warm sense of humor. Our thoughts and prayers are with his partner Ronald Wallace, his brother and sister-in-law Stephen and Marjorie Darby and his neices and nephews.

You put Michael Jackson's name on a record, you'd think it's a given that Jackson is somehow involved in the material it contains. But the Epic Records division of Sony Music now finds itself in the unusual position of having to reaffirm that the King of Pop really did provide the vocals for a new release being put out under Jackson's name - and to make clear that Prince is not connected to the album. On Friday a portion of ''Breaking News,'' a song that will appear on the posthumous album ''Michael,'' was posted on Jackson's official site, michaeljackson.com, and the entire track was published there on Monday. The song, which mixes audio from news reports about Jackson with lyrics that refer to him in the third person, was quickly condemned by members of his family: Canada's CTV.ca reported that Jackson's mother, Katherine, had condemned the song as fraudulent in an interview with Oprah Winfrey scheduled for broadcast on Monday; the singer's nephews Taryll and T. J., both sons of Tito Jackson, have also raised questions about the song's authenticity on their Twitter accounts.

LEWIN--Michael, age 88, on November 7, 2010, passed peacefully at home in New York. Beloved husband of Irene Szor, father of James and grandfather of Eva. He was born in Poland but lived through World War II in France and escaped from deportation camp in Southern France. He then joined the Maquis. He moved to the USA in 1946 after the war, where he worked in real estate and subsequently as an old masters art dealer. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a funeral service Wednesday 10 November at 11:30 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028 and subsequently for the interment at Kensico Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY 10595, and afterwards at home from 4:30-6:30pm.

CALHOUN--John Clark, Jr.,Consulting Forester, died suddenly in his home in Peterborough, NH, on November 3, 2010. Born May 27, 1926, Springfield, MA. Son of John C. and Cecelia Machado Calhoun. Hotchkiss School 1944, Yale College BA 1948 and MS 1952, Yale School of Environmental Studies. Predeceased by his wife Rosemarie Studer Calhoun and his brother Jose Machado Calhoun. Survived by wife Helen Whiting Livingston-Calhoun, five children, three step-daughters, eight grandchildren, five step-grandchildren. Service Saturday November 13, 2010, Rivermead Retirement Community, 150 Rivermead Rd, Peterborough, 11am. No Calling hours. In lieu of flowers, family prefers contributions to Monadnock Conservancy, P.O. Box 337 Keene, NH 03431.
TALBOT--Cary Lawrence. ALWAYS Roslyn, James, Tiffani, and Brad

BAUM--Martin. Boss, mentor, friend, hero. Heartfelt condolences to Fern and Richard. Lionel Larner

CLAYBURGH--Jill. Roundabout Theatre Company is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Jill Clayburgh. Jill's beautiful work and loving dedication to her family will be remembered with joy and admiration. We have lost Jill far too soon, and we mourn the wonderful years and performances that will never be seen. We send our deepest condolences to David, Lily, Michael, and the entire family. Todd Haimes, Harold Wolpert, Julia Levy, Scott Ellis, and the Board of Directors and staff of Roundabout Theatre Company

ESHAGHIAN--Massoud Jack, MD. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing, in Los Angeles, of Massoud Jack Eshaghian, M.D. the beloved brother of David Eshaghian, Chairman of Yeshiva University's Sephardic Council of Overseers and a Trustee Emeritus of the YU Board of Trustees. Dr. Eshaghian was revered in the Los Angeles community as a widely respected, compassionate and distinguished, ophthalmologist, who was an active leader in the Jewish community. The Eshaghian family are Benefactors of Yeshiva University who established The Ebrahim Ben Davood Eliahu Eshaghian Transgenic Facility for Biomedical Research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in honor of their late father, of blessed memory, in whose name a major scholarship fund for Sephardic students was also established. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Dr. Eshaghian's wife, May, and their children: Patricia Eshaghian, MD, an Einstein alumna, George, Claude and Averel Eshaghian, five grandchildren and to his sister, Helen Iloulian and brothers, David (and Simone) Eshaghian, Dr. Joseph (and Dr. Faye) Eshaghian and the entire family. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Min Hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson Board of Overseers

WEINSTEIN--Dr. Sidney, on Monday, in Chapel Hill, NC. Dr. Sidney Weinstein, 88, eminent neuroscientist and retired professor at Albert Einstein and New York Medical Colleges. Survived by wife, Margaret, five children, six grandchildren. Hallwynne.com for funeral and memorial information.

MALAMOOD--Anna, died peacefully on November 5th, 2010 surrounded by her loving family and friends. Contributions can be made to the Cutaneous Lymphoma Foundation. Services, Tuesday, November 16th, 5:30pm at "The Riverside"; 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

WINTER--Eleanor L.,of Delray Beach, Florida died on November 3, 2010 at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Marvin S. Winter; adored mother of Benjamin and Susan Winter, James and Susan Winter, Douglas and Bonnie Winter, Karen and Barry Miller; adoring grandmother of David (Liz), Jennifer (Matt), Alison, Stacy (Ross), Kira, Eric, Jonathan, Nathan, Matthew and Dana; loving great grandmother of Mia, Charlie and Lily; and dear companion to Julius Spencer. Eleanor was a graduate of Skidmore College where she developed a lifelong interest in the arts and was a founding donor and continuing benefactor of the Tang Museum on the Skidmore campus. She was a dedicated philanthropist and formerly a trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Eleanor was a talented artist, a world traveler, a patron of the arts and a woman of indomitable spirit. She will be deeply missed and remembered with love. The family will observe a private funeral but will receive family and friends at Eleanor's apartment this coming Monday and Tuesday from 4pm to 8pm.

FRONT PAGE An article on Oct. 16 about a new exhibition at the German Historical Museum in Berlin that focuses on how German society accepted, nurtured and often celebrated Hitler misstated the method by which Johann Georg Elser, a celebrated Nazi-resistance fighter, was executed. Mr. Elser, a carpenter who tried to kill Hitler at the start of World War II, was shot to death in the Dachau concentration camp. He was not hanged. (Go to Article)

We send our sincerest condolences to Elisabeth, Rabbi and the entire Nordmann family. Polly Etkind Hochberg, President Lois Kirsh, Ninette Stiskin, Co-Chairs

McDADE--Elaine Bushey, 83, of Tucson, AZ passed away on October 31, 2010 after a long illness. Beloved and cherished wife of James R. McDade, she is survived by her husband, sisters Patricia Bushey Stuhr and Roberta Bushey Glackin and 22 nieces and nephews from the Bushey, Glackin and Stuhr families. She was the daughter of the late Raymond and Alma Bushey of Brooklyn and Huntington, NY. Elaine lived life to the fullest during the 30 years that she and Jim lived in Aspen, CO; she was an accomplished artist, avid skier and horsewoman, exceptional hostess and enthusiastic world traveler. She and Jim have made so much possible for their extended family and for others as well. She will be greatly missed and remain in our hearts forever. The family will hold a private memorial in Denver at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her name to your favorite charity or to the American Heart Association. Services entrusted to Adair Funeral Homes-Avalon Chapel (520-742-7901).

SACHS--Burton A.,85, Gay's husband of 55 years, sons Lawrence and Richard, granddaughter Ellen, brother Myles Sachs, Glen Ridge, NJ. Cornell, the Navy, Harvard Business School and 35 years at Bloomingdale's from training squad to Vice President. Happiest years post retirement on the tennis court with his luncheon buddies and as scholar and Chairman of Friends of the Humanities at SUNY-Purchase. Interment private. Memorial Service at Sunningdale Country Club, Monday, November 15, 2pm.

Musical America, which publishes the Musical America International Directory of the Performing Arts and maintains the Web site musicalamerica.com, has announced the winners of its 2011 Musical America Awards. Its musician of the year is the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, soon to begin a season-long stint as artist in residence at the New York Philharmonic. The composer of the year is Thomas Ades; the conductor, Rafael Fruhbeck dr Burgos; the vocalist, the baritone Simon Keenlyside; and the educator, Vivian Perlis, the founder of Yale University's Oral History of American Music. The awards are to be presented at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 13. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WEBER--Filmore George, US Navy veteran of WWII, born May 5, 1924, Manhattan, NY, died November 7, 2010 in Madison, WI. Fil as he was known to his friends and business associates spent 60 years in the jewelry industry starting on 47th Street in 1950. In 1968 he opened George Fillmore Goldsmith and Jewelers in Canton, CT and ran the business till 2008, (in proud partnership with his daughter Raimie since 1982). He was well known through the industry for his humor, honesty, precision craftsmanship and his unique creative jewelry design. Remembered by wife of 62 years, Claire (nee Schiffman), brother, Ira; children, Candace, Raimie, Laurance, Marshall; grandchildren Samuel and Isabelle; and great-granddaughter, MaKenna.

DICKINSON--Betty, died peacefully on Sunday, November 7, at her home in Ridgewood, New Jersey, a few weeks before her ninetieth birthday. Her husband, Fairleigh S. Dickinson, Jr., died in 1996. She was born Mary Elizabeth Harrington on November 30, 1920, in Mansfield, Ohio, to Alfred Irving and Mary Crawford Harrington. A graduate of The Bishop's School in La Jolla, California, and Bennington College, she served as a Pharmacist's Mate, 2nd Class, in the United States Navy during World War II. Stationed at the US Naval Hospital in Honolulu, Mrs. Dickinson vividly recalled seeing the ships at Pearl Harbor set off their artillery in jubilant celebration of V-J Day. Betty, as her friends and family knew her, relished new experiences. An avid photographer and watercolorist, she traveled to every continent on Earth, including a 2008 voyage to Antarctica. She also obtained her private pilot certificate when she was in her fifties, reasoning, "If something happened to your pilot, how dumb would you feel flying around, waiting to run out of gas? It's so stupid not to be able to do something." A competitive sailor and golfer, Mrs. Dickinson won the club championship at Arcola Country Club in 1968 and, later that year, scored a hole-in-one. She and her husband were pictured on the front page of The New York Times in October, 1980, along with other survivors of the burning and sinking of the M.V. Prinsendam off the coast of Alaska. After their fourteen hour ordeal in a lifeboat had drawn to a close and all were declared safe, Betty recalled the scene aboard the doomed liner in a telephone interview from Sitka: "It was just like what you'd see in a B-movie. The only person missing was Tallulah Bankhead." A former trustee of both Kent School in Kent, Connecticut, and Bennington College, Betty will be sorely missed by all who knew her great wit and quiet generosity. She is survived by her daughters Ann B. Dickinson and her husband Richard Purington, of Ridgewood, New Jersey and Tracy H. Dickinson of Park Ridge, New Jersey, by her granddaughter Amanda Turner Phillips and her husband Briggs, of Burlington, Vermont, by her grandson David Dickinson Turner, of New York, and by her great-grandson Crawford Dickinson Phillips of Burlington. She also leaves a nephew, Peter Strachan and his wife Linda and nieces Emily Strachan and Nancy Strachan, and Nancy's husband Peter Bland, all of California. In addition to her husband Fairleigh S. "Dick" Dickinson, Jr., Mrs. Dickinson was predeceased by her son Fairleigh S. "Terry" Dickinson, III, by an infant son, James Dickinson, and by her sister Eleanor "Bunny" Strachan. She was also preceded in death by her beloved cat, the debonair and peripatetic Bucky. The funeral service will be held at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA., on Thursday, November 11 at 11:00am. Interment at Tower Hill Cemetery, Edgartown, will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate memorial donations to the Martha's Vineyard Boys and Girls Club, PO Box 654, Edgartown, MA 02539 or the Martha's Vineyard Museum, PO Box 1310, Edgartown, MA, 02539. Services by C.C. Van Emburgh, Ridgewood, New Jersey. www.vanemburgh.com

The N.F.L. and other sports leagues were dealt a setback Monday when the Supreme Court said it would not review a lower court decision that said players could challenge positive drug tests in state court. A federal appeals court in Minnesota ruled in 2009 that the Minnesota Vikings players Kevin Williams and Pat Williams could contest their positive tests in Minnesota state courts, which have laws that give greater protection to employees. The court said that the N.F.L.'s collective bargaining agreement did not override state laws.

Describing his travels in Thailand while filming a small role in ''The Killing Fields,'' Spalding Gray, the actor, author and monologist, compared the experience to - among other things - a stay at ''a pleasurable prison.'' Though the experience, preserved in his indelible performance piece ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' found him famously concluding that he ''knew what it was that had killed Marilyn Monroe,'' the notebooks and journals that formed the basis of that monologue will surely be treated to a better stay at their new permanent residence at the University of Texas at Austin. On Monday the Harry Ransom Center, a humanities library at the university, said it had acquired Gray's archives, comprising more than 40 years of work dating to the 1970s. Among the materials in the archive, the center said, are more than 90 performance notebooks and more than 100 diaries that chronicle the development of Gray's performance pieces, including ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' ''It's a Slippery Slope,'' ''Morning, Noon and Night'' and ''Monster in a Box.''

NEW HAVEN -- A jury voted on Monday to impose the death penalty on a habitual criminal who took part in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead, a crime of such inexplicable cruelty and randomness -- the family was apparently chosen after being spotted in a shopping center parking lot -- that it upended a debate about capital punishment. For nearly two months, jurors learned every searing detail of the night and morning in July 2007, when two men armed only with a BB gun that looked like a real pistol burst into the Colonial-style home of a successful doctor.

It feels a little sacrilegious to call anything stamped Louis Vuitton a doorstop, but ''Louis Vuitton: 100 Legendary Trunks'' (Abrams; $170 for the deluxe edition, above) qualifies by heft alone - it's nearly 500 pages and weighs about 10 pounds. The exhaustive, lushly illustrated book traces the history of Vuitton luggage; carry-ons these are not, either in spirit or in scale. There are engineering innovations (a bed that folds into a trunk, for the 19th-century explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza), concept-only wonders (the ''Jetsons''-esque Mars Trunk, which opens to reveal a mini cocktail bar and CD and book storage) and trunks customized to hold the inspirations and playthings of writers and artists (books for Ernest Hemingway, surgical knives for Damien Hirst). An accompanying exhibit is on view at the Carnavelet Museum in Paris until Feb. 27, 2011.

Designers and cultural producers are in the business of divining the future. Now, thanks to a new exhibition at the National Arts Club, some of the world's leading creatives have made a full-fledged jump to the dark side. Curated by Stacy Engman, "Contemporary Magic: A Tarot Deck Art Project" features the minor and major arcana as reinterpreted by 78 art and fashion world luminaries who were each matched with a card based on themes that recur in their work. Among the newly anointed mystics are Karl Lagerfeld (King of Wands), Marc Jacobs (Knight of Pentacles), John Currin (Ten of Cups) and Tracey Emin (the Empress). And in an occult line call that would have taken a master magician to adjudicate, Mickalene Thomas gets the nod as the High Priestess.

In Revlon's 1952 ad for the Fire & Ice Collection, Richard Avedon photographed model-of-the-moment Dorian Leigh in a sparkling silver gown framed by an amorphous tuft of red fabric (a copy of a Balenciaga cape), her hands drawing attention to her blood-colored manicure and lipstick. One of the most indelible ads in fashion history, the image was part of a niche campaign that included a Peggy Olsen-worthy tagline - "Are you made for Fire & Ice?" - and a bizarre questionnaire that asked, 'Have you ever wanted to wear an ankle bracelet?' and 'Does gypsy music make you sad?' While a lot has changed since 1952, Fire & Ice has a new shelf life now that Revlon has re-released three "lip-and-tip" pairings ($4.79 - $ 8.99). The ad, shot by Mario Testino, restages the original, with a few notable exceptions - the actress Jessica Biel stands in for Leigh, ankle bracelets are so last century, and that dress is no knockoff.

Australian drinking culture took a serious hit during the temperance movement: for the better part of the 20th century, pubs were required to close by 6 p.m., a restriction that fostered binge drinking (the notorious ''six o'clock swill'') and dampened any creativity behind the bar. But an interest in cocktail craft has sprung up in cities down under, starting first in Melbourne's small, speakeasy-style laneway bars and taking hold most recently in Sydney. In 2007, new laws made it easier and cheaper to open bars here, resulting in an onslaught of pocket-size watering holes that are big on character, from buttoned-up boîtes to faux dives.

I used to love "Mystery Science Theater 3000." It ran on TV from 1988 to 1999, and cracked me up every time. You can read up on it on Wikipedia, but the basic idea was you watch a really terrible old movie, usually a sci-fi B movie. At the bottom of the screen, you see the silhouettes of three professional hecklers as they talk to the screen and riff on the awfulness of the movie and the acting.

Noah Snyder-Mackler, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, is studying the evolution of social behavior in the gelada, a primate found in Ethiopia. Scientist at Work will check in from time to time with Mr. Snyder-Mackler, whose expedition continues into December.

Audience members at "Promises, Promises" were concerned at the end of Tuesday night's performance when star Kristin Chenoweth did not appear for the curtain call beside cast mates Sean Hayes, Molly Shannon, and others - some of whom looked disconcerted. The arrival of an ambulance near the stage door was troubling, too. But Ms. Chenoweth, the original Glinda in "Wicked" and a Tony Award winner for "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown," appears to be all right. A publicist for the production said on Wednesday that Ms. Chenoweth, 42, experienced dizziness after her final scene and was unable to take her curtain call. Per standard policy, the production stage manager called an ambulance and emergency medical technicians examined the actress in her dressing room. She was diagnosed with mild dehydration and was released shortly thereafter. Ms. Chenoweth is taking off the Wednesday matinee to rest and is expected to return to the show for the Wednesday night performance.

Matthew Swanson and Robbi Behr are idiots. No, really - the couple (after bidding a Steven Slater-esque adieu to their previous careers as graphic designers) founded Idiots' Books, an independent press run out of their Maryland barn. There they live, work and raise two children. Swanson writes and Behr illustrates, and together they distribute their snide, satirical works through a bimonthly subscription service. (Titles include "The Baby Is Disappointing," a sarcastic paean to parenting, and "Facial Features of French Explorers," a microanalysis of the craniofacial quirks of adventurers like Samuel de Champlain.) They also maintain a blog about their lives.

Bucking the trend for rustic satchels, some luggage designers are boldly traveling forward. Delsey has developed a way to prevent surprise overweight charges: two bags in the company's Helium Fusion Lite 2.0 line ($120 and $130; delsey.com) have a built-in scale that triggers a red indicator when your luggage tops 50 pounds. At Tumi, where all-black Alpha rollers are standard business issue, innovation comes in a splash of color. The new Accent Your Alpha program ($50 at Tumi boutiques; tumi.com) lets road warriors distinguish their bags with monogram patches, zipper pulls and luggage tags in six punchy hues. And while you're waiting in baggage claim, you may wish you had Travelteq's Trip, a sit-on carry-on (above; about $1,100; travelteq.com). The aluminum frame has wheels that pivot outward to stabilize, the telescoping handle acts as a seat back, and an upholstered seat invites you to take a load off. Upgrade to the fully loaded model with battery-powered stereo speakers, and time will fly.

Public Policy Polling offers more grist for my "Sarah Palin is not the 2012 Republican front-runner" mill. They have 2012 polls out for California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, New Hampshire, and Pennsylvania, and Mitt Romney is ahead in four of them (and ahead by a mile in New Hampshire), while Mike Huckabee leads in two. Palin performs respectably across the board, but she never breaks 20 percent; her numbers are similar to Newt Gingrich's, who regularly polls in the mid-teens. In general, Romney leads because he wins moderates by a mile and then splits conservatives with the other candidates, while Palin generally polls in the single digits among moderates. I set out to see if I could make it in Los Angeles on $100 a day. It's possible, it turns out. But only if you do away with a car. Now, I know what you're thinking. Los Angeles, the sprawling metropolitan region that is home to both the Hollywood Hills and the Valley, on a bike? Well, I found it not only possible but enjoyable. In truth, I was liberally aided by the surprisingly nimble public transportation system. But I rode 15 to 40 miles a day on trips to Beverly Hills, along the coast, downtown and to Pasadena. Highlights from my trip (and some cool photos) are already online. Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got to get back to my very demanding research of frugal Buenos Aires.

Haider Ackermann's spring collection of pleated maxi skirts was one of the most lauded shows of the season, but if you're wondering what the designer may reference for fall, look in your own backyard. The Colombian-born, Belgian-trained Ackermann, who is in New York for a lightning visit, says he has been keeping his eyes wide open during his stay. "The youth culture here is really cool to look at," Ackermann said Tuesday at a special personal appearance at Saks. "I stayed uptown and downtown and I loved seeing the different types and attitudes." Even watching runners in Central Park and along the Hudson is apparently grist for the mill. "They're absolutely lovely," he said. "I will translate everything I've seen into my next collection."

Could sports drinks be improved with the addition of protein? That question has long gripped physiologists and nutritionists. It’s well established that the carbohydrates (sugars) that sweeten most sports drinks aid performance. They provide immediate fuel for straining muscles, keep blood-sugar levels stable and allow you to work out for a longer period of time or at a higher intensity, or both, than if you don’t swallow any extra fuel. But why wouldn’t taking in protein, together with carbohydrates, during a workout or race make you even more speedy and durable? Protein, after all, is what muscles fundamentally are made of, so it seems reasonable to imagine that adding it to sports drinks could provide some additional benefit.

DICKINSON--Elizabeth H.,Betty died peacefully on Sunday, November 7, at her home in Ridgewood, New Jersey, a few weeks before her ninetieth birthday. Her husband, Fairleigh S. Dickinson, Jr., died in 1996. She was born Mary Elizabeth Harrington on November 30, 1920, in Mansfield, Ohio, to Alfred Irving and Mary Crawford Harrington. A graduate of The Bishop's School in La Jolla, California, and Bennington College, she served as a Pharmacist's Mate, 2nd Class, in the United States Navy during World War II. Stationed at the US Naval Hospital in Honolulu, Mrs. Dickinson vividly recalled seeing the ships at Pearl Harbor set off their artillery in jubilant celebration of V-J Day. Betty, as her friends and family knew her, relished new experiences. An avid photographer and watercolorist, she traveled to every continent on Earth, including a 2008 voyage to Antarctica. She also obtained her private pilot certificate when she was in her fifties, reasoning, "If something happened to your pilot, how dumb would you feel flying around, waiting to run out of gas? It's so stupid not to be able to do something." A competitive sailor and golfer, Mrs. Dickinson won the club championship at Arcola Country Club in 1968 and, later that year, scored a hole-in-one. She and her husband were pictured on the front page of The New York Times in October, 1980, along with other survivors of the burning and sinking of the M.V. Prinsendam off the coast of Alaska. After their fourteen hour ordeal in a lifeboat had drawn to a close and all were declared safe, Betty recalled the scene aboard the doomed liner in a telephone interview from Sitka: "It was just like what you'd see in a B-movie. The only person missing was Tallulah Bankhead." A former trustee of both Kent School in Kent, Connecticut, and Bennington College, Betty will be sorely missed by all who knew her great wit and quiet generosity. She is survived by her daughters Ann B. Dickinson and her husband Richard Purington, of Ridgewood, New Jersey and Tracy H. Dickinson of Park Ridge, New Jersey, by her granddaughter Amanda Turner Phillips and her husband Briggs, of Burlington, Vermont, by her grandson David Dickinson Turner, of New York, and by her great-grandson Crawford Dickinson Phillips of Burlington. She also leaves a nephew, Peter Strachan and his wife Linda and nieces Emily Strachan and Nancy Strachan, and Nancy's husband Peter Bland, all of California. In addition to her husband Fairleigh S. "Dick" Dickinson, Jr., Mrs. Dickinson was predeceased by her son Fairleigh S. "Terry" Dickinson, III, by an infant son, James Dickinson, and by her sister Eleanor "Bunny" Strachan. She was also preceded in death by her beloved cat, the debonair and peripatetic Bucky. The funeral service will be held at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA., on Thursday, November 11 at 11:00am. Interment at Tower Hill Cemetery, Edgartown, will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate memorial donations to the Martha's Vineyard Boys and Girls Club, PO Box 654, Edgartown, MA 02539 or the Martha's Vineyard Museum, PO Box 1310, Edgartown, MA, 02539. Services by C.C. Van Emburgh, Ridgewood, New Jersey. www.vanemburgh.com

BEIJING -- China's trade surplus surged to $27.1 billion in October, providing fodder for political tensions a day before the Group of 20 leaders were set to tackle a framework to correct the trade imbalances that economists say threaten the global recovery. The rise is in marked contrast to the September figures, when China's trade surplus, down 15.7 percent from the previous month, was at its smallest in nearly half a year.

STRAUSS--Peter, 89, of Scarsdale, New York, died at home on November 9, 2010. Beloved husband of 61 years to Barbara Strauss, he was the cherished father to John, Eileen and Sally and "Papa" to Jennifer, David, Jill, Amy, Alexandra, Ariel and Drew. Without resources for medical school, he pursued a career in finance, becoming a partner at Neuberger Berman, where he labeled himself a financial "doctor" promoting the financial health for his family, friends and clients. Many owe their way of life and opportunities to his exceptional judgment. His investment acumen first became apparent during the depression when at the age of eight he insisted on removing his entire savings from the bank just days before the crash. He went on to graduate early from Yale so he could join the Marines where he was one of three officers who accepted the Japanese surrender in China and received the Bronze Star. He was an avid reader with a keen mind who loved to share and discuss the latest history books. A strong believer in the value of education, he established several scholarship programs to enable needy students to pursue their dreams. In lieu of flowers, he requested that donations be sent to the Peter Strauss family scholarship fund at Yale or the Dr. Israel Strauss Scholarship Fund at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. A memorial service will be held at the Yale Club in early January.

As Charlie Crist walks on down the hall to the end, beautiful friend, of his term as governor of Florida, he still has a few items on his agenda. Among them: the possibility that he could pardon Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, for convictions stemming from a 1969 concert appearance in Miami. In an interview with The Hill, Mr. Crist, a Republican turned independent who was defeated last week by Marco Rubio in his bid for a United States Senate seat and whose term as governor ends in January, said ''stay tuned'' when asked if he would consider pardoning Morrison.

LEVINE--Jack, age 95, artist, born Boston, 1915. Died peacefully at his home in New York City on November 8, 2010. Beloved father of Susanna Fisher Levine, father-in-law of Leonard Fisher, and grandfather of Rachel and Ari Fisher. A witty and insightful individual, Levine was a painter of prodigious talent and great integrity who imparted a wry and penetrating social commentary to his work, deftly critiquing the hypocrisy and injustice in American society. Levine remained true to his inimitable creative vision over eight decades of artistic work. Those of us who knew him well and who worked with him over the years have always known that we were truly privileged. We treasure and honor our memories of his love and friendship. He will be greatly missed. Bridget Moore, Edward DeLuca, Heidi Lange and the staff of DC Moore Gallery.

It's official. TBS is the Sherwood Forest of late-night television and Conan O'Brien is its Robin Hood, leading his band of merry followers to basic cable to battle against the usurper host of ''The Tonight Show.'' Mr. O'Brien made his long-awaited debut on his new show, ''Conan,'' on Monday in the same insurrectionist mood that he left NBC last January. Starting with an opening sketch that likened NBC executives to ''The Godfather''-style hit men, almost every joke was a barb about the conflict with Jay Leno that led him to quit.

Yankees catcher Jorge Posada is scheduled to have surgery Wednesday to repair a torn meniscus in his left knee, according to a person in baseball briefed on the matter. While the operation is not serious, it underlines the age issues that the Yankees have to confront with Posada, who turned 39 this past season and may be entering the final year of his major league career. Posada was examined Monday by doctors for the Yankees who determined the operation was necessary.

With the effort to repeal the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy facing uncertain prospects in Congress, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut independent, and two Senate Democrats, Mark Udall of Colorado and Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, on Tuesday reiterated their call for allowing gay soldiers to serve openly. Mr. Lieberman, a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, led the push to include language authorizing the repeal of the policy in the annual military policy bill.

BARCELONA, Spain -- Johan Cruyff, the Dutchman who both played for and coached F.C. Barcelona, once noted that in soccer ''it doesn't matter how many goals they score, as long as you score one more.'' Winning, however, has not been the only thing that has mattered recently at Cruyff's former club. Instead, one of Barcelona's most successful presidents, Joan Laporta, found himself last month on the receiving end of a lawsuit initiated by his successor, Sandro Rosell, alleging unlawful accounting.

A film review on Friday about the animated feature ''Megamind'' misidentified the character who tries to impress Roxanne by repeatedly dropping her from high in the air then swooping down to rescue her. He is Tighten, not Metro Man.

The Jets' NICK FOLK kicked the overtime winner against Detroit on Sunday as if he didn't feel the pressure of a game-deciding play. It turns out he didn't. He thought the Lions would get a possession if he made the kick. In the off-season, the N.F.L. changed its overtime rules for the postseason, not for the regular season, but Folk wasn't aware of that distinction. ''He thought we were going to turn around and kick off,'' Jets Coach Rex Ryan saidMonday. ''I thought it was hilarious that he did not know.'' Folk didn't celebrate after the kick. Ryan said: ''I just thought he was trying to be cool, like: 'Yeah, I made it, no biggie. This is what you're paying me to do.''' A reader, Craig Garretson of New York, wrote on The Fifth Down blog: ''It's just troubling that last week, the punter didn't know the distance he had to run to get a fourth down; this week, the kicker doesn't know he's going for the game-winning kick. ''The kicker and the punter. What exactly are they thinking about during the 57 minutes each game when they aren't on the field?'' TONI MONKOVIC

The brevity of the congratulatory note was satisfaction in itself. Andy Roddick, in Switzerland for a tennis tournament, sent a text to Justin Gimelstob on Sunday night saying simply: ''Well done, Sir. Send me wiring instructions.'' The next morning he would get another congratulatory call from the tennis great Andre Agassi, also looking to add money to the pot, and another text from Roddick urging Gimelstob to send along the instructions, playfully adding, ''I don't want to owe you money for one more minute.''

An obituary on Monday about Artie Wilson, a Negro leagues baseball star, misstated the number of games he played with the New York Giants in 1951 and referred incorrectly to his association with Willie Mays at that time. Wilson played 19 games, not 22. (He had 22 at-bats in those games.) And while Wilson and Mays were former teammates on the Birmingham Black Barons, they did not play for the Giants at the same time. (Mays moved to New York after Wilson was released.)

An art review on Saturday about ''Infinity of Nations: Art and History in the Collections of the National Museum of the American Indian'' at the George Gustav Heye Center, the museum's branch in Lower Manhattan, misstated the name of the tribe to which the master carver Bob Harris, whose potlatch dance mask from around 1900 is on display, belonged. It is the New Vancouver Tribe, not the Vancouver Island Tribe.

BLISS--Richard Mitchell, died November 7th at his home in Manhattan surrounded by his family. He was 80 years old. Richard died at the same time as the start of the New York Marathon which he proudly ran 12 times. He was born on December 16, 1929, the son of Ella Flanders Bliss and Charles Mitchell Bliss. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and received an MBA from NYU. He served in the United States Army. He invented the euro dollar syndicated loan which came to be the dominant financing vehicle for governments. He held top ranking positions at Bankers Trust and was a Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of American Express International Bank. He founded the merchant banking firm, Asian Oceanic Group. He served as a Founding Trustee of the Asian Cultural Council and as a Board Chairman of the New York Urban League. He loved great literature, running, playing tennis, and his family. He is survived by his wife, Alicia, his sister Marjorie Garling, his children Jackie, Richard, Steve, Laura, Alyssa, Sara and Cassie, and his eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

Harvey Fierstein's two Tony Awards for best actor resulted from his signature talent playing women, as the drag artist Arnold Beckwith in his play ''Torch Song Trilogy'' (1982) and as house frau Edna Turnblad in the musical ''Hairspray'' (2002). He also won a Tony in 1984 for writing the book of the musical ''La Cage aux Folles,'' which centered on the drag performer Albin, a role that won Tonys for George Hearn in the original ''La Cage'' and for Douglas Hodge in the current Broadway revival. For all that, Mr. Fierstein has never had a chance to play the drag artist that he himself scripted in ''La Cage'' - until now. Mr. Fierstein, 56, will take over as Albin on Feb. 15 from Mr. Hodge, who is departing the show with co-star Kelsey Grammer on Feb. 13 with the expiration of their contracts, the producers announced on Tuesday. A replacement for Mr. Grammer, as Albin's lover and night club impresario Georges, will be announced at a later date.

IT was hardly a World Wrestling Federation smack down. But there was enough of a red-meat frenzy to excite a fiercely appreciative audience of aficionados. On the card? Two rock-star neo-butchers. In the southern corner, in chef's whites: the Meat Magician of Asnières -- Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec, a 42-year-old French butcher from the Asnières suburb of Paris. He was wielding Solingen steel. In the northern corner, in butcher apron, gray shirt and black tee: the Butcher of Brooklyn -- Tom Mylan, 34. His weapon of preference: a five-inch Forschner boning knife.

McLAUGHLIN--Robert C. of Delray Beach, FL and Rye, NY, passed on November 8, 2010. Born January 1, 1937 in Freeport, NY. He was the son of the late Catherine Lalor and Carroll W. and brother to Barbara, Nancy and Carol (June 2008). Graduate of Cranwell Prep and Brown University, Class of 1958. He was the founder of ValCon Construction Consultants, Inc., in New York City. He spent his last day surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Judith, devoted father to Michael, Steven, Catherine, Julie and Robert Jr. (September 11, 2001). He is also survived by fourteen grandchildren who love their Papa very much. Visiting hours at Fairchild & Sons, 2-4 and 7-9, Thursday, November 11, Funeral Mass, St. Joseph's Church, 10am, Friday, November 12, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation.

Good news for undead zombies who consume the flesh of the living and the television viewers who love them: AMC said on Monday that it has officially ordered a second season of ''The Walking Dead,'' its original series adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman about human survivors in a world overrun by the ambulatory deceased. (Catchy phrase, no?) Though AMC ordered just six episodes of ''The Walking Dead'' for its first season, it seemed a virtual certainty that the show would rise again when its debut episode, broadcast on Halloween, broke a ratings record for that cable channel by drawing 5.3 million viewers, the largest audience it had recorded for an original series. AMC, which is also the home of the serial dramas ''Mad Men,'' ''Breaking Bad'' and ''Rubicon,'' said the second episode of ''The Walking Dead'' was watched by more than 4.7 million people. Season 2 of ''The Walking Dead'' will be 13 episodes long, AMC said, though no dates were given for the start of its production or its premiere. (Given that the show is produced in and around Atlanta, we'll assume AMC will do all it can to avoid filming in the hot, sweltering, zombie-makeup-melting summer.)

As an "imperialist power," he says, America is in danger of being at "sundown." Stockman, who turned 64 on Wednesday, has always been ahead of the curve on tax and fiscal issues, and it appears that he is ahead of it again this time, too.

'If you think big,'' says the tag line for the 1,000-acre Baha Mar resort about to break ground in the Bahamas, ''think bigger.'' Sound ridiculous in a recession? It's more of a harbinger than you'd imagine, at least in the travel world: led by Las Vegas's CityCenter and the Marina Bay Sands Singapore, a new wave of mega-scale complexes that were conceived during the boom have recently opened their doors, with several more in development, from the Alps to Abu Dhabi. ''I think it's the future,'' says Andy Cohen, executive director of the architecture firm Gensler, which worked on CityCenter and has a similar mixed-use project brewing in Shanghai. ''Whether it's sports, entertainment or retail, the ability to have all that variety in one place is key. People want choice.''

Chocolate lovers will soon find plenty to satisfy their sweet tooth on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia. In December, the upscale British chocolatier Hotel Chocolat (which has a Stateside flagship on Boston's Newbury Street) will make good on its name by opening a boutique resort on Rabot Estate, its 140-acre cocoa plantation in the shadow of the twin-peaked Pitons. The hotel will offer guests the full chocolate-making experience, including taking part in the cocoa harvest while learning about the company's philanthropic program to benefit local farmers. ''The idea is to let our customers have the same experience that we have every time we step onto the estate,'' says Angus Thirlwell, who co-founded the company 17 years ago with Peter Harris. Should chocolate-making wear thin, guests, who stay in contemporary West Indian-style cottages, can also hike Gros Piton, embark on a fruit-tasting safari and dine on dishes like sautéed prawns with chocolate tapenade.

For three decades the designer Anna Sui has tickled a hard-nosed industry with unabashed imagination and the kind of fairytale twinkle that is straight out of childhood ballerina boxes and teenage diaries. At their most fanciful, her clothes summon a dream of fun-loving womanhood, of idols and heroines: Janis Joplin, Marie Antoinette and Marisa Berenson on the dance floor, all in a single collection. But reverie hardly explains Sui's loved and labored métier. She started her eponymous collection in 1981 while working a day job, and opened her New York boutique in 1992 - the first of 300 sales outlets - just a year after her first runway show. Since 1997, Sui has also parlayed licensing deals in cosmetics, accessories and spin-off clothing lines that extend from Turkey to Japan. A new anthology published by Chronicle Books suggests that the lynchpin of her unique career is encyclopedic curiosity as much as commercial acumen, studied process and a deep respect for the techniques and traditions of her craft.

The American Theater Wing announced on Wednesday that the awards for the 2010-11 Broadway season, which are also presented by the trade group the Broadway League, would be given out at the Beacon Theater on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The Beacon has roughly 2,900 seats, less than half as many as Radio City Music Hall, where the Tony Awards have been held since 1997. DEANE--Disque D.,died on November 8, 2010 in Boston, Massachusetts. He was one of the most innovative and creative financiers on Wall Street. One of Disque Deane's more prestigious accomplishments was his revolutionary approach to sale-leaseback transactions. He was a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1963 1978. In 1972, Mr. Deane and Andre Meyer restructured and financed Starrett City, a 5,881 unit model community in Brooklyn, New York. The community was restructured so that investors could benefit from a partnership that combined equity investments from private banks, state agencies and loans from federal housing authorities. The Community, opened in January, 1974, has its own shopping center, newspaper, power plant and security force. It is the largest and most successful affordable housing community in the United States. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Group and founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Corporate Property Investors, the largest private REIT prior to its acquisition by Simon Property Group in 1998. He believed in education and medical research. Mr. Deane supported primary and secondary schools as well as universities. He established the Deane Laboratories in Neurobiology at Duke University. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Institute for Integrated Research on Atrial Fibrillation and Stroke at Massachusetts General Hospital as well as a Trustee at the Linus Pauling Institute, Rockefeller University and Duke University. Mr. Deane was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and attended Duke University. He graduated from the U.S.M.S. United States Navy Officer Training School. He is survived by his wife, Carol and their two children, Anne and Carl, and his children by his deceased wife, Marjorie Schlesinger Deane: Marjorie Swain, Kathryn Deane, Disque Deane, Jr. and Walter Deane. He has seven grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A service will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11:00am on Friday, November 19. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Starrett City Community Fund for Scholarships. Please make donations to: Spring Creek Community Corp Scholarship Fund, Office of Public Affairs, Spring Creek Towers, 1310 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11239.

The NFL Network hype wagon pulls into Atlanta, and not a moment too soon. If any teams deserve the spotlight to themselves and some extra ink, it's these two. The Falcons and the Ravens have everything a fan could ask for: winning records, electrifying offensive stars like Roddy White and Ray Rice, still-productive probable Hall of Famers like Ray Lewis and Tony Gonzalez, solid rosters, creative and capable coaches. Quarterbacks Matt Ryan and Joe Flacco, meeting for the first time, emphasize substance over style: they have developed steadily since their selections in the first round of the 2008 draft, winning games by playing within their systems, taking what the defense gives them. What these teams lack is that reality television, ''Behind the Music,'' overdramatized sizzle that makes teams like the Cowboys and the Vikings so compelling. After a week of Wade watching, we need a little more tackling and a lot less intrigue. Pick: Falcons. MIKE TANIER

Anyone who's spent time writing for the Web knows the basic rule: Keep it short. Attention spans, we are told, are collapsing faster than pig houses on Angry Birds. At this rate, municipalities won't just fluoridate their city water supply, they'll have to Ritalinize it as well. Standing athwart this progress, yelling ''Stop,'' is Longreads, a project created by Mark Armstrong, who is also the content chief at personal-finance site Bundle. Longreads' premise is to collect, collate and curate long-form journalism for online reading. It started in April 2009 as a Twitter hashtag. Users who found long (1,500+ word) articles or stories could append #longreads to the article's url and tweet it. Followers of @longreads would then get a daily river of lengthy, in-depth fiction and nonfiction from magazines, newspapers and online publications.

SKARIMBAS--Elias. Adored husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother and uncle passed away at home on November 10. Survived by his loving wife Carol, children Jon, Michael, Thomas and Crissa, seven grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Born in Itea, Greece in 1926 he joined the Greek Resistance as a teen and came to the US several years later. An Air Force veteran, he taught at the Army Language School in Monterey, CA and was given a full scholarship to Midwestern University in voice. Studied at the New York College of Music (Mannes), Made his recital debut with an impressive review from the NYTimes. Sang for many years with an operatic/musical theatre quartet at "Chez Vito", prominent supper club on E. 60th Street, complete with strolling violins and much atmosphere. All this time working "day jobs". Sang in Paris and Basel, Switzerland, eventually became the conductor of the choir and chanter at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox church in New York. A sales rep until his retirement with Winward International. Elias was a great Papou, artist, poet, actor, husband and romantic - but most of all a singer. Unavoidably yours. A celebration of Elias' life will be announced at a later date. Donations to the Parkinson's Foundation would be appreciated.
