DEANE--Disque. The Rockefeller University community mourns the passing of our longtime friend Disque Deane. A member of the Board of Trustees (1987 to 1990), Disque was a visionary leader in the effort to advance AIDS research. We deeply appreciate his generous support, from the earliest years, for HIV research conducted by Ralph Steinman and the late Zanvil Cohn--work that continues today under Dr. Steinman's leadership. Along with his wife, Carol, Disque also generously launched an innovative research program at Rockefeller in neuroimmunology and inflammation, which is directed by Dr. Karen Bulloch. We are deeply grateful for his passionate commitment to advancing research and education, and his embrace of crucial health, science, and education initiatives at Rockefeller and many other prestigious institutions. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved Carol; to their children, Anne and Carl; to his daughter Kathryn Deane, a member of The Rockefeller University Council; to his nephew Curt Deane, a dedicated University volunteer; and to all of the family. Russell Carson, Chair Paul Nurse, President Ralph Steinman, Professor Bruce McEwen, Professor Karen Bulloch, Research Associate Professor The Rockefeller University

Network television was a night of two Kurts on Tuesday as the retired N.F.L. quarterback Kurt Warner became the latest player eliminated on ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' and Kurt Hummel (Chris Colfer) on ''Glee'' stood up to a bully in an episode of the Fox series inspired by recent news reports. Both programs fared well in the ratings. The ABC dancing show attracted 16.8 million viewers to win the 9 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Glee'' drew a relatively modest 10.8 million viewers at 8 but led the night in the demographic prized by advertisers, adults 18 to 49. CBS averaged the most viewers over the course of the night with ''NCIS'' (19.8 million), ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (15.5 million) and ''The Good Wife'' (12.2 million). ABC placed second, with 7.8 million viewers for both ''No Ordinary Family'' at 8 and ''Detroit 1-8-7'' at 10. Fox ranked third, and NBC was fourth.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The bottles of nail polish at the Nova Nail Spa include Sky Sparkle blue, Hot Blooded pink and I Feel The Earth Move brown. But the predominant color at Kim Pham's chic salon is health-conscious green. ''My husband made the decision he wants everything to be natural and healthy for myself,'' Ms. Pham said of the couple's decision to open a ''green'' nail salon out of a growing concern about the adverse effects from chemicals used in some polishes, removers, top coats and other products. ''I always like to search for something new,'' she added. ''Healthy is different for the customer.''

''Next to Normal,'' above, the Broadway show that became only the eighth musical to win the Pulitzer Prize for drama since 1918, will end its run on Jan. 16, after 21 preview performances and 733 regular performances at the Booth Theater, the show's lead producer, David Stone, said on Wednesday. The show is closing after a slow but modest weekly decline in its grosses in 2010. Mr. Stone said the producers had wanted to ''get close to having a two-year run.'' The musical opened at the Booth on April 15, 2009. The Pulitzer board, critics and many theatergoers have praised ''Next to Normal'' as a groundbreaking production for its story of a family coping with bipolar disorder, drug addiction, attempted suicide and a tragic death. Those factors made it an unlikely natural draw for commercial Broadway or for musical treatment by the composer Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey, who wrote the book and lyrics. Even so, the show recouped its $4 million capitalization this year, putting it among the 25 percent to 30 percent of Broadway shows that do so annually. A tour of the show will begin Nov. 23 in Los Angeles, led by its original star, Alice Ripley, who won the 2009 Tony Award for best actress in a musical as the troubled mother, Diana Goodman. ''Next to Normal'' received 11 Tony nominations, including best musical, and won for best original score and best orchestrations, in addition to Ms. Ripley's honor. Directed by Michael Greif, the Broadway production was recast over the summer with a real-life couple, Marin Mazzie and Jason Danieley, taking the roles of Diana and her husband, Dan; they will continue through Jan. 16.

EWER--Jacob (Jack) Wolfgang, age 99, died November 4, 2010 in Lenox, MA. He was predeceased by his wife Ruth (Salinger) Ewer. Father of Dorothy Dachinger Lerner of Becket, MA and Dr. Michael Ewer of Houston, TX. Grandfather of four and great-grandfather of five.

Some of Broadway's most-watched singer-actors have signed on for the coming musical ''Catch Me if You Can,'' with the Tony Award winner Norbert Leo Butz (''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'') and Aaron Tveit (''Next to Normal'') assuming the lead roles of an F.B.I. agent and a charming scoundrel who were played by Tom Hanks and Leonardo DiCaprio in the 2002 movie of the same name, the producers announced on Wednesday. The Tony nominee Tom Wopat (''Annie Get Your Gun'') will play the deceiving father of Mr. Tveit's character, and the Tony nominee Kerry Butler (''Xanadu'') will portray the Tveit character's love interest. Also in the cast are Linda Hart and Nick Wyman as the parents of Ms. Butler's character and Rachel De Benedet as the mother of Mr. Tveit's. The seven actors originated their roles in a 2009 tryout in Seattle for ''Catch Me if You Can.'' Since that Seattle run, above, which drew encouraging but pointed critiques from the theatrical press, Brian Yorkey -- who shared a Tony and the Pulitzer Prize in drama for ''Next to Normal,'' for which he wrote the book and lyrics -- contributed substantial work on the book by the playwright Terrence McNally. Mr. Yorkey was not credited in the producers' statement. With music by Marc Shaiman and lyrics by Scott Wittman and Mr. Shaiman (who performed the same duties on ''Hairspray''), ''Catch Me if You Can'' is scheduled to begin previews on March 7 at the Neil Simon Theater and to open on April 10. Jack O'Brien is the director, and Jerry Mitchell is the choreographer.

Taylor Swift's new album, ''Speak Now,'' was released two weeks ago, and it sailed to No. 1 on Billboard's chart. In its second week out, sales dropped 69 percent, which for most albums would mean a trip way down the chart. But since Ms. Swift had such strong initial sales -- 1,047,000 copies, more than any other album in five years -- she remains comfortably on top. Nielsen SoundScan reported that ''Speak Now'' (Big Machine) sold 320,000 copies last week. That is about 66 percent more than the album's closest competitor, ''My Kinda Party'' (Broken Bow) by the country singer Jason Aldean, which opens at No. 2 with 193,000. Sugarland's ''Incredible Machine'' (Mercury Nashville) dropped one spot to No. 3 this week with 60,000 sales. According to Billboard this is the first time in three years that country albums have held the top three spots on the album chart. Also on the chart this week, ''Merry Christmas II You'' (Island), Mariah Carey's new holiday album (it's her second, after ''Merry Christmas'' in 1994 -- get it?), opened at No. 4 with 55,000 sales. The newly free Lil Wayne sold 49,000 copies of ''I Am Not a Human Being'' (Cash Money/Universal Motown), good enough for fifth place.

Jawbone, maker of all kinds of earpieces for mobile phones, has branched out into the speaker business. Its first foray, the four-pack-of-butter size Jambox, seems to have succeeded right out of the gate. The Jambox is a wireless speaker that, using a Bluetooth connection to your smartphone, can play any music you start on your smartphone. Sound quality is surprisingly good, with rich bass and no peaky behavior at the high end.

The election of Nov. 6 was big news, to put it mildly. In the days following, newspaper headlines screamed it from one city to another, across the not very united states. As Adam Goodheart wrote earlier, the telegraph allowed the results to be known nearly as quickly as we would know today. Now, thanks to another marvel of technology - the Internet - we can see the private telegrams and letters that Lincoln himself was seeing, as Americans exhaled and realized, to their amazement, that he had pulled it off. In the days following the verdict, an enormous range of Americans, from all walks of life, wrote to their president-elect to express their feelings about where the country was headed. These letters present a remarkable documentary portrait of a nation at a crossroads.

The Siena senior Ryan Rossiter was named the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference preseason player of the year last month. When the Saints' season begins Saturday against Vermont, Rossiter, a Staten Island native, will attempt to become the program's third straight postseason player of the year, following Kenny Hasbrouck and Alex Franklin. "Tenacious, intelligent, hard worker" was how Siena Coach Mitch Buonaguro described Rossiter at the league's media day, adding that he was a "terrific person" and a "wonderful player to coach."

It seems that just about everybody has had experience with babies or bullies - or both. Which is why the commentary that followed this week's Fixes column about Roots of Empathy - an organization that decreases bullying by bringing babies into school classrooms - was so rich, personal and detailed. At the end of the column, I asked readers if they had ideas for ways to reduce bullying. Many offered suggestions about organizations, techniques and books (some of which I list at the bottom of this column), but many more readers reflected on their own experiences having witnessed bullying or the surprising effect babies can have on children and teenagers.Christine, from Montpelier, Vt., (35), recounted her experiences driving a school bus accompanied by her baby boy in a car seat behind her. When necessary, she would place "unruly students" ─ mostly in grades four through eight ─ near her, as well. "[T]hey started to ask to sit in the front so that they could play and read and talk to him during the ride. I observed that they softened and gentled with my son and seemed to feel safe expressing that tender side of their natures."
Thursday, Nov. 4

There is plenty happening off the field in the Southeastern Conference, but on the field Saturday there is no bigger game than South Carolina at Florida. The Gamecocks, led by Steve Spurrier, will head into the Swamp against the resurgent Gators. Whichever team is victorious will be the champion of the SEC East and secure a spot in the conference championship game. On the other side of the SEC, Alabama will try to get back on the winning track when it takes on Mississippi State, which has rapidly improved under Dan Mullen. In other action, Missouri will look to remain in second place in the Big 12 North when it hosts Kansas State, Syracuse hopes to become bowl eligible when it travels to Rutgers, and Florida State and Clemson face off in a key Atlantic Coast Conference Atlantic Division game.

In New York, a visit to the Museum of Modern Art will set you back $20, but down in Washington, the Smithsonian Institution, which is 70 percent federally funded, has long been free. That would change under a proposal by the national commission charged with reducing the deficit. In a draft report Wednesday, it recommended that the Smithsonian's federal appropriation be cut by $225 million, or roughly 30 percent, and that the institution make up the loss by charging a $7.50 admission fee.

Beginning this Sunday in Arts & Leisure, a new column called Watchlist will sample the vast and largely uncharted world of Web video -- not dancing Filipino prisoners or Baby Bob Marley, but the thousands of online serials, Webisodes, cartoons, talk shows, newsmagazines, reality shows and other formats that have sprung up over the last decade as a quick-and-cheap parallel world to television and film. "We told children to think about how pictures tell a story like in fairy tales," says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni about the latest chapter in her ongoing project to help underprivileged children. "We hoped to stimulate their creativity and make something that could be sold with the proceeds going back to bettering their hospitals and schools." The three resulting tote bags feature vintage Marni prints on one side and drawings by children from East Asia and South America on the other. Eighty percent of the proceeds will go to children's developmental programs geared toward learning and creativity. "It seemed like the natural thing to do around the holidays," adds Castiglioni. This week I reported on a push by a number of nations to expand the scope of the Montreal Protocol, the treaty designed to deal with the degradation of the Earth's ozone layer, to begin to address global warming. Several countries, including the island nation of Micronesia, joined by the United States, Mexico and Canada, are proposing to phase out a family of industrial chemicals known as hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, which have a minimal effect on the ozone layer but are highly potent greenhouse gases.

In the last round of collective bargaining negotiations in 2005, a novel clause was included in the final agreement that came to be known as the Amnesty Clause. It allowed N.B.A. teams to designate one of the outstanding contracts on their payroll as being exempt from the end-of-season luxury tax calculations. For example, if a team had a payroll of $256 billion dollars against a luxury tax threshold of $40 billion, and one of their players was earning $220 billion alone, using the amnesty clause on that player would then put that team under the luxury tax threshold (as their payroll for luxury tax purposes was now considered to be only $36 billion). The player still got his money, and the teams got the reprieve -- everyone, indeed, was a winner.

For more than 30 years, Neil L. Selinger had his hand in major securities litigation cases that played out in New York courts. He helped to obtain a nearly $80 million settlement for investors of Philip Services Corp., a Canadian resource recovery company. In 2007, Mr. Selinger stepped away from the practice of law to pursue his interest in writing and volunteer endeavors.

Lean, tattooed and hunky in the way of a young Henry Rollins, Brian Reaume is living the life of a gay indie Brooklyn or Bay Area artist. He lives in what real estate agents call a ''transitional'' neighborhood, in a house filled with midcentury furniture and quirky art by him and his friends. In a small shop on a funky strip of cafes, bars and galleries, he sells his paintings along with the vintage housewares that he collects with the shop's co-owner, Nancy Carlson, who lives upstairs. Two years ago he created ''There's No Truth in Silence,'' an installation in his studio - which is among a warren of artists' spaces in an old warehouse - that drew thousands one weekend with its controversial use of the American flag, a swastika, a cross and a chair emblazoned with the word ''fag.''

Patch NYC has come a long way since its debut collection, 15 years ago, of crocheted hats made by the mother of John Ross, the brand's co-owner. The company has grown over the years to include both fashion and home items, all with a modern twist on a vintage look. Enough, in fact, to fill a store, which opened in the South End of Boston two weeks ago. "Our collection had expanded into a lot of new categories, and we wanted a space where we could show everything together," explained Ross, referring to himself and his co-owner, Don Carney. "We found an ideal space in the back of a brick-lined courtyard in our favorite Boston neighborhood, and it felt like a perfect location to create a Patch NYC world." That world includes the company's jewelry, scarves, candles and pillows, along with original art by Carney,  who hails from Boston. Also in the mix are a selection of porcelain from the Brooklyn-based designers Klein Reid, ceramic sculptures by the Boston-based artist Steve Murphy and vintage decorative objects and Indian textiles. Ross and Carney's mothers are still involved - they're currently working on framed needlepoint art that will be sold at Barneys.Patch NYC, 46 Waltham Street, Boston; (917) 292-2640.

It has been three years since Joe Torre stopped managing the Yankees. But his presence is still cause for a Yankees reunion, which turned into a reason to discuss the organization's free-agent plans. It had to be with Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and General Manager Brian Cashman walking the red carpet Thursday at Torre's Safe at Home Foundation Gala in Manhattan and reporters clamoring for updates after the team's first off-season meetings.

The much-anticipated Broadway production of ''The Mountaintop,'' Katori Hall's acclaimed play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the eve of his assassination, is now looking likely for fall 2011, with Samuel L. Jackson (''Pulp Fiction'') and Halle Berry (''Monster's Ball'') poised to star, according to two executives involved in the production. There had been much talk about the play coming in this fall or spring to compete in the 2011 Tony Awards but that was always iffy, the executives said, given the busy schedules of the two stars. The executives insisted on remaining anonymous because private negotiations are continuing. One lead producer, Jean Doumanian, declined to comment on Thursday in advance of the producers' eventual announcement with details about the show. The drama was produced in London in 2009, drawing critical praise and emerging as a somewhat unexpected winner of the 2010 Olivier Award for best new play. Set in Room 306 of the Lorraine Hotel in Memphis, the play revolves around King (Mr. Jackson) and a hotel maid (Ms. Berry) who proves to have oratorical skills of her own. The production would mark the Broadway debut of Ms. Berry; Mr. Jackson is listed in a Broadway production database as having been an understudy in 1990 for August Wilson's ''The Piano Lesson'' as the lead character Boy Willie, a role he originated at Yale Repertory Theater.

OXENBERG--Cynthia Price, died peacefully with grace and courage, as she lived, at home on November 8, 2010. She fought a short battle with a fierce leukemia and chose to accept death. She had a wonderful 85 years and wanted her life to end the same way. A memorial will be held on December 12th at The Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, from 3-5pm.

An article in the special Giving section on Thursday about the Giving Pledge, whose signers promise to give away at least half of their large fortunes, misidentified the university children's hospital to which Marc Benioff, the billionaire founder of SalesForce.com, gave $100 million. It is the University of California, San Francisco -- not the University of Southern California.

In a rare partnership for a Broadway show, the coming musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' has struck a deal with Syfy, the ''imagination based'' cable outlet formerly known as the Sci-Fi Channel, to be the show's lead media partner for television and Internet commercials, promotions and contests. Neither of Broadway's current blockbuster entertainments, the musicals ''Wicked'' and ''The Lion King,'' has media partnerships like this one. Several Broadway executives said they could not recall a similar example other than MTV programs that tied into the musical ''Legally Blonde,'' though some Broadway productions and touring shows do special promotions and sometimes contests with local television stations.

FRANKFURT -- Siemens, the German electronics and engineering group, reported a big jump in orders on Thursday as the global economic recovery stimulated demand for products from factory equipment to offshore windmills. Siemens raised its dividend more than expected because of an increase in profit during its fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30. But the company said that it lost money in the fourth quarter after writing down the value of a unit that makes medical equipment.

While the center's headquarters is at 539 Tremont Street in Boston, the plays are at the Calderwood Pavilion at 527 Tremont Street.

As Wall Street scrambles to comply with the regulations of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, one little-noticed provision has executives scratching their heads. The statute, contained in Section 342 of the bill, creates 20 Offices of Minority and Women Inclusion at the various regulatory agencies, including the Treasury, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the 12 Federal Reserve banks and the newly created Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

It's a bright morning in the Presidio in San Francisco, and Andy Goldsworthy is trudging around a muddy forest clearing as he examines felled eucalyptus trees. For two years, Presidio Trust workers have carefully set aside this lumber, the byproduct of various construction and environmental projects, at the behest of Mr. Goldsworthy, the celebrated British artist. Mr. Goldsworthy intends to repurpose the trunks for his latest artwork, ''Wood Line.''

For nearly two decades, the mathematical whiz Peter Muller and his secretive band of traders have helped power Morgan Stanley to bigger profits. But now Morgan Stanley and Mr. Muller are in advanced talks about splitting up. Under the plan being discussed, Morgan Stanley would spin off Mr. Muller's unit, called Process Driven Trading, and keep a minority stake. Mr. Muller and his team would get access to Morgan Stanley's infrastructure, including its legal and other resources.

On Thursday morning, Luis Crossman, 61, slipped his still-lean, 61-year-old body into a faded green jumpsuit and zipped it up. He pulled on his black army boots and put on his aviator shades and black cowboy hat. He tied a kerchief around his neck. ''Happy Veterans Day,'' he said, giving a tight salute, stiffening his spine and snapping together his heels in one motion that recalled the discipline he learned serving in the Air Force during the Vietnam War.

DEANE--Disque D. The Trinity School Community notes with sorrow the death of Disque D. Deane, devoted trustee of Trinity School 1972-1980, father of alumni Kathryn Deane-Krantz '74 and D.D. Deane '77, and grandfather of alumna Tarara Deane-Krantz '08.

An article on Monday about the magazine The Nation, using incorrect information from the Media Industry Newsletter, overstated the magazine's loss of advertising pages so far this year. Advertising pages are down 5 percent, not 30 percent. And because of that incorrect information, the article erroneously attributed a distinction to the magazine. It is not the case that The Nation lost more pages of advertising this year than any other weekly magazine tracked by the newsletter.

An article on Tuesday about a report on the achievement gap in schools between black male students and white male students in reading and math referred incorrectly in some editions to data from Baltimore's urban school district. The information for the district's progress in dropout rates and graduation rates for African-American boys in the last academic year was compared with data from three years ago, not four years ago. The article also referred imprecisely to the significance of the number of black men in college. While black men made up ''just 5 percent'' of college students in 2008, that figure did not represent one of the areas in which blacks showed a lack of achievement, given that black men make up only about 6.5 percent of the general population.

An article on Nov. 3 about the Texas Rangers' finances and their chances of re-signing the pitching ace Cliff Lee misstated, in some editions, the surname of a relief pitcher who will not be eligible for arbitration. He is Neftali Feliz, not Perez.

ROME -- The Temple of Venus and of Rome - once one of Rome's most majestic shrines - reopened to the public on Thursday after a long restoration. ''This temple has been both a school and course of study for many,'' said Claudia Del Monte, who began working on the restoration 23 years ago and directed the project. The temple, which consists mostly of ruins and columns both from the chamber and the perimeter of the ancient building (part of which was incorporated into a church), was restored to consolidate the structure and allow the ancient building to be more easily studied. ''We're introducing new itineraries even as we work to better monitor the buildings,'' said Roberto Cecchi, a culture ministry official who formally oversaw the most recent phase of restoration.

As Wall Street scrambles to comply with the regulations of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, one little-noticed provision has executives scratching their heads. The statute, included in Section 342 of the bill, creates 20 Offices of Minority and Women Inclusion at the various regulatory agencies, including the Treasury, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the 12 Federal Reserve banks and the newly created Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew from a performance of ''Don Pasquale'' at intermission Wednesday night because of a stomach virus, the Met said. Joseph Colaneri, an assistant conductor at the house, stepped in and led the final act. The Met said on Thursday that Mr. Levine, 67, was ''much better'' and planned to conduct the opera on Saturday, as scheduled. Mr. Levine has suffered a series of health problems in past years, most recently back trouble that resulted in spinal surgery in April. The problems have forced him to cancel many performances at the Met and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, where he is also music director. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Before Lehman Brothers imploded, before Bernard L. Madoff's arrest and before the global economy's near-collapse, there was the backdating of stock options. On Wednesday, a federal judge in Los Angeles sentenced Bruce E. Karatz, the former chief executive of KB Home, to five years of probation. His case is likely to be the last criminal trial relating to backdating, a scandal that ensnared dozens of executives over allegations that the dates of stock-option awards had been manipulated to enrich recipients.

Charlie Riedel/Associated PressSeneca Capital, Dynegy's largest shareholder and a staunch opponent of the energy company's proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group, on Thursday made good on its promise to mount a proxy fight against the company. The investor nominated a former railroad executive, E. Hunter Harrison, and an energy company executive, Jeff D. Hunter. If elected, they would replace Bruce Williamson, Dynegy's chief executive, and David Biegler, a current director.

DEANE--Disque D.,died on November 8, 2010 in Boston, Massachusetts. He was one of the most innovative and creative financiers on Wall Street. One of Disque Deane's more prestigious accomplishments was his revolutionary approach to sale-leaseback transactions. He was a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1963 1978. In 1972, Mr. Deane and Andre Meyer restructured and financed Starrett City, a 5,881 unit model community in Brooklyn, New York. The community was restructured so that investors could benefit from a partnership that combined equity investments from private banks, state agencies and loans from federal housing authorities. The Community, opened in January, 1974, has its own shopping center, newspaper, power plant and security force. It is the largest and most successful affordable housing community in the United States. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Group and founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Corporate Property Investors, the largest private REIT prior to its acquisition by Simon Property Group in 1998. He believed in education and medical research. Mr. Deane supported primary and secondary schools as well as universities. He established the Deane Laboratories in Neurobiology at Duke University. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Institute for Integrated Research on Atrial Fibrillation and Stroke at Massachusetts General Hospital as well as a Trustee at the Linus Pauling Institute, Rockefeller University and Duke University. Mr. Deane was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and attended Duke University. He graduated from the U.S.M.S. United States Navy Officer Training School. He is survived by his wife, Carol and their two children, Anne and Carl, and his children by his deceased wife, Marjorie Schlesinger Deane: Marjorie Swain, Kathryn Deane, Disque Deane, Jr. and Walter Deane. He has seven grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A service will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11:00am on Friday, November 19. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Starrett City Community Fund for Scholarships. Please make donations to: Spring Creek Community Corp Scholarship Fund, Office of Public Affairs, Spring Creek Towers, 1310 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11239.

ROSS--Dorien, PhD, cherished, beloved and precious daughter of Blanche and Chester (deceased), sister of Arthur (deceased) died suddenly in Berkeley, CA, November 8. Author of "Returning to A". Definitive work Flaminco arts, music and dance and numerous other articles and essays. Her numerous writings has been widely anthologized and published. One of her essays was selected for the prestigious annual volume, Best American Essays. Skilled clinical psychologist on both West and East coasts. She will be profoundly missed by the many who loved her. She is survived by her mother Blanche Ross and a wide circle of friends around the world who will miss her vibrant energy, her humor, her honesty and her big heart. Services November 12, 2010, 11am, Campbell's, 81st and Madison. Family will receive guests Thursday, November 11 and Friday November 12.

Days after ordering a new season of its hit horror series ''The Walking Dead'' AMC has swung its scythe at another original drama, announcing on Thursday that it would not pick up more episodes of its conspiracy thriller ''Rubicon.'' Created by the screenwriter Jason Horwitch, ''Rubicon'' starred James Badge Dale (of HBO's ''The Pacific'') as an intelligence analyst who discovers what he believes is an ominous pattern in seemingly unrelated data. A sneak preview of its pilot episode was shown twice over the summer with the season finale of ''Breaking Bad'' and the season premiere of ''Mad Men,'' two other AMC mainstays, before it made its official debut on Aug. 1. Reviewing ''Rubicon'' for The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley wrote: ''It's easy to fall under the spell of the murky, paranoid world of 'Rubicon.' It's harder to tell from this preview whether the atmospherics add up to a solid and complex mystery.''

NUSSBAUM--Molly, New York, NY, passed away peacefully at home, November 11, 2010 at the age of 101. Beloved wife of Frank, who predeceased her and companion of Max Jussem, who also predeceased her. Loving mother of Bernard (Nancy), Albert (Joy) and Martin (Kane). Devoted grandmother of Emily, Peter, Frank, Caroline and David and great grandmother of Wylie, Levi, Gabriel and Zev. She came to America in 1929 from Poland and was the oldest of a family of seven brothers and sisters. Her younger sister Helen (and brother-in-law Harold) survive her. Molly led a wonderful life and was a woman of valor and great strength. She was a life force. Her family admired and loved her and she will live forever in their hearts. The funeral will be held on Sunday, November 14, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 or Workmen's Circle, 45 East 33rd Street, New York, NY 10016.

Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

For the second year in a row the dependable design fair Modernism has teamed up with the younger Art20, giving visitors to the Park Avenue Armory a concentrated look at 20th-century art and design. The marriage of these two fairs has allowed both to ride out a difficult economy. It has also nudged painting and sculpture into close contact with furnishings, jewelry and decorative objects, producing a kind of friction that rarely occurs in museums. Because Modernism is the more established of the two fairs (with 25 years under its belt, to 9 for Art20), the design tends to dominate. This is generally not the place to go shopping for big-ticket 20th-century art, although the also-rans have plenty of personality.

When you see a good show, you like to come away with a keepsake: the ticket stub, the program, perhaps a T-shirt purchased in the lobby. The people behind ''Play Dead'' apparently know this, because they make every effort to send you home with a fellow audience member's entrails stuck in your hair or lodged in your tote bag. This gleefully grotesque orgy of death and fright, which leaves the Players Theater looking like a movie house after a midnight showing of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show,'' is the creation of the magician Teller, who directs, and Todd Robbins, the main performer, whose areas of expertise include sword swallowing, séances and sideshow freaks. If you find that Halloween haunted houses just don't do it for you anymore, this just might be the show for you: scarier and smarter.

(Sundance) NO ONE KNOWS ABOUT PERSIAN CATS (2009) Negar (Negar Shaghaghi) and Ashkan (Ashkan Koshanejad) are young musicians with dreams of touring Europe and a need for backup players for their indie rock band -- in Tehran. ''Of course circumstances for iconoclastic, bohemian young people in Iran are not what they are elsewhere,'' A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times, adding that ''both the pathos and the buoyant energy'' of this ''bouncy, seething'' film by Bahman Ghobadi ''come from the sense that Negar, Ashkan and their friends are bravely laying claim to creativity, idealism and free expression in defiance of an authoritarian state that seeks to deny them those universal birthrights of modern youth.'' The film, above, which won a jury award in Cannes, is one of several movies that prompted the Iranian government to announce that it would punish filmmakers who do not obtain approval for their work. ''Productions in Iran are subject to review before being released there,'' The Times reported in December 2009, ''and directors are expected to submit screenplays for approval before beginning shooting, though some ignore the process.'' 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Sunita L. Williams and Leland Melvin met in a NASA astronaut class in 1998 and have each journeyed to the International Space Station. But back on Earth they spend a lot of time trying to manage their problem dogs. Ms. Williams's Jack Russell terrier, Gorby, likes to pick on dogs bigger than he is. Mr. Leland's Rhodesian Ridgeback mix Jake will try to bite anyone who gets near his owner. Cesar Millan comes to the rescue. In ''Squid vs. Whale,'' at 9, marine biologists attach a remote camera to a sperm whale, the largest toothed predator on the planet, as it journeys 1,000 feet below the ocean's surface in the Gulf of California in search of its favorite meal, the colossal squid.

Eight projects to save historic and culturally significant sites in New York City have been awarded grants by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced. The recipients include the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts in Manhattan, and the Louis Armstrong House Museum and the Free Synagogue of Flushing, both in Queens. The grants, which range from $2,000 to $10,000, were financed by Robert and Elizabeth Jeffe, longtime supporters of historic reservation. Ms. Jeffe is a board member at the trust. The recipients, selected in August and announced on Wednesday, were evaluated based on urgency of need, geographical distribution, historical significance and overall impact. The other winners were the Bartow-Pell Landmark Fund; the Columbia Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation; the New York Landmarks Conservancy; the Two Bridges Neighborhood Council; and the World Monuments Fund. The next deadline for proposals for financing is Feb. 1.

Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers. In 1982, the ''Bill James Baseball Abstract'' was published on a wide scale for the first time, sparking a statistical revolution in baseball. James's influence, however, was not confined to the diamond. Two young basketball fans, Daryl Morey and Dean Oliver, fascinated by James's innovations, began to view basketball through a similar lens. Today, the approach of combining traditional scouting with statistical analysis has taken hold in the N.B.A. Morey, who never played competitive basketball beyond high school, is general manager of the Houston Rockets, and Oliver is in the Denver Nuggets' front office.

DENMARK--Lenny. After a wonderful 92 years of life, Lenny Denmark passed away on November 9th 2010, with his children close at his side. Lenny was the loving husband of Selma Denmark (who preceded him in death on October 28, 2008), father of Steven and wife Maxine, Phyllis and husband Marc, and Scott. He was adored by his grandchildren Michelle and husband Todd Strassberg, Gary Denmark, Jennifer Borak and husband Michael Sharkansky, and Amy Borak and husband Brian Webb. He treasured his great-grandchildren Abby and Evan Strassberg, Ben and Peri Denmark, and Isaiah Webb. Lenny was the patriarch of a close knit family and will be dearly missed.

As I report in Sunday's Times, many climate scientists are frustrated by the lack of good information about the status of the world's land ice. Yet they have nonetheless come to an informal consensus about the extent to which the sea may rise in the course of this century: roughly three feet.
Researchers have been startled to see signs of rapid melting in Greenland and Antarctica, but lack data to precisely calculate how much flooding could result.

My Sunday column is about Roshaneh Zafar and her microfinance organization, Kashf, in Pakistan. I've been frustrated to see so much American money pouring into the Pakistani army, accomplishing nothing as far as I can see, while economic development has been starved. As I wrote in my previous column, the best way for America to create jobs and promote the business sector in Pakistan would be to ease tariff barriers on Pakistani garment exports (Pakistan is a huge manufacturer of socks and similar products). But economic development programs like Kashf are also a mechanism to create jobs, boost civil society and undermine extremism.

Prudential Financial sold sold more than 18.3 million shares to help pay for two units it is buying from the American International Group.
A dream season has turned dark for quarterback Cam Newton as No. 2 Auburn prepares for its longtime rival Georgia.
A lack of progress after the military’s campaign against the Taliban has raised fears of renewed militancy.
A book arguing that Muslim immigrants are socially, culturally and intellectually inferior has sold more than a million copies.
A New York appellate court said “ordinary street crime” was not terrorism.
The audit stemmed from questions about potential conflicts of interest at the Social Innovation Fund, which distributes federal money to promising nonprofits.
A hip-hop crew that’s rising online hungers for more.
Writers and other literary types compete at Ping-Pong to support a cause and promote a new book about the game of table tennis.
Kremerata Baltica and Alexei Lubimov played separate concerts for Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival on Thursday.
“The Locator,” a reality series on WE TV, tries to find people their long-lost relatives, even though there’s often a fractured family involved.
Call of Duty: Black Ops reflects a keen intelligence and a rigorous understanding of each individual element of modern game design.
“The Big Bang Theory” and “The Mentalist” topped the ratings on Thursday as CBS racked up another No. 1 night.
Budweiser’s decades-long connection to baseball frayed when its parent company alleged in a federal lawsuit that baseball reneged on an agreement to extend the beer maker’s sponsorship.
The 14th World Computer-Bridge Championship was held last month in Philadelphia.
Whether smart electric meters are ripping off consumers by overstating electricity use is now a matter of debate.
In “Skyline,” a pack of hungry space aliens drops in on Southern California for a bite.
There are thousands of places in Manhattan to spend the night, but for two men from Florida, the best rest is found in an elm tree.
Yale Repertory mounts a “Notes From Underground” for the Internet age.
The $69.5 million for an 18th-century vase, found in a family home, is believed to be the highest ever paid at auction for a Chinese antiquity.
The military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy will remain while a legal challenge is being considered by a federal appeals court, the U.S. Supreme Court declared.
Chelsea Opera presented a spare, affecting production of Tom Cipullo’s “Glory Denied” on Thursday evening at St. Peter’s Church.
At one point in Henry Threadgill’s performance on Thursday at Roulette with Zooid with the Flux String Quartet, blam: the sky opened up. Then blam: sunny again.
In a war-torn landscape, a wanderer identifies with a winged outsider in Pavel Zustiak’s latest dance, at the Ellen Stewart Theater at the La MaMa Annex.
Jean Butler, who embodied the spirit of Irish step dancing in “Riverdance,” performs a contemporary solo at Danspace Project.
The Chamber Music Society presented the New York premiere of “Northern Lights” by Bright Sheng on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.
A militant who was barred from Britain was sentenced in absentia for belonging to a terrorist group and inciting violence.
President Obama will nominate North Carolina’s chief banking regulator, Joseph A. Smith Jr., to run the federal agency that regulates and controls the mortgage giants.
The football teams from Williams (7-0) and Amherst (6-1) will meet on Saturday for the 125th time in what is called the Biggest Little Game in America.
George Steinbrenner, the sports editor for the Williams Record and a halfback on the football team, wrote a scathing open letter in 1951 aimed at the Amherst coach, for which he later apologized.
The Giants said on Friday that receiver Steve Smith partly tore his pectoral muscle in practice on Thursday. Mario Manningham is a likely replacement.
Congress has five weeks before the holiday recess to handle the issue of income and estate taxes, but few are placing bets that it will get done.
A court ruled against a man who said he was denied a teaching job after his H.I.V. status was known.
More than a decade ago Joel I. Klein fought a monopoly, Microsoft. He took on another kind of monopoly when he became New York’s schools chief.
Vince Young acts as a big brother for the young sons of Steve McNair, who was murdered last year.
What looked like smaller trade deficits and surpluses during the global recession only reflected the shrinkage in trade. As trade revives, so do those imbalances.
Owen Marecic, the only two-way player in Division I, starts at fullback and linebacker and is an A student studying infectious diseases.
A film by the director Sara Driver that was believed to be lost was found in a dusty Moroccan house.
After a two-day meeting marked by anxieties and trade frictions, the leaders of the Group of 20 agreed to a year-long cooling-off period, in which they will tackle persistent problems.
The Heat is 5-4 and has matchup problems with the Celtics, and the fans in Miami are getting restless.
Louis Gallois said EADS wanted a top executive from Asia by 2013 and to build regional headquarters there.
While Haitians in the United States have long played a role in Haitian elections, foreigners have emerged as a key constituency after the January earthquake.
Diabetes patients spend $6,000 on average a year on care, one reason only 25 percent of diabetics get the treatment they need.
Some residents lament the arrival of Duane Reade and Starbucks in Williamsburg’s main shopping district.
The chip maker’s move provides a counterpoint to the weak quarterly sales forecast from Cisco Systems, another technology giant, which has weighed on markets.
Declines occurred after world leaders meeting at the G-20 meeting came up with an agreement that fell short of the White House’s goals for trade surpluses and deficits.
Supporters of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi gathered amid reports about her release from house arrest.
President Obama said he made “no apologies for doing whatever I can” to create American jobs.
G-20 leaders left open numerous details, including how to deal with institutions whose failure could affect the whole financial system.
Euro weakness continued, however, suggesting that investors remained concerned that the market unrest was a symptom of a broader problem.
The company said a “specific component in the turbine area” caused an oil fire that forced an A380 Airbus to make an emergency landing in Singapore last week.
President Obama said major economies had not acted assertively to address global economic imbalances and left little doubt that he considered China the source of the problem.
The former Israeli prime minister, who has been in a coma in a hospital room since a stroke five years ago, was moved on Friday to his ranch in the Negev Desert.

One of the more challenging acting assignments of this Off Broadway season, Rajiv Joseph's romantic drama ''Gruesome Playground Injuries,'' has cast the roles of two self-sabotaging childhood friends who jump back and forth in time between the ages of 8 and 38. Pablo Schreiber, a Tony Award nominee for the 2006 revival of ''Awake and Sing!,'' will play the manic Doug, and Jennifer Carpenter, who stars on the Showtime series ''Dexter'' as the title character's sister Debra Morgan, will play the pained Kayleen in the New York premiere at Second Stage Theater this winter, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. The play, which has previously been produced in Houston and Washington is Mr. Joseph's follow-up to his critically acclaimed ''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' which had two popular runs in Los Angeles in 2009 and 2010 and will open on Broadway in the spring starring Robin Williams. (''Bengal Tiger'' was also a finalist for the 2010 Pulitzer Prize in drama.) ''Gruesome Playground Injuries'' will be directed by Scott Ellis (''The Little Dog Laughed'') and is set to begin previews on Jan. 5 and open on Jan. 31.

An article on Page 6 this weekend about the actor Denis O'Hare, one of the stars of HBO's ''True Blood,'' who is about to appear on Broadway in ''Elling,'' misstates the year his partner, Derek Anson Jones, died of AIDS. It was in 2000, not in 2010. The article also misidentifies the city in which Mr. O'Hare was born. It is Kansas City, Mo. -- not Detroit, which he moved to when he was 2.

When he announced that Cathleen P. Black, the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, would become the next chancellor of New York City's schools, Mayor Michael Bloomberg touted Ms. Black as uniquely qualified for the role. ''There is virtually nobody who knows more about the needs of the 21st century workforce for which we need to prepare our kids,'' the mayor said.

SEOUL - President Obama on Friday gave his tacit endorsement to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's bid to stay on as Democratic leader after January, calling her ''an outstanding partner for me.'' Mr. Obama was asked during a news conference here whether he believes the Democratic Party needs new leadership in the wake of the Election Day trouncing that cost Democrats control of the House. At first, he did not reply directly, though he ultimately did seem to give Ms. Pelosi his blessing.

Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in Dynegy and will extend the company a $2 billion line of credit if its proposed takeover by the Blackstone Group is rejected and other financing cannot be obtained, according to a regulatory filing. The announcement ratchets up the already tense dispute between Dynegy and shareholders who oppose the takeover, including the hedge fund Seneca Capital.

The Republican Party's embattled chairman, Michael S. Steele, has drawn his first, but perhaps not his last, challenger: Saul Anuzis, the former Michigan party chairman who made it to the final rounds of voting when Mr. Steele was elected nearly two years ago. In an e-mail Friday morning to members of the Republican National Committee, Mr. Anuzis wrote, ''I don't take lightly the fact that I am challenging a friend and colleague for the chairmanship.'' Then he contrasted what he could do as chairman with Mr. Steele's stewardship, a tenure marked by widespread complaints about gaffes, personal spending, self-promotion and, as a consequence, the exodus of big donors to other organizations, some of them set up in 2010 expressly to sop up the conservative cash that otherwise would have flowed into the R.N.C. treasury.

Kanye West is free to spend the morning after Thanksgiving looking forward to football and fretting about how much he ate the day before: the mercurial rapper will not perform a concert on the ''Today'' show scheduled for Nov. 26 amid a feud with that NBC morning program.

8 P.M. (HBO) IT'S COMPLICATED (2009) Meryl Streep, above with Alec Baldwin, plays Jane Adler, a successful restaurateur somewhere near Santa Barbara, who is just about to settle into life as an empty-nester when she is blindsided by advances from her ex-husband (Mr. Baldwin), who left her a decade earlier for a pretty young thing (Lake Bell) with a steely smile and intimidating abs. Steve Martin is thrown into the mix as the architect overseeing the renovation of Jane's house, who is not without his own charms. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this ''pleasurable, daffy if at times daft'' comedy from Nancy Meyers ''transforms a divorced couple into a romantic couple, which suggests a belief in love enduring even after a marriage dies,'' adding, ''That sounds wonderfully romantic or a prescription for pathology, maybe both.'' She continued, ''But no matter how liberating some of her conceits, notably the older heroine, her embrace of sexist stereotypes, including male characters as agents of narrative change, keep her and her female characters down.'' Still, with winning performances from Ms. Streep and Mr. Baldwin, and an eye-candy set, ''the truth is that everyone needs a little coddling,'' Ms. Dargis said, ''which could be the key to Ms. Meyers's peculiar talent: She pampers her audience shamelessly.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Betty Rollin reports on a Buddhist chaplaincy training program at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

SMITH--Samuel Z.,of Fairfield, CT passed away November 10, 2010. Predeceased by his son William, he is survived by his wife Betty, daughter, Amy; two granddaughters, Kelley and Meaghan and son-in-law, Jim. A graduate of Yale University, he served in the US Army during World War II and earned a Bronze Star. A Memorial is planned for a later date.

The Minnesota Twins had a fine first season back outdoors, drawing sellout crowds at Target Field and winning the American League Central title. But the difficulty the Twins players had hitting home runs there has become an issue, with first baseman Justin Morneau sending an e-mail to The Star Tribune of Minneapolis in which he complained about the team's decision to spend $4 million to $6 million on Target Field alterations but to leave the outfield fences untouched. ''Right-center to left-center is ridiculous,'' Morneau said in the e-mail, adding that it was almost impossible for hitters to hit opposite-field home runs at Target Field.

Among the stately columns and dusty books in the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen Library on West 44th Street in Manhattan, men, women and some babies gathered for the fifth annual Grand Meeting of the Corduroy Appreciation Club on Thursday night wearing all manner of the cloth. There were jackets, suits, skirts, leggings and vests; rompers, capes, hats, spats - and even one (visible) corduroy bra. The occasion was the seminal date in every corduroy aficionado's calendar, the president and founder Miles Rohan, 34, explained, addressing the crowd from a lectern draped in corduroy, flanked by corduroy-caped guards. Nov. 11, when written numerically, 11/11, is the date that most closely resembles the parallel ribbing, technically called ''wale,'' characteristic of the cloth.

The Republican Party's embattled chairman, Michael S. Steele, has drawn his first, but perhaps not his last, challenger: Saul Anuzis, the former Michigan party chairman who made it to the final rounds of voting when Mr. Steele was elected nearly two years ago. In an e-mail Friday morning to members of the Republican National Committee, Mr. Anuzis wrote, ''I don't take lightly the fact that I am challenging a friend and colleague for the chairmanship.'' Then he contrasted what he could do as chairman with Mr. Steele's stewardship, a tenure marked by widespread complaints about gaffes, personal spending, self-promotion and, as a consequence, the exodus of big donors to other organizations, some of them set up in 2010 expressly to sop up the conservative cash that otherwise would have flowed into the R.N.C. treasury.

ROTHSCHILD--Gertrude Neumark. The Dean and Faculty of The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science at Columbia University mourn the loss of Gertrude Neumark Rothschild, Howe Professor Emerita. While at Columbia, she conceived the doping process that has been the basis for devices improving the quality of consumer products ranging from flat screen TVs to mobile phone screens. We send our deepest condolences to her husband, Henry Rothschild. Feniosky Pena-Mora Dean Morris A. and Alma Schapiro Professor

In this weak economy, many recent, and soon-to-be, graduates of colleges and graduate schools are having a difficult time finding jobs, leading at least one to ask whether it's possible to get back money spent on tuition. Last month, an anonymous third-year Boston College Law School student posted a letter on a student newspaper site asking the school's interim dean for a refund.

An obituary on Friday by The Associated Press about Dave Niehaus, the Seattle Mariners broadcaster, erroneously included one honor among his accomplishments. He was never inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame. (He did receive the Ford C. Frick Award, in 2008, given to a broadcaster for major contributions to baseball.)

The Most Beautiful Woman in the World walked into Harry Cipriani on Fifth Avenue in black boots and a riding-hood-red cloak, and for the only person in the room expecting her, it perhaps was a trick of the imagination, but it seemed as if the whole restaurant lost its train of thought for a second. Then it righted itself, and the maitre d'hotel hustled over, and the woman became wrapped in warm Italian greetings and air kisses before finally removing her big sunglasses. Gina Lollobrigida blinked lashes as thick as flora and smiled, and there it was, that smile, the one that snared Yul Brynner's Solomon in ''Solomon and Sheba'' 50 years ago, and she said, fooling absolutely no one, ''What is surprising is I'm still popular. They still know me.'' Ms. Lollobrigida is now 83, as vital and vibrant and hot-blooded as she was in her many roles as the voluptuous queen/gypsy/trapeze artist/opera singer/who cares, when she was routinely referred to by the aforementioned superlative, and even starred in a film by that name (retitled ''Beautiful but Dangerous'' for its American release, for some reason). She lives in Italy, but was passing through New York these last two weeks for a bunch of reasons, explained over the course of a couple of chats.

VISCUSI--Fred J. passed away peacefully November 12. Survived by two children Stephen Viscusi and Laura Viscusi and her husband Ross Garnick, all of Manhattan. Also, survived by his twin sister Rose Basciano. Funeral Mass at 10:30am, St. Patrick's Church, Armonk, NY. Interment at Middle Patent Cemetery, Banksville, NY on Monday November 15.

Because of an editing error, a classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday misstated the time of tonight's performance of ''Intermezzo'' by the New York City Opera at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. It is at 8 p.m., not at 1:30 p.m. Tickets can be obtained by calling CenterCharge at (212) 721-6500. (While the number in the listing was for the theater's box office, that office is not selling tickets over the telephone.)

ROME -- Hundreds of Italian cultural institutions took part in a nationwide protest on Friday against a series of measures passed recently that critics say will stifle cultural development in Italy. Some museums and archaeological sites closed for the day; others shut their doors for a few hours. Libraries and archives around the country were closed. Pamphlets explaining the reasons for the protest were distributed in theaters and concert halls.

WHITMORE--Glenn E.,loving father of Jackson D. Whitmore and Edward Z. Whitmore. Beloved brother of Evelyn Fischel and cherished nephew of Edward Hooper, died on Thursday, November 11, 2010 in Pelham Manor, NY. Visitation at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, NY, on Sunday, November 14, 3-7pm. Memorial Service: Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday, November 15, at 11am.

KOSTMAYER--John H.,95 died on October 31 in Key West, FL. Preceded in death by his wife of 58 years, Julia C. Kostmayer and survived by his wife Sally, her four children, four grandchildren, and his three sons, Roger, Kos and Peter, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

There is no shortage of places in Manhattan where visitors can spend the night. Luxury hotels offer lavish suites that can run thousands of dollars, and youth hostels have beds for as little as $20. At least one flophouse survives on the Bowery. And, of course, there is couch-surfing -- countless travelers bunk with old friends or near-strangers for little more than an owed favor. Cory and Dana Foht have taken another route. On some 20 nights over the past two months, the Fohts, 25-year-old twins from Florida, have climbed about 25 feet up the side of a tall European beech tree in Central Park, stretched nylon hammocks between its branches, unrolled sleeping bags and, with a few acrobatic moves, squirmed into their makeshift beds.

Will the Tony Award-winning actor Mark Rylance (''Boeing-Boeing'') be competing against himself in the 2011 Tony competition for best actor in a play? It's increasingly possible. Mr. Rylance has earned rave reviews as the delightfully narcissistic street performer Valere in the play ''La Bete,'' which is scheduled to run at the Music Box through mid-February, and it now looks very likely that he will return to Broadway in the spring to reprise his widely acclaimed London performance as Rooster Byron in Jez Butterworth's play ''Jerusalem.''

MAXMAN--Al. Passed away at home on November 12th after 82 wonderful years. Beloved husband of Bobbi; father of Joel (Sherri) and Ron (Helen); grandfather of Andrew, Elizabeth, Nicole, Sophie and Julia. Warm, witty, loving and caring. Social worker, college professor, and consummate camp director. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 9:30am Plaza Chapel 91st and Amsterdam
SLIDE SHOW Paul McDonough's photographs, which are on exhibit at the Sasha Wolf Gallery, evoke the New York of the 1970s. nytimes.com/lens
We're not big fans of gift cards but we know that many people like the convenience of receiving them or buying them as gifts.

O'HALLORAN--James. The Council of the Grolier Club is deeply saddened to learn of the death of fellow member and former Councilor James O'Halloran. A Grolier member since 1984, O'Halloran served on the Grolier Club Council from 1987 to 1992, and headed with distinction the House Committee (1987-1991) and Publications Committee (1993-1995). His interest in books was broad and scholarly, and his particular passion for Irish literature and poetry was the springboard for a number of Grolier Club exhibitions and other events, including the landmark exhibition, "To Set the Darkness Echoing," which he co-curated in 2002. We extend our sympathy to his family, and to his many friends and colleagues at the Grolier Club, and in the world of books at large. Eugene S. Flamm, President, The Grolier Club

STANFORD, Calif. -- Outside the locker room, Owen Marecic was being interviewed last Saturday when Jim Harbaugh, the Stanford coach, sidled up to him. Harbaugh made no bones about the fact that Marecic, who starts at fullback and middle linebacker, is one of his favorites, describing him as ''the football player I always wanted to be.''

BRAUER--Evelyn Shugar, of Jersey City, NJ passed away November 6. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Charles K. Brauer, MD, she is survived by her devoted children Richard and Mary Brauer of Greenwich, CT and Joyce and Jon Weston, of Chatham, NJ, grandchildren Samantha, Alexander, Philip, and Charlotte, sister Marguerite Brill, brother Gerald Shugar, and her devoted companion the Honorable Sam Eisenberg. A graduate of UNC at Chapel Hill, she was a practicing pharmacist until recent years. Her life, dedicated to family, learning, culture and community, was an inspiration to family and friends. Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, NJ, Sunday at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Coalition for Pulmonary Fibrosis, Hadassah, or Temple Beth-El, Jersey City. For info: Gutterman Bros., 1-866-473-3700.

GOODMAN--Richard F. The Stecher and Horowitz Foundation has lost a treasured Board member. Devoted enthusiast for all the young artists affiliated with the Foundation. Richard's imprint will remain indelible. William S. Hearst, Chairman Melvin Stecher and Norman Horowitz, Executive Directors

Is it Michael Jackson's voice, or isn't it? After testimonials by Jackson's record label and a former manager and producer, a lawyer for the Jackson estate has offered a detailed response to concerns that the lead vocal on ''Breaking News'' -- the first track released from a posthumously assembled album, ''Michael'' -- is that of Michael Jackson. Epic, the label, has also quickly announced the release of another song from the album.

Garfield may hate Mondays, but Thursday wasn't a banner day for that cartoon cat, either. Jim Davis, the creator and author of ''Garfield,'' apologized for a comic strip published on Thursday that some readers said was insensitive to the Veterans Day holiday. In the comic strip a spider warns him that if Garfield squishes him with a newspaper, the spider ''shall become famous'' and ''they will hold an annual day of remembrance in my honor.'' The final panel shows a gathering of spiders in a spider classroom, being asked by a spider teacher, ''Does anyone here know why we celebrate 'National Stupid Day'?''

PINKERTON--Ann, of Bedford, New York passed away peacefully at home on November 10, 2010. Daughter of the late Robert A. Pinkerton and Louise Pinkerton Marshall; descended from the late Allan Pinkerton who founded The Pinkerton National Detective Agency. "Pink" will be remembered fondly by her many adoring cousins and friends all of whom contributed to her wonderful life. She was 78 and worked for many years at the Corlears School where she was a valued member of the community. A champion equestrian at Pegasus, she enjoyed riding until the end of her life. "Pink" and her contagious laugh will be sorely missed by her family and many friends. A celebration of her life will take place at a later date. Memorial contributions to Pegasus Therapeutic Riding, 310 Peach Lake Road, Brewster, NY 10509-1715.

DEANE--Disque D. The staff of Starrett City is deeply saddened by the news of Disque Deane's passing this past week. Disque, as we fondly called him, set consistently high standards for all of us who work at Starrett. A strong motivating presence, he, together with his wife Carol, provided the leadership and guidance that put Starrett at the forefront of many initiatives, particularly energy conservation. His vision provided Starett's residents with an unparalleled quality of life. As well as remembering Disque for his professional commitment, we will never forget that Disque was one of a kind. For all his achievements, he made us feel comfortable and glad to be in his presence. Our memory of his frequent visits dressed in a baseball cap and bow tie askew, along with his extraordinary vision, will be etched in our hearts and minds forever. We will miss him very much.

The authorities don't seem to understand the way Twitter works. There's no provision in the law for people being hyperbolic, sarcastic or ironic. For a country that prides itself on its sense of irony, that is unfortunate. PADRAIG REIDY, news editor of Index on Censorship, a London magazine that covers free-speech issues. [A3]

A theater review last Saturday about ''Photograph 51,'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, referred imprecisely to the acknowledgment of the contribution of the British scientist Rosalind Franklin to the discovery of the structure of DNA. While some scholars and others feel she was not given proper credit, her work was indeed mentioned by others; it did not go unacknowledged for 15 years.

NUSSBAUM--Molly, New York, NY, passed away peacefully at home, November 11, 2010 at the age of 101. Beloved wife of Frank, who predeceased her and companion of Max Jussem, who also predeceased her. Loving mother of Bernard (Nancy), Albert (Joy) and Martin (Kane). Devoted grandmother of Emily, Peter, Frank, Caroline and David and great grandmother of Wylie, Levi, Gabriel and Zev. She came to America in 1929 from Poland and was the oldest of a family of seven brothers and sisters. Her younger sister Helen (and brother-in-law Harold) survive her. Molly led a wonderful life and was a woman of valor and great strength. She was a life force. Her family admired and loved her and she will live forever in their hearts. The funeral will be held on Sunday, November 14, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 or Workmen's Circle, 45 East 33rd Street, New York, NY 10016.

''Nightly Business Report, '' the business newscast on PBS, laid off eight people on Friday, or about 20 percent of the staff, in the first major change since it was acquired in August by a new company, NBR Worldwide. The layoffs at the half-hour daily program included several on-air faces, but not the anchors Susie Gharib and Tom Hudson, according to employees who asked not to be named because they were not authorized to speak publicly.

A listing in the Westchester Calendar in some editions on Sunday for a performance of Haydn's St. Cecilia Mass scheduled for today and Sunday, at Bedford Presbyterian Church referred incorrectly to the admission. Tickets are $25 ($20 for seniors and students); admission is not free. Tickets may be purchased at the door or by calling (914) 645-0705 or by e-mailing mastersingers@optonline.net.

An article last Saturday about the role of Latinos in the midterm elections referred incorrectly to the margin of defeat for Carly Fiorina, the Republican Senate candidate in California, in her race against Senator Barbara Boxer. Ms. Fiorina lost by fewer percentage points -- not more -- than Meg Whitman lost to Jerry Brown in the California governor's race. (Ms. Fiorina lost by 10 percentage points, 52 percent to 42 percent; Ms. Whitman lost by 11 percentage points, 53 to 42.)

Federal authorities have begun an inquiry into whether a prominent hedge fund gave an improper advantage to its founder and certain clients and whether disclosures were made in a timely fashion, according to a person who has been interviewed by regulators about the matter. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States attorney's office in Manhattan are examining whether Philip A. Falcone, the founder of Harbinger Capital Partners, failed to inform investors quickly enough after taking a $113 million loan to pay off a personal tax bill last year.
KRACH--Bill. November 13, 1922 - May 20, 2006. I miss you not a day goes by that I don't think of you. Thank you for your love. I love you. Ellie

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- The Giants' potent offense will be without one of its most dangerous weapons Sunday, and possibly longer. Steve Smith partly tore his pectoral muscle while making a catch Thursday in practice and will be sidelined when the Giants (6-2) play the Dallas Cowboys (1-7) on Sunday at New Meadowlands Stadium. Coach Tom Coughlin said that Smith would be considered week to week, and that the injury would not require surgery.

INDIANA at 6 WISCONSIN - Noon, ESPN2; --- ; It is crowded at the top of the Big Ten, and the Badgers need to keep winning to stay in the mix. GEORGIA at 2 AUBURN- 3:30 p.m., CBS; ---- Will off-the-field distractions derail Auburn's national title hopes?

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Samsung Galaxy tablet computer, referred imprecisely in some editions to features available on its main rival, the Apple iPad. Many of the features the Galaxy offers are available on the iPad, although through separate apps. It is not the case that such features are not available on the iPad. (As the column noted, one Galaxy feature that is not available on the iPad is the ability to place icons anywhere on the touch screen. The iPad requires icons to be placed within a fixed grid.) The article also misidentified the iPad model that could be purchased for $600, the price of a Galaxy. It is the 32-gigabyte iPad, not the 16-gigabyte version.
International ITALIAN LEFT CALLS FOR A VOTE

SINTON--Thomas E.,Jr. 78, of Mahwah, NJ and Peru, VT, on November 11, 2010 after a brief illness. Mr. Sinton was born in New York City on August 26, 1932. He was a long-time resident of Upper Saddle River, NJ and a long-standing member of both Hackensack Golf Club and The New York Athletic Club. Mr. Sinton attended Fordham Prep, Columbia University, and the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. He commenced a career with Arthur Young in New York in 1955 and retired in 1992, as a partner, from its successor company Ernst & Young LLP. He then joined Bankers Trust as a managing director and also board member of related funds management businesses until his retirement in 2005. Tom's keen intellect, sharp wit, and unswerving support will be greatly missed by his close family and friends. His tireless work ethic, ability to challenge and encourage the best in those around him will be a lasting legacy. He was an avid golfer and both a New York Rangers and New Jersey Devils fan. Mr. Sinton is survived by his beloved wife Susan (nee Creter) and was a devoted father to Jill Polansky and her husband Ronald of Oakland, NJ, Sally Sinton and her husband Thomas Lorenzen of Melbourne, Australia, and the late Thomas E. Sinton III. He was a cherished son-in-law of Margaret Creter and a loving grandfather to Emily and Sarah Polansky, Alexandra Sinton, and Annabel Lorenzen. His brother Donald Sinton and his wife Patricia, brother-in-law Joseph Daly, daughter-in-law Trudy Sinton and many loving cousins, nieces, and nephews also survive him. He is pre-deceased by his sister, Audrey Daly. Visitation will be held on Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Monday, November 15, 2010 at 10am at St. Luke's R.C. Church in Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ. Interment will follow at Maryrest Cemetery in Mahwah, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association Greater New Jersey Chapter, 400 Morris Ave., Suite 251, Denville, NJ 07834. Please send tributes, memories and condolences at www.vanemburghsneider.com

DENMARK--Lenny. After a wonderful 92 years of life, Lenny Denmark passed away on November 9th 2010, with his children close at his side. Lenny was the loving husband of Selma Denmark (who preceded him in death on October 28, 2008), father of Steven and wife Maxine, Phyllis and husband Marc, and Scott. He was adored by his grandchildren Michelle and husband Todd Strassberg, Gary Denmark, Jennifer Borak and husband Michael Sharkansky, and Amy Borak and husband Brian Webb. He treasured his great-grandchildren Abby and Evan Strassberg, Ben and Peri Denmark, and Isaiah Webb. Lenny was the patriarch of a close knit family and will be dearly missed.

MIHALTSE--Leonidas, November 11, 1911 - November 10, 2010. Beloved husband for 61 years of Anne (d. 1999). Adored his children, William (Diana M.), Donna Saytanides, and his three grandchildren. Hardworking, determined, with a big heart, who became a fanatical golfer later in life. He was loved by all and will be sorely missed. Fairchild 516-627-2000.

WEIDER--Arthur, died November 8th at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old. A perfectly content and optimistic man, Arthur's generosity and trust were absolute. A practicing clinical psychologist until his death, he developed and held the copyright to the Cornell Index, a psychological instrument used to screen inductees in WWII and still in use by police departments around the world. Born in Brooklyn and raised in the Bronx, he attended DeWitt Clinton High School and Columbia University before earning a Ph.D. at New York University, in whose alumni association he was active. He served on the medical staffs of New York Hospital and Roosevelt Hospital and on the faculty of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, also teaching for many years at the Bellevue School of Nursing. Known to early cable television viewers as "The People's Psychologist", he often conducted therapy sessions in the dining rooms of the restaurants and nightclubs he owned on Manhattan's East Side during the 1970s and 80s. The two horses he owned on the harness racing circuit in the late 1960's were celebrated for preferentially winning on Jewish holidays. His publications included text books of psychology and an autobiography, published in 1994. He is survived by his wife, Sissie, five children, five grandchildren, a great-granddaughter and a sister.

Despite rumors to the contrary, there are many ways in which the human brain isn't all that fancy. Let's compare it to the nervous system of a fruit fly. Both are made up of cells, of course, with neurons playing particularly important roles. Now one might expect that a neuron from a human will differ dramatically from one from a fly. Maybe the human's will have especially ornate ways of communicating with other neurons, making use of unique "neurotransmitter" messengers. Maybe compared to the lowly fly neuron, human neurons are bigger, more complex, in some way can run faster and jump higher.
