ARTS & LEISURE An article on Page 6 this weekend about the actor Denis O'Hare, one of the stars of HBO's ''True Blood,'' who is about to appear on Broadway in ''Elling,'' misstates the year his partner, Derek Anson Jones, died of AIDS. It was in 2000, not in 2010. The article also misidentifies the city in which Mr. O'Hare was born. It is Kansas City, Mo. -- not Detroit, which he moved to when he was two years old.

WOODFIN--Gene Mack, died Friday, the 12th of November 2010, in Houston, Texas. Gene was born February 7, 1919 in Paris, Texas to Alma Kathryn Smiley and John Elmer Woodfin. After attending public schools in Paris, Texas, Gene earned his LLB from the University of Texas School of Law, graduating with highest honors in 1940. Immediately after graduation, he joined the law firm of Vinson, Elkins, Weems and Francis (now Vinson & Elkins) in Houston, Texas, becoming a partner in 1948. During his tenure at Vinson & Elkins, Gene was instrumental in obtaining the rights of way for many transcontinental gas pipelines, including those for Columbia Gas, Pacific Gas and Trunkline Gas Companies. During this time he also worked with the Federal Power Commission in Washington, D.C. As many of his generation did after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Gene joined the armed forces in 1942. He entered the US Navy as an ensign and served at sea on fleet mine sweepers in the Atlantic, Pacific, Mediterranean and South China Sea, and was awarded five battle stars. He was detached from the Navy at Sasebo, Japan in December of 1946 as a Senior Lieutenant. In 1959 Gene became a senior partner in Loeb, Rhoades & Co., a New York investment banking firm. While living in New York, he discovered his beloved Quaker Hill in Pawling, New York where he maintained a home since 1965. Gene left Wall Street in 1973 to return to Houston as the President and CEO of Marathon Manufacturing Company, a global offshore drilling rig producer. He became Chairman of Marathon in 1974. The company was acquired by Penn Central Corporation in 1980, and Gene was a director until 1982. He served on many boards as a director, including the Houston Branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas as Chairman from 1979-1980, and the University of Texas Foundation, Inc. as President. He also served on the boards of Apco Oil Corporation, Susquehanna Corporation, Jim Walter Corporation, Big Three Industries, Salisbury School, Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston and the Playboy Club. Gene loved his family and friends and thoroughly enjoyed entertaining. He was an avid sportsman, golfer and hunter, and especially loved fishing and hunting at Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, Pennsylvania and Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club in LaGrangeville, New York. He was an unswerving and loyal friend and generous with his time and resources to anyone in need. He was the quintessential Texan: fiercely independent and passionate in his devotion to his family, friends, career and community. Gene's Texas roots were deep, with the Smiley-Woodfin prairie grassland in Lamar County being recognized as the largest section of native grassland in Texas by the Texas Historical Commission. His past and present club affiliations include Houston Country Club, Quaker Hill Country Club, Eldorado Country Club, Castle Pines Golf Club, Garden of the Gods Club, Links Club, Doubles Club, Coronado Club, The Argyle, Harry's Bar, and Mark's Club. Gene is survived by his wife of 32 years, Jerry Ann McFaddin Woodfin of Houston, Texas; his son Dr. William S. Woodfin and wife Fran of McKinney, Texas; Robert Eldon Young III and wife Jennifer Young of Austin, Texas; Jerry McFaddin Young and Kim Herbsleb of Houston, Texas; his six grandchildren, William Keith Woodfin, Gene Sam Woodfin, Victoria Young, Grace Young, Katharine Young, and Caroline Young; former daughter-in-law Jennifer Stokes Young; nieces Hester Parker and husband Richard of Dallas, Texas and Georgia Leddy and husband Mike of Paris, Texas; nephew John Mack Woodfin and wife Dora of Paris, Texas; numerous grandnieces and his beloved Jack Russell, Wags. He was preceded in death by his daughter Kay Woodfin. The family expresses its gracious thanks to Ken Hall, Alicia Aguirre, Esther Castillo, Hannah Barrett, Linwood Boone, Dennis Brunow, and to Dr. James Willerson and Mae Thomas at St. Luke's Hospital and their staff for their tender loving care. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm Monday, November 15, 2010 at St. John the Divine Episcopal Church, 2450 River Oaks Boulevard, Houston, Texas. Gene's remains will be interred in the family cemetery on the Woodfin Brothers Ranch in Lamar County, Texas. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The University of Texas Law School Foundation, Office of Development and Alumni Relations, 727 E. Dean Keeton Street, Austin, Texas 78705 or the Glassell School of Art, Gene M. Woodfin Design Fund, Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, 5101 Montrose Boulevard, Houston, Texas 77006.

The Check In/Check Out column on Oct. 24, about the Rafayel on the Left Bank in London, located the hotel and the district of Battersea incorrectly. Battersea is in the borough of Wandsworth, south of the Thames; it is not in the West End, which is in central London.

LE CORBEILLER--Jean. Died November 13th at age 83. Born in Paris, France, he graduated from Harvard University and taught for many years at the Seminar and Lang Colleges of the New School for Social Research. Predeceased by wife Clare, he is survived by daughter Suzanne Le Corbeiller and partner Anne, daughter Genevieve White and husband Anthony, and grandchildren Jesse, Graham, Mia and Simon.

Hotel perks usually come in the form of chocolates with turndown service, free Wi-Fi or a breakfast buffet. Now Marriott is offering a nontraditional perk: concerts. The company's Renaissance Hotels brand is teaming up with up-and-coming musical acts as they tour the country to offer free concerts, listening parties and artist appearances in their lobbies. The music-focused series, known as RLife Live, kicked off last month with sets by the R&B singer Robin Thicke and the D.J. Sam Ronson.

Zsolt Erdei wished his wife and 4-year-old son a good night, put down his cellphone and picked up a lunch menu at Andre's Cafe, a tiny Hungarian restaurant on the Upper East Side. ''I'm helping my wife potty-train my son right now, so it's tough to be so far away from home,'' Erdei said Friday through his manager and interpreter, Christof Hawerkamp. ''I miss my family, but being in a place like this is like enjoying a little piece of home.''
DIMSTON--Blanche K. Happy Birthday, Mommy. We miss you very much with lots of love.

DUNCAN--Abbey Christine. Age 27, of New York, Connecticut, and Bloomington, MN, passed away November 3. Abbey was a beautiful dancer who found a way to inspire the lives of many through the arts. She was an avid environmentalist who believed in doing right for everything and everyone around her. She was a caring and nurturing daughter, sister, aunt and friend. She worked as a hydrogeologist in Connecticut at Leggette, Brashears & Graham Inc. 2006-2008 and for the City of New York at the Office of Environmental Remediation 2008-2009. A member of Soka Gakkai International-USA (SGI-USA) since 2003, Abbey was active in the Connecticut and New York communities. Since 2008 Abbey served as Verdi Square District's Young Women's leader mentoring young women in their practice and study of Buddhism. She was a member of Byakuren (white lotus group) at the New York Culture Center and practiced as the young women's vice-chapter leader in Manhattan Plaza. Her heartfelt efforts to empower young women touched the lives of many and will never be forgotten. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations will go to support Abbey's garden and various organizations that benefit the arts and the environment in the communities that she served. Donations may be sent to the Duncan Family, c/o Washburn-McReavy Funeral Chapel, 5000 W. 50th St., Edina, MN 55436, 952-920-3996.

Having two 6-foot-3, 185-pound guards who like to shoot may not seem like a recipe for great success, but so far this season, the Golden State Warriors and their matched pair of Stephen Curry and Monta Ellis have thrived. The Warriors (6-3) are in second place in the Pacific Division after being picked by many to finish close to the bottom. The magic may not last, but it is worth noting that they have allowed 106 points a game under their new coach, Keith Smart, the lowest they have allowed since 2005-6.

BLOODGOOD--Margaret, of Wilton, Connecticut died on November 6th 2010 of a sudden heart attack. She was born and raised in New York City. She attended the City and Country School and the United Nations International School. She graduated from Princeton University in 1981. She and her husband, John (Chip) Bloodgood, moved to Connecticut in 1986. She is survived by her husband, her sister Sarah Barnes Halper and her family (Tor Krogius, Max and Emma) of Northampton, MA, and her Aunts and Uncles and their families. She was predeceased by her parents, Joseph and Ann Barnes Halper.

Designers and cultural producers are in the business of divining the future. Now, thanks to a new exhibition at the National Arts Club, some of the world's leading creatives have made a full-fledged jump to the dark side. Curated by Stacy Engman, ''Contemporary Magic: A Tarot Deck Art Project'' features the minor and major arcana as reinterpreted by 78 art and fashion world luminaries who were each matched with a card based on themes that recur in their work. Among the newly anointed mystics are Karl Lagerfeld (King of Wands), Marc Jacobs (Knight of Pentacles), John Currin (Ten of Cups) and Tracey Emin (the Empress). And in an occult line call that would have taken a master magician to adjudicate, Mickalene Thomas gets the nod as the High Priestess. ''Contemporary Magic: A Tarot Deck Art Project'' runs through Nov. 30.

MAY 10, 2010, NEAR MORRETES, BRAZIL I was traveling through southern Brazil and had a few days to pass with my friend in Curitiba, so we decided to take a day trip on the Serra Verde Express. The train not only wound through luscious mountainous landscapes with breathtaking views of waterfalls, but it was also a ride through the past. (The track was inaugurated in 1885.)

BURNS--Dr. Henry. Dr. Henry was born in Antwerp Belgium on August 20, 1929 and he was a Holocaust Survivor. He went to Medical School in Switzerland and became a Surgeon whose specialty was Hand Surgery. He practiced at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn for 31 years and was head of Hand Surgery there. He also was a co-founder of the "American Association for Hand Surgery": and was its president in 1973. Dr. Burns retired to Arizona in 1997 and was very happy living there with its many days of sun and great weather. All his life he was an avid walker and swimmer. He had many talents; among them he did wonderful pen and ink drawings, wood sculptures and photography. He passed away peacefully on October 30, 2010 with his loving wife of 40 years, Cathleen and son Shawn at his side. He was a wonderful husband to Cathleen and so proud of his son Shawn's accomplishments. He is survived by his brother Murray and a large extended family. Dr. Burns was laid to rest at Mariposa Gardens Memorial Park in Mesa, Arizona. In lieu of flowers please send donations to East Mesa Health Care Center 51 S. 48th St., Mesa, AZ 85206 Attn: Administrator, as they cared for him so well. We would also like to thank Covenant Southwest Hospice. He is resting in a quiet place where the sun shines on him all day; we know he will love that. He is not gone from us only waiting to be with us all again.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said that his surprise choice of Cathleen P. Black as the new schools chancellor was a result of an open search for the most qualified candidate. But so far, The New York Times has been unable to turn up any evidence that the mayor considered anyone else besides Ms. Black, the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, to replace Joel I. Klein. So City Room began a search of its own, asking readers if they had been interviewed for the position, or if anyone at City Hall had reached out to them for suggestions on potential candidates.

THE sun streamed down on the hilly, cobbled streets of the Czech town of Kutna Hora, but I didn't feel its warmth. I was 130 feet underground in a dark, dripping, medieval mine shaft, clutching a 50-year-old hydroxide lamp. Ahead of me, my claustrophobic fiancé, Tod, identifiable by the gleam reflecting from his hard hat, navigated the narrow, chilly hand-carved passages. ''You think this is bad?'' asked our guide, an eager Czech teenager. ''Now you will all shut off your light.''

I know how to ride a bike. I've been doing it for about 25 years now. But I recently found myself wobbling down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, trying to get the knack of pedaling again. I was riding, or at least trying to ride, while practically lying down. ''Relax your hands and lean back,'' said Robert Matson, my coach in learning to ride a recumbent bicycle. ''You have to accept the comfort,'' he offered. I tried, but found myself quickly teetering on the odd machine.

An article last Sunday about new gay anthems misstated the given name of one of two Occidental College sophomores who have been posting clips of themselves on YouTube singing covers of pop songs. As a picture caption with the article correctly noted, he is Ben Klute, not Bill. The caption, however, misspelled the surname of Mr. Klute's singing partner. As the article correctly noted, his partner is Josh Erdman, not Erdmanm.

EWER--Jacob (Jack) Wolfgang, age 99, died November 4, 2010 in Lenox, MA. He was predeceased by his wife Ruth (Salinger) Ewer. Father of Dorothy Dachinger Lerner of Becket, MA and Dr. Michael Ewer of Houston, TX. Grandfather of four and great-grandfather of five.

A renegade point of view came into focus at the recent New York and Paris Fashion Weeks with the return of large numbers of young people outside the shows for the first time in decades. These kids weren't having any of cookie-cutter commercial fashion. Many observers passed them off as exhibitionists, but their exuberance and experimentation suggest the imagination and wit Elsa Schiaparelli introduced in the mid-'30s to a world cemented in a suffocating dress code. She dusted fashion with magic and dreams. The youthful turnout in Paris included a half-dozen street photographers dressed like their subjects. Their photos have to be different from those of the hundreds of scruffily dressed photographers at the runways, for whom fashion is purely business. Of course, a few women, like Louise Doktor, Anna Piaggi and Marjorie Stern (from left, starting with third photo from top left), have always viewed fashion as an art form. Right now, the reigning goddess of the insouciant set is Anna Dello Russo (center left, with wings), the editor at large for Vogue Japan.

POLLACK--Seymour, optician, artist, eccentric, died on Wednesday, November 10, 2010 of pancreatic cancer. He was 82 years old. Born and raised in Paterson, NJ, he entered the family optical business and became a pioneer in the retail industry. In Sag Harbor, NY, where he was frequently seen driving his flashy yellow TriHawk, Mr. Pollack was both an artist-in-residence as well as a fixture at the weekend softball games. Mr. Pollack is survived by his wife and life partner, Mindy Bernstein her two children and four grandchildren as well as his four children from his first marriage, twelve grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A Memorial will be held on Sunday, November 14 at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Hackensack, NJ at 3:00pm

TASIILAQ, Greenland -- With a tense pilot gripping the stick, the helicopter hovered above the water, a red speck of machinery lost in a wilderness of rock and ice. To the right, a great fjord stretched toward the sea, choked with icebergs. To the left loomed one of the immense glaciers that bring ice from the top of the Greenland ice sheet and dump it into the ocean.

LIFE is unfair, as everyone knows. But never has this been clearer than in the aftermath of the financial crisis. Small banks that took no part in reckless lending are saddled with higher costs because of the bailout used to rescue big banks that messed up; individuals who scrimped and saved during the boom are being hurt by interest rates kept artificially low to rescue the economy.

Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, announced his candidacy for mayor of Chicago on Saturday. Pledging to fight higher taxes, he said, ''We cannot price Chicagoans out of their homes, their schools and their communities.'' He also promised to reduce crime, create jobs, improve education and make government more accessible, The Associated Press reported.
Theater Jason Zinoman

On Tuesday night, the Design Trust for Public Space sponsored a panel discussion about the future of the New York taxi at the Museum of the City of New York. The trust was also the sponsor of Taxi 07, which issued policy proposals about the taxi industry in New York and displayed eight concept vehicles at the New York auto show in 2007. The panel focused on a little publicized project called Taxi of Tomorrow, the New York Taxi and Limousine Commission's effort to choose a single model of taxi for the next decade. Currently, about 16 different vehicle models are approved by the commission. The majority of taxis are still Ford Crown Victorias, but Ford plans to discontinue the model. The commission, according to its chief, David Yassky, wants a vehicle that is greener, more space efficient, more accessible and also iconic - serving as a visual symbol of the city. The new car would be established as the single approved model for a decade.

Brian Leetch helped the Rangers win the Stanley Cup in 1994, when he became the only American-born player to win the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the N.H.L. playoffs. He was twice awarded the Norris Trophy as the league's top defenseman and was inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame in Minnesota in 2008 and the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto in 2009. Leetch, 42, who played most of his 18 seasons with the Rangers, was in Manhattan recently to attend the Great Sports Legends Dinner to benefit the Buoniconti Fund to Cure Paralysis. JOE BRESCIA

I'd like to get my hands on the guy who coined the phrase ''find your passion.'' These three words have wreaked havoc on families everywhere - families that have come to believe that if you haven't found your passion by the time you apply to college (and I bet some of you are sweating over those application essays right now), you might as well kiss that scholarship goodbye.

IT'S HARD TO IMAGINE one small carton creating such a stir. Last week, federal drug regulators proposed stark new warnings for cigarette packages to scare smokers straight, including one showing a toe tag on a corpse. Once again, a familiar issue was engaged: where to draw the line between our freedom to damage ourselves and the role of government to protect us. What if different food products also had to warn consumers about their damaging, if less lethal, effects? Three artists imagined the possibilities.

The head of the City Council's education committee and a vocal critic of mayoral control is now speaking out against the mayor's choice of Cathleen P. Black to oversee New York City schools. ''Cathie Black meets none of the professional experience requirements, apparently satisfying only the undergraduate graduation standard,'' the committee chairman, Councilman Robert Jackson, wrote in a letter to David M. Steiner, the state education commissioner.

ACT I of ''The Nutcracker'' ends with snow falling and snowflakes dancing. Yet ''The Nutcracker'' is now seasonal entertainment even in parts of America where snow seldom falls: Hawaii, the California coast, Florida. Over the last 70 years this ballet -- conceived in the Old World -- has become an American institution. Its amalgam of children, parents, toys, a Christmas tree, snow, sweets and Tchaikovsky's astounding score is integral to the season of good will that runs from Thanksgiving to New Year. Nowhere else in the world is this ballet so beloved as in the United States. The troupes of Russia -- where it originated -- have not maintained the long traditions of performing it that they treasure with, say, ''Giselle'' and ''Swan Lake.'' Covent Garden was a ''Nutcracker''-free zone for more than 20 years. European companies have come around and perform it annually now, but years after American companies pointed the way. Kent Stowell, former co-director of Pacific Northwest Ballet, has proposed that for many Americans ''The Nutcracker'' is ''their first experience of art.''
Pop Nate Chinen

COPPEDGE--Arthur L.,is a respected member of the art community. He taught at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and Jamaican Arts School in Kingston, Jamaica. In 2006, he was featured in Cynthia Dantzic's book 100 New York Painters. He was an artist-in-residence at Long Island University and a member of the Arts Students League of New York. Arthur is survived by a daughter, Courtney; a sister, Margot John; a nephew, Daymond John; loyal companion, Marilyn Franklin; his cousins Mattie, Wilbur, Duroff, Chester, Cornell, Louis, and Phillip Manning; his most trusted friend, Glenn Pogue; and many other loving relatives and friends. We will remember his youthful spirit and love for life. He passed away Saturday, November 6, 2010 at his home in Brooklyn, NY. He was 72. Memorial services will be held on Monday, November 15, 5:30pm at the Lawrence H. Woodward Funeral Home. Brooklyn, NY. For more information, call 718-493-8120.

TIMOTHY EGAN If common sense were currency Michele Bachmann would be broke, and holding a tin can by the road-side just now. Alas, because we live in an age where hyperbole is gold, Bachmann is rich. She was on CNN the other day,a rare departure from the in-house fawning of Fox ''News,'' expressing out-rage that President Obama's trip to India was going to cost $200 million a day and involve nearly three dozen war-ships. In fact, this figure was made up. Now that they have to govern, Republicans are grappling with a tough initial challenge: how to detach themselves from an influential wing of their party that has never been interested in arguing facts. On a daily basis, these people bemoan, detest and feign outrage over utter fantasies. Some of the loudest voices are elected representatives; others are professional provocateurs i-terested in keeping their lecture feeshigh and their base in a lather.Bachmann's disastrous turn outside the Fox bubble was instructive, for its howed how the liars' club works.-- Excerpt from ''Liars' Club'' FIXES The typical institutional response to bullying is to get tough. In the case of the suicide of Tyler Clementi, a gay college student who was a victim of cyber-bullying, prosecutors are considering bringing hate-crime charges. But some programs show the potential of augmenting our innate impulses to care for one another instead of just fall-ing back on punishment as a deterrent. And what's the secret formula? A baby. We know that humans are hardwired to be aggressive and selfish. But a growing body of research is demonstrating that there is also a biological basis for human compassion. Brain scans reveal that when we contemplate violence done to others we activate the same regions in our brains that fire up when mothers gaze at their children, suggesting that caring for strangers may be instinctual. We are beginning to understand how to nurture this biolog-ical potential. It seems that it's not only possible to make people kinder, it'spossible to do it systematically -- at least with schoolchildren.-- DAVID BORNSTEIN, excerpt from''Fighting Bullying With Babies''For more, nytimes.com/opinionator

THE scene has been played out so many times as to border on cliché. It begins with an impromptu meet-up of two Chevy Camaros, each announcing its prowess with a V-8 rumble. Then, despite good-natured banter between the drivers, an unspoken challenge is made. Finally, a tire-smoking showdown ensues. One big difference this time: the encounter, which took place at summer's end, did not begin on the main drag of a small Midwestern town and pursue resolution on a deserted country road. Instead, the Camaros, a pair of pumped-up early '70s models owned by friends, faced off at the Azadi Stadium Race Track in Tehran.

Calling Heat Fans It has certainly been a wild ride in Miami as the Heat's Big Three of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh has failed to live up to the hype. At 6-4, the team has looked great at times, but has also been inconsistent, and that inconsistency is reflecting itself in the lackadaisical crowds at American Airlines Arena. Every game has been sold out, but there have been empty seats visible on television, even during Wednesday's loss to the rival Boston Celtics.

THE NEWS A senior White House adviser, David Axelrod, signaled in an interview that the administration was considering acceding to Republican demands that Bush-era lowered income tax rates, due to expire on Dec. 31, be extended for wealthy taxpayers. BEHIND THE NEWSPresident Obama wanted to make the lower rates permanent for most families, but let them expire for incomes over $250,000. After the elections, he said he'd consider a temporary extension for the rich as well; the White House said Mr. Axelrod was not signaling a change in that stance.

NUSSBAUM--Molly, New York, NY, passed away peacefully at home, November 11, 2010 at the age of 101. Beloved wife of Frank, who predeceased her and companion of Max Jussem, who also predeceased her. Young designers are now the focus of a New York City initiative to provide mentors and new retail concepts. Others are trying to save the garment district, where many factories have closed or laid off workers and raised prices. Fabric costs are up, especially for cotton, and just about everyone who deals with manufacturing in China knows you can't get a minimum of anything: 1,000 blouses maybe, but not 100. Department stores threaten to cancel orders if a delivery is late. Meanwhile fast-fashion companies reap the rewards of being nimble and democratic while grabbing the ideas of others. Prestige labels hold on to their heritage. And consumers wonder: Where's your app? Does that about sum up the current fashion logjam?

The 36 Hours column on Oct. 3, about Moscow, referred incorrectly to the airline service available between Moscow and Chicago. While there is indeed nonstop service between Moscow and New York and Moscow and Atlanta, there is no longer nonstop service between Moscow and Chicago.

SADEK--Norman W.,92, loving husband, father, and grandfather passed away peacefully Saturday at his home in Hartsdale, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Constance (nee Meyer), children Andrea Schrier Miller (Neil), Jim Sadek (Sandy), Robin Ascher (Peter) and Lauren Krzyzewski (George) and grandchildren Adam, Eric, Zach, Rebecca, Toby, Samuel, David, Joseph and Anna. Inquisitive and charismatic, he befriended every person he met. Norman was the founder of Charles Sadek Import Company (1936) and creator of the world renowned Andrea Birds, a WWII Marine, Norman was a pioneer in postwar trade with Japan and an industry leader in early New York gift and lamp trade associations. His products touch the lives of millions of people to this day, thousands of whom he personally met during signings across the country. He was honored by AMFAR with a lifetime achievement award in 2004. A founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and early contributor to the Hebrew Home for the Aged of Riverdale, Norman supported numerous charities continually throughout his life. Many of the commitments began with his father Charles 40 years ago. Funeral services will be held 11am, Monday at Congregation Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, White Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the City of Hope, Daniel R. Schrier Fund.

HAS any art form -- or entertainment category or visual medium or whatever you want to call it -- grown so large so fast as the online serial, while remaining so consistently outside the mainstream cultural conversation? Quick, name a Web series. We'll wait. Did you come up with ''lonelygirl15''? Two years after that initial series ended, it's probably still the best known online serial -- not because of its quality, but because of the fuss when it was revealed to be fiction.

Japan's high-speed bullet train system is expanding, reducing transit time to tourist attractions in remote corners of the country. Beginning Dec. 4, the Tohoku linewill reach the northernmost region of Honshu Island, Japan's main island, with a 51-mile extension to Shin-Aomori, hub of the Aomori prefecture and home to the big summertime Nebuta Festival.

In Revlon's 1952 ad for the Fire & Ice Collection, Richard Avedon photographed model-of-the-moment Dorian Leigh in a sparkling silver gown framed by an amorphous tuft of red fabric (a copy of a Balenciaga cape), her hands drawing attention to her blood-colored manicure and lipstick. One of the most indelible ads in fashion history, the image was part of a niche campaign that included a Peggy Olsen-worthy tagline - ''Are you made for Fire & Ice?'' - and a bizarre questionnaire that asked, 'Have you ever wanted to wear an ankle bracelet?' and 'Does gypsy music make you sad?' While a lot has changed since 1952, Fire & Ice has a new shelf life now that Revlon has re-released three ''lip-and-tip'' pairings ($4.79 - $ 8.99). The ad, shot by Mario Testino, restages the original, with a few notable exceptions - the actress Jessica Biel stands in for Leigh, ankle bracelets are so last century, and that dress is no knockoff. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

If you're the sort of traveler who can't leave home without your antihistamine, Hyatt may have a solution for you: a hypoallergenic guest room. For an extra $20 to $30 a night, guests can stay in one of 2,000 specially scrubbed and air-filtered rooms, most of which will be available by year's end, in all of its 125 full-service North American properties. Though many hotels offer purified guest rooms, Hyatt will be the first chain to offer them across a broad swath of its properties. Hyatt cited as a study from Cornell University -- commissioned by an air purifying company -- that found that 83 percent of travelers prefer an allergen-free room, even if they don't have allergies.

As sales to developing nations become ever more important to giant tobacco companies, they are stepping up efforts around the world to fight tough restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes. Companies like Philip Morris International and British American Tobacco are contesting limits on ads in Britain, bigger health warnings in South America and higher cigarette taxes in the Philippines and Mexico. They are also spending billions on lobbying and marketing campaigns in Africa and Asia, and in one case provided undisclosed financing for TV commercials in Australia.

Why would anyone pay $80,000 on old bijoux made from glass beads, wire, imitation pearls and gilt-metal filigree? That's the price the collector Susan Kelner Freeman paid in the 1980s for a rare collection of vintage Miriam Haskell jewelry, which by then was seriously declasse. Today, a single Miriam Haskell broach can sell in the thousands, and, on Dec. 7, the auction house Skinner Boston will offer its first sale of costume jewelry when Freeman's collection goes up for bid.

NEEDIEST | FINDING A NEW HOME Judith Racine, 43, and her twin daughters lost their home and middle-class lifestyle in the Haiti quake. The Neediest Cases Fund helped them settle in Brooklyn by paying for the girls' school supplies.

DEANE--Disque D. The staff of Starrett City is deeply saddened by the news of Disque Deane's passing this past week. Disque, as we fondly called him, set consistently high standards for all of us who work at Starrett. A strong motivating presence, he, together with his wife Carol, provided the leadership and guidance that put Starrett at the forefront of many initiatives, particularly energy conservation. His vision provided Starett's residents with an unparalleled quality of life. As well as remembering Disque for his professional commitment, we will never forget that Disque was one of a kind. For all his achievements, he made us feel comfortable and glad to be in his presence. Our memory of his frequent visits dressed in a baseball cap and bow tie askew, along with his extraordinary vision, will be etched in our hearts and minds forever. We will miss him very much.

GREENBUSH--Eric. Born October 28, 1940 to Lillian and Abraham "Kibby" Greenbush of Bronx, NY died peacefully at Roosevelt Hospital on November 12, 2010. A graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, Union College and NYU Law School, Eric was life-long defense attorney in the New York Courts and a life-long New Yorker. Eric Loved good food, summers on Cape Cod and most of all his wonderful family and friends by whom he will be sorely missed. Eric is survived by his loving son Brian, brother Larry, nephews Steven and Kenneth and companion Barbara. The Funeral will be held on Monday, November 15th at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made in Eric's name to the American Cancer Society www.cancer.org (800)227-2345.

ON THE SCREEN In a list on its home page, the group blog Young Manhattanite offers 13 definitions of itself, including ''a random Tumblr page'' and ''blogging Illuminati.'' Both are accurate, as is this: YM is a cipher of insider chatter. ''It is like a nuclear launch code,'' admits its founder and lead blogger, Andrew Krucoff. Witty, timely, often sharp-fanged riffs on news and culture, simply presented, dominate the site. A day of posts can include a denunciation of the Shake Shack, a video of Israel's national anthem performed live by Megadeth and commentary on politics or news media outlets (Newsweek and The New York Times are favorite targets). About four items are posted each day, unless there is a game of Bomb the Dashboard, when dozens of posts erupt on-screen in a stream of consciousness among the bloggers.

Jets (6-2) at Browns (3-5)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Jets by 3 Eric Mangini is on a cross-country quest to silence his doubters, joined by a ragtag company of spunky rookie quarterbacks, castoff veterans, fleet-footed punters and other misfits. Having conquered the defending champion Saints and vanquished his mentor Bill Belichick, Mangini hosts the Jets, whom he coached through his metamorphosis from Boy Genius to baby-faced Machiavelli before being ripped apart by the tectonic forces of Big Apple expectations and Brett Favre egocentrism. Now slightly cowed but no less ambitious, he plans to beat the Jets by baffling them. Thirteen players have carried the ball for the Browns, 13 have caught passes, 5 have thrown them and Mangini has developed a new arsenal of trick plays and sneaky strategies to overcome his team's lack of talent.

VOGEL--Joan Goldgraben, was born on February 19, 1934 in NYC to Henry and Shirley Goldgraben. She died unexpectedly on November 5, 2010 in Dallas, TX. Joan graduated from Columbus High School in the Bronx in 1949. She earned a B.S. in geography from Hunter College in the Bronx in 1952 and a M.S. from Penn State in 1954. She served on the faculty at Hunter College in the Bronx 1955-1957 where she met her future husband. Joan married Harvey Vogel on June 23, 1957. They lived in San Diego, CA where their daughters Lauren and Nancy were born. The family moved to Dallas in 1963. Joan earned a second M.S. from Western Michigan and worked for many years with the Dallas schools. She also worked in the family business, Lone Star Percussion, from 1978-2000. Joan is survived by her husband of 53 years, Harvey, daughter Lauren and husband Ronald Weiss, daughter Nancy and husband Steven Glick, and her two cherished grandchildren, Andrew and Sarah Glick. Joan Vogel was buried next to her parents in Cedar Park Cemetery in New Jersey on November 9, 2010. Donations may be made to Greenhill School, 4141 Spring Valley Rd., Addison, TX 75001 or greenhill.org.

An article on Oct. 31 about new ways of getting voters to the polls omitted an attribution for a direct-mail technique used by Hal Malchow, a political consultant, in the New Jersey governor's race in 2009. The technique of thanking voters for having voted in the past, and expressing hope that they could be thanked in the future, was adopted from the Fordham political scientist Costas Panagopoulos.

EVERY time Stacy Igel concludes a meeting with her staff, she ends it roughly the same way: ''O.K., I'll see you on Oprah!'' There's just one hitch: Ms. Igel, the founder and creative director of Boy Meets Girl, a clothing company in Manhattan, has not been invited to appear on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show.''

A few years ago, when the San Francisco company Aliph released the Jawbone - a pretty little nugget of a Bluetooth headset that offers superior ''noise assassin'' technology - I wasn't quite sure what to make of it. It was certainly an attractive piece of design. Early models sported a super-techy grill designed by the company's chief creative officer, Yves Behar, and later models included one that was just the shade of red to match my hair. But I could never get past the fact that I didn't really mind talking on a phone, no matter how many bells and whistles the Jawbone could offer. Next week, Aliph will release its next product: a wireless speaker called the Jambox, which connects to any Bluetooth-enabled device (like a laptop, smartphone or iPad, which is being packaged as its ultimate match in Apple stores worldwide). Like the Jawbone, it offers quality and craftsmanship in the smallest possible package - think of it like a Victor JVC boombox that has been reduced to the size of a butter dish. But unlike its predecessor, the Jambox ought to have broader appeal - it certainly does for me. Like most people these days, I'd been listening to music through iTunes. But I'd been listening to iTunes through a complex system of demode devices: in the living room, a pair of wired Logitech speakers; in the bedroom, a five-CD stereo system's auxiliary input; and in the kitchen, a retro-looking Tivoli radio. Woe was me if I ever wanted to listen to music in the shower.

DEANE--Disque D.,died on November 8, 2010 in Boston, Massachusetts. He was one of the most innovative and creative financiers on Wall Street. One of Disque Deane's more prestigious accomplishments was his revolutionary approach to sale-leaseback transactions. He was a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1963 1978. In 1972, Mr. Deane and Andre Meyer restructured and financed Starrett City, a 5,881 unit model community in Brooklyn, New York. The community was restructured so that investors could benefit from a partnership that combined equity investments from private banks, state agencies and loans from federal housing authorities. The Community, opened in January, 1974, has its own shopping center, newspaper, power plant and security force. It is the largest and most successful affordable housing community in the United States. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Group and founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Corporate Property Investors, the largest private REIT prior to its acquisition by Simon Property Group in 1998. He believed in education and medical research. Mr. Deane supported primary and secondary schools as well as universities. He established the Deane Laboratories in Neurobiology at Duke University. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Institute for Integrated Research on Atrial Fibrillation and Stroke at Massachusetts General Hospital as well as a Trustee at the Linus Pauling Institute, Rockefeller University and Duke University. Mr. Deane was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and attended Duke University. He graduated from the U.S.M.S. United States Navy Officer Training School. He is survived by his wife, Carol and their two children, Anne and Carl, and his children by his deceased wife, Marjorie Schlesinger Deane: Marjorie Swain, Kathryn Deane, Disque Deane, Jr. and Walter Deane. He has seven grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A service will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11:00am on Friday, November 19. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Starrett City Community Fund for Scholarships. Please make donations to: Spring Creek Community Corp Scholarship Fund, Office of Public Affairs, Spring Creek Towers, 1310 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11239.

THE first movie theater in New York City, the Regent, opened in a German section of Harlem in 1913, with a showing of ''Pandora's Box.'' The Regent, at 116th Street and Seventh Avenue, was designed by Thomas W. Lamb and had about 1,800 seats. Since the 1960s, it has been an evangelical church. The city is dotted with such old theaters -- many recognizable by signature marquees -- that have been transformed into coffee shops and drugstores, retail outlets and temples of exercise. Instead of showtimes, these marquees show the passage of time.

Part old-school gymnasium, part downtown gallery, the first VPL store from the British designer and former stylist Victoria Bartlett is further evidence that the label with a funny name - VPL is short for Visible Panty Line - is a serious concern. Bartlett says she chose the eclectic interior, which brings to mind onesie-clad musclemen doing chin-ups, in order ''to evoke a vintage gymnasium, since the VPL aesthetic was originally based on vintage undergarments.'' Besides, she adds with a nudge, ''I'm inspired by a life well-lived - I'm not stuck on minimalism.'' Created with the Brooklyn-based architecture firm Studio a+i, the shop carries the main VPL line of comfy basics and the more sports-inspired VPL Too, as well as various accessory and jewelry collaborations. As part of the designer's commitment to showcase the work of artist friends, a large photo collage (of the first VPL collection) by Mark Borthwick hangs behind the register. 5 Mercer Street; (212) 966-2145; vplnyc.com.

BACK in the early '80s, when the Zagat Survey was still just a single sheet of legal-size paper that Nina and Tim Zagat gave to friends and colleagues, they learned that their list of the best restaurants in New York had been reproduced -- en masse -- inside Citibank. ''I had a friend there who called me and said he'd just gotten one of these things on his desk,'' Mr. Zagat recalls. ''Printed across the top, it said, 'To all officers of the bank.' And when I asked how many officers there were, he told me there were 3,000.''

I will be traveling by myself to Manhattan in the first part of December to Christmas shop. I like the area near the Plaza Hotel for its proximity to concerts and good restaurants. Can you recommend restaurants where I would be comfortable dining alone, and some lodging and cultural locations? No limit on expenses. Neal Noorlag, Oak Harbor, Wash. A.First, be sure to make hotel reservations as soon as possible, as December is a busy time in New York. If price is not a concern, Michelle Higgins, The Times's Practical Traveler columnist, echoed your preference for the Plaza Hotel (Fifth Avenue at Central Park South; theplaza.com), the New York landmark that recently went through a partial conversion to condo units but still offers almost 300 hotel rooms. She also recommended the Pierre (2 East 61 Street; tajhotels.com/pierre), the flagship of the luxurious Taj Hotels chain, that is just around the corner from the Plaza, overlooking Central Park; it reopened in June 2009 after a $100 million renovation. And if your hotel style leans more toward the modern, Ms. Higgins recommended the London NYC (151 West 54 Street; thelondonnyc.com), ''which is a bit more sleek yet also in a good spot for shopping, with Fifth Avenue shops in one direction and the shops at Columbus Circle in the other.''

Visa problems have forced Lincoln Center to delay the culminating performances of its White Light Festival, dedicated to transcendence in music, until next week. "The Manganiyar Seduction," which was scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, will now take place on Monday and Tuesday. Manganiyars are a caste of Indian musicians of Muslim origin from western Rajasthan state whose songs celebrate Hindu deities. Jane Moss, Lincoln Center's vice president for programming and the organizer of the festival, said that visa applications were made in May and that about half of the 50-member troupe involved in the show had received visas by Oct. 13, but the rest were sent for further review by State Department officials. By Friday a dozen members still had not received visas, so the performances were postponed. Word came over the weekend that the remaining visas had been granted. The Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center was available Monday and Tuesday for the shift. Tickets can be used for the new dates, refunded or exchanged.

In this week's Critics' Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at the 1927 silent film "The General," a movie that "turns the intractable and cruel laws of physics into cinematic poetry," he says. Brad DeLong is exercised, and rightly so, over the fact that some good economists have joined the crazies in signing the Republican anti-QE letter. How is this possible? he asks. After all, we're not even talking about Keynesianism here, we're talking about monetarism -- at least in terms of the spirit of the thing. For Friedman's whole case against the Fed was not, fundamentally, about monetary aggregates; they were just intermediate targets. It was that the Fed was supposed to do whatever it took to avoid an economic plunge, and didn't. So calling on the Fed not to act now is a betrayal of Friedmanism as well as Keynesianism.

While checking in at the hotel that first afternoon in the French Alps, I met a fine, terrier-like dog named Al Capone. He was admirably groomed, pearl coat nearly glowing, and he proceeded through the lobby with such aplomb - did he realize that he stood only a foot and a half? - that I was filled with immediate admiration for him, if not a scintilla of envy. Judging by the clientele here, his owner might have been a Russian oligarch, a Euro titan or a celebrity scion of some sort, and so could only offer me a wan smile and a few brief words. But that was to be expected. Women sashayed past in ski outfits that would have cost your average proletarian a month's wages; men sat by the fireplace drinking bottles of Cognac whose sticker price resembled that of a compact car. And Al Capone followed his curious nose, snuffling for nonexistent crumbs, until he bumped up against my alien, American shoe.

Like other cities around the country, Austin, Tex., recently tightened its rules for its ever-expanding mobile-food contingent. New regulations include needing to provide proof of a state sales tax permit, passing a fire-department inspection and filing an itinerary of truck routes. (Apparently Twitter doesn't count.) Despite these new regulations, the food-trailer scene is still thriving: the city estimates that there will be 1,620 mobile food vendors by the end of 2011; in 2006, there were only 648. ''Western paper turns away the light, while our paper seems to take it in, to envelop it gently, like the soft surface of a first snowfall,'' wrote the Japanese author Jun'ichiro Tanizaki in ''In Praise of Shadows,'' his 1933 manifesto on the aesthetic differences between the East and West. His observations on subtlety, the play of light and dark, and, for that matter, all things Japanese, have lately been on the minds of Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the design duo behind the label Ohne Titel. ''While I was reading his work, I felt like I was experiencing this slice of traditional Japanese aesthetics visually,'' Adams says. Adds Gill, ''It's almost a goal toward perfect design, which as designers we're always searching for.'' In their spring 2011 collection, the pair softened their usual aggressive silhouettes with nods to the Orient: striped ribbed knitwear inspired by the Japanese woodblock print artist Utagawa Kuniyoshi, linen tie-front pants, jackets with kimono-style volume in the sleeves. The two recently made their inaugural trip to Japan, traveling to Kyoto to take in tea ceremonies, ancient temples and Noh theater. As Tanizaki saw it, the purity of great modern design comes, first, with an appreciation for the old.

The composer Matthew Sklar and the lyricist Chad Beguelin narrate a look at the number ''Christmastown'' from the new Broadway musical ''Elf.'' nytimes.com/theater

Of all the news commercials on the networks this year, one running this fall for ''NBC Nightly News'' might be the most unorthodox. In it, the anchor Brian Williams recommends that people record the 6:30 p.m. newscast if they will not be home in time to watch live. ''I just thought it was high time to acknowledge, in our 'Nightly News' promos, the way we live,'' Mr. Williams wrote by e-mail.

LISKIN--Anita. Passed peacefully at her home in Englewood, NJ, on November 14, 2010. Beloved mother of David and Max Liskin, Diana Chapman and Alisa Liskin Clausen, and the late Barbara Liskin, beloved grandmother of Rebecca and Elizabeth Bonagura and Helene Clausen, beloved mother-in-law of Mary Liskin, Vincent Bonagura, Gordon Chapman, and Claus Clausen, and beloved sister of the late Rene and George Merker. Born Antoinette Merker on March 2, 1926 to Albert and Helene Merker, and known as Anita, Anita spent her childhood in Paris, France. In 1941, Anita's family fled the German invasion, eventually reaching New York City where she graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology and met her husband of over fifty years, the late Louis D. Liskin. Anita taught French at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood, NJ for over ten years where her charm, enthusiasm and patience inspired many a previously reluctant student to embrace the French language. Anita also took great pleasure in using her knowledge of fashion and design to costume a number of the school's theatrical productions. Anita's bonds with her students and fellow teachers continued well after she retired from teaching. Immensely generous and warm-hearted, full of intellectual curiosity and joie de vivre and always possessed of that quintessentially French sense of style, Anita was loved by everyone who knew her well. We will miss her more than words could ever express. Services are private.

An article on Friday about a spinoff of Morgan Stanley's Process Driving Trading unit, where employees known as quants use high-speed computers to trade, misstated a word in the title of a book on such employees. The book, by Scott Patterson, is ''The Quants: How a New Breed of Math Whizzes Conquered Wall Street and Nearly Destroyed It'' (not ''Match Whizzes'').

Quarterback statistics can be broken down into home-and-road splits, first-down and third-down splits, and so on. Donovan McNabb has been the focal point of so many intrigues that he gets his own category: controversy and noncontroversy splits. McNabb's controversy splits are very good. During the Rush Limbaugh flap in 2003, he shook off a 1-2 Eagles start, led the team to a victory over Washington, and soon embarked on a nine-game winning streak. In 2005, he passed for 1,333 yards, 11 touchdowns and 3 interceptions while Terrell Owens criticized everything but his goatee. Then McNabb came back from a brief 2008 benching to throw four touchdown passes in the next game. Pick: Redskins.

An article on Tuesday about the foolishness of making precise predictions in science misstated the number of developments that the writer said would not come true in 2011. There were 9, not 10. The article also misstated the date of a correction in which The New York Times finally apologized for having ridiculed, in 1920, the idea that rockets would one day be able to leave the surface of the Earth. The correction was published on July 17, 1969 -- a day after the Apollo 11 moon mission began; it was not published on June 17 of that year.

Geoff Howe/Bloomberg News7:50 p.m. | Updated BHP Billiton said Sunday that it withdrew its $38.6 billion unsolicited takeover offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the world's biggest producers of a key fertilizer ingredient, after the Canadian government blocked the potential deal. BHP's decision was all but preordained after the Canadian government's decision earlier this month, which scuttled it for not representing a ''net benefit'' for Canada. While BHP had 30 days to change the Canadian industry minister's mind, people briefed on the matter have said that such efforts were probably futile.

KHEEL--Theodore Woodrow. Died November 12, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Ann Sunstein Kheel. Devoted father of Ellen (Mrs. Arnold Jacobs), Robert, Constance, Marti, Jane Kheel Stanley, Katherine. Eleven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date. No flowers please. Donations may be made to the Kheel Center at Cornell University, attention Allison D. Riley.

Number of Chinese students in U.S. colleges soars 30% The number of Chinese students studying in the United States surged 30 percent in the 2009-2010 academic year, making China, for the first time, the top country of origin for international students, according to ''Open Doors,'' the Institute of International Education's annual report, being issued Monday.
International FREED DISSIDENT URGES

Coming pretty soon to a record store near you (if you are lucky enough to have a record store near you): a whole bunch of deluxe reissues of Paul Simon albums, with a different record company logo on them. After 30 years with Warner Brothers, Mr. Simon has made a deal with Sony to release all of his recordings as a solo artist beginning next year, including classic studio albums like ''There Goes Rhymin' Simon'' (1973), ''Still Crazy After All These Years'' (1975) and ''Graceland'' (1986), as well as live recordings like ''Paul Simon's Concert in the Park,'' recorded in Central Park in 1991.

Mike Thomas, left, caught a batted-down desperation pass from David Garrard on the final play to give the Jaguars a 31-24 win over the Texans. The ball was knocked directly into his hands by a defender. Injuries to starter Chad Pennington (shoulder) and the former starter Chad Henne (knee) forced the third-stringer Tyler Thigpen to finish off the Dolphins' 29-17 win over the Titans.

While the 50,000 Canadian dollars that accompany the Scotiabank Giller Prize are always welcome, the bigger gain for novelists who win the highly publicized literary award comes later. Winners can expect to sell about 75,000 additional hardcover copies of their books, a substantial number for serious fiction in a country with one-tenth the population of the United States.

One week after pounding Utah in Salt Lake City and seemingly taking control of the No. 3 slot in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, Texas Christian saw everything fall apart. Although No. 4 Boise State still trails No. 3 T.C.U. in the B.C.S. standings, the Horned Frogs' lead took a significant hit. T.C.U. leads Boise State by a margin of .897 to .863, but that is one week after leading, .925 to .866. With T.C.U. (11-0) having only lowly New Mexico (1-9) remaining on its schedule, the independent B.C.S. analyst Jerry Palm said that he expected Boise State, which has three games remaining, to pass T.C.U. That is significant because if No. 1 Oregon or No. 2 Auburn loses, the next team in line will get a chance to play for the national title.
MARMALSTEIN--Liz. A year has gone by since we lost our Lizzy. We loved her so. Rest In Peace Baby. Always, Mo e

Outside of a book club, reading a book is a pretty solitary affair. Two entrepreneurs, Jason Johnson and Jason Illian, are trying to change that with the new mobile application Social Books. ''Short-form content on the Web is very interactive, very dynamic,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''You can see which of your friends read the same article and what they thought of it. It made us ask, 'Can this be applied to long-form content? Can we take the advent of social media and apply it to the way we read books on tablets?'''

LICHTENDORF--Arthur E. Everyone who knew and loved Arthur just found their lives a little smaller. He died Saturday November 13, 2010, at six thirty in the evening after doing everything he could to stay alive. He was 74. Arthur was a graduate of The Wharton School and Columbia School of Business. A very complex person, he was exceptionally smart, kind, irascible, funny, and a dandy in his own way. He was madly in love with his grandson, Max Wolf Lichtendorf. He died holding little Max's picture. Arthur was a consummate traveler who visited all seven continents. He loved food, theater, and history in its big picture as well as the story of his ancestors and his Jewish faith. He loved his small extended family and life-long friends. Most of all, he adored his daughter, Victoria Lichtedorf, son-in-law, Harper Langston, his first wife who died before him after thirty years of marriage, his soul mate Susan, and his beloved wife Judith who only wishes they had had more time. The funeral will be at 1pm Tuesday, November 16, at Temple Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, burial to follow at Beth El Cemetery.

An article in the Your Money special section on Nov. 5, about longevity insurance, a product that allows people to insure against outliving their retirement assets, described imprecisely the benefits of a state guarantee association should an insurance company fail. The association would provide coverage based on the value of the insured's projected annuity benefits; it would not be based on the amount paid for the insurance and thus would not necessarily ''pay back the amount you invested.''

10 P.M. (Sundance) JAR CITY (2006) In this moody thriller from Baltasar Kormakur, a weary homicide detective named Erlendur (Ingvar E. Sigurdsson) investigates the murder of an old man and opens up a hornet's nest of long-ago crimes and buried secrets. ''The picture of Iceland that emerges'' in the film ''is vivid and powerful but not something the country's tourist board would be likely to endorse,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The landscape has its austere poetry to be sure -- mountains framing the apartment blocks of Reykjavik, spits of volcanic rock jutting into a churning sea -- but a fog of damp unhappiness seems to pervade every face and conversation. And yet by the end of this film, based on a popular mystery novel by Arnaldur Indridason, it is hard not to feel a certain affection for the place.'' Mr. Scott described the movie as ''intricate and pointed, conjuring a haunting, satisfying puzzle out of violence and chaos.'' In Icelandic, with English subtitles. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS

KREUTTNER--Jane. After 101 years of life, Jane passed away on November 8, 2010 at home in New York City. Jane was employed by Irving Trust Co. from 1927 until 1977; she retired as vice president. John, her devoted husband, predeceased her in 1988. Survived by nephews; Paul Spengler, Berton Spivy, III and Peter Spivy. Jane was a gracious and fun loving lady; admired by all who knew her. Burial service November 27 in Alexandria, VA. Donations to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Hospice Care.

FULD--Beatrice. Beloved wife of Fred Fuld, passed away in her 89th year. She conveyed an aura of poise, dignity, grace, caring and beauty. Through her appreciation and gratitude for all the things that are truly important in life she served as a shining role model for her children and grandchildren. Survived in deep mourning by her husband, her children, Michelle and Leonard Fuld, Linda and Ilan Kaufthal, her grandchildren, Ari and Talia Fuld, Rebecca and Elie Mischel, Jessica and Daniel Tabak, Abby and Joshua Kaufthal, Lori and David Kaufthal and Daniel Kaufthal and her great grandchildren, Eden, Levana, Klilah, Emunah, Joseph, Jack and Sydney. We will sorely miss her. Shiva at 143 East Linden Avenue, Englewood, N.J.

As expected, Clear Channel on Monday named Robert W. Pittman as a senior adviser for its radio business, and confirmed that he will make an investment in the company. Robert W. Pittman has jumped across the media spectrum throughout his career, with positions at MTV, AOL and DailyCandy, the Internet newsletter company. Now, he is preparing to head back to the industry where he got his start: radio.

The Sports of The Times column on Nov. 4, about a runner in the New York City Marathon who honored the late folk singer Kate McGarrigle, misidentified the composer of the ''Swimming Song.'' It was written by Loudon Wainwright III, McGarrigle's former husband -- not by McGarrigle and her sister Anna, who sang and recorded it.

If you want to use the civil justice system, you have to have money. If there's less money, you'd have less litigation. But then you'd also have less justice. ALAN ZIMMERMAN, founder of the LawFinance Group, a litigation finance company. [A20]

An article on Nov. 4 about a small group of developers, architects and urban experts that questioned the application of a Congressional law limiting the heights of buildings in Washington misidentified the hospital for which an amendment to the 1910 act was made. It is Georgetown University Hospital, not George Washington University Hospital.

In Silicon Valley, where even mid-level executives seem to be escorted by public relations handlers, Bill Campbell is a bit of an exception. An elder statesman of the tech industry, he prefers to remain out of the limelight. Yet his influence behind the scenes has been enormous. He served as chief executive of Intuit; the Go Corporation, a pioneering, but ultimately failed, maker of pen computing technology; and Claris, the software maker that Apple spun off in 1987. He currently serves as chairman of Intuit and a board member of Apple. He has been a close adviser and confidant to some of the Valley's best-known figures, including Steve Jobs, Eric Schmidt and John Doerr. And he has been a mentor to scores of young entrepreneurs and executives, a role that has earned Mr. Campbell, a former football coach at Columbia University, the moniker of ''coach.'' Mr. Campbell said he does all this simply as way of ''giving back'' to colleagues and to an industry that has been good to him.

There are outtakes from one of John F. Kennedy's last television interviews, a lengthy appearance on ''The Huntley-Brinkley Report.'' There is a scene in Fort Worth as the president cheerfully accepts a gift of a cowboy hat, but declines to try it on for the cameras. There is even a rare glimpse of an impeccably dressed Jacqueline Kennedy happily smoking a cigarette, at a dinner party in Australia. The first television president is starring in a video-and-text-filled iPad app adapted from a book, ''JFK: Day by Day,'' written by Terry Golway and Les Krantz and published by Running Press. The app, called JFK: 50 Days, will be released by NBC News and the Perseus Books Group on Monday and will be available in the App Store for $6.99.

A picture caption on Friday with an obituary about the movie producer Dino De Laurentiis misspelled the given name of the actress shown with Mr. De Laurentiis and Federico Fellini. She is Giulietta Masina, not Giuletta.

An article last Saturday about a Census Bureau report that for the first time measured the percentage of unmarried mothers who were not living alone misstated, in some copies, the name of a university in Baltimore where Andrew Cherlin is a demographer. He is at Johns Hopkins, not John Hopkins.

SHOOBE--Joel. We will truly miss our dear friend Joel. He was unsurpassed as our attorney, consultant, and confidante over the 40 years that we have known him. Joel was the true professional-- a man of class and incredible intelligence. His guidance and friendship was invaluable to us over the years. He will be greatly missed by the entire Jerome family. Our deepest sympathies to Linda, and the children and grandchildren. We hope they will take comfort in all the happy memories they have of him. Leslie and Stephen Jerome

SADEK--Norman W.,92, loving husband, father, and grandfather passed away peacefully Saturday at his home in Hartsdale, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Constance (nee Meyer), children Andrea Schrier Miller (Neil), Jim Sadek (Sandy), Robin Ascher (Peter) and Lauren Krzyzewski (George) and grandchildren Adam, Eric, Zach, Rebecca, Toby, Samuel, David, Joseph and Anna. Inquisitive and charismatic, he befriended every person he met. Norman was the founder of Charles Sadek Import Company (1936) and creator of the world renowned Andrea Birds, a WWII Marine, Norman was a pioneer in postwar trade with Japan and an industry leader in early New York gift and lamp trade associations. His products touch the lives of millions of people to this day, thousands of whom he personally met during signings across the country. He was honored by AMFAR with a lifetime achievement award in 2004. A founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and early contributor to the Hebrew Home for the Aged of Riverdale, Norman supported numerous charities continually throughout his life. Many of the commitments began with his father Charles 40 years ago. Funeral services will be held 11am, Monday at Congregation Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, White Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the City of Hope, Daniel R. Schrier Fund.
DEAN--Andy Chen, M.D.,Ph.D. 3/26/60 - 11/15/06. We remember you with love and respect. Your Family

MERINGOFF--Evelyn. 93 years of age residing in Tamarac, Florida passed away peacefully on November 13th. Evelyn was the loving wife of Leo (who preceded her in death), the beloved mother of Stephen, Paul and wife Carol, adored grandmother of Jay, Todd, Brett, Victoria, Katie, Charlotte and Sophie, cherished great-grandmother of Benjamin, and loving sister of Shirley Bass. Evelyn led a wonderful life. She was a woman of valor and great strength. She was a life force. Her family adored her, and she will live forever in their hearts.

Massey Energy, the beleaguered coal mining company that has attracted takeover interest, has now garnered the attention of the global steelmaker ArcelorMittal, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook. Massey has suffered several prominent disasters in recent years, including an explosion in April at the company's Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia. It has already received a takeover offer from its bigger rival Alpha Natural Resources, this person said. Arch Coal, also a coal producer, has expressed interest.
DENHOFF--Harvey. Died November 9th. He is survived by his wife Iris of 53 years. Children Roger Denhoff and his wife Elizabeth and Amanda Shepherd and her husband Bruce and three grandchildren.

TOLL--Dorothy Morris. 90, passed away peacefully at home in Scarsdale, NY on November 13, 2010. Predeceased by husband of 64 years Lionel, survived by devoted children Elizabeth and William and adored grandchildren Christie, Lindsay, Andy and Ted. A graduate of NYU, she was an avid world traveler, tennis player and art lover. For many years, she volunteered at White Plains Hospital. Private family graveside services. Family will sit shiva from 4-8pm Tuesday November 16 at 917 Cove Rd, Mamaroneck. Donations in her honor may be made to Fisher Center for Alzheimers Research, alzinfo.org, or W.P. Hospital.

Clubbed Thumb, a New York theater company that commissions and develops new plays, and Off Broadway's Playwrights Horizons are collaborating on a series of weeklong ''lab'' workshops to help American writers hone their new projects for the stage - one attempt at the kind of support systems that playwrights have been pleading for. On Friday the two organizations announced the effort, called SuperLab, and said they had spent the week working on the first new play, ''Seven Homeless Mammoths Wander New England,'' with its author, Madeleine George. SuperLab will be held once a month; among the works already selected are ''Annie Bosh is Missing'' by Janine Nabers, ''The Many Mistresses of Martin Luther King'' by Andrew Dolan and ''3C'' by David Adjmi (''Stunning'').Each playwright is given 29 hours over a week and decides how to allot that time, with a director and actors recruited for readings and scene work. The writers also work with Clubbed Thumb's producing artistic director, Maria Striar, and Playwrights' director of new play development, Adam Greenfield, to identify what to work on in their script revisions, and the two artistic leaders provide feedback before, during, and after the labs.

BRUSSELS -- European ministers worked over the weekend on a financial rescue plan for Ireland, as pressure mounted on Dublin to seek a bailout to prevent the markets from spreading turbulence to other European countries, officials said on Sunday. The Irish government continued to insist that it did not need a bailout, arguing that it could present a credible austerity budget next month that would satisfy investors, and that it had enough money to finance its operations through early next year.

LE CORBEILLER--Jean. Died November 13th at age 83. Born in Paris, France, he graduated from Harvard University and taught for many years at the Seminar and Lang Colleges of the New School for Social Research. Predeceased by wife Clare, he is survived by daughter Suzanne Le Corbeiller and partner Anne, daughter Genevieve White and husband Anthony, and grandchildren Jesse, Graham, Mia and Simon.

In each of the last two World Series, the No. 3 hitter for the champions was a freshly signed first baseman who led his team in homers and runs batted in. In 2009, it was Mark Teixeira, who had just signed an eight-year, $180 million contact with the Yankees. In 2010, it was Aubrey Huff, who had just signed a one-year, $3 million deal with the San Francisco Giants. To sign Teixeira, the Yankees outbid the Los Angeles Angels, the Boston Red Sox, the Baltimore Orioles and the Washington Nationals. To sign Huff, the Giants had no competition.

Among the top 25 TV advertisers, average spending is up 9 percent on network commercials and 25 percent on cable in the first three quarters of this year, compared with the same period a year ago. Some companies have shifted priorities, like Pfizer, which spent 9 percent less on network ads, but increased cable buys by 4 percent. Some, like Toyota and Unilever, have increased spending across the board. Proctor & Gamble makes the top five for network and cable, with ads for products as varied as Tide, above, and Fixodent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

John Alderson, the father of Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, died early Sunday after being struck by an automobile while crossing a street just before midnight in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 87. It was not clear whether he would be able to attend the general managers meetings this week in Orlando, Fla., where he had planned to conduct second interviews with Terry Collins and Bob Melvin for the Mets' vacant manager's job.

They belong to worlds that, in the normal course of events, would never intersect. But Shakespeare, as the creator of their universe, saw fit to let their paths cross just once. And when Portia finally meets Shylock, in Daniel Sullivan's absolutely splendid production of ''The Merchant of Venice'' at the Broadhurst Theater, the collision lights up the sky. Giving what promise to be the performances of this season, Lily Rabe, as Portia the heiress, and Al Pacino, as Shylock the usurer, invest the much-parsed trial scene of this fascinating, irksome work with a passion and an anger that purge it of preconceptions. You may find yourself trembling, as one often does when something scary and baffling starts to make sense. At the same time you're likely to have trouble figuring out exactly where your sympathies lie. For at this moment everybody hurts.

The designer Rachel Comey and her boyfriend, Sean Carmody, are two months away from having their first child, and the mom-to-be is bumping up her wardrobe accordingly. "The maternity trend seems to be not buying any clothes," Comey says with a laugh. "That excludes the flea market, because it's been fun to shop and try on shapes that I wouldn't normally try on now that my body is so different." Comey, who is known for her flirty prints and cool shoe designs, transformed a thrift shop cat suit into a pair of cool trousers. Day wear has become jumpsuits, overalls and stretchy knits, especially knit dresses paired with a sharp tailored blazer from Ellsworth for a more defined shape. "With my changing body and changing lifestyle, I am also changing my need for clothing to be practical for a woman's body at any stage," she says. We are looking forward to see how this new sensibility plays out in Comey's next collection. Great expectations indeed.

Now on view at the French Embassy (located at 972 Fifth Avenue, at 79th Street) are about 30 rarely seen black-and-white prints by Guy Bourdin. The works evoke the same spirit of his wildly iconic color photographs, except that they are distilled to their essence -- maintaining their boldly graphic nature, and imaginative discourse, and packed full of playful elegance. Also on display is a slide show of Bourdin's recently released monograph, "In Between," published by Steidl Dangin. The exhibition was largely made possible by the perseverance of Shelly Verthime, the show's curator, and Guy Bourdin's son Samuel Bourdin. Samuel endured many challenges gaining control of his father's estate to be able to exhibit the works freely and worldwide. T caught up with him to find out more about his insights about  his father and to congratulate him on the show, which closes Dec. 10.

On Monday afternoon, Bergdorf Goodman's display guru David Hoey gave The Moment an exclusive peek at the department store's holiday windows, which won't be unveiled until later this week. As Hoey drew up the heavy tarps covering each of them, a crowd of flash-happy tourists appeared (not to mention our very own Bill Cunningham, who was on the street, as is his wont). Still works in progress, the windows are being pored over by a team of artists. Hoey oversees the whole production, the culmination of a year's efforts, and he often can be seen on Fifth Avenue, instructing his minions. Can they hear him through all that glass? "If I stand exactly at 14-and-a-half inches from the window, the glass becomes a natural megaphone and they can hear me perfectly," he says. This year the windows are dedicated not so much to the act of travel as the fantasies that trip-taking might engender: flying horses, flying machines, and a journey to the moon. Bergdorf's best windows over the past two decades are collected in a new $550 hand-made book by Assouline, part of its exquisitely crafted "Ultimate Collection," which weighs a ton and goes on sale this week at Bergdorf and bergdorfgoodman.com.

MENDOZA--Irwin Charles, beloved husband of Barbara for over sixty years, dutiful son of William and Mae Victoria. Wyn is survived by his daughters Kathy, Susan, Liza and Julie, by his grandson Joseph, and by his sons-in-law Gregory Taylor and Thomas Maholchic. Wyn was educated at Townsend Harris High School, City College of New York, and Columbia University Teachers College. During WWII, he served in the United States Army Air Corps with the rank of Major. Praised by business counterparts as visionary, creative and always a man of integrity, he rose to leadership positions in international trade, textiles and metals. In his retirement, he served for many years as President of the Navesink Library/Duryea Trust, and was an active supporter of the Leonardo First Aid Squad, the Navesink Hook & Ladder Company and the Middletown Police. In his seventies, Wyn designed and built his family's home in Navesink, NJ, and took great pride in passing all code requirements on first inspection. On November 13, 2010 at the age of ninety-two, he died peacefully in his sleep in the home he had built.

Kristen Hall isn't about to be Pete Best-ed out of Sugarland. Though Sugarland, the best-selling award-winning country music act, is now the duo Kristian Bush and Jennifer Nettles, Ms. Hall, a singer-songwriter who founded the group, has obtained a settlement from her former bandmates after suing for profits she said she was owed after she left, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Hall, who founded Sugarland with Mr. Bush in 2002, said in her complaint that she had also served as the band's manager when it started and had used her own credit cards to help cover its expenses; she left in 2005 to go solo. Ms. Hall was seeking more than one-third of the band's profits. Mr. Bush and Ms. Nettles said they had no profit-sharing agreement with Ms. Hall, who, they said, left them with debts of nearly $100,000.
