The spring of 2007, as the financial markets roared, David J. Grais, a journeyman New York trial lawyer, was searching for new cases to bring. ''I wanted to find something very complex that could face big losses,'' said Mr. Grais, who had just left a large corporate law firm to hang his own shingle. He sought advice from an old friend, James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a well-known market bear. Over lunch at the Core Club, a private salon on East 55th Street, Mr. Grant suggested that he explore collateralized debt obligations.

The House ethics committee ruled on Monday that there was evidence to support 13 counts of misconduct by Representative Charles B. Rangel, and began considering whether to formally convict and recommend punishment against him. The ruling came after a dramatic and puzzling appearance by Mr. Rangel, 80, in which he protested that he could no longer afford to pay his lawyers, and indignantly walked out of the proceedings, calling them unfair.

MITCHELL--Pamela Battey. Died on Cape Cod November 10, 2010. Born June 3, 1934 to Dorothy and Edward Battey, she spent her childhood in Old Greenwich, Connecticut, a town she always loved. She was a graduate of Oak Grove School in Vassalboro, Maine, attended Skidmore and Bennington Colleges, and graduated from Colorado College with a Bachelor of Arts, focusing on sculpture and dance. She spent two summers at Colorado College dancing under the direction of choreographer and modern dance educator Hanya Holm. She moved to Washington, DC in 1958 and worked on Capitol Hill for the late Senator Thomas Dodd of Connecticut. While working in DC she met Dr. Jere H. Mitchell, a physician scientist working at the National Institutes of Health. They married on October 1, 1960 and later moved to Dallas where they raised their three daughters and enjoyed a life filled with family, friends, travel and good heath. They developed a particular attachment for Copenhagen, Denmark, a place where they spent many summers. For the past twenty years, they spent part of each year on Cape Cod at their summer home, which Pam treasured. Throughout her life, Pam had an unusual sensibility and understanding of nature and an intense appreciation for the landscape and wildlife of Texas and her beloved Cape Cod. She was a committed environmentalist and a strong believer in preserving open space and habitats, particularly wetlands, for native plants and animals to thrive. Pam was known for having an eye for beautiful, artful objects. She had an extensive knowledge of art and antiquities from cultures all over the world. Her broad interest in art contributed to her imaginative, keen sense of style and her ability to bring together disparate objects in aesthetically pleasing and surprising ways. She enjoyed no place more than an ethnographic museum with a terrific collection. Those who knew Pam admired her athleticism, her strength, and her amazing skill as a downhill skier, an activity she enjoyed until very recently. Her strength was apparent as she endured the hardships of cancer; she was uncomplaining and strong throughout her illness, something her family and friends found remarkable and inspiring. Pamela is survived by Dr. Jere H. Mitchell, her husband of 50 years, and her three loving daughters: Wendy O'Sullivan (and her husband Jon) of Dallas, TX, Dr. Laurie Mitchell (and her husband Brent Woods) of San Diego, CA, and Amy Poeppel (and her husband David) of New York, NY. She will be greatly missed by her eight grandchildren, Mathew O'Sullivan, Megan O'Sullivan, Madeline Woods, Sophie Woods, Calvin Woods, Alex Poeppel, Andrew Poeppel and Luke Poeppel. She will also be remembered by many dear friends around the world. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made in her name to Planned Parenthood, World Wildlife Fund, or VNA Hospice of Cape Cod.

MERINGOFF--Evelyn. 93 years of age residing in Tamarac, Florida passed away peacefully on November 13th. Evelyn was the loving wife of Leo (who preceded her in death), the beloved mother of Stephen, Paul and wife Carol, adored grandmother of Jay, Todd and his wife Angela, Brett and his wife Ally, Victoria, Katie, Charlotte and Sophie, cherished great-grandmother of Benjamin, and loving sister of Shirley Bass. Evelyn led a wonderful life. She was a woman of valor and great strength. She was a life force. Her family adored her, and she will live forever in their hearts.

GILBERT--Grace (Gay), 80, widow of the Reverend Cass Gilbert, III, a resident of Pippin Knoll passed away peacefully on Saturday November 13, 2010 at her home in the company of her loving family. Mrs. Gilbert was born on May 1, 1930 in New York City, she was the daughter of Roynon and Grace (Coffin) Cholmeley-Jones. She graduated from the Chapin School and from Tufts University with a degree in Physical Education. She was married to Cass Gilbert, III in 1952, he died January 22, 2009. They had lived in Wilton, CT until 1969 when her husband entered the Methodist Ministry. After that they lived in Salem, Ticonderoga, and Greenwich, NY and then in Bennington, while serving these local churches. Following semi-retirement they moved to Dorset until 2001 when they returned to Bennington. During the time her husband was active in churches, Mrs. Gilbert taught physical education in Salem. She then became involved in preschools, founding one in Greenwich and Bennington. She is survived by her five children Cass A. Gilbert (Beatrice) of North Yarmouth, ME, Elizabeth (Betsy) Pryor (Douglas) of Winston-Salem, NC, Sarah (Sally) Bisaccio (Kevin) of Bennington, Jeannette (Jeannie) Allyson (Russ) of Durham, NH and Julia Gilbert (Nathan Cleveland) of Charlotte, VT and 12 grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, November 17 at 10am at St. Peters Episcopal Church. Memorial gifts may be made to The Second Chance Animal Center in care of the Hanson-Walbridge Funeral Home, 213 West Main Street, Bennington, VT 05201. To send personal e-mail condolences to the family, please visit www.sheafuneralhomes.com

Luis García Berlanga, an influential Spanish filmmaker who tweaked the fascist regime of Gen. Francisco Franco and its censors with shrewdly subversive social satires, died on Saturday in Madrid. He was 89. His death was confirmed by the Spanish film academy. He had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

MARCKWALD--Clarissa Price, 97, of Far Hills, NJ died November 13 at home with her family. She died, as she lived, with will and grace. She was pre-deceased by her husband Andrew K. Marckwald. Memorial service will be held on Wednesday 11 am at St John's on the Mt., Bernards- ville, NJ. Contributions to Schiff National Lands Trust or the Masters School.

Caterpillar is paying $92 a share for Bucyrus, which represents a 32 percent premium over Friday's closing price. Caterpillar said that it would locate the headquarters of its mining business in South Milwaukee, Wis., where Bucyrus is based, and that it would preserve the Bucyrus brand, which dates back to 1880.

Visa problems have forced Lincoln Center to delay the culminating performances of its White Light Festival, dedicated to transcendence in music, until next week. ''The Manganiyar Seduction,'' which was scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, will now take place on Monday and Tuesday. Manganiyars are a caste of Indian musicians of Muslim origin from western Rajasthan state whose songs celebrate Hindu deities. Jane Moss, Lincoln Center's vice president for programming and the organizer of the festival, said that visa applications were made in May and that about half of the 50-member troupe involved in the show had received visas by Oct. 13, but the rest were sent for further review by State Department officials. By Friday a dozen members still had not received visas, so the performances were postponed. Word came over the weekend that the remaining visas had been granted. The Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center was available Monday and Tuesday for the shift. Tickets can be used for the new dates, refunded or exchanged. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HELFER--Joanne Salomon, 81, died November 14, 2010, after a long illness. Daughter of the poet I. L. Salomon and Frances Salomon, she is survived by her husband, H. Lawrence Helfer, her children, Adam Helfer and Aisha Ginwalla, Elizabeth Helfer and Bruce Levin, Martha Helfer and Steven Nowick, and Tamara Helfer and John Lugten, her grandchildren, Rokaya and Riaz Helfer, Rebecca and Aaron Levin, and Benjamin and Joseph Lugten, and her cousin, Jon Salmon. Private services will be held by the family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of Rochester, NY. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

ROTHWELL--Kenneth Sprague, Professor Emeritus of English at the University of Vermont, passed away on November 8, 2010, in Burlington, VT. He was born the son of Clarence and Benita Rothwell in Bay Shore, NY, grew up in New York City; Shanghai, China; San Antonio, TX; and completed high school in Bay Shore. He received a B.A. from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a Ph.D. in English and Comparative Literature from Columbia University. During World War II he served in the Aleutian Islands, as a second lieutenant in the 159th Infantry on Attu and Amchitka. As a teacher of English, he held full-time appointments at the Universities of Rochester, Cincinnati, Kansas, and came to the University of Vermont as department chair in 1970. His signature contributions to scholarship included Shakespeare on Screen: An International Filmography and Videography (1990) and, with Cambridge University Press, A History of Shakespeare on Screen: A Century of Film and Television (1999, 2nd edition 2004). He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 50 years, Marilyn Gregg Rothwell. He is survived by his son Kenneth Jr. and daughter-in-law Pamela Jones of Newton, Mass.; a daughter Mary Carroll Rothwell Davis and son-in-law Evan Davis of New York City and Westport, NY; a daughter Elizabeth Gregg Rothwell of South Royalton, VT; a daughter Anne Gregg Rothwell of Burlington, VT and New York City; and five grandchildren: Rosalind Springs Rothwell, James Waddell Rothwell, Sara Li-Hu Upham Davis, Charlotte Davis, and Phoebe Davis; a sister, Benita Rothwell Feldman and a nephew, Ed Feldman, both of Monroe, MI; nieces Marjorie Meyer of San Juan Bautista, CA, and Terry Rothwell, of La Jolla, CA. He was predeceased by his brother Col. Franklin Rothwell and sister Marjorie Rothwell Palmer. Services will be held at St. Paul's Cathedral, Burlington, VT, at 2:00pm on Saturday, November 20. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Marilyn Rothwell Scholarship Fund at the University of Vermont College of Nursing.

Hong Kong is making a bold bid to challenge London and New York as global financial centers this week. And judging by its gains in recent years, it might be in the running soon. Depicting Hong Kong as the financial center of China, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau of the government of Hong Kong is hosting a conference on Tuesday to highlight Hong Kong as a reliable source of investment capital.

An art review on Nov. 5 about ''Grain of Emptiness: Buddhism-Inspired Contemporary Art'' at the Rubin Museum of Art on West 17th Street in Manhattan, using information from the exhibition's catalog, referred incorrectly to the show's five artists in describing their relationship to Buddhism. One of the artists, Charmion von Wiegand, does in fact consider herself a Buddhist; it is not the case that none of the five are Buddhists.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the dominance of football teams from private high schools in New Jersey misidentified the location of Seton Hall Prep. It is in West Orange, not South Orange. (Seton Hall University is in South Orange.)

A question and answer in the Q&A column on the Personal Tech pages on Nov. 4 about preventing Microsoft Word from converting straight apostrophes and quotation marks to curled versions referred incorrectly to the straight marks. They are indeed apostrophes and quotation marks, although not in the curled form preferred in print; they are not foot and inch marks. (In typography, the prime and double-prime marks are used to indicate feet and inches.)

PINKERTON--Ann. Past and present Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of Corlears School are deeply saddened by the passing of Ann Pinkerton, dedicated employee of Corlears School from 1975 to 2007. Ann was a wonderful member of the school community and gave of herself in numerous ways to the school. Her assistance in the business office was valued always. She will be remembered as a happy, loyal friend of all, especially the late Eppie Lockhart, former administrative director of Corlears. We send our deepest condolences to Ann's many friends and family members. Thya Merz, Head of School Corlears School

Malcolm Gladwell hates private equity. Mr. Gladwell, the author of ''Blink'' and ''Outliers,'' recently wrote a review of Steven L. Rattner's book about his tenure as the nation's car czar. The review, in The New Yorker, is notable less for Mr. Gladwell's view of Mr. Rattner's book, ''Overhaul,'' than for a provocative and profound question that pervades the article: Can financiers ever do anything beyond financial engineering?

WELLNER--Rick. Beloved husband of Gabrielle, adored son of Kenneth and the late Barbara Wellner and of stepmother JoAnn Wellner, died on November 13th, age 62, in Ft. Lauderdale, FL after a brief illness.

KHEEL--Theodore. A pioneering social entrepreneur and civic giant, Ted Kheel's boundless enthusiasm for nurturing the planet, supporting the work of artists and ensuring social justice leaves behind a legacy of a more sustainable, beautiful and equitable New York. We are fortunate to have had him as a mentor and will miss his wise counsel and generosity. Seth Waugh, Chairman Gary Hattem, President Deutsche Bank Americas Foundation

LICHTENDORF--Arthur E. Everyone who knew and loved Arthur just found their lives a little smaller. He died Saturday November 13, 2010, at six thirty in the evening after doing everything he could to stay alive. He was 74. Arthur was a graduate of The Wharton School and Columbia School of Business. A very complex person, he was exceptionally smart, kind, irascible, funny, and a dandy in his own way. He was madly in love with his grandson, Max Wolf Lichtendorf. He died holding little Max's picture. Arthur was a consummate traveler who visited all seven continents. He loved food, theater, and history in its big picture as well as the story of his ancestors and his Jewish faith. He loved his small extended family and life-long friends. Most of all, he adored his daughter, Victoria Lichtedorf, son-in-law, Harper Langston, his first wife who died before him after thirty years of marriage, his soul mate Susan, and his beloved wife Judith who only wishes they had had more time. The funeral will be at 1pm Tuesday, November 16, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue, and East 65th Street. Interment Beth El Cemetery.

LISKIN--Anita. Passed peacefully at her home in Englewood, NJ, on November 14, 2010. Beloved mother of David and Max Liskin, Diana Chapman and Alisa Liskin Clausen, and the late Barbara Liskin, beloved grandmother of Rebecca and Elizabeth Bonagura and Helene Clausen, beloved mother-in-law of Mary Liskin, Vincent Bonagura, Gordon Chapman, and Claus Clausen, and beloved sister of the late Rene and George Merker. Born Antoinette Merker on March 2, 1926 to Albert and Helene Merker, and known as Anita, Anita spent her childhood in Paris, France. In 1941, Anita's family fled the German invasion, eventually reaching New York City where she graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology and met her husband of over fifty years, the late Louis D. Liskin. Anita taught French at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood, NJ for over ten years where her charm, enthusiasm and patience inspired many a previously reluctant student to embrace the French language. Anita also took great pleasure in using her knowledge of fashion and design to costume a number of the school's theatrical productions. Anita's bonds with her students and fellow teachers continued well after she retired from teaching. Immensely generous and warm-hearted, full of intellectual curiosity and joie de vivre and always possessed of that quintessentially French sense of style, Anita was loved by everyone who knew her well. We will miss her more than words could ever express. Services are private.

BELSON--Maxine (Rogg) Adored wife, and devoted mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend died Sunday. She was 90 and lived in Brooklyn. During her active and vibrant life she was known for her profound care and help of others. She devoted her life to helping children and adults with physical and intellectual disabilities to achieve their maximum potential and pleasure to enable them to lead full and productive lives. Her boundless energy was evident when involved in countless philanthropic endeavors as a leader, organizer and benefactor. Among her many accomplishments she was especially proud of creating The Big E for Epilepsy and founding a free clinic at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for individuals with epilepsy. To raise money for the clinic she organized and led tours around the world. As a pioneer in promoting the independence of people with intellectual disabilities she helped create New Hope Community in Loch Sheldrake, NY - motivated by her son Tad, who was the light of her life. She was recently honored at the community by the naming of a facility she helped sponsor and fund called "Maxie's Place." She was an esteemed member of the St. John's University family and was an enthusiastic fan of the soccer team. The family funded the Belson soccer stadium on campus and the Maxine & Jerome Belson Moot Court at the university's law school. She was honored for her work with disabled children by St. John's University with their Medal of Honor and awarded a Doctorate of Pedeology by Niagara University. Her family was a great source of joy throughout her life. She was the adored wife of Jerome, her husband for 56 years. She was the devoted and loving mother of her son Tad; daughter Brianne and son-in-law Sanford; her predeceased son Michael and daughter-in-law Kathy; and daughter-in-law Marjorie. She was a beloved grandmother of Matthew and his wife Jodi; Joshua and his wife Katy; Jaclyn, Toby and Jonathan. She was also great grandmother to Noah, Ariel and Paisley. Her love for her family was only matched by the love for her. She will be missed by the multitude of friends and family who were the beneficiaries of her care, love and sense of humor. She will not be forgotten. A graveside service will be held. In lieu of flowers, those inclined to do so, may make a donation to the New Hope Community, a 503c charity located at: PO Box 289, Route 52, Loch Sheldrake, NY 12759.

Loehmann's, the retail discounter of designer fashions, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization on Monday after it failed to reach a new debt agreement with one of its lenders. Loehmann's, which operates 48 stores in 13 states and Washington, D.C., said in a court filing that its operations had been hurt by the economic downturn in markets where its stores are concentrated, particularly California, the Northeast, the Midwest and Florida.

BELSON--Maxine. The St. John's University family mourns the passing of Maxine Belson, cherished friend, accomplished honorary alumna, and, with her husband, trustee emeritus Jerome Belson, extraordinarily generous benefactor. For almost a quarter century, Maxine has been a vibrant and vital force at this institution. Belson Hall, Belson Stadium, and the Belson Moot Court all evidence her caring, her indomitable spirit, and her lifelong commitment to helping others improve their lives. Our University is better and stronger because she was a part of it. We shall remember her with affection always. Our thoughts and prayers go to her beloved husband, Jerry; her children, Tad and Brianne; and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren in this time of sorrow. Thomas E. McInerney, Chair, Board of Trustees Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President
BELSON--Maxine. Our fondest thoughts and deepest condolences to Jerry and the entire Belson family on the loss of Maxine, a great and unique lady. Phyllis and Alan Wolpert

RAPPAPORT--Marty. It is with great sadness that the Trustees, Administration, and Staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of a dear friend and beloved trustee, Marty Rappaport. Marty's leadership and guidance helped create a legacy of health and independence for thousands of children. A paragon of generosity, benevolence and compassion, Marty was a tireless champion for children in need. We will miss him profoundly, and we extend our deepest sympathy to Marty's wife, Sandy and his family, during this difficult time. Owen Gutfreund, Chair, Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, New York

Are lung cancer scans really ready for prime time? News that annual CT lung scans can reduce the risk of lung cancer death among former and current heavy smokers was celebrated by national heath officials this month. A major government study found the screening scans saved the life of one person for every 300 current or former smokers who were scanned.

BORRESEN--A. John 78, of Miami, FL died November 5th. Survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Charlotte, son AJ, daughter Charann Claire (Tom) and three granddaughters Kelsey, Courtney and Remi. Donations may be made to the Wood-Ridge Memorial Scholarship Foundation., PO Box 282, Wood-Ridge, NJ 07075.
PARADNY--Robert, M.D. You are with us all of the time. With forever love, Your Family

A Broadway newcomer, Rose Hemingway, will play one of the most coveted ingenue roles of the season, Rosemary Pilkington, opposite Daniel Radcliffe's J. Pierrepont Finch in this winter's revival of the Frank Loesser musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' the producers announced on Monday. Ms. Hemingway appeared in the Donmar Warehouse production of ''Parade'' in Los Angeles last year. Also new to the cast is Christopher J. Hanke (''In My Life'') as Bud Frump, the role that won a featured actor Tony Award for Charles Nelson Reilly in the original production, which ran from 1961 to 1965 and won seven Tonys in all (including best musical) as well as the Pulitzer Prize in drama. Other cast members announced Monday were Tammy Blanchard (Louise in the Bernadette Peters-led revival of ''Gypsy'') as Hedy La Rue, the mistress of bossman J.B. Biggley (to be played by John Larroquette of ''Night Court'' fame); Rob Bartlett (''More to Love'') as Twimble and Wally Womper; Mary Faber (Heather in the current run of ''American Idiot'') as Smitty, Rosemary's best friend; and Ellen Harvey (''Thou Shalt Not'') as the secretary of Mr. Larroquette's character. The musical was last revived on Broadway in 1995, starring Matthew Broderick as Finch and Megan Mullally as Rosemary, and ran 16 months. This new production, to be directed and choreographed by Rob Ashford (the current revival of ''Promises, Promises''), is scheduled to begin preview performances on Feb. 26 at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

KHEEL--Theodore Woodrow. Died November 12, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Ann Sunstein Kheel. Devoted father of Ellen (Mrs. Arnold Jacobs), Robert, Constance, Marti, Jane Kheel Stanley, Katherine. Eleven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date. No flowers please. Donations may be made to the Kheel Center at Cornell University, attention Allison D. Riley.
GOODMAN--Ron. Devoted husband, loving father, brother, uncle and wonderful son. You will live in our hearts forever.

SALEM--Isaac. Age 88, died November 12, after a full life and a full career. He practiced law for 60 years as a Maritime Lawyer, a New York City Corporation Counsel and an Administrative Judge. He was a talented chess player, a student of languages and ancient history. He enjoyed a rubber of bridge. Above all he cared for and loved his devoted wife Sylvia and his exceptional daughters Esther and Debbie.

An article on Thursday about the rapper Shyne, who is living as an Orthodox Jew in Jerusalem, misstated his age in 1999 when he was involved in a shooting incident that resulted in a 10-year prison sentence. He was 21, not 19.

EMC, the data management and storage company, said on Monday that it would pay $2.25 billion for Isilon Systems, a Seattle company that provides network storage. Isilon makes so-called scale-out network attached storage, a type of storage that can start small and grow fast -- reaching up to 10 petabytes -- without disrupting a network.
International SOUTHERN SUDANESE REGISTER

Mounting criticism and attention over word that the $25,000 Wendy Wasserstein Prize for playwriting would not be awarded this year because no script by a young female writer was deemed worthy has led to a turnaround. The administrator of the prize announced on Monday that the selection process would be refined and done over in hopes of finding a winner. A mini-firestorm erupted among writers, teachers and theater artists as word spread last week from some of 19 award nominees that there would be no 2010 recipient of the prize, one of the most financially meaningful to young playwrights. More than 800 people have signed an online petition to the prize committee and the administrator, the Theater Development Fund, asking for reconsideration of the decision. The playwright Michael Lew (''Roanoke'') also wrote a letter of protest to the fund.

GERTNER--Sheldon "Bud." February 16, 1927 - November 12, 2010. Beloved husband of Doreen; father to David, Patricia, and Jon; brother to Rainy; grandfather of six. He passed away unexpectedly but peacefully during the night. He grew up in Brooklyn; served in the Navy during World War II; and was educated at Brooklyn College and Yale. A former resident of Berkeley Heights, NJ, he enjoyed a 40-year career as a professor of pharmacology at the UMDNJ. He was kind, dependable, optimistic, and endlessly curious. We will miss him terribly. Condolences: dorbud@optonline.net. Memorial service: November 17, 10am at Temple Sharey-Tefilo in South Orange.
RAPPAPORT--Marty. We who knew you will miss you. You tried to make it. I remember when you scored your hole in one. The people that you helped will never forget you. Herb Spiegel
I told them, 'Why should I say I'm sick? You did your job badly, guys.' IOSIF L. NAGLE, on being pressured by Russian government officials to step down from a jury. [A1]

BELSON--Maxine. The Officers and the Board of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with deep sorrow the passing of Maxine Belson, wife of our Board President, Jerome Belson. When their younger son, Tad, was diagnosed with epilepsy, Maxine transformed this knowledge into a lifetime commitment to bring aid, information and comfort to people with special needs and their families. For her lifetime devotion to the disability community, Maxine received the Luella Bennack Community Service Award at our 2007 Women Who Care Luncheon during our 60th anniversary year. She is missed and we extend our sincere sympathy to Jerome, Tad, daughter, Briann, and son-in-law, Sandy Goldstein, and grandchildren, Matthew, Jackie, Jonathan, Joshua and Toby, and to the extended Belson family.Martin C. Hausman, ChairmanEdward R. Matthews, CEOUCP of New York City

Given the level of curiosity and news media coverage that has greeted a possible course of action that may have been taken by former President Bill Clinton, you'd think he was still in office, having just decided on a candidate for a vacancy in his cabinet or on the Supreme Court. But no. On Monday, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton would neither confirm nor deny that the former president had filmed a cameo appearance in ''The Hangover 2,'' a sequel to the hit Todd Phillips comedy.

BELSON--Maxine. Mom had a great sense of humor and loved to laugh, especially at the absurdities of life. She was a caretaker who took great care of her parents, Tillie and Louie Rogg, as well as the rest of her family. Mom loved when the house was filled with the noise of her grandchildren and great- grandchildren. She willingly embraced our friends. But her life's work was to help create a place where our brother Tad would have a safe, dignified and productive life. Oh, how she shined at New Hope Community. We will miss her laughter and seeing her dance like no one was watching. Brianne and Sandy

The doormen at 941 Park Avenue, where Cathleen P. Black occupies a penthouse apartment, have quickly transformed her morning ritual into an art form. Determined to help Ms. Black elude the reporters who waited outside her building starting at 5:15 a.m. Monday, they orchestrated a seamless, starlet-worthy, question-dodging, cab-to-curb handoff of the woman poised to become New York City's next schools chancellor.

An obituary on Sunday about the cardiologist Richard J. Bing referred incorrectly to the coronary sinus, which figured in his research. It delivers deoxygenated blood to the right atrium, not to the right ventricle.

FAISON--Eric A.,died on November 10, 2010 at his home of natural causes. He is survived by his mother, his siblings and their children. We will miss Eric's vibrant personality and warm sense of humor that shone brightly in every setting in which he was present. He was passionate about his family and friends all of whom feel his loss deeply. Service: November 16th, 7pm at Miles Funeral Home, Brooklyn, NY.

Two members of President Obama's bipartisan debt-reduction commission -- one a Congressional Republican leader and the other a prominent Democratic economist -- proposed on Wednesday to turn Medicare into a voucher program in 2021, raise its retirement age and give states block grants to take over Medicaid.

David Burke has just signed on to do the restaurant in the James New York, a new hotel at Grand Street and Avenue of the Americas in SoHo. It is expected to open in February on a site, 32 Grand Street, that is essentially where the Moonstruck Diner used to be, Mr. Burke said.

Playing chess in New York City parks is a well established custom, so much so that the city has installed more than 2,000 tables among its 536 parks. But, if adults want to play on those tables - and those are typically the people who do - and those tables happen to be in a playground, the players may run into trouble. With the police. That is evidently what a group of players found out at the Emerson Playground in Inwood Hill Park in Manhattan.
The effort by the Chevrolet division of General Motors to familiarize drivers with the 2011 Chevrolet Volt - an electric car with a gasoline engine - is accelerating with additional commercials.

Still buzzing over Billy Reid's win at the CFDA Awards and the news of the royal engagement, various fashion cognoscenti trekked up to the landmark townhouse occupied by the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute (684 Park Avenue, at 68th Street) to get a sneak peek at the exhibition, "Balenciaga: Spanish Master." Oscar de la Renta, the Institute's Chairman of the Board explained that the influences in his world "were very Spanish because even after his big success in Paris he still remained very Spanish as a person." He went on to say that Balenciaga "was deeply influenced by all the culture and folklore of Spain from the religious to the gypsy and the flamencos and bullfighters." T caught up with Hamish Bowles, who curated the show but who also has an impressive collection of Balenciaga all his own.

In an article in the special Energy section of The New York Times on Wednesday, I write about a developer who wants to sell "garden plots" in a 15-megawatt photovoltaic farm in Davis, Calif., so that residents can go solar without having to cut down trees in the city's urban forest to install rooftop arrays.

The British store Matches has stocked its virtual and digital racks with Erdem for quite some time now. Now the designer behind the brand, Erdem Moralioglu, has created an exclusive pre-spring collection just for the Matches Web site. The five pieces, available now through March 2011, come in an Erdem signature floral print and a range of styles including a jean blouse, a maxi skirt and a couple of dresses. "The special collection is targeted toward cocktail wear, hence the Deco feel to the pieces," says Ruth Chapman, a co-founder of the store. Here is a sneak peek behind the making of this stellar match by the photographer Errol Rainey and featuring the model Valentine Fillol-Cordier.

While the album is "terrific," as Mr. Caramanica writes, "that doesn't matter nearly as much as it should, at least partly because of Mr. West's insistence on his own greatness. By not allowing for responses to his work other than awe, the value of the work itself is diminished; it becomes an object of admiration, not of study." Read his story here.

On November 19, the French director Claire Denis's latest film, "White Material" opens in New York. It's her 10th feature and, like her first and fifth films, "Chocolat," (1988) and "Beau Travail," (1999), it was shot in Africa, where she grew up. You can usually recognize a Denis production due to its minimal dialogue, evocative sense of place, long, lingering shots, non-linear narrative flow and intense focus on complex human relationships. These are provocative slow burns that leave unanswered questions in their wakes. We asked Denis to answer a few.

Recently, researchers in Finland made the discovery that some people’s bodies do not respond as expected to weight training, others don’t respond to endurance exercise and, in some lamentable cases, some don’t respond to either. In other words, there are those who just do not become fitter or stronger, no matter what exercise they undertake. To reach this conclusion, the researchers enrolled 175 sedentary adults in a 21-week exercise program. Some lifted weights twice a week. Others jogged or walked. Some did both. Before and after the program, the volunteers’ fitness and muscular strength were assessed. At the end of the 21 weeks, the results, published earlier this year in Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, were mixed. In the combined strength-and-endurance-exercise program, the volunteers’ physiological improvement ranged from a negative 8 percent (meaning they became 8 percent less fit) to a positive 42 percent. The results were similar in the groups that undertook only strength or only endurance training. Some improved their strength enormously, some not at all. Others became aerobically fitter but not stronger, while still others showed no improvements in either area. Only a fortunate few became both fitter and more buff. As the researchers from the University of Jyvaskyla wrote with some understatement, “large individual differences” exist “in the responses to both endurance and strength training.”

The owner of the landmark Lipstick Building in Manhattan - also known as ground zero for the $65 billion Ponzi scheme of Bernard L. Madoff - filed for Chapter 11 reorganization on Monday. According to the court documents, the building's owner, Metropolitan 885 Third Avenue Leasehold, defaulted on a $210 million mortgage held by the Royal Bank of Canada. The company was not able to maintain a minimum balance of $2.3 million in the loan's debt service fund, which triggered a default notice in April, according to court documents. After several notifications, the Royal Bank of Canada filed a lawsuit against the firm, calling for a sale of the well-known property to pay off the loan.

An art review on Friday about an exhibition of paintings by William N. Copley at the Paul Kasmin Gallery in Manhattan and an exhibition of Peter Saul paintings at Haunch of Venison, also in Manhattan, misstated the year Copley was born. It was 1919, not 1910.

The producers of the coming Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' are planning to tap the cast member Matthew James Thomas to serve as an alternate for the leading man, Reeve Carney, in the role of Peter Parker/Spider-Man for as many as two performances a week after the show opens, executives involved with the production said on Tuesday. Mr. Carney, a 27-year-old rock musician with the band Carney, and a relatively new actor making his Broadway debut in ''Spider-Man,'' has not pressed for an alternate but the producers are considering Mr. Thomas because of the physical demands of the central performance, the executives said. They spoke on condition of anonymity because the producers did not want the matter discussed publicly until a final decision has been made.

SCHON--Nicolae, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Nicolae Schon. Dr. Schon was a pediatrician in the Department of Pediatrics for over 30 years, until his retirement. His caring manner towards the children he treated always made their fears slip away. His smile was infectious and always put people at ease. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. H. Wasserman, M.D., Pres E. Fitzpatrick, M.D., Pres Elect G. Neiderman, M.D., Secy E. Chapnick, M.D., Treas

As the private school admissions process rolls into full gear, so, too, does the parental rumor mill, churning out dubious claims about the meaning of each move a school makes as the anxious mothers and fathers of applicants seek to read the tea leaves of their child's academic future. Some talismanic beliefs are based in kernels of truth, like, say, the importance of sending thank-you notes, which admissions people say can have an impact. But others, such as the belief that where you sit in a certain school's interview chambers can affect your child's prospects, are merely a product of parents' anxieties, according to admissions officials. Others attribute the misinformation to a darker source.

REMEMBER Trader Vic's in the Plaza Hotel, all dark wood and sweet drinks, steel guitar and Polynesian dreams? Donald Trump closed the restaurant in 1993 when he bought the hotel, calling it ''tacky,'' but it had 25 years under its grass skirt before that day. Trader Vic's served pu pu platters and mai tais to generations of New Yorkers delighted to dream of the South Pacific and all its naked, willing charms. Michael Stillman surely must recall the place, even if he was only a child when the ax came down. Mr. Stillman, the son of the legendary New York restaurateur Alan Stillman and himself the owner of a number of Manhattan restaurants, recently opened the Hurricane Club on Park Avenue South. It is a sprawling, hilarious restaurant that evokes the style and hubris of Trader Vic's while improving on its food.
$5.5 MILLION 333 West 38th Street (between Eighth and Ninth Avenues)

BELSON--Maxine (Rogg) Adored wife, and devoted mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend died Sunday. She was 90 and lived in Brooklyn. During her active and vibrant life she was known for her profound care and help of others. She devoted her life to helping children and adults with physical and intellectual disabilities to achieve their maximum potential and pleasure to enable them to lead full and productive lives. Her boundless energy was evident when involved in countless philanthropic endeavors as a leader, organizer and benefactor. Among her many accomplishments she was especially proud of creating The Big E for Epilepsy and founding a free clinic at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for individuals with epilepsy. To raise money for the clinic she organized and led tours around the world. As a pioneer in promoting the independence of people with intellectual disabilities she helped create New Hope Community in Loch Sheldrake, NY - motivated by her son Tad, who was the light of her life. She was recently honored at the community by the naming of a facility she helped sponsor and fund called "Maxie's Place." She was an esteemed member of the St. John's University family and was an enthusiastic fan of the soccer team. The family funded the Belson soccer stadium on campus and the Maxine & Jerome Belson Moot Court at the university's law school. She was honored for her work with disabled children by St. John's University with their Medal of Honor and awarded a Doctorate of Pedeology by Niagara University. Her family was a great source of joy throughout her life. She was the adored wife of Jerome, her husband for 56 years. She was the devoted and loving mother of her son Tad; daughter Brianne and son-in-law Sanford; her predeceased son Michael and daughter-in-law Kathy; and daughter-in-law Marjorie. She was a beloved grandmother of Matthew and his wife Jodi; Joshua and his wife Katy; Jaclyn, Toby and Jonathan. She was also great grandmother to Noah, Ariel and Paisley. Her love for her family was only matched by the love for her. She will be missed by the multitude of friends and family who were the beneficiaries of her care, love and sense of humor. She will not be forgotten. A graveside service will be held. In lieu of flowers, those inclined to do so, may make a donation to the New Hope Community, a 503c charity located at: PO Box 289, Route 52, Loch Sheldrake, NY 12759.

Thirteen days after George Steinbrenner's death in July, the National Baseball Hall of Fame altered the procedures for voting on executives, managers, umpires and longtime retired players by its veterans committee in a way that seemed to favor the Boss's swift election next month. If Steinbrenner is instantly worthy of induction, his election would complete a 37-year arc that included the good (seven World Series titles), the bad (two suspensions from baseball) and the ugly (paying a gambler for dirt on Dave Winfield).

BELSON--Maxine. Victor Belson and his family mourn the loss of Maxine, Victor's sister-in-law and the wife of his brother, Jerry. Maxine was a caring wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and aunt; a tireless advocate for people with disabilities; the pulse of every room she entered. With Jerry, she raised Tad, Brianne and Michael (pre-deceased). She is remembered by Victor, and his wife, Arlene; her nephew, Jeffrey, his wife, Susan, and their children, Jared and Emma; her nephew, Ken, and his wife, Harumi; her niece, Elizabeth. Her trademark humor, drive and compassion will not be forgotten.

An article on Tuesday about molecular animation misstated the academic affiliation of Peter Walter, a cell biologist who said that some such animations can be ''clearly more Hollywood than useful display.'' He is a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator at the University of California, San Francisco -- not an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, a philanthropy in Maryland.

Despite contests for every statewide office for the first time in decades, a smaller share of eligible voters turned out two weeks ago in New York than in any other state. In fact, New York's turnout was lower than in any midterm election for at least three decades.

HOHRI--William Minoru, 83, died on November 12, 2010. He led the historic class action suit Hohri vs. US to the Supreme Court on behalf of all Japanese Americans incarcerated in WWII. A celebration of his life will be held on Sunday, November 21 at 11am in Los Angeles at Fukui Mortuary, 707 E. Temple St., 90012.

Although Wall Street's payroll is shrinking, its profit machine is alive and well. Profit at New York securities firms is on track to top $19 billion this year, according to an analysis released Tuesday by the New York State comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli. After suffering losses totaling $54 billion in 2007 and 2008, during the depths of the financial crisis, the securities industry has enjoyed a solid bounce.

Sam Gold, the director of two Off Broadway productions that received major praise last season, Annie Baker's plays ''Circle Mirror Transformation'' and ''The Aliens,'' has been named an associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, where he directed its current black box hit ''Tigers Be Still.'' That production has been extended through Nov. 28 but is now sold out, Roundabout said on Tuesday in a statement announcing Mr. Gold's appointment. At 32, Mr. Gold will be the youngest associate artist on the Roundabout roster and will probably be a significant bridge to more emerging and experimental theater artists. From 2003 to 2006 he worked as dramaturg at the Wooster Group, the downtown avant-garde theater troupe, and has since directed several works by young playwrights at Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway spaces. He is currently directing ''The Coward,'' a new period comedy by Nick Jones set in 18th-century England, for Lincoln Center Theater in a production at LCT3, its endeavor to stage the work of new writers.

BRIGHTON--G. Renfrew of Rowayton, CT and Culebra, PR, died October 23, 2010 following a long illness. He was the son of George Renfrew Brighton, MD, and Dorothy Rosencrans. Born in 1925, in New York City, he grew up in Rye, NY, and attended Taft School in Watertown CT, and Dartmouth College after serving in the Marine Corps in the Pacific theatre during World War II. Until his retirement he was the Chairman of Business Journals, Inc., a publishing/communications company in Norwalk, CT. He enjoyed skiing, aerobatic flying, and sailing, especially his Atlantic out of Cedar Point Yacht Club in Westport, CT. Following his retirement, he and wife Marsha set sail for the Caribbean and, after several years exploring the islands, they settled in Culebra, PR which quickly became their home away from home, and community. He is survived by his children Deborah P. Brighton, Pamela W. Brighton and Renfrew M. Brighton; his stepdaughter Susan Freel; his sister, Waldo Jones; eleven grandchildren and four great grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Louise McDowell Brighton and his sister Burns Vitzthum. His wife Marsha J. Brighton's death followed his by one week. A Memorial Service is planned for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Animal Welfare of Culebra, PO Box 527, Culebra, PR 00775 or Addison County Home Health and Hospice, PO Box 754, Middlebury, VT 05753.

An article on Sunday about the release of Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, from house arrest by that country's military rulers misidentified, in some editions, which of her lawyers said that the rulers may still restrict her movements, as they have done before. The comment was made by U Kyi Win -- not by U Kyi Maung.

STADLER--Jack. The Westchester Community College family extends condolences to the family of Jack Stadler. Jack had been one of the cornerstones of the institution for a quarter century. In 1984, he became involved with the Westchester Community College Foundation, ultimately serving as its chairperson for eight years. In this role, he assisted the Foundation in its efforts to raise funds for college projects, faculty support, and student scholarships. In addition to contributing personally to all three, he was instrumental in helping set the fundraising bar high in order to assist students. Largely due to his efforts, the Foundation now annually contributes more than $1 Million in student scholarships. In 2008, Jack was named an Emeritus member of the Foundation board. In addition to scholarships, this nationally-known patron of the arts supported the college's efforts to showcase a wide variety of cultural events including the Jack and Ralynn Stadler Distinguished Chair Lecture Series. This event was established through his generosity and was named after Jack and his late wife Ralynn. Ralynn predated Jack on the college's Board of Trustees. He was appointed to finish her term on the board in 1990 and since that time, had been part of the leadership group that directed college efforts, shepherding in an expansion of programs, facilities, and resources resulting in the dramatic growth of the student body. We will miss Jack's wisdom and wit, and we mourn the loss of this leader, benefactor, and friend. In lieu of flowers, the Stadler family wishes any contributions to be sent to the Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 311 North Street, Suite 204, White Plains, NY 10605.
CHIARA--Judy. We will love and miss you forever. We extend our deepest sympathy to her siblings and family. Charles Krewson & Richard Feuring

A report in some editions of the National Briefing column on Tuesday about the nomination of a new director for the Justice Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, misspelled the nominee's surname. He is Andrew Traver, not Taver.

RUBINE--George A.,age 93. Died in Providence, RI on Wednesday, November 15, from complications of Parkinson's disease. He was predeceased by his wife Vera Newmark. A graduate of Rutgers University, he served in the United States Army in World War II as a member of the Third Infantry Division in the European Theatre. George worked for over 50 years as President of the companies founded by his father: The Hudson Iron and Metal Company and The Bayonne Nipple Company. He lived in both Cranford and Westfield, NJ where he was active in community service. George was also predeceased by a sister Miriam Herr and is survived by a sister, Helen Lappe, and by his son, Superior Court Associate Justice Allen Rubine of Cranston, RI and his wife Barbara; and by his daughter Marcia Rubine of New York City and her husband John Masten. He is also survived by five grandchildren; Daniel, Michael, and Jessica Rubine and Benjamin and Andrew Masten. A graveside service will be conducted on Thursday, November 18 at 1pm at the Baron Hirsch Cemetery, 1126 Richmond Ave., Staten Island, NY. Services through Menorah Chapels, Millburn, NJ. 1-800-437-5151.

BUIZINGEN, Belgium -- Willy Delsaert is a retired railroad employee with dyslexia who practiced intensively before facing the suburban Don Bosco Catholic parish to perform the Sunday Mass rituals he grew up with. ''Who takes this bread and eats,'' he murmured, cracking a communion wafer with his wife at his side, ''declares a desire for a new world.''

Simons and the St. John's University School of Law Alumni Association mourn the passing of Maxine Belson, the beloved wife of our alumnus and former Alumni Association President Jerome Belson '48, '80HON. Maxine was a dear friend of the Law School and, with her husband Jerry, was an extraordinarily generous benefactor. The bricks and mortar of our building bear her name. But more importantly, our community resounds with her spirit. Our thoughts and prayers are with Jerry and the entire Belson family. Michael A. Simons, Dean and John V. Brennan Professor of Law Hon. Reinaldo E. Rivera, President, Law School Alumni Association

DEUTSCH--Lawrence, passed away on November 15th in Sarasota, FL. He is survived by his wife Toby, his children Allison and Barry, his son-in-law Tim, his grandchildren Silas and Jemma, and his sister Marlene. Larry was born in Brooklyn in 1942 and married his high school sweetheart in 1962. An audiologist for decades, Larry was a leader among colleagues and an empathic doctor to his patients. In retirement, a passionate scholar and teacher of Judaism. A man whose energy was exceeded only by his generosity, Larry was much loved and will be missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:15am, Wednesday, November 17, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

KHEEL--Theodore W. The City University of New York mourns the loss of Theodore W. Kheel, prominent labor negotiator, lawyer, environmentalist and supporter of the University. Mr. Kheel's longstanding connection with CUNY grew out of his ambition to change the way New Yorkers saw their relationship with the city's environment. In 2004 he approached the University with an idea and the funding to develop a course, "The Nature of New York: Its Natural History and Environment," which was first offered through the School of Professional Studies and is now integrated into the CUNY Online Baccalaureate program as a science proficiency course. The CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities, now based at Hunter College, was also created out of the vision and financial support of Mr. Kheel, who was awarded the Chancellor's Medal in 2005 for his environmental education work. Mr. Kheel's avid commitment and support will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Benno Schmidt, Chair, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

As long as the Beatles and Apple have co-existed, fans of both have wondered: when are these crazy kids finally going to get together? It has finally happened, but it wasn't easy. The two sides have been fighting off and on since 1978 when the Beatles accused Apple Computer of infringing on the trademark of their business concern, Apple Corps. They settled that one -- the Beatles licensed the Apple name to the computer company -- fought again over Apple's music synthesizer, settled again, fought again over iTunes' apple logo and settled that one too. And now, 32 years later, the two are ready to do business, with Apple selling Beatles singles and albums on iTunes.

de ST. PAER--Virginia. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors of the Group of North American Insurance Enterprises memorializes the death of Virginia de St. Paer, the mother of GNAIE Executive Chair, Jerry de St. Paer. Virginia B. de St. Paer, age 95, a resident of Wheaton for over 50 years, died Sunday, November 14 at Wynscape Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Wheaton. She was born on November 12, 1915 in Storm Lake, Iowa to Hazel nee Crawford and John W. Edwards. Ginny graduated from Buena Vista College in Storm Lake, Iowa and Teacher College in Cedar Falls, Iowa. She was a member of Delta Phi Beta Sorority at Buena Vista College. She worked as a teacher and substitute teacher for a number of years. On August 15, 1940 she married Claude de St. Paer. They lived in Iowa until 1959 when they and their children, Sue and Jerry, moved to Wheaton. She was passionate about Wheaton and Republican politics. She was chairwoman of DuPage County Republican Party from 1976 until 1987, having been named DuPage Republican Woman of the Year in 1975. She was president of the Women's Department Club, president of the Wheaton A.M. Homemakers, vice-president of the Home Garden Club and Secretary and Guardian of Chapter J.O. of P.E.O. She was very active at Gary United Methodist Church where she volunteered in Wesley Shop for many years. She is survived by her husband Claude, two children, Sue (William) Lee of Horicon, Wisconsin and Jerry (Karen) de St. Paer of Chatham, NJ, nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren, and one sister, Mary Ellen Kelling of Montezuma, Iowa. She was preceded in death by her parents and one sister, Francine Schlee. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 19 at 11:00am at Gary Memorial United Methodist Church, 224 N. Main St., Wheaton, IL 60187. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be directed to Outreach Community Center, Older Adults Program, 122 W. Liberty Dr., Wheaton, IL 60187. Information and guest book are available at hultgrenfh.com or call Hultgren Funeral Home at 630-668-0027.

Voting for baseball's major awards must be completed before the first game of the playoffs. This means that Roy Halladay earned every first-place vote for the National League Cy Young Award -- and then pitched the game of his life. Halladay, the ace of the Philadelphia Phillies, fired the second no-hitter in postseason history in Game 1 of the division series against the Cincinnati Reds. Given the context, it was probably even more impressive than his perfect game in Florida on May 29.

Ross, brilliant, beautiful and beloved mother of Ann Ross Loeb, James Jarcho Ross and Lynn Ross Rosenfeld, mother-in-law of Michael Loeb, Laura Gore Ross and Edward Rosenfeld, grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of nine. SZALITA--Dr. Alberta B.,the Polish born Jewish intellectual who became one of New York's most influential psychoanalytic teachers and theorists, died on Wednesday November 10, 2010. She was 100 years old. A survivor of the Holocaust, Dr. Szalita began her psychoanalytic work at Chestnut Lodge. Frieda Fromm-Reichmann has been quoted as saying that her first referral choice for a loved one in trouble would always be Alberta Szalita. She was a Training and Supervising Analyst at the White Institute and Columbia University. She helped to establish psychoanalytic institutes in Israel and Norway. Her writings include perspectives on empathy, reanalysis, schizophrenia, and psychotherapy, which she labeled psychointegration. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Sunday, November 21, 2010 at 11:15am. It will take place at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. The service will begin promptly at 11:15am. Attendees are urged to arrive no later than 11:00am.

Sometimes a photograph grabs your attention by its sheer mystery. Here is Eleanor Roosevelt at La Guardia Airport in 1960, carrying her luggage, seemingly alone -- without entourage or Secret Service, press or onlookers. I came across it in a photo bin at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum, in Hyde Park, N.Y. I asked my wife, Mary, ''Why is she carrying her own suitcase?'' She gives me a look like I should know: ''Because she's Eleanor Roosevelt.'' Earlier photographs in the series are online at nytimes.com/lens.

Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman does not have an obvious candidate for a new pitching coach, but he does have a unique approach to finding a replacement for Dave Eiland. Cashman has devised a comprehensive two-day process, in which the candidates will be brought into the video room in the Yankee Stadium clubhouse and be shown Yankee pitchers and opposing hitters. The candidates will return the next day for an exam on what they saw and how they interpreted it, along with the usual discussion about their philosophies and previous experience.

WHAT'S the best oil for everyday frying? Some markets where I shop offer more than a dozen oils, from argan and avocado to tea seed and walnut. I'd long figured that the choice is a matter of taste and price. I usually use canola oil because it's neutral in flavor, a good source of omega-3s and inexpensive. Like soy oil, it costs about a dime a tablespoon, whereas extra-virgin olive oils can run well over a dollar. Partisans of the olive maintain that a high-quality extra-virgin oil brings its special flavor and health benefits to foods cooked in it. More recipes now suggest it for frying and other high-heat techniques, not just for last-minute drizzling. But does it make enough difference that it's worth a tenfold premium in price?

As hard as it is to run a public company, it may be even more difficult to sell it. Take the all-out brawl over Dynegy 's proposed sale to the Blackstone Group. Carl C. Icahn and another big Dynegy investor have been vocal in their opposition to the offer from Blackstone, calling it ''inadequate.'' The proxy advisory services are split on their recommendations. Dynegy's management, meanwhile, has made ominous references to its ''challenging financial position'' if the deal is not approved.

Could there eventually come a day when our popular culture's disposition toward all things zombie-related goes from fixation to saturation, from saturation to revulsion, and from revulsion to a point where people are actually persecuted for showing zombie movies? Richard Wolstencroft, the director of the Melbourne Underground Film Festival in Australia, might argue that the day is already here. But then again the zombie movie he tried to show at his festival over the summer is not exactly your ordinary horror flick. In July, Agence France-Presse reported, the Melbourne International Film Festival pulled its planned screening of ''L.A. Zombie,'' a movie by Bruce LaBruce, a Canadian filmmaker.

CHIARA--Judith Helen Loeb. With great sorrow, her family announces the death of Judith Helen Loeb (Beaty) Chiara, born 1927, in New York City. Judy never awoke from a night's sleep and passed away peacefully on November 14th at Lenox Hill Hospital, attended by many family and friends. Judy as everyone knew her, was the daughter of John and Frances Loeb, both scions of illustrious New York Families. Judy was their oldest child and is survived by her four brothers and sisters, including the Honorable John Loeb Jr., former US Ambassador to Denmark, Ann Loeb Bronfman, Arthur Lehman Loeb, the former owner of the Madison Avenue Bookshop, and Deborah Brice of London, England. She was a loving mother and grandmother to her six children, two step-children and fourteen grandchildren. A first great-grandchild is on the way. Judy was first married to Richard N. Beat, an American fighter pilot who fought in WWII with the Royal Air Force and died in 1965. She subsequently married and was divorced from Marco Chiara, the son of the Italian novelist Piero Chiara. Judy graduated from the Madeira School and attended Vassar College before graduating from Barnard. Both Vassar and Madeira remained important to Judy and she became close to Madeira's headmistress, Betsey Griffiths, who had important changes to the curriculum. Last year, Vassar's oldest building was modernized and dedicated to Judy, due to her and her family interest and contributions to the College's expanding social programs. The Judith L. Chiara scholarship is given in her honor to one Vassar student each year. Judy was an active philanthropist who was involved in many New York institutions and charities. She was the Chairman of the Board of Exponents/Arrive, the first New York City counseling program to assist AIDS patients; she was on the Board of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a human rights watchdog organization; and had become a major supporter of Teamwork Foundation, a long term highly successful after-school program for athletes in the Bronx (the New York Gauchos basketball team). She was a contributor and Board member as well of the Harlem Symphony, a founder of The Catalogue for Giving and many other similar groups and organizations all of which will miss her spirit and support. Judy always lived a very full life and leaves behind friends from Maine to the Bahamas, from Venice Beach, California to Venice, Italy and too many other places to mention. She was an avid sailor and the skipper of her own racing yawl, the Susanna, and proud of her race successes. But she was proudest of her family and friends. Her life affected many people, none more so than her children: Nancy, Susan, Richard, Frances, Anne, John, Charlie, and Daniela. We all miss her and will always miss her. A private burial is planned for Sunday, November 21, at Kenisco Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift in her name to the charity of your choice. For more information please contact Richard Beaty at: 212-421-2403 or 201-960-0342.

An article on Tuesday about a large study's conclusions that nesiritide, a drug used to treat heart failure, is neither dangerous nor particularly effective misstated the number of sites involved in a clinical trial of cholesterol drugs conducted by Merck. There are 1,046 trial sites around the world, not 380.

8 P.M. (HBO2) DARK LIGHT: THE ART OF BLIND PHOTOGRAPHERS Pete Eckert, who lost his sight to retinitis pigmentosa, uses a Braille light meter to take photographs based on a mental image. Henry Butler, who had infantile glaucoma, relies on his theory that everything gives off vibrations to generate pictures. Bruce Hall, who has very limited sight, uses his camera underwater, above, so that he can see what he was looking at when he returns to dry land. This documentary from Neil Leifer explores how photography provides a creative opportunity for three artists for whom sight is mostly in the mind. The men were featured in ''Sight Unseen,'' a showcase, organized by Douglas McCulloh, of work by blind photographers that ran at the California Museum of Photography at the University of California, Riverside, in 2009. ''Most people think that photographers operate through sight and their eyes, but photographers know that they actually operate through their mind,'' Mr. McCulloh said. ''These photographers, since they have no sight, are making purely mental constructions of these photographs.'' 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The remaining four contestants meet Franca Sozzani, editor in chief of Vogue Italia, after which the women are challenged to bring their poses to life through movement and emotion. And then there were two.

A New York University photography professor will have a camera surgically implanted in the back of his head for several months as part of an art project commissioned by the government of Qatar, The Wall Street Journal reported. The project, called ''The 3rd I'' and organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, will involve the camera taking pictures at one-minute intervals with the images being streamed to a computer database and then appearing in different sequences, some in real time, on monitors in an exhibition space in Doha between December and May. According to The Journal, the professor, Wafaa Bilal, has offered to cover the camera with a lens cap when he is on the N.Y.U. campus, out of respect for students' privacy, but the university may require him to turn the camera off. In a statement on Tuesday the university said it was in discussions with Mr. Bilal about to how to ensure that his camera would not take pictures in N.Y.U. buildings. Mr. Bilal, who was born in Iraq, has provoked controversy with earlier projects, including one in 2008 called ''Virtual Jihadi,'' in which he altered a video game to insert an avatar of himself as a suicide-bomber targeting George W. Bush.

OWENS--Mary (Minnie) (nee Hanlon), died November 13th, 2010 at 104 years of age. Min came to New York from Kilkenny, Ireland at 17 and loved this city and especially the NY Times. It was her "best friend" because it educated and informed her. Her life will be celebrated by her family and friends on Thursday, 11am at Sacred Heart Church in Bayside. She has joined her husband Andy and son Jimmy (FDNY) in glory. She is survived by Thomas Owens and family, John Owens and family, Carol Owens and family, and Sr. Mary Anne Owens, SSND. Eight grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. She never met a stranger, who did not become a friend and her belief in God and city included volunteering, organizing, entertaining whoever and whatever built up the common good of all. Her legacy of love and service goes on for us all! In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Catholic Charities Endowment Trust, 9461LBJ Freeway, suite 128, Dallas, TX 75243.

BAGHDAD - Iraqis this week are celebrating Id al-Adha, like millions of Muslims across the world. The festival, also known as the Feast of Sacrifice, is one of the principal holidays in the Islamic calendar and comes as a relief for a city that has been hit hard by bombs and killings in recent weeks. In large numbers, Iraqis flocked to Al Zawraa Park in the center of the capital, to enjoy carnival rides, cotton candy, a Ferris wheel and a boating lake.

Now is the time for bold attempts at bipartisan policymaking, apparently. In the wake of the Simpson-Bowles blueprint comes an even more detailed vision for deficit reduction from the Bipartisan Policy Center, which some of the liberal wonks who snarked at Simpson-Bowles have decided is a budget-balancing proposal they can get behind. (That's a good thing, to my mind, because the B.P.C. report and Simpson-Bowles are both much closer to one another than either is to the current left-wing vision of how to bring the budget into balance.) Meanwhile, Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan has persuaded Alice Rivlin, Bill Clinton's former O.M.B. director, to join him in championing a sweeping overhaul of Medicare, which would transform the program from an open-ended entitlement into a means-tested system that provides vouchers to purchase health insurance.

Years of efforts to produce an American version of the popular offbeat British television show about cars, "Top Gear," are coming to fruition when the History cable channel presents the first episode of the United States "Top Gear" on Sunday night. When we last checked in on efforts in Congress to roll back the expansion of 1099 reporting that passed as part of the health care overhaul, we found the parties deadlocked. One great and glorious advantage that the theater used to have over the movies was the third dimension. You knew that when you watched actors on stage that they were just as fully rounded - physically, I mean - as the people in the lobby at intermission. Actors on film, no matter how big they looked in 10-foot close-ups, were as hopelessly flat as the screens on which their images flickered.

The statue of Mars and Venus that greets visitors to the official residence of Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, is a striking example of classical Roman sculpture but to certain observers it seemed incomplete. Dating back to 175 A.D., the representation of Venus was missing one of her hands, and her companion, Mars, was missing the very feature that some might say made him such a manly god of war. But the work at Palazzo Chigi in Rome has been restored to anatomical completeness, The Guardian reported: Venus now has all of her digits and Mars was given a new penis. The Italian newspaper La Repubblica said Mr. Berlusconi had requested the restoration of the statue, but Mario Catalano, the prime minister's architect, told The Guardian, "I took the decision." Mr. Catalano added that the replacement parts were attached using a magnetic system and were removable but declined to provide additional details.

It takes a supremely confident artist to take on so comprehensive and controversial a subject as the history of art in the Arab world. But Walid Raad, a Lebanese-born artist who lives and teaches in New York, has never shied away from challenges. In his last project, in collaboration with the Atlas Group, a fictitious, pseudo-collective/think-tank, he researched and documented the history of Lebanon between 1989 and 2004 with text and images, intentionally blurring the line between fact and fiction to underline the ambiguity and inadequacy of memory.

WASHINGTON -- In June, the Supreme Court issued a decision on the privacy rights of a police officer whose sexually explicit text messages had been reviewed by his employer. Ever since, lower court judges have struggled to figure out what the decision means. The case ''touches issues of far-reaching significance,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote. Then he explained why the court would decide none of them. A definitive ruling should be avoided, he said, because ''it might have implications for future cases that cannot be predicted.''

WHAT is the Ohwow Book Club, which since May has occupied a subterranean space on Waverly Place near Seventh Avenue in the West Village? It's an art-book shop. It's also a publisher's outlet; the owners, Aaron Bondaroff and Al Moran, manufacture the books at Mr. Moran's printing press in Miami. And now Ohwow will become a gallery, showing what the two men, who met about five years ago through friends, hope will be the next generation of downtown art and literature stars.
An article on Nov. 4 about aspiring Victoria's Secret models misspelled the surname of a model who attended a recent casting call. She is Anne Vyalitsyna, not Vialitsina.

An article on Saturday about Canada's immigration policy referred incompletely to the policy in the province of Quebec. While Quebec, like all the other provinces, selects its own immigrants subject to federal approval on health, security and criminality questions, its program operates under a different power-sharing agreement with Canada's federal government. Quebec's policy gives preference to people who speak French. Also, its agreement with the federal government can be amended only by mutual consent while the other provincial agreements are subject to federal approval.

SCHARER--Seymore passed away on November 13, 2010 in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 91. Si was born in Perth Amboy, New Jersey. He attended Rutgers University, interrupted by his service in the Army, and graduated from NYU where he taught radio dramatics. His work life took many turns, as a retail buyer, manager of a chain of supermarkets, and an advertising executive. Ultimately he had a highly successful career in marketing and promotions, including the development of Pocket Planner. Si was handsome, charming, and widely regarded as a person of keen intellect who was generous to his relatives, friends, and charitable causes and deeply committed to social justice and equality. He was an accomplished tennis player who loved the game which he played well into his eighties. Before it became trendy, Si was always dedicated to and enjoyed exercising whether that meant riding his bicycle to work or doing a strict workout routine every day. One of Si's proudest moments was his inclusion on Nixon's Enemies List for actions against the Vietnam War. He is survived and will be greatly missed by the love of his life, his wife Vivian, who was joyfully by his side for 69 years, his daughter Joan Karan, his son Jimmy, his nieces, and many friends. He was predeceased by his son, Jonathan. A private service will be held at a later date. Memorial donations are suggested to The Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County.

GEWIRTZ--Dr Alan M.,born September 3, 1949, died November 17, 2010. C. Willard Robinson Professor of Hematology-Oncology, University of Pennsylvania, School of Medicine. Beloved unto Joanna Opalinska and Elizabeth Bien, loving father to Jamie Gewirtz and Emily Stiebel, cherished brother to Elliot, Henry and David Gewirtz, grandfather to Jane Gewirtz, and loving brother-in-law to Barbara Gewirtz and Lisa Anderson. Distinguished scientist, physician, author and pilot. Recipient of the Doris Duke Distinguished Clinical Scientist Award. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alan Gewirtz Leukemia Research Fund, Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania.
