CHIARA--Judith Helen Loeb. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Judith Helen Loeb Chiara, beloved sister of our dear friend Ann Loeb Bronfman. Ann enriches the lives of many in the Jewish community with her unwavering commitment to social and humanitarian causes in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest condolences to Ann; to Judith's children, grandchildren, and siblings; and to the entire Chiara family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

BASSETT--Susan (Dobbie) Coleman Bassett de Segur. May 9, 1942 November 4, 2010. Born in Miami, Oklahoma, to Elizabeth Fullerton Coleman and George L. Coleman. Dobbie Bassett, died Thursday night at her home in Upperville, VA. after a long illness. Ms. Bassett was born in Miami, Oklahoma to George and Elizabeth Coleman in 1942. Her family moved to Pebble Beach, California a few years later because of her father's love of golf. Dobbie began riding horses as a very young child and was a consummate horsewoman from the start. She competed nationally from a young age, under the expert eye of the renowned horse trainer Richard (Dick) Collins. She won blue ribbons on her horse Fancy Free throughout her entire childhood. Her striving for perfection and her competitive spirit, later served her well when showing and winning with her beloved Cardigan Welsh Corgis. Her education included Santa Catalina School for Girls in Monterey, California and then onto Garrison Forrest in Maryland. She attended finishing school in Switzerland, where she learned to speak French fluently, and then went to Florence, Italy to study art history. Moving to New York City at age twenty, Dobbie studied interior design and fashion, and developed her innate sense of style and flair, which would be one of her trademarks throughout her life. Dobbie's passion was her animals- specifically horses and dogs. Through her young daughter, Carolines Corgi, Gwendolyn, she fell in love with the breed. She moved to Middleburg, Virginia in 1983 where she could live out her dream of fox hunting in the beautiful Virginia Piedmont, and continue breeding and showing Cardigans. She focused her creative energies in breeding championship lines of his wonderful breed and made an enormous contribution to the Corgi world. She had two marriages. She was married to Theodore S. Bassett and they had one daughter, Caroline. Her second marriage was to Pierre de Segur in Paris, France, a city very dear to her heart. She had many friends from all walks of life. Dobbie Coleman Bassett de Segur will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her only child Caroline E. Bassett who resides in New York City. In lieu of flowers donations would be most welcome to the Cardigan Welsh Corgi Association of America (CWCCA) c/o Ingrid Greca PO Box 0069 Willoughby, OH 44094 "earmarked" for the "Veterans".

WOOD--Garland E. Garland Wood, an innovator in the municipal bonds market, passed away on Monday, November 15, after a long illness. He was 66. Mr. Wood rose through the ranks at Goldman Sachs over two decades to become a renowned leader and innovator in public finance. He is widely recognized as being instrumental in leading the firm's advanced refunding efforts in the late 70s and early 80s. Garland Wood was born on December 29, 1943. He earned a BA from Columbia and remained there to pursue his MBA, graduating in 1972. Following graduation, Mr. Wood joined the Securities Division at Goldman Sachs in the Municipal Bonds Department. Mr. Wood distinguished himself early in his career by creating strategies that allowed the firm's clients to convert standing bonds from high to low interest rates. He also played a significant role in the firm's early work financing single family housing and helped to establish Goldman Sachs' leadership as a top firm in the tax-exempt business. The firm named Mr. Wood a general partner in 1986, making him the first black professional to reach the top tier of leadership at Goldman Sachs and among the first black partners on Wall Street. Mr. Wood retired from Goldman Sachs in 1994 and remained an advisor to the firm for many years. Mr. Wood is survived by his children, Michelle, Cynthia and Scott Wood, all of New York; his mother, Lou Lee Wood of Prairie View, Texas; his brothers, Curtis Wood Jr. of New York City and Craig Wood of Prairie View; and his sisters, Barbara Wood Harrison of Washington DC, Beth Setrakian and Gina Hector, both of San Francisco, California. A memorial service will be held for Mr. Wood early next year.

CHIARA--Judith Helen Loeb. With great sorrow, her family announces the death of Judith Helen Loeb (Beaty) Chiara, born 1927, in New York City. Judy never awoke from a night's sleep and passed away peacefully on November 14th at Lenox Hill Hospital, attended by many family and friends. Judy, as everyone knew her, was the daughter of John and Frances Loeb, both scions of illustrious New York Families. Judy was their oldest child and is survived by her four brothers and sisters, including the Honorable John Loeb Jr., former US Ambassador to Denmark, Ann Loeb Bronfman, Arthur Lehman Loeb, the former owner of the Madison Avenue Bookshop, and Deborah Brice of London, England. She was a loving mother and grandmother to her six children, two step-children and fourteen grandchildren. A first great-grandchild is on the way. Judy was first married to Richard N. Beaty, an American fighter pilot who fought in WWII with the Royal Air Force and died in 1965. She subsequently married and was divorced from Marco Chiara, the son of the Italian novelist Piero Chiara. Judy graduated from the Madeira School and attended Vassar College before graduating from Barnard. Both Vassar and Madeira remained important to Judy and she became close to Madeira's headmistress, Betsey Griffiths, who made important changes to the curriculum. Last year, Vassar's oldest building was modernized and dedicated to Judy, due to her and her family interest and contributions to the College's expanding social programs. The Judith L. Chiara scholarship is given in her honor to one Vassar student each year. Judy was an active philanthropist who was involved in many New York institutions and charities. She was the Chairman of the Board of Exponents/Arrive, the first New York City counseling program to assist AIDS patients; she was on the Board of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a human rights watchdog organization; and had become a major supporter of Teamwork Foundation, a long term highly successful after-school program for athletes in the Bronx (the New York Gauchos basketball team). She was a contributor and Board member as well of the Harlem Symphony, a founder of The Catalogue for Giving and many other similar groups and organizations all of which will miss her spirit and support. Judy always lived a very full life and leaves behind friends from Maine to the Bahamas, from Venice Beach, California to Venice, Italy and too many other places to mention. She was an avid sailor and the skipper of her own racing yawl, the Susanna, and proud of her race successes. But she was proudest of her family and friends. Her life affected many people, none more so than her children: Nancy, Susan, Richard, Frances, Anne, John, Charlie, and Daniela. We all miss her and will always miss her. A private burial is planned for Sunday, November 21, at Kenisco Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift in her name to the charity of your choice. A memorial service is planned for late January 2011. Exact date and venue to be announced.

HITTING THE SHELVES LANVIN'S exclusive 30-piece capsule collection for H & M will go on sale on Saturday at select H & M stores, including 505 Fifth Avenue (51st Street), (212) 661-7012; hm.com. The women's collection, designed byALBER ELBAZ, includes a one-shoulder dress in purple or hot pink with a puffed sleeve ($199) and a three-tiered ballerina dress with red tulle ($249). A black tuxedo jacket ($99) or a black evening coat with a fake-fur collar ($349) can go over the dresses. The men's wear collection by LANVIN'S men's designer LUCAS OSSENDRIJVER also has a tuxedo ($149), conceived for daytime, in a relaxed cut and worn with matching tailored jogging pants trimmed with grosgrain ($59.95). Separates include a three-button blazer ($149) and fine-knit cardigans ($69.96). ... When the designer TORY BURCH tweeted her dismay about the moment passengers remove their shoes in security lines, her fans responded that she should design a travel sock. The one-size-fits-all sock ($45), in her signature orange and navy, features no-slip grips and comes in a carrying pouch with gold Tory Burch hardware to clip onto your carry-on. Available at Tory Burch boutiques starting Friday or from toryburch.com.

BARBALATA--Milly (nee Comissiona), on November 16, 2010. Predeceased by her husband Dr. Victor Barbalata and brother Maestro Sergiu Comissiona. She loved music, travel, art, literature, and America. She leaves behind her daughter Jeanne Schayes, Esq., son-in-law Dr. Bernard Schayes, granddaughters Stephanie, Alexandra and Isabelle.

OWENS--Mary (Minnie) (nee Hanlon), died November 13th, 2010 at 104 years of age. Min came to New York from Kilkenny, Ireland at 17 and loved this city and especially the NY Times. It was her "best friend" because it educated and informed her. Her life will be celebrated by her family and friends on Thursday, 11am at Sacred Heart Church in Bayside. She has joined her husband Andy and son Jimmy (FDNY) in glory. She is survived by Thomas Owens and family, John Owens and family, Carol Owens and family, and Sr. Mary Anne Owens, SSND. Eight grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. She never met a stranger, who did not become a friend and her belief in God and city included volunteering, organizing, entertaining whoever and whatever built up the common good of all. Her legacy of love and service goes on for us all! In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Catholic Charities Endowment Trust, 9461LBJ Freeway, suite 128, Dallas, TX 75243.

They just don't make great movie lines the way they used to. They also don't make great Supreme Court passages the way they used to. FRED R. SHAPIRO, an associate librarian at Yale Law School and the editor of The Oxford Dictionary of American Legal Quotations. [A22]

The initial public offering of General Motors has been getting all the headlines and dominating the airtime on the financial news networks. But what about the other companies that are scheduled to go public on Thursday? There are several - and analysts say they are unlucky to have their initial offering at the same time as G.M.'s, which may end up being the largest in history, and certainly one of the most anticipated.

David J. Phillip/Associated Press The energy company Dynegy said Wednesday that it had postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group after the firm raised its bid in the face of opposition from two big Dynegy shareholders.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Hundreds of students angry at a proposed fee increase at the University of California staged a protest on Wednesday resulting in 13 arrests and injuries to several police officers. In one case, an officer drew a side arm after being struck on the head with his own baton, said Pete King, a spokesman for the university president, Mark G. Yudof. Mr. Yudof has proposed an 8 percent increase in student fees, a year after the Board of Regents approved a 32 percent increase. The 10-campus system has been squeezed by budget cuts , though it is promised a $370 million increase for the current fiscal year. It also faces a $21 billion gap in its pension and health programs.

HUEMER--Christina. The Trustees, Fellows and staff of the American Academy in Rome mourn the loss of Christina Huemer, beloved Drue Heinz Librarian Emerita, and spirited leader of the Arthur & Janet C. Ross Library for 15 years, who died November 12 after a long illness. The thousands of artists and scholars touched by her learning, creativity and curiosity will remember her forever. William B. Hart, Chairman Adele Chatfield-Taylor, President Christopher S. Celenza, Director

American taxpayers' ownership of General Motors was halved on Wednesday, and billions of dollars in bailout money was returned to the federal government, as a result one of the nation's largest initial stock offerings ever. The offering, which raised $23.1 billion, is bigger and more ambitious than had once seemed possible. But the recently bankrupt automaker will have to build on its revival for the government to recoup its entire $50 billion investment and validate the Obama administration's decision to keep G.M. from collapsing.

SHAW--Samuel P.,of Boston, Massachusetts, died peacefully on November 12 at Spaulding Hospital, Cambridge, at the age of 94. He was a graduate of Harvard College '39, and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. After serving in the Marines in WWII, he practiced law in Boston, New York City and Millerton, NY. Beloved father of Jane and Parkman, stepfather of Christopher Anne and Linda, and husband of the late Elizabeth Roberts Shaw. He is survived by his sisters, Eleanor S. Mittendorf, Joan S. Coburn, Gertrude S. Crittenden and Rosemary S. Blake, his four grandchildren, Sam, Ben, Casey and Jason; four great grandchildren, and numerous nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by family, friends and everyone who called on Uncle Sam when in need of wisdom or wit. Memorial service will be held at 11am on December 11, 2010 at the Church of Our Saviour, 25 Monmouth Street, Brookline, MA.

5:13 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs has selected 110 executives to become partners, one of the most lucrative tickets on Wall Street. Kelvin Koh, an oil and gas analyst, and Dina Powell, head of corporate engagement at Goldman and a former official in the last Bush administration, were among the 110. Dhruv Piplani, a trader, and Daniel Wainstein, a banker, also made the list.

DEUTSCH--Lawrence, passed away on November 15th in Sarasota, FL. He is survived by his wife Toby, his children Allison and Barry, his son-in-law Tim, his grandchildren Silas and Jemma, and his sister Marlene. Larry was born in Brooklyn in 1942 and married his high school sweetheart in 1962. An audiologist for decades, Larry was a leader among colleagues and an empathic doctor to his patients. In retirement, a passionate scholar and teacher of Judaism. A man whose energy was exceeded only by his generosity, Larry was much loved and will be missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:15am, Wednesday, November 17, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

A picture caption on Sept. 9 with The Scene column, about the author Jonathan Franzen, misidentified the author Zadie Smith shown with two other people at a party for Mr. Franzen. She was seated at the right, not in the middle. (The other two people were not identified.) The error was pointed out in an e-mail on Sept. 9. This correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow through on the complaint.

A French doctor accused of illegally leaking sensitive material about a clinical drug trial to a hedge fund manager will be held on $3 million bail, a magistrate judge said on Wednesday. The doctor, Yves M. Benhamou, will be placed on home incarceration and his bail must be secured by $1 million in cash or property in the United States as well, the magistrate judge, Frank Maas, said in Federal District Court in Manhattan. In addition, his bond will require three co-signers.

CALELLO--Paul. Columbia Business School mourns the loss of Paul Calello, a member of its Board of Overseers and a graduate of the MBA class of 1987. Mr. Calello was chairman of the investment bank and a member of the executive board of Credit Suisse Group and Credit Suisse, where he also served as CEO of the investment bank from 2007 to 2010. Mr. Calello's colleagues recently established the Paul Calello Professorship of Leadership and Ethics and the Paul Calello Fund for Research on Leadership and Ethics at Columbia Business School in his honor. Mr. Calello was a consummate friend to the School, and heartfelt condolences go out to his family at this time. Gifts to Columbia Business School in his memory can be made to the Paul Calello Scholarship Fund. For information, contact Lisa Yeh at 212-854-5359.

Massey Energy is officially in play. Massey's blunt-speaking chief executive, Don L. Blankenship, acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that the board of the coal-mining company is seriously considering takeover bids.

SZALITA--Dr. Alberta B.,the Polish born Jewish intellectual who became one of New York's most influential psychoanalytic teachers and theorists, died on Wednesday November 10, 2010. She was 100 years old. A survivor of the Holocaust, Dr. Szalita began her psychoanalytic work at Chestnut Lodge. Frieda Fromm-Reichmann has been quoted as saying that her first referral choice for a loved one in trouble would always be Alberta Szalita. She was a Training and Supervising Analyst at the White Institute and Columbia University. She helped to establish psychoanalytic institutes in Israel and Norway. Her writings include perspectives on empathy, reanalysis, schizophrenia, and psychotherapy, which she labeled psychointegration. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Sunday, November 21, 2010 at 11:15am. It will take place at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. The service will begin promptly at 11:15am. Attendees are urged to arrive no later than 11:00am.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the Playboy TV channel's plans to change its programming gave an incorrect identification from a publicist for the couple shown kissing in a scene from the coming program ''Brooklyn Kinda Love.'' They are Rhiannon and Vinny, not Braniff and Francis.

Updated, 6:10 p.m. | Wherever you find yourself in the city, there is probably an outdoor chess table nearby. According to the parks department, there are more than 2,000 public chess or checkers tables spread among 536 parks, offering the perfect spot to sacrifice a queen or promote a pawn. Unless, apparently, the chess tables are inside a playground.

STUDIED NONCHALANCE Selecting a scarf is the first step toward sartorial self-expression; the second is how it is tied. The Midnight-Blue Dark Green Tie-Dye Scarf from Bottega Veneta Boutiques ($390) is shown draped in a loose, deceptively casual way. Bottega Veneta, 697 Fifth Avenue (55th Street), (212) 371-5511; bottegaveneta.com. CLASSIC CHIC The Adams Stripe Scarf from Club Monaco ($149) is a jump on next season's Breton stripes. A traditional striped scarf tied in the tried-and-true manner (fold in half, center at back of neck; pull loose ends through the loop created by the fold). Club Monaco stores, including 6 West 57th Street, (212) 459-9863.

When the actress Carey Mulligan announced last night that Billy Reid had been voted the winner of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner for 2010 - in front of a crowd that included the designers Michael Kors, Olivier Theyskens, Jason Wu, Zac Posen and Alexander Wang; the ''True Blood'' stars Stephen Moyer and Anna Paquin; the ubiquitous Kim Kardashian; and the evening's co-chairwoman Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue - there was a brief, seemingly stunned silence, followed by a burst of enthusiastic applause and whoops and hollers from the back of the room, from which the 46-year-old designer shakily made his way toward the stage. ''I did not expect to be up here tonight,'' he said in an emotional voice. ''I'm shocked.''

Robotic cleaning devices, despite their veneer of science-fiction, are hardly new to the scene. IRobot has popularized the category with its Scooba floor washers and its Roomba robotic vacuums. Neato Robotics came onto the scene earlier this year with its XV-11 vacuum cleaner. A new contender, Evolution Robotics, believes that it has done the category one better. Its Mint hard-floor robotic cleaner combines a floor washer and dry sweeper into one device that, with the help of what it bills as GPS-like technology, figures out where it's been and what to avoid.

In another digital publishing experiment Houghton Mifflin Harcourt will publish 12 of Jose Saramago's novels - plus a novella - in an e-book collection for $36. ''In print, it would be unwieldy and expensive, but electronically, it is affordable and convenient,'' Bruce Nichols, the senior vice president and publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, said. ''Now readers can complement their Saramago print titles and discover some new gems they may have missed.'' Mr. Saramago, the Portuguese Nobel laureate, died in June at the age of 87. This e-book equivalent of a box set, titled ''The Collected Novels of Jose Saramago,'' will be available on Nov. 29, with novels including ''Blindness,'' ''The Gospel According to Jesus Christ'' and ''Baltasar and Blimunda,'' along with an introductory essay by Ursula K. Le Guin.

BELSON--Maxine. It is with profound sorrow that the Associated Builders and Owners note the passing of our " First Lady" Maxine, devoted wife of our President, Jerome. A woman of class and dignity she spent her life serving those in need. Her warmth and generosity will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies to her children, Brianne and Tad. Rest In Peace Michael Kerr. Co-chair Arnold Sollar. Co-chair Nicholas LaPorte Exec. Dir.

An Associated Press report in the college football roundup on Sunday misstated Columbia's record after its victory over Cornell on Saturday. Columbia is 4-5 over all and 2-4 in the Ivy League -- not 2-7 and 1-5. (That is Cornell's record).

An article on Tuesday about the Rangers' overtime victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins misidentified, in some editions, the Penguins defenseman whom the Rangers' Brandon Dubinsky outmaneuvered before making an assist on the winning goal. It was Paul Martin -- not Mark Eaton, who now plays for the Islanders. (Martin wears No. 7, as did Eaton last season.)

TREATING nutria as a kind of ''guilt free'' fur is tough when you're cutting the pelt and fur gets caught in your eyes. That's what Micha Michelle Melancon, a fashion designer in New Orleans, found out when she was making a cloak from what is commonly known as a swamp rat. ''This is an animal,'' Ms. Melancon said, after her work space became filled with fluffy piles of excess fur. ''A soft, furry, once-living-and-breathing being.''

BELSON--Maxine (Rogg) Adored wife, and devoted mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend died Sunday. She was 90 and lived in Brooklyn. During her active and vibrant life she was known for her profound care and help of others. She devoted her life to helping children and adults with physical and intellectual disabilities to achieve their maximum potential and pleasure to enable them to lead full and productive lives. Her boundless energy was evident when involved in countless philanthropic endeavors as a leader, organizer and benefactor. Among her many accomplishments she was especially proud of creating The Big E for Epilepsy and founding a free clinic at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for individuals with epilepsy. To raise money for the clinic she organized and led tours around the world. As a pioneer in promoting the independence of people with intellectual disabilities she helped create New Hope Community in Loch Sheldrake, NY - motivated by her son Tad, who was the light of her life. She was recently honored at the community by the naming of a facility she helped sponsor and fund called "Maxie's Place." She was an esteemed member of the St. John's University family and was an enthusiastic fan of the soccer team. The family funded the Belson soccer stadium on campus and the Maxine & Jerome Belson Moot Court at the university's law school. She was honored for her work with disabled children by St. John's University with their Medal of Honor and awarded a Doctorate of Pedeology by Niagara University. Her family was a great source of joy throughout her life. She was the adored wife of Jerome, her husband for 56 years. She was the devoted and loving mother of her son Tad; daughter Brianne and son-in-law Sanford; her predeceased son Michael and daughter-in-law Kathy; and daughter-in-law Marjorie. She was a beloved grandmother of Matthew and his wife Jodi; Joshua and his wife Katy; Jaclyn, Toby and Jonathan. She was also great-grandmother to Noah, Ariel and Paisley. Her love for her family was only matched by the love for her. She will be missed by the multitude of friends and family who were the beneficiaries of her care, love and sense of humor. She will not be forgotten. A graveside service was held. Lieu of flowers, those inclined to do so, may make a donation to the New Hope Community, a 503c charity located at: PO Box 289, Route 52, Loch Sheldrake, NY 12759.

Anyone who has prepared a Thanksgiving family dinner knows that the emotional minefield is laid long before the turkey goes in the oven. I speak of the annual quandary over whose recipe to use. Is it going to be Mom's pumpkin pie or your mother-in-law's? Either way, you risk offending half the family. That's reason to give thanks for apps like Allrecipes and Epicurious, which offer terrific recipes and bring a Swiss-like neutrality to the Thanksgiving kitchen.

SCHWINGER--Matthew Evan, MD. Born July 3, 1957, passed away in Los Angeles on November 11, 2010 at age 53, after a courageous struggle with pancreatic and liver cancer. Born in Brooklyn, raised on Long Island, a resident of Manhattan and then Encino, California for the past 18 years. Beloved husband of Nanette, devoted father of Mariel, Michael and Zachary, esteemed and respected cardiologist. He was taken much too soon. His love, kindness and dedication will be remembered by all who knew him. Services were held in California on November 14, 2010 at Mount Sinai Simi Valley. A memorial service in New York will be scheduled in the coming weeks.

An article on the Itineraries pages on Tuesday about expense account fraud by business travelers described incorrectly the allegations against Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, that led to his resignation last August. As reported at the time, the H.P. board criticized him for authorizing more than $75,000 in payments and expenses for an occasional contractor when the company's employees traveled under more austere conditions. The board did not allege that he falsified his expense reports.

CARESS--Robert S. Died November 16, 2010 at the age of 93. He lived a long life but died too soon. Preceded in death by Ruth, his beloved wife of 50 years, son Jeffrey, grandson Benjamin, brother Bernard, and companion Marcella Gilbert. Survived by daughters Barbara Caress and Jane (Herb) Bardavid, grandchildren, Jessica (Steve) Graff, David, Josh and Lucas, great-grandchildren Samantha and Carter. Also by sister Elaine and a loving and extended family. He never stopped fighting for his family and his community.

In a compromise of sorts with its television network parents, Hulu is lowering the price of its TV subscription service from $9.99 to $7.99 a month. The paid service, Hulu Plus, allows access to fuller catalogs of TV shows than the free, ad-supported Hulu provides. Hulu Plus was announced in June, and was made available more widely this month.The $7.99 price point makes Hulu Plus more competitive with Netflix, which streams films and some TV shows and mails DVDs for as low as $8.99 a month.

CALELLO--Paul. The Board, Musicians, and Staff of the New York Philharmonic mourn the untimely passing, on November 16, 2010, of our esteemed Board Member and friend. Always a warm and enthusiastic supporter of the Orchestra, Paul, at his death, was Chairman of the Investment Bank of Credit Suisse and a member of the Executive Board of Credit Suisse Group and Credit Suisse -- the New York Philharmonic's exclusive Global Sponsor. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife, Jane DeBevoise, and family.

GEWIRTZ--Tabitha D. Congregation B'nai Jeshurun mourns the loss of the mother of our beloved Senior Rabbi, Matthew D. Gewirtz. To her partner, Liz Menendez, to her children: Elizabeth Gewirtz (Jason Juriako), Matthew Gewirtz (Lauren Rutkin), Joshua Gewirtz (Neota), Rivka Gewirtz Little (Bruce), to her grandchildren (their adoring Bubby): Navah and Assata Little, Gabrielle Gewirtz, Jake, Natalia and Sadie Gewirtz, to her sister Wendy (Hartley) Spatt, and to all who were touched by Tabitha's magnificent spirit, unconditional love, brilliance, depth, courage and humor, we send our profound condolences. Funeral services: Thursday, November 18th, 11am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., in Manhattan. Eric S. Sellinger, President Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, NJ

''I did not expect to be up here tonight,'' he said in an emotional voice. ''I'm shocked.''

KHEEL--Theodore. Hunter College mourns the loss of a great visionary and distinguished public servant. We were fortunate to work closely with Ted who generously founded The CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities at Hunter College. We will miss his inspiration and friendship. Sincere condolences to Jane, Robert, and his entire family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College William Solecki, Director, The CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities

The Schwab YieldPlus Fund was supposed to be safe - ''a smart alternative for your cash,'' the pitch went. But like so many seemingly secure investments, the mutual fund plunged in value when the financial crisis struck - and the Charles Schwab Corporation is still struggling to contain the damage.

An article on Monday about a report by the Institute of International Education on the number of foreign students studying in the United States referred incorrectly to the significance of China's current ranking among countries that send the most students to the United States. China was the top country of origin for international students from the academic year 1998-99 until 2001-2002. The 2009-10 academic year was not the first time China was ranked No. 1.

ROSS--Grace Jarcho, died peacefully at home on November 15, three months short of her 98th birthday. She was the adored wife of the late Daniel G. Ross, brilliant, beautiful and beloved mother of Ann Ross Loeb, James Jarcho Ross and Lynn Ross Rosenfeld, mother-in-law of Michael Loeb, Laura Gore Ross and Edward Rosenfeld, grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of nine. A graduate of The Fieldston School, Smith College and the NYU Institute of Fine Arts. Funeral private. A memorial service will be held at a future date. No flowers please. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park West, New York, NY 10023.

An obituary on Wednesday about the astronomer Allan R. Sandage misidentified a university he attended. It is Miami University in Oxford, Ohio -- not the University of Miami. The obituary also misstated the name of a university his wife, Mary Connelly, attended. It is Indiana University, not the University of Indiana.

In an effort to become the world's most important repository for the work of the photographer Paul Strand, the Philadelphia Museum of Art announced on Wednesday that it is well on its way to acquiring Strand's entire output - a chronicle of his six-decade career. Although the museum already had one of the most complete holdings of Strand's work, now through a combination of partial and promised gifts from the Philadelphia philanthropists Lynne and Harold Honickman, Marjorie and Jeffrey Honickman and Gerry and Marguerite Lenfest, it has received 1,422 images from the Paul Strand Archive at the Aperture Foundation, which is based in New York.

THE semiannual Steven Alan sample sale features many of the designer's signature updated classics at prices at least half the original. On sale will be the cotton Charlton Dress (right) originally $225, now $89, and a men's waxed-cotton rain slicker that was reduced to $125 from $328. Wool cable sweaters, which were $348, are now $135. The sale will take place from Thursday through Sunday at 87 Franklin Street (Broadway). Thursday and Friday hours are 8:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., and Sunday 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.
7:37 p.m. | Updated The number of Americans who pay for television service has dropped for the second quarter in a row, the media research firm SNL Kagan said on Wednesday.

THE Sock Hop in NoLIta is a thoughtfully curated store of imports, heritage brands and basic socks, run by two brothers, Vincent and Ted Nasserbakht. They play vinyl records, display goods on old ladders and sell thigh-highs by Hansel from Basel ($40); patterned stockings by Falke ($56) and colorful, cashmere argyles by the British company, Pantherella (right, $62). The store has a machine on site to attach the required buttons to pants or skirts for its logger suspenders from Welch Suspenders Company in Oregon ($40); 248 Elizabeth Street (East Houston), (212) 625-3105.

Forget ''Love and Other Disasters.'' Forget ''Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow.'' Forget ''Running With Scissors,'' forget ''Iron Man''s 1 and 2, forget GOOP and forget that she named her first-born child Apple. To watch Gwyneth Paltrow on ''Glee'' Tuesday was like being transported back to the late 1990s, when she could do no wrong and to see her on a screen was a guarantee of a compelling performance (and maybe the possibility of seeing her decapitated head in a box). Whether she came onto ''Glee'' as a sweeps-week stunt, to again show off her pipes before the release of her film ''Country Strong'' or simply out of the kindness of her heart, Ms. Paltrow was perfectly suited to her role as Holly Holliday, a substitute teacher with a seriously reckless streak.

A return to boom-time dividends remains distant for bank investors in the United States. It's not just that the Federal Reserve is imposing strict criteria, including stress-testing their portfolios again, before financial firms can return more capital to shareholders next year. Dividends have also dwindled so badly that they already face a long slog back. Banks accounted for almost a third of all dividends paid by S.&.P. 500 companies in 2007. That has fallen to just 8.9 percent this year, according to Standard & Poor's. At $18.7 billion, the total expected to be disbursed by financial firms is only about a quarter of the payout three years ago. For the biggest banks the gap is even bigger.

''The Book of Mormon,'' the first Broadway musical from Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the creators of ''South Park,'' has found its Mormons. Josh Gad, a correspondent on ''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,'' and Andrew Rannells (''Jersey Boys'') will play Elders Cunningham and Price, ''a pair of mismatched Mormon boys sent on a mission to a place that's about as far from Salt Lake City as you can get,'' as described in a press release. Other cast members include Nikki M. James (''All Shook Up''), Rory O'Malley (''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee'') and Michael Potts (''Grey Gardens''). Additional casting is still to be announced.

Ab Ex now has its own app. In conjunction with its ''Abstract Expressionist New York'' exhibition, the grand tour through the Museum of Modern Art's holdings of (mostly) New York School masterpieces, the museum has just released its first application for the Apple iPad, which is rapidly becoming a museum-going staple. The app, which is free at Apple's store, includes images of 60 of the paintings, drawings and sculptures in the show, which can be navigated chronologically or by artist, from William Baziotes to Jack Tworkov. It includes a customized Google map that allows users to pinch and scroll around Manhattan and parts of Long Island for the sites where Abstract Expressionism was born and nurtured, from Barnett Newman's East 19th Street Studio to the Cedar Tavern. And it also includes 20 short videos featuring curators and other experts, along with a dictionary for the truly dedicated art patron of Ab Ex technical terms like emulsion and turpentine burn.

Bang & Olufsen has a proud tradition of high-design audio equipment. In the 1980s, nothing came close to the Danish company's sleek BeoCenter phonograph systems. (Nakamichi was in the running, but they followed a different aesthetic - chunkier, more brutalist than B&O's Modernist slickness.) There's another tradition at B&O, one the company may be less inclined to refer to: Charging obscene, Adnan-Khashoggi-amounts of money for fairly ordinary consumer products. This tradition includes (but is not limited to):

On the day the United States national team defeated 2010 World Cup host South Africa, 1-0, and Argentina beat Brazil by the same score in Qatar, FIFA released details of a report that finds fault with both the American and Qatari bids to host the 2022 World Cup. Technical advisers for international soccer's governing body said the United States bid needs stronger guarantees of federal government support and that the heat in the Qatari desert poses a health risk to players. (Perhaps the report should have also included a knock on the Qatar team's finishing abilities.)

Coming up with a tasty recipe for lasagna required lots of trial and error for Lance Johnson, who dreams of becoming a chef. ''You've got to mess it up a couple times before you get it perfect,'' Mr. Johnson, 36, said in a statement that could easily sum up the early part of his life.

GEWIRTZ--Dr. Alan M. The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society's Board of Directors, its Medical and Scientific Advisory Board and staff mourn the loss of Dr. Alan M. Gewirtz. Dr. Gewirtz first joined the LLS community as a clinical researcher in 1983. Since 1998, Dr. Gewirtz served as a valued member of the Board of Directors and the Medical and Scientific Advisory Board. As a former Chair on the advisory board, he utilized his expertise as a pioneer in the field of blood cancer to help LLS identify and select the most promising research worldwide. Dr. Gewirtz's major contributions and extraordinary generosity of time, talent and tenacious pursuit of our mission, helped patients with blood cancer live better, longer lives. It is with a heavy heart that we mourn his passing.

Is InterOil a great way to play Asia's commodity boom or a overhyped company worth a fraction of its $3.4 billion market value? In recent weeks, the debate has escalated over InterOil, a publicly traded exploration outfit drilling for natural gas in Papua New Guinea.

9:30 P.M. (Bloomberg) BLOOMBERG GAME CHANGERSJay-Z, above, has had more No. 1 albums on the Billboard 200 than Elvis Presley. As the head of a nearly billion-dollar enterprise, Jay-Z, born Shawn Carter, oversees interests in the record labels Def Jam and Roc-A-Fella, concert promotion, music publishing, Live Nation, artist management, clothing lines, real estate, sports bars and the New Jersey Nets. This program chronicles his life, from his early years in the public Marcy Houses in Brooklyn to drug dealing, to his career as a rapper and ascent as one of the music industry's biggest players, whose memoir, ''Decoded,'' was published on Tuesday. Among those interviewed are Russell Simmons, a co-founder of Def Jam; Lyor Cohen, chairman and chief executive of Warner Brothers Records; the music journalist Zack O'Malley Greenburg; the screenwriter Barry Michael Cooper; Jay-Z's childhood friends Jaz-O and Mr. Cee; and his grade-school teacher Renee Lowden. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Nigel Lythgoe, James Earl Jones and Vanessa Redgrave.

BARR--Carl. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Dear father of David (Liz) and the late Robin. Devoted grandfather of Jacob and Rachel. Services Friday, 11:15am at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Rego Park.
CHASEN--Ronni. My friend and mentor. Our awards season will never be the same. Annie Schulhof, NBR President

Update: Added calculations regarding the amount of data per minute was used when placing an VoIP call.Thanks to the wonder that is Voice over Internet Protocol, better known as VoIP, people have long been able to make phone calls from computers or, say, an iPod Touch. But a new iPhone case with a built-in 3G-to-Wi-Fi hot spot comes closest yet to turning an iPod Touch into a real phone. The case, called the ZTE Peel, wraps around a second- or third-generation iPod Touch to connect it to Sprint's 3G data service.

BAUM--Herbert, CPA, beloved husband of Ann (Whitehill), devoted father of Stuart and Jeffrey, father-in-law of Marleen and Rhonda, adored pop-pop of Ilysse, David, Jonathan, Raquel. Brother of Gladys Blumenthal and Marilyn Flom. Tireless worker for many charities. Services today 12:45pm "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

FORGET Nathan's and the Cyclone. For the last decade, determined fashionistas have been making the nearly hourlong pilgrimage to Lola Star Souvenir Boutique to indulge in the whimsical retail offerings of Dianna Carlin, a k a Lola. Now, a version of that Coney Island institution can be found in SoHo. The Lola Star SoHo Pop-Up Boutique (left) has opened in a 1,500-square-foot space, big enough to try out the pink leopard roller skates ($200) and the custom-made Hula-Hoops ($40 and up). On Tuesday I wrote about the LifeStraw Family, an in-home water purification device. The product itself is interesting, but what I wanted to highlight in the column is how its manufacturer, Vestergaard Frandsen, is planning to make money with it. Not from the poor families who use it - they will give it away in western Kenya. Instead, the company plans to be paid in credits they can sell on the global carbon markets. In this system, credits are awarded to projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. They may then be then bought by polluting companies or governments to offset their own emissions. LifeStraw Family users no longer have to boil their water to make it safe to drink. Less boiling means fewer emissions.

"Tiny Furniture" is Lena Dunham's breakout indie, a picture so promising that, after its debut at the South by Southwest film festival in March, it landed Dunham, 24, work on both an HBO series with Judd Apatow and a film project with Scott Rudin. Last week, Apatow was in the audience at the Museum of Modern Art for the premiere of "Tiny Furniture," and during a question-and-answer session afterward, he asked something of Laurie Simmons, who is Dunham's mother, both in the movie and in real life. Ah, Thanksgiving is almost upon us. We can look forward to a full belly, good wine, bad football and the worst travel day of the year. And in 2010, apparently, it will be the worst travel day in the history of mankind: "In the three weeks since the Transportation Security Administration began more aggressive pat-downs of passengers at airport security checkpoints, traveler complaints have poured in," reports The Times's Susan Stellin. "Some offer graphic accounts of genital contact, others tell of agents gawking or making inappropriate comments, and many express a general sense of powerlessness and humiliation ...It remains to be seen whether travelers approve of the pat-downs, especially as millions more people experience them for the first time during the holiday travel season."

"Ann Agee: Rules of the Pattern," at the Locks Gallery in Philadelphia until Dec. 30, offers a look at recent work by the artist, who is known for her playful, subversive treatment of traditional decorative porcelain archetypes, like blue-and-white patterns (which she has applied to ceramic sex toys, or an entire bathroom) or 18th century figurines (which she re-imagines in contemporary clothing, doing things like carrying shopping bags). In this show, Agee continues to give domesticity her own spin, in hand-painted and stenciled, large-scale "wallpaper drawings" that depict idealized interiors, and which allude to models as diverse as 19th century scenic wallpaper, Matisse's "The Dessert: Harmony in Red," and the spaces depicted in Roy Lichtenstein's paintings. Along with a display of intricate white porcelain vases, the exhibition includes three works that are groups of hand-made porcelain platters and bowls arranged on a steel armature. Traditional pieces like this are decorated with floral patterns or pastoral scenes, but Agee's depict modest domestic interiors, including everyday items like washing machines and stoves.

While Oregon, Auburn, Texas Christian and Boise State are firmly entrenched in the race for the national championship, there are a multitude of teams with one, two or three losses that still have plenty to play for. Ohio State has just one blemish on its record -- a loss to Wisconsin -- but it still has its eye on the Big Ten title and a Rose Bowl berth. The Buckeyes will need to win out, starting Saturday at Iowa, and get some help from the Badgers, but the goal is still a realistic one. Virginia Tech -- which began the season with two losses, including an embarrassing defeat at the hands of James Madison -- has won eight in a row and has its sights set on the A.C.C. title. Miami would love to give the Hokies their first conference loss. Nebraska is kicking itself for the egg it laid against Texas. If not for that, the Cornhuskers would be in the middle of the race for the national title. As it is, they will travel to College Station on Saturday to take on Texas A&M, which has won four in a row. Neither Arkansas nor Mississippi State is going to win the SEC, but both teams have enjoyed successful seasons. A win over the Razorbacks would get the Bulldogs to eight victories in their second year under Coach Dan Mullen. And, finally, there is Southern California, all but forgotten in the wake of the N.C.A.A. sanctions that followed the Reggie Bush mess. But Lane Kiffin has had the Trojans playing well of late. Now they will try to win at Oregon State, whose season has been a disappointment.

T's winter travel edition begins with a fairy tale, by way of a cover shoot in the snowy Swedish countryside. Then it's off to another kind of winter wonderland: the high-rolling peaks of Courchevel (where's there as much "ice" on the skiers as on the slopes). Ready for a thaw? There's serious surfing on Sumba Island, home to some of the world's best breaks and the ultimate eco-resort. For more beach time, we drop in on St. Lucia before heading to Rio, where the art scene is heating up. It's a season of pilgrimages, too: In the temples of Tamil Nadu, India, Guy Trebay partakes in bathing rituals that give a whole new meaning to taking the waters. In Taipei, the designer Jason Wu goes home looking for inspiration for his next collection. And in Los Angeles, Frank Bruni eats his way through what has become America's great food city. Wash it all down with the artisanal cocktails of Sydney, then sleep it off at the latest slumber spas. Plus: check into the hottest new hotels, from Buenos Aires to Bangkok.

At the government's request, the tribes that populate the remote Indonesian island of Sumba stopped hunting heads in the 1950s. Or at least that was what was supposed to happen. In reality, a head was lopped off in an intratribal war as recently as last March. ''We had to stop sending people on trips to the waterfall for months until things settled down,'' says Claude Graves, one of three Westerners living permanently on the island. Graves and his wife have spent the last 20 years building Nihiwatu, the most exclusive and lavish surf destination in the world. The hideaway resort draws ultrarich, über-athletic adventurers, who come to test themselves against a legendary wave and to be surrounded by one of the last Stone Age cultures on Earth.

The hardcover list has a double dose of Grant Morrison this week. The British writer takes on two of the biggest heroes published by DC Comics: Superman and Batman. In "All-Star Superman" Mr. Morrison took the Man of Steel, stripped him of years of continuity and came up with some ingenious adventures. This deluxe "Absolute" edition (at No. 4 on the list) reprints the 12 stories, illustrated by Frank Quietly, and includes bonus sketch material. In reviewing the second volume for The New York Times Book Review, Doug Wolk wrote, "Grant Morrison is one of the deftest superhero-comics writers of the moment." He added, "Nearly every visual detail and line of dialogue has some subtler implication or resonance that emerges on rereading."

On Thursday night, underneath the shabby opulence of a dozen or so sparkling chandeliers, mismatched and hanging at different heights from the ceiling of one of the ball rooms at the Pierre Hotel, an array of top models - Dree Hemingway, Siri Tollerod and Lindsey Wixson among them - wore one-of-a-kind versions of Alber Elbaz's new Lanvin for H&M collaboration, slinking, flirting and vamping down the runway in bright patterned tights, amazing costume jewelry and gowns made up of sexy mishmashes of bows, ribbon and poofy fabric. Set against the Pierre's rarefied setting, this didn't feel like fashion for the masses so much as an exclusive collection narrowed down to its more tarty elements. It isn't always clear exactly what brands dripping in luxury hope to get out of such dips into the more shallow end of the pool. But they clearly are getting something. And if there were any doubt, Anna Dello Russo, dressed in a hot-pink one-shoulder number, prancing under the bright lights with a poodle in tow, made things crystal clear: these were true Lanvin girls.

For her first artistic collaboration for the new brand Chance, the designer Julia Leach decided to work with the photographer Jarret Schecter, who is known for his documentary-style take on subjects as diverse as Romany Gypsies and the Russian countryside, shot from a trans-Siberian railway car. When Leach discovered his series "Stalking Paris," she says, she was struck by the mood of the photos, which dovetailed nicely with her aesthetic for Chance - a mix of classic design and modern graphics. Instead of showing the typical touristy side of Paris, Schecter created an almost abstract view of the city- he photographed people walking with umbrellas from above, the shadows of chairs in the Luxembourg Gardens and the Eiffel Tower in a layer of mist. "His photos capture a Paris that's not a postcard-perfect city," says Leach, who served as the longtime creative director for Kate Spade. "It's a raw Paris that shows history and modernity wrestling with each other." The prints will be available starting today at www.chanceco.com ($250 for each 17-by-24-inch unframed image from the limited edition of 250).

Jean-Luc Godard is one eminently quotable auteur. He said, "All you need for a movie is a gun and a girl." And "my aesthetic is that of the sniper on the roof." And also, "there is no point in having sharp images when you have fuzzy ideas." This last quotation, while less famous, is a roundabout way of introducing Scott Sternberg, ex-Hollywood talent agent, film nerd and serious Godard fan. Not only was Godard's 1967 film "La Chinoise" the inspiration for Sternberg's fall 2009 collection, but his fashion label's own name, Band of Outsiders, comes from the English title of Godard's canonical 1964 film "Bande à Part." Sternberg has himself shot all of the Band of Outsiders look-books with a Polaroid camera, which means he's probably willing to take Godard's axiom a step further: There's no point in having sharp images when you can have fuzzy ones.

The statue of Mars and Venus that greets visitors to the official residence of Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, is a striking example of classical Roman sculpture but to certain observers it seemed incomplete. Dating back to 175 A.D., the representation of Venus was missing one of her hands, and her companion, Mars, was missing the very feature that some might say made him such a manly god of war. But the work at Palazzo Chigi in Rome has been restored to anatomical completeness, The Guardian reported: Venus now has all of her digits and Mars was given a new penis. The Italian newspaper La Repubblica said Mr. Berlusconi had requested the restoration of the statue, but Mario Catalano, the prime minister's architect, told The Guardian, ''I took the decision.'' Mr. Catalano added that the replacement parts were attached using a magnetic system and were removable but declined to provide additional details. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Terence Riley, below, the former director of the Miami Art Museum, has been appointed chief curator for the 2011 edition of the Shenzhen & Hong Kong Biennale of UrbanismArchitecture. The appointment makes Mr. Riley the first non-Chinese curator for the event, which started in 2005. ''Our idea is to create a paradigm that considers the cyclical growth pattern of urban sites such as Shenzhen, where cities create architecture, architecture creates cities, and how this process continues without end,'' Mr. Riley said in a statement. Before leading the Miami Museum Mr. Riley was the chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. He is a founding partner of the architecture firm K/R.

Dynegy recessed its shareholder meeting on Wednesday. It did not adjourn the meeting. Nor did it postpone the meeting. It also illustrates how the mechanics of proxy voting can drive the course of shareholder votes, and how deal makers are struggling to keep up.

SMITH--Richard E.,64, of Williamsburg, Virginia, and Punta Gorda, Florida, died November 15, 2010, after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of the late Elizabeth Rose Lowrie Smith and Arthur B. Smith. Mr. Smith was President of NorthPort Advisors, Inc., an advisory firm providing insurance and reinsurance consulting services. He was also a Managing Director for Century Capital Management, a private equity firm in Boston, MA. Mr. Smith's expertise came from more than thirty years in the property casualty insurance and reinsurance business. From 1995-2003, he served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Zurich Reinsurance, Inc., and Converium Reinsurance, Inc., respectively, and was instrumental in their IPO's on the New York Stock Exchange. At Zurich Re, he sat on the Board since its inception as a public company, and subsequently oversaw the firm's privatization through its merger with Centre Reinsurance Company of New York. At Converium, he served on the boards of the US, German and Swiss operating companies. Mr. Smith served in Vietnam as a fighter pilot aboard the U.S.S. Coral Sea. He earned a Bachelor of Arts Degree from US International University in San Diego, California, and he was a Trustee Emeritus of The Children's Storefront, a non-profit, tuition-free school in Harlem. Mr. Smith's fondest memories were of his boat "Mr. Magoo" and fishing with his son Peter. He passes knowing that he lived a good life, had a wonderful wife and has no regrets. He is survived by his wife, Pamela Lee Smith of Williamsburg, Virginia; son, Peter Taylor Smith of Orlando, Florida; sister and brother-in-law, June and Richard Kershaw of Greenville, South Carolina; sister, Barbara Petriello of Coram, New York; brother, Arthur Smith of Worcester, Massachusetts; nephew, James Kershaw of West Chester, Pennsylvania and niece, Patricia Hallberg, of Severna Park, Maryland. A Memorial Service will be held in Williamsburg, Virginia, on December 6, 2010, at 1:00pm, and Wilton, Connecticut, on Saturday, January 8, 2011, at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Children's Storefront, 70 East 129th Street, New York, NY 10035, and Hospice House & Support Care of 4445 Powhatan Parkway, Williamsburg, VA 23188.

House Democrats on Thursday shot down a G.O.P. attempt to roll back federal funding to NPR, a move that many Republicans have called for since the public radio network fired the analyst Juan Williams last month. Republicans in the House tried to advance the defunding measure as part of their ''YouCut'' initiative, which allows the public to vote on which spending cuts the G.O.P. should pursue. But their push was blocked, 239 to 171, with only three Democrats voting with a united bloc of Republicans.

Because of an editing error, the Reuters Breakingviews column last Friday, about the deal-making of the private equity investor J. Christopher Flowers misstated the release date of ''Rock Me Amadeus,'' the only major hit in the United States by the pop star Falco, to whom Mr. Flowers was compared as a one-hit wonder. It was 1986, not 1980.

DEANE--Disque D.,died on November 8, 2010 in Boston, Massachusetts. He was one of the most innovative and creative financiers on Wall Street. One of Disque Deane's more prestigious accomplishments was his revolutionary approach to sale-leaseback transactions. He was a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1963 1978. In 1972, Mr. Deane and Andre Meyer restructured and financed Starrett City, a 5,881 unit model community in Brooklyn, New York. The community was restructured so that investors could benefit from a partnership that combined equity investments from private banks, state agencies and loans from federal housing authorities. The Community, opened in January, 1974, has its own shopping center, newspaper, power plant and security force. It is the largest and most successful affordable housing community in the United States. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Group and founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Corporate Property Investors, the largest private REIT prior to its acquisition by Simon Property Group in 1998. He believed in education and medical research. Mr. Deane supported primary and secondary schools as well as universities. He established the Deane Laboratories in Neurobiology at Duke University. Disque Deane was the Chairman of the Deane Institute for Integrated Research on Atrial Fibrillation and Stroke at Massachusetts General Hospital as well as a Trustee at the Linus Pauling Institute, Rockefeller University and Duke University. Mr. Deane was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and attended Duke University. He graduated from the U.S.M.S. United States Navy Officer Training School. He is survived by his wife, Carol and their two children, Anne and Carl, and his children by his deceased wife, Marjorie Schlesinger Deane: Marjorie Swain, Kathryn Deane, Disque Deane, Jr. and Walter Deane. He has seven grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A service will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11:00am on Friday, November 19. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Starrett City Community Fund for Scholarships. Please make donations to: Spring Creek Community Corp Scholarship Fund, Office of Public Affairs, Spring Creek Towers, 1310 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11239.

MATTHEWS--Philip J. of Bronxville on November 17, 2010. Beloved husband of Grace Matthews. Mr. Matthews spent most of his working career with Phelps Dodge Corp. Services by Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville 914-337-6770. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The International Myeloma Foundation, www.myeloma.org

BOEHM--Mrs. Helen F.,of Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully at home on Monday, November 15, 2010. She was Chairman of the Boehm Porcelain Studio in Trenton, NJ. The studio, which is still operating, was established in 1950 by Helen and Edward Boehm and is internationally acclaimed for the finest sculptures of porcelain birds, flowers and animals. Boehm Porcelains are exhibited in 137 museums and institutions throughout the world. Since it's founding, every American President has requested Boehm Porcelains as gifts to heads of state and foreign dignitaries. Mrs. Boehm's philanthropies include the Scheie Eye Institute, Philadelphia, PA, Sacred Heart School, Trenton, NJ, Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, PA, The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, Alexandria VA and Palm Beach FL, Girl Scouts of America and Children's hospitals nationwide. Mrs. Boehm is survived by three nieces, three nephews and many beloved and devoted friends. The family will receive friends from 2:00 to 4:00pm and 6:00 to 8:00pm Tuesday, November 23, 2010 at the M. William Murphy Funeral Home, 935 Parkway Ave., Ewing, NJ. Visit www.murphyfh.com. Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday November 24, at 10:00am at the Church of the Sacred Heart, 343 S. Broad Street, Trenton, NJ. Interment in St. Mary's Cemetery, Hamilton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Helen F. Boehm to The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children 9176 Alt. A1A, Lake Park, FL. 33403.

A man convicted of impersonating a New York University scholar in a debate over the Dead Sea Scrolls was sentenced on Thursday to six months in jail and five years' probation. The man, Raphael Haim Golb, was taken from a courtroom in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in handcuffs, after which one of his lawyers headed to the appellate division to ask that he be allowed to remain free pending appeal.

If you can't find your favorite comedian on tour or at the clubs in the months ahead, check to see if he's performing on Broadway. Dane Cook, the standup comic and a featured actor in films like ''Dan in Real Life'' and ''Mr. Brooks,'' has become the latest funnyman to enlist for a tour of duty of Broadway: he'll star opposite Josh Hamilton in a production of Neil LaBute's ''Fat Pig'' that is planned for the spring, press representatives for the show said on Thursday. This incarnation of ''Fat Pig,'' to be produced by Heather Provost and Aldo Scrofani, will not only mark the Broadway debut of Mr. Cook but will also be the first time Mr. LaBute has directed a show there. The play, which made its debut in a 2004 MCC Theater production at Off Broadway's Lucille Lortel Theater, tells the story of a young man who begins dating an overweight woman, and his obnoxious pal and an ex-girlfriend who question the relationship.

Cuomo, on Thursday of engaging in a kickback scheme involving the state's pension system. On the same day that Mr. Rattner was being celebrated on Wall Street for his role in turning around General Motors, he found himself embroiled in a bitter public battle with Mr. Cuomo, he settled similar charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission and he escalated a separate legal fight against his former investment firm.

Will Ferrell played an over-the-top newscaster in the Hollywood hit ''Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy.'' Now the comedian is back in the news, as he lost a big arbitration case against JPMorgan Chase. Mr. Ferrell, his wife, a business manager and a trust for another comedian, Larry David, filed an arbitration claim against JPMorgan in August 2008, asserting that the Wall Street bank ''engaged in unauthorized and unsuitable purchases'' of $18 million of preferred securities. On Wednesday, a three-member arbitration panel denied the claim and ordered Mr. Ferrell and the others to pay JPMorgan $600,000 in legal fees. And the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority arbitration panel, in a move that is highly unusual, also ordered the group to pay $22,500 for ''discovery abuse and failure to comply with the forum's discovery rules and procedures.''

FLORENCE, Ariz. -- When a suicide bomber entered an American military barracks in Afghanistan in February, it was not American soldiers but Afghan stray dogs that confronted him. Target and two other dogs snarled, barked and snapped at the man, who detonated his bomb at the entrance to the facility but did not kill anyone. The dogs were from the Dand Aw Patan district, in the eastern Paktia Province near the Pakistani border. One died of wounds suffered in the blast, and months later, Target and the other dog, Rufus, were flown to the United States by a charity and adopted by families. Target -- who received a hero's welcome, including an appearance on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' -- went to live with the family of Sgt. Terry Young, 37, an Army medic who witnessed the animals' bravery that night and helped treat the dogs and several American soldiers who were wounded.

CALELLO--Paul. Columbia Business School mourns the loss of Paul Calello, a member of its Board of Overseers and a graduate of the MBA class of 1987. Mr. Calello was chairman of the investment bank and a member of the executive board of Credit Suisse Group and Credit Suisse, where he also served as CEO of the investment bank from 2007 to 2010. Mr. Calello's colleagues recently established the Paul Calello Professorship of Leadership and Ethics and the Paul Calello Fund for Research on Leadership and Ethics at Columbia Business School in his honor. Mr. Calello was a consummate friend to the School, and heartfelt condolences go out to his family at this time. Gifts to Columbia Business School in his memory can be made to the Paul Calello Scholarship Fund. For information, contact Lisa Yeh at 212-854-5359.

BERGER--Professor Margaret. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Margaret A. Berger, a cherished member of the faculty for over 35 years. She was revered by her students and was widely recognized as one of the nation's leading evidence scholars. She was instrumental in shaping the Federal Rules of Evidence and did pioneering work in the field of scientific evidence. Her influence on lawyers, judges and scholars was legendary. She authored or co-authored more than a dozen books, and 35 law review articles. She received many awards and honors for her work. Margaret was an extraordinary woman and a beloved friend. We will miss her dearly, but her legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to her sons, Joshua and David, Class of 1989, and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, President Michael A. Gerber, Interim Dean

Sterns III, beloved by her grandchildren, Reed Merrill, Sara Shafer, William S. Sterns IV, Stefan Sterns, and Olivia Sterns, and by her great-grandchildren, Rebecca Merrill, Alexander Shafer and Catherine Shafer. The Civilian Complaint Review Board, which is supposed to have 13 members, has three openings. When they will be filled is anyone's guess. ''We do not know when they will be filled, but filling them is important,'' said Linda Sachs, a spokeswoman for the board, which investigates allegations of police abuse. ''Chairman Ernest Hart mentioned the need at our last board meeting on Nov. 10.''

An article on Nov. 11 about lax security in Ugandan government laboratories that house specimens of dangerous pathogens misstated the title and category of a book on the type of disease outbreak that experts fear could result from terrorist infiltration of such facilities. The book is titled ''The Hot Zone,'' not ''Hot Zone,'' and is a nonfiction thriller, not a novel.

The producers of Broadway's ''The Merchant of Venice,'' one of the few hits of the fall theater season, are talking to its stars - Al Pacino (Shylock) and Lily Rabe (Portia) - and others in the play about extending its run beyond the current closing date of Jan. 9, according to two people working on the production. ''Merchant'' received mostly rave reviews this month, and its star power and positive word-of-mouth have helped the box office grosses to exceed $1 million during some weeks, a very high amount for a play. Any production doing that well would look to extend closer to May, when Tony Award nominations are determined and shows still running tend to fare best. But Mr. Pacino, Ms. Rabe and several other cast members have other acting commitments and offers, so the ''Merchant'' run at the Broadhurst Theater was scheduled for only 78 performances.

CHIARA--Judith L. The Board of Directors of the Housing Symphony Orchestra expresses its deepest sympathy to the family of Judith L. Chiara. She gave unfailing support to the Orchestra. We will miss her very much. Janet Wolfe, Director and Vice President

An obituary on Nov. 11 about the conductor and violist Rudolf Barshai gave an outdated name for an ensemble of which he was music director. Although it had been known as the Israel Chamber Ensemble, its name had been changed to the Israel Chamber Orchestra by the time Mr. Barshai was hired.

(National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Marcy and Nicholas Razum met through a canine search-and-rescue program. Fourteen years later, their 12-year-old German shepherd, Nakota, is preparing to retire, and two puppies -- the year-old Neco and the 10-month-old Yona -- are in training to assume her duties. The problem is, they can't stop chasing their shadows. Cesar Millan helps them get serious about their mission. Elsewhere, he tries to save a snappish cocker spaniel named Justice whose pregnant owner, Chandra Fortier, is worried he will bite her baby.

Philip Carlo, who produced novels and nonfiction accounts of serial killers and hit men before writing about his own struggles with disease, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 61. The cause was a combination of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, and cancer, said his wife, Laura Garofalo-Carlo.

Two former employees of Bernard L. Madoff, including his onetime personal secretary, were indicted Thursday on fraud and conspiracy charges related to his multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme. The arrests of the two, Annette Bongiorno and JoAnn Crupi, bring to eight the number of people charged in the case.
Doctors and Medicare beneficiaries can breathe a sigh of relief, for at least one month.

Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers. The season is only three weeks old, but the compelling chemistry experiment known as the Miami Heat is struggling, at least in the eyes of some observers. Miami's 7-4 record puts it third in the Southeast Division, and the knee-jerk reaction by many has been to look for someone to blame. That person, based on numerous critical columns in the past week, is apparently Chris Bosh. But is Bosh really failing to live up to expectations? And is the Heat really struggling?

TOKYO -- Shifting its focus to faster-growing emerging markets, Ford will sell most of its longstanding stake in Japan's Mazda Motor, part of a push by the Detroit automaker to buttress its return to healthy profits. Ford has decided to cut its stake in Mazda to 3.5 percent from 11 percent, losing its standing as the Japanese automaker's biggest shareholder, Mazda said on Thursday in a statement. Based on Mazda's most recent closing price, the shares being let go by Ford are worth 31 billion yen ($372 million).

The inspector general of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told The Wall Street Journal recently that the agency had opened criminal investigations into about 50 banks that had failed since the financial collapse in 2008. While that makes it sound like prosecutors will soon be filing charges against a number of bank executives, do not hold your breath waiting for a flood of prosecutions. The last time there was a surge in bank fraud prosecutions was in the early 1990s during the savings and loan crisis that led to the collapse of nearly 1,800 financial institutions. Unlike that era, the number of bank failures has totaled 311 since 2008, and most of those were smaller institutions that got caught up in construction lending.

The first lady, Michelle Obama, led the children in jumping jacks at the Police Athletic League in Harlem on Thursday. Before the 20-minute workout, which included push-ups, Mrs. Obama lectured them on the importance of good nutrition and healthy living.

As it turns out, one of the biggest losers on Election Night wasn't a Democrat. It was Waco. A year ago, the Waco area had, in Representative Chet Edwards, a Democratic member of Congress with juicy assignments on the House Appropriations and Budget Committees. It had its own state senator in Kip Averitt, a Republican, and his portfolio was full, too, with the chairmanship of Natural Resources and membership on other key panels, including Finance and Education. And it had, in Jim Dunnam, the Texas version of (you have to squint for this one) Nancy Pelosi. Like her, he was the leader of the Democrats in the lower chamber, distinguished for years as the sharpest and most persistent thorn in the conservative paw. ''Dunnam'' is an epithet Texas Republicans use in their fund-raising letters.

General Motors returned to the stock market Thursday with a car show on Wall Street and a congratulatory message from President Obama, but the shares did not deliver a big surge above the price of the initial public offering. Shares in the nation's biggest automaker closed at $34.19 in heavy trading, a 3.6 percent increase over the $33-a-share price of its offering.

Cablevision Systems said on Thursday that it was considering a spinoff of its cable networks business, Rainbow Media Holdings, a move that would be another step in its strategy of focusing on the core business of providing cable television service. Such a move would immediately make Rainbow - whose properties include IFC; Sundance; and AMC, home of ''Mad Men'' - a prime acquisition target for entertainment companies looking to expand their cable network portfolios.

It's a Hitchcock ending without any unforeseen twists, murders or characters falling off Mount Rushmore. The Off Broadway production of ''Alfred Hitchcock's The 39 Steps,'' the stage play adapted from that classic 1935 suspense film as well as John Buchan's 1915 novel, will end its run on Jan. 16, press representatives for the play said on Thursday. The stage version of ''The 39 Steps,'' which enlists four dynamic, unfortunate, overworked actors to play the dozens of characters seen in the film, has been running at New World Stages since March 25, and will have played 23 previews and 318 performances there when it closes. Fittingly, the quick-change show arrived at New World after a frantic Broadway run that saw it move from the American Airlines Theater (where it opened in January 2008) to the Cort Theater to the Helen Hayes Theater, in a span of just over a year. It also endured some economically brutal months for the theater industry, and was at one point in 2009 the only nonmusical playing on Broadway.

My Sunday column is about charitable contributions, particularly by Christians, Jews and Muslims, that are well-intentioned but poorly thought out -- and thus not nearly as effective as they might be. Pat Burns, who coached the Devils to the 2003 Stanley Cup and was a three-time N.H.L. coach of the year, died Friday. He succumbed to lung cancer two months after his death was erroneously reported the morning of Sept. 17, the word spreading widely by Twitter.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - Second Sunday puzzles don't get enough respect, or at least enough attention. Acrostics, in particular, deserve a wider audience. Many regular crossword solvers I know regularly cross over to the next page when the Second Sunday puzzle appears. Maybe this incentive will help: the skills you hone on these puzzles will make you a better solver on the straight puzzles too. I know, I'm not talking about you or that throng whose biggest regret in life is that acrostics arrive but once a fortnight, but if you have a friend who could benefit from some congenial prodding, this is a good one to try. For one thing, it's all about food, and you don't have to be an EPICURE or a legendary chef like ESCOFFIER to appreciate that. Be sure to remind your friend that the puzzle is way easier if you do it on the computer.

RITTER--Burton, passed away Thursday, November 18, 2010. Born March 7, 1929 in New York City. A graduate of NYU and Brooklyn Law, he was New York City attorney for over 50 years and captain in the Korean War. He is survived by his wife Nino and sons David, Stewart and Michael. Funeral services Sinai Chapel in Fresh Meadows, NY, Sunday, November 21 at 11:30am.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) CRAZY HEART (2009) Jeff Bridges, above, in his Oscar-winning role, stars as Bad Blake, an aging country singer with a wayward streak, and Maggie Gyllenhaal is Jean Craddock, the small-town reporter in whom Bad finds inspiration, in this tale of second chances written and directed by Scott Cooper. ''Some of Mr. Bridges' peers may have burned more intensely in their prime, but very few American actors over the past 35 years have flickered and smoldered with such craft and resilience,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Neither blandly likable nor operatically emotional, this actor has a sly kind of charisma and a casual intelligence.'' The film ''owes an obvious debt to'' Bruce Beresford's 1983 drama ''Tender Mercies,'' Mr. Scott added, ''but there can never be too many songs about drinking, loving and feeling bad, and there is always room for another version of that old song about the guy who messed it all up and kept on going. Especially when that guy can play the tune as truly and as well as Mr. Bridges.'' 8 P.M. (CMT) CMT CROSSROADS: TRAIN AND MARTINA McBRIDE Train, which took a three-year hiatus from performing before releasing its fifth album, ''Save Me, San Francisco,'' in October 2009, and Ms. McBride, the four-time Country Music Association female vocalist of the year, take the stage before an invitation-only audience in Nashville. The playlist includes Train's hits ''Drops of Jupiter,'' ''Marry Me'' and ''Hey, Soul Sister'' and Ms. McBride's ''Broken Wing'' and ''Wrong Baby Wrong.''
