An article on the Personal Tech pages on Nov. 11, about keeping computers free of tracking programs, misstated what the acronym DOM stands for. It is document object model, not management. (The term describes a type of powerful tracking software, or ''supercookie,'' that can record data about a user's Web activities.)

MCCARTHY--Dr. Eugene G.,Jr., age 76 passed away at Sloan Kettering Hospital on Tuesday, November 16, 2010. The cause of death was cancer. Dr. McCarthy was born in Boston. His parents were Eugene G. McCarthy and Mary Murphy McCarthy. He graduated from Boston College, Yale University School of Medicine, John Hopkins University School of Public Health and School of International Medicine. President John F. Kennedy chose Dr. McCarthy to be the Chief Medical Advisor in the Alliance for Progress Program for Paraguay. From 1970 to 1977 he was Clinical Associate Professor of Public Health at Cornell University. In 1982, having assessed the acute need for a country wide resource enabling people to obtain a second opinion, he initiated the Health Research Unit at Cornell Medical University. Dr. McCarthy is known as the "Father of Second Opinion." His last honor was being awarded the Clinical Professor Emeritus of Public Health at Weill Cornell Medical College. He was medical advisor for a variety of local New York Unions. Eugene was predeceased by his wife, Maureen Goggin McCarthy, on September 3, 1999. Son, Joseph McCarthy, who was his oldest son, passed away at the age of twenty five. Brothers, Thomas and Frank McCarthy. Survivors include his two sons, John and Paul McCarthy. Three grandchildren, Anya, Matthew and Peter McCarthy. Brother, James McCarthy. Sisters, Marjorie Slien and Marie Ohman. As a result of their son, Joseph's death he and his wife established the Joseph Gregory McCarthy Foundation in coordination with the Franciscan Fathers who help the mentally impaired and homeless. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Foundation, 11587 Lost Tree Way, North Palm Beach, FL 33408. Visiting hours will be held from 4-8pm, Monday, November 22, 2010 at the Dolan Funeral Home, 460 Granite Avenue, Milton, MA 02186. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11am, Tuesday, November 23, 2010 at St. Ignatius, 28 Commonwealth Avenue, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts 02467. A wake will be held from 10 to 11:45am, Wednesday, November 24, 2010 at Simmons, Harrington & Hall Funeral Home, 975 Wiscasset Road, Boothbay, Maine. All are welcome to walk with the family to the graveside from the funeral home and a Rosary will be recited. Interment will be at 12:15pm at the Evergreen Cemetery in Boothbay, Maine. A celebration of Dr. McCarthy's life will be held at 5pm, Tuesday, November 30, 2010 at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128 with a reception in the Rochester Room to follow. You are invited to share your condolences, memories and photos with the McCarthy family by visiting their Book of Memories at: www.hallfuneralhomes.com. Services are entrusted to Simmons, Harrington & Hall, 975 Wiscasset Road, Boothbay, Maine.

The Securities and Exchange Commissionproposed rules on Friday that would require the registration of hedge funds and other private funds, the first such move regarding private asset pools since the passage of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul. There were few surprises for hedge funds. Many of the proposals had been largely spelled out in the financial regulatory bill, but the new proposals would place a level of scrutiny over firms that were previously subject to minimal oversight. The S.E.C. is hoping with the regulations to create a framework to both monitor the investment advisers and protect investors from fraud in a world largely unknown to the public.

Disque D. Deane, a financier and real estate investor who at one time controlled the General Motors Building, shopping centers in New York, Massachusetts and Georgia, and the nation's largest federally subsidized housing complex, Starrett City in Brooklyn, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Boston. He was 89. The cause was pneumonia, his nephew, Curt Deane, said.

SEIDELL--Herbert A.,on November 19, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Marguerite. Loving father of James R., Martin A., Herbert A., Jr. (Barbara), Christopher T. (Jeanne), and Patrick M. (Gloria). Survived by 15 grandchildren, one brand new great-grandchild, and dear friend, Jan Kerr. Proud WWII US Naval aviator, Knight of Malta, and Captain of the 1948 and 1949 Fordham Rams football team, coached by Vince Lombardi. Founder of North American Engineering Sales Division in 1972. Viewing will be held at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home in Garden City, NY on Monday, November 22nd from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Burial Mass on Tuesday at 10:00am at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, NY with burial to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hospice Care Network, Woodbury, NY (www.hospicecarenetwork.org) would be appreciated.

CALELLO--Paul. It is with profound sorrow that our family announces the death of Paul Calello on November 16, 2010, after a yearlong battle with cancer. Paul was the cherished father of Jin, David, James and Peter, adored husband of Jane DeBevoise, treasured son of Albert and Mary Calello, revered brother of Cathy Staples, Ann Groccia and Kristan Bishop, beloved brother-in-law of Alex Gibney and Anne DeBevoise, Charles and Andrea DeBevoise, Jim Staples, Al Groccia and Rick Bishop, idolized uncle of thirteen nieces and nephews, and deeply admired son-in-law of Lillie DeBevoise. Please no flowers. Donation possibilities include Columbia Business School and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, but everyone should also feel free to give to the charity of their choice. We will miss Paul deeply, but his spirit will be with us forever.

An article on Friday about a plan to cut 10,000 city jobs by 2012 referred incorrectly to cuts at one agency, the Department of Cultural Affairs. As a result of decreases in financing, there will be an estimated 193 layoffs of employees at museums and other institutions that receive money from the Department of Cultural Affairs; the 193 layoffs will not be of employees at that department.

An article on Friday about New York State's lawsuit against the financier Steven L. Rattner incorrectly characterized the payment that Mr. Rattner will make to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle allegations about his role in New York's state pension kickback case. Mr. Rattner agreed to disgorge $3.2 million related to the accusations and pay a penalty of $3 million; he will not pay a $6.2 million fine.

After the 18-year-old Saudi equestrian Dalma Malhas won a bronze medal in show jumping at the first Youth Olympic Games in Singapore in August, she was singled out for praise by Jacques Rogge, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, in a news conference at the Games' conclusion. ''This is indeed the first time that a Saudi woman is participating in an international event,'' let alone winning a medal, Mr. Rogge said of Olympic events. Ms. Malhas's achievement, he said, had made the I.O.C. ''absolutely happy.''

PARIS -- Not long ago, Roger Federer had no official coach. Now, intent on remaining a major force in the majors, he finds himself with two: Severin Luethi, his longtime confidant from Switzerland, and Paul Annacone, the former American player turned mentor who has worked with Pete Sampras and Tim Henman. Luethi, Annacone and Federer have been together since July, when Annacone, then still with the British Lawn Tennis Association, began working with Federer on a trial basis in Zurich. The trial became official before the United States Open in August, and Annacone, who is no longer with the British association, and Luethi have been sharing duties, e-mails, text messages and Federer's ear without evident rancor.

The hedge fund FrontPoint Partners will liquidate its $1.5 billion health care fund in the wake of allegations that a manager at the firm received insider information from a French doctor, a person familiar with the matter said. The fund has been hit with a number of redemption requests following federal criminal and civil charges that were filed against the doctor on Nov. 2. Court documents allege that the French doctor, Yves Benhamou, passed sensitive information about a clinical drug trial to a portfolio manager at the hedge fund, which has been identified as FrontPoint.

The hedge fund FrontPoint Partners will liquidate its $1.5 billion health care fund in the wake of allegations that a manager at the firm received insider information about a clinical drug trial, a person with knowledge of the matter said Friday. The fund has been hit with a number of redemption requests since prosecutors on Nov. 2 accused a French doctor, Yves M. Benhamou, of passing sensitive information to a portfolio manager at a hedge fund, which has been identified as FrontPoint.

Last year, as part of the stimulus package, Congress nearly doubled the maximum amount workers could deduct from their paychecks, before taxes, to apply toward monthly mass transit commuting costs. That meant rail and bus commuters could deduct the same amount each month as commuters who drive and pay for parking. But if Congress doesn't act soon, the increase for mass transit riders to $230 a month is set to expire at the end of the year, and the benefit will return to $120 a month.

The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed regulations on Friday that would require the registration of hedge funds and other private funds, the first such move regarding the private asset pools since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act on financial regulation. There were few surprises for hedge funds. Many of the proposals had been largely spelled out in the financial regulatory bill, but the new proposals would place a level of scrutiny over the firms that have previously been subject to minimal oversight. The S.E.C. is hoping these regulations will create a framework to both monitor the investment advisers as well as protect investors from fraud in an world largely unknown to the public.

In 1989, after the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company closed its landmark $25 billion buyout of the food and cigarette giant RJR Nabisco, it swiftly moved to sell its food brands. Among the first sales was Del Monte, which K.K.R. offloaded to a group of private investors. More than two decades later, Del Monte is back on the private equity carousel, and K.K.R. is interested in scooping the company back up.
8 OHIO STATE at 20 IOWA; 3:30 p.m., ABC*; ----;A chance for the Buckeyes to prove that they (and not Wisconsin) belong in the Rose Bowl.
London Taking America's M.L.S. Cup final outside of the United States for the first time might seem to be a bold piece of business, or a journey too far.

Leading money managers and mutual funds have a message for Washington: We may be big - but we aren't too big to fail. The Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law requires the newly created Financial Stability Oversight Council to identify specific nonbank financial firms - mutual funds, hedge funds, private equity shops - that pose a systemic risk to the financial system. Big bank holding companies like Citigroup and Goldman Sachs have already been designated as ''systemically important.'' The council has begun looking at nonbank financial firms and will propose criteria by next year.

The painkilling drug propoxyphene, sold under the Darvon and Darvocet brands and used by about 10 million Americans last year, will be removed from the market because of serious heart risks, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday. The announcement ended a 32-year dispute over the safety of the 53-year-old drug. The F.D.A. recommended doctors switch patients to other painkillers, notably Extra Strength Tylenol or acetaminophen.
An obituary on Friday about Nathan Oliveira, a leading Bay Area artist, misspelled the last name of one of his daughters. She is Lisa Lamoure, not Lamour.

St. Ann's Warehouse, the Dumbo-based theater best known for presenting work from the Wooster Group and other downtown favorites, has been conditionally designated by the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation to become the primary tenant of the Tobacco Warehouse, located across the street from the theater's current home. Last year St. Ann's began a search for a new space after the New York City Councilapproved a development project for Dumbo that would turn the 14,000-square-foot theater into an apartment complex and middle school. The announcement of the move was made on Thursday by St. Ann's and Brooklyn Bridge Park, a nonprofit organization responsible for the 85-acre waterfront park along the East River shoreline.

Lollapalooza began in 1991 as a summer package tour, solidifying the idea of alternative rock as a commercial format. In 2005, it was reborn as a weekend event in Chicago. And next year Lollapalooza will begin its next phase, with a branch of the festival opening in Santiago, Chile. Lollapalooza Chile will take place on April 2 and 3 at O'Higgins Park in Santiago, and will be produced by Perry Farrell of Jane's Addiction, who founded Lollapalooza, along with Lotus Producciones, a Chilean promoter, with the William Morris Endeavor agency and C3 Presents, the promoter behind Lollapalooza's reinvention in Chicago.

Usually an Off Broadway theater company trumpets its production starring an Academy Award winner. But not so the Culture Project with its production of Colin Greer's play ''Imagining Heschel,'' running through Nov. 28 at the Cherry Lane Theater and starring Richard Dreyfuss (a 1977 Oscar winner for best actor in ''The Goodbye Girl'') as the prominent 20th century Jewish theologian Abraham Heschel. The Culture Project has canceled the opening night for the production, which began performances on Nov. 4, and has asked theater critics not to review the show, which imagines what was said during years of conversations between Rabbi Heschel and Cardinal Augustin Bea as they worked to improve Jewish-Catholic relations.

A chart with the continuation of an article on Thursday about General Motors' initial stock offering erroneously attributed a distinction to the offering. While it was the largest initial stock offering, at $23.1 billion, it was not the largest stock offering ever. That distinction is held by Petrobras, which sold $69.8 billion in new shares in September.

The remaining contestants had endured the usual round of criticism that punctuates every episode of NBC's ''The Apprentice'' when Donald J. Trump, the show's boardroom master, announced the prize reserved for the leader of the night's winning team: ''You're going to be meeting with a true business icon, Cathie Black.''

Is the Allman Brothers Band ready to end its rambling and return to the Beacon Theater? The hard-livin' Southern rock act was a mainstay at the Beacon, where its residencies at that Upper West Side concert hall had become an annual New York tradition and where the band played 190 shows over the past 20 years. In January the band announced that it had lost its home away from home to the Cirque du Soleil show ''Banana Shpeel,'' and would instead move its residency to the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights. (At the time, Gregg Allman, the band's co-founder and longtime lead singer, calmly remarked, ''It's a drag, but one monkey don't stop no show.'')

An ice skater discussed fashion design. Drag queens strolled sedately among suited men. A porn star spoke of his insecurities, and a tattooed woman gyrated against a Buick sedan parked in the middle of the party. Out magazine's 16th annual Out 100 event, a celebration of people who have influenced the gay population, held on Thursday night in Chelsea, was a mash-up of the staid and the sensational. Stars of the magazine's December-January issue in honor of the ''100 Influential Men and Women Who Inspired, Shaped, and Changed Our World in 2010,'' according to a press release, fielded reporters on an L-shaped red carpet in the lobby of Frank Gehry's IAC Building. The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, rubbed elbows with reality television stars from ''The A-List,'' and guests like Calli Carvajal, a tattooed hairdresser, clambered on and into high-end Buicks parked on display.

When you want to sell a used good, figuring out how much to sell it for can be a laborious process involving checking multiple sites and sources online. Enter WorthMonkey. The site, a little over month-old, aims to do the secondary market pricing work for both sellers and buyers and present them with what it believes is the fair price.

Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the troubled Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' is being sued for more than $5 million by his former employer, Live Nation Entertainment, over what that company says are violations of the deal they struck when he left in 2008. Before his turn as a Broadway producer Mr. Cohl, 62, had a long career as one of the most powerful rock promoters in the business and is often credited with creating the big-ticket mega-tour for acts like U2 and the Rolling Stones. He joined Live Nation, the giant concert and ticketing company, in 2007 and became its chairman and largest shareholder but he was forced out in a power struggle a year later.

MORITZ--Hella. World Jewish Congress mourns the loss of its longest serving colleague, esteemed and beloved friend, Hella Moritz, who passed away in Sao Paulo, Brazil on Wednesday at the age of 81. For 45 years, until the end of 2009, Hella served as chief secretary under World Jewish Congress Presidents Nahum Goldmann, Philip M. Klutznick, Edgar M. Bronfman and Ronald S. Lauder. She served WJC in Paris, Geneva and New York, and met with countless heads of state and all Israeli Prime Ministers since the founding of the State of Israel. Hella spoke eight languages fluently, had an extraordinary memory, a peerless anthology of Jewish jokes and a good sense of humor and was always discreet, respectful and good natured. Hella will be deeply missed by the entire WJC family. We pray that her entire family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. May her memory be for a blessing. Ronald S. Lauder, President Michael Schneider, Secretary General

WASHINGTON - Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday named Representative Steve Israel of New York to lead the House Democratic campaign committee into the next election, putting him in charge of the party's effort to regain the majority it lost in November. Mr. Israel, 52, a moderate who represents portions of Long Island, would succeed Representative Chris Van Hollen of Maryland. Republicans picked up at least 61 House seats in this year's midterm elections, knocking off many Democratic incumbents, some in swing and Republican-leaning districts.

Nearly two years after Citigroup was outfoxed for the troubled Wachovia Corporation, Citi is walking away with an unexpected prize: a $100 million check from Wells Fargo to resolve claims that it had unfairly wrestled Wachovia out of Citi's hands. The settlement, reached Friday, ends the bitter legal sparring that began just hours after Wells Fargo made a stunning middle-of-the-night bid for Wachovia in October 2008, days after Citigroup announced that it had a deal. Although Wells Fargo's offer ultimately prevailed, Citigroup mounted an aggressive fight to recover as much as $60 billion in damages - and to change the public perception that it had bungled one of the watershed deals of the financial crisis.
In the wake of the devastating earthquake, Haitians are experiencing new guilt, new expenses, new worries, new opportunities, new risks. And enduring grief.
The cone beam CT scanner’s popularity has grown in part from misinformation about its safety and efficacy.

On sale for about a week, "Of Thee I Sing," President Obama's 31-page children's picture book, an ode to 13 inspirational Americans written as a letter to his daughters, Malia and Sasha, is already on the best-seller lists on Amazon.com and BN.com.

One of the more "awww"-inspiring YouTube clips making the rounds this holiday season is "How to Wrap a Cat for Christmas," a quasi-instructional clip in which a man gently encases his patient tuxedo cat, Flippy, in Santa-themed paper.
Does it really matter what camera Damon Winter used to make these beautifully composed images? I don't think so. It's the images that are important.

TORONTO -- Hours before Major League Soccer will crown a new champion, the commissioner of the league announced a number of changes, including fundamentally altering the playoff format and a potential move away from a summer schedule to an international calendar similar to the one followed by soccer leagues around the world.

An interception with a second left seals it for the Eagles -- Eli Manning's third pick and fourth turnover tonight. The Giants may have trouble deciding what to focus on tomorrow. Will it be the fact that the Eagles dominated them in the first half? Or the fact that they showed some grit, overcame that and took the lead when Philadelphia put the game on a platter for them by missing chances to pad its lead? Or will it be the fact that, once they had the lead, they threw it away by blowing their defense on a fourth-and-1 and giving up a 50-yard touchdown run? And then kicked away their final chance with three -- three!! -- turnovers in the closing minutes, including two on one drive? That will be for them to chew over in the postgame. Feel free to weigh in with your comments, and thanks for reading.Pregame: Live coverage and analysis of the Giants' game against the Philadelphia Eagles at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia. Both teams are 6-3, but the winner will emerge in the driver's seat in the N.F.C. East.

6:47 p.m. | Updated The American International Group is shopping around its rail-car unit, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Sunday. The move would be part of the insurer's effort to sell noncore businesses to pay down its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout.

It has been a whirlwind year for Clayton Kendrick-Holmes. His Maritime College team went 10-0 in the regular season. He was named the conference coach of the year. He became friendly with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Today's constructor, David Poole, brings us four slang terms for money that each happen to be a kind of food that each happen to have a variety identified by a prefixed location name. So, for example, that Manitoba meal money would be CANADIAN BACON.

7:48 p.m. | Updated The Mets have chosen Terry Collins, their minor league field coordinator, as their new manager, according to three baseball executives who have been briefed on the subject. Struggling under 4.8 billion euros in debt, Prisa, the largest media company in Spain, is hoping shareholders will support a plan to return it to financial health this week by approving a shift from family ownership to control by a group of financiers, hedge funds and investment banks, Raphael Minder of The New York Times reports.

Megan Taber, a teacher at Culbreth Middle School in Chapel Hill, N.C., was taken by the instant gratification. She leads her students through a writing exercise at the beginning of each class, as they respond to a question she writes on a blackboard. In the past, they used notebooks that she would collect periodically. Then her school began using iPod Touches in class. Ms. Taber changed the routine so that the students submit their writing directly to a spreadsheet on her computer over a wireless network. She now responds to the work within minutes instead of weeks.
The Air Force accidentally sent each bidder for an aerial tanker contract sensitive data about the other’s proposal, Pentagon officials said.

Quinn has spent 34 years as a wildlife artist and curator for the American Museum of Natural History, and has led field expeditions to places as wild and varied as The Galapagos Islands, Antarctica, Egypt and the Bering Sea. Travelers to Seattle and certain other cities may want to make every effort to find and use their own bank's A.T.M. Why? Banks in Seattle and certain other cities on average charge noncustomers higher A.T.M. fees than the national average, according to a recently released Bankrate.com survey covered more generally in a recent Bucks post.

Some readers may recall that back during the Democratic primary Barack Obama shocked many progressives by praising Ronald Reagan as someone who brought America a "sense of dynamism and entrepreneurship that had been missing." I was among those who found this deeply troubling -- because the idea that Reagan brought a transfomation in American dynamism is a right-wing myth, not borne out by the facts. (There was a surge in productivity and innovation -- but it happened in the 90s, under Clinton, not under Reagan).

WASHINGTON -- North Korea showed a visiting American nuclear scientist earlier this month a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium, confronting the Obama administration with the prospect that the country is preparing to expand its nuclear arsenal or build a far more powerful type of atomic bomb. Whether the calculated revelation is a negotiating ploy by North Korea or a signal that it plans to accelerate its weapons program even as it goes through a perilous leadership change, it creates a new challenge for President Obama at a moment when his program for gradual, global nuclear disarmament appears imperiled at home and abroad. The administration hurriedly began to brief allies and lawmakers on Friday and Saturday -- and braced for an international debate over the repercussions.

MORITZ--Hella. World Jewish Congress mourns the loss of its longest serving colleague, esteemed and beloved friend, Hella Moritz, who passed away in Sao Paulo, Brazil on Wednesday at the age of 81. For 45 years, until the end of 2009, Hella served as chief secretary under World Jewish Congress Presidents Nahum Goldmann, Philip M. Klutznick, Edgar M. Bronfman and Ronald S. Lauder. She served WJC in Paris, Geneva and New York, and met with countless heads of state and all Israeli Prime Ministers since the founding of the State of Israel. Hella spoke eight languages fluently, had an extraordinary memory, a peerless anthology of Jewish jokes and a good sense of humor and was always discreet, respectful and good natured. Hella will be deeply missed by the entire WJC family. We pray that her entire family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. May her memory be for a blessing. Ronald S. Lauder, President Michael Schneider, Secretary General

Lean, tattooed and hunky in the way of a young Henry Rollins, Brian Reaume is living the life of a gay indie Brooklyn or Bay Area artist. He lives in what real estate agents call a ''transitional'' neighborhood, in a house filled with midcentury furniture and quirky art by him and his friends. In a small shop on a funky strip of cafes, bars and galleries, he sells his paintings along with the vintage housewares that he collects with the shop's co-owner, Nancy Carlson, who lives upstairs. Two years ago he created ''There's No Truth in Silence,'' an installation in his studio -- which is among a warren of artists' spaces in an old warehouse -- that drew thousands one weekend with its controversial use of the American flag, a swastika, a cross and a chair emblazoned with the word ''fag.'' But the life that Reaume leads isn't in Brooklyn or San Francisco. His tatty-cool neighborhood isn't Bushwick or the Tenderloin; it's Kenmore Park in northeast Columbus, Ohio, in, as he put it to me on a recent visit, ''a very good pocket in the middle of the ghetto.'' And that funky strip with his shop, Birchwater Studios, is North High Street in Columbus's Short North, which has gone from sketchy to stylish in the past 15 years.

SPALDING--L Murray, 66, passed away November 8th at her home in Washington, DC of complications due to cancer. She was born January 30, 1944 in Louisville, KY to Margaret Rodman Murray and J. Greig Spalding. Murray was a dancer, choreographer, educator and presenter of dance for over 35 years. Mentored by the dance pioneer, Bessie Schonberg, she received her BA and MFA in Dance from Sarah Lawrence College. She founded Murray Spalding Dance Theater in 1974. Her repertory of over 40 works have been performed in the US and Mexico. Since 1997 she focused on creating a series of minimalist, ethereal Mandalas, "movement mediations that occupy a place between prayer and performance," that she continued until the time of her death and that her company performed in numerous venues. Murray received numerous prestigious artistic grants during her career, from such notable organizations as the NEA, the DC Commission for the Arts, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Andy Warhol Foundation, and in 2002 was awarded a New York Foundation for the Arts Artists' Fellowship. She is survived by her husband James F Bleakley, four step-children: Forrest, James, Brittin and Silas Bleakley, a sister Greig O'Dea as well as extended family, friends and dancers who will miss her inspiration. A memorial service will be held in Washington, DC at Grace Church, Georgetown on January 15, 2011 at 4:00pm with a reception to follow at the Church. Contributions in lieu of flowers, may be sent to the attention of Ms. Jill Barkan, Development Department, New York Presbyterian Hospital, directed to the research of Dr Robert Fine, 654 W. 170th St, New York, NY 10032. A graveside service will be held in Louisville, KY at Cave Hill Cemetery at a later date.

AVID travelers are notoriously hard to buy gifts for. They seem to want only things that will make their trips easier or their luggage lighter, even though they already have the perfect suitcase and the best noise-canceling headset. You can try finding something luxurious, but beware those Ghurka luggage tags for your backpacking sister-in-law or that elegant swivel-lid alarm clock that weighs a ton. It doesn't help that every holiday, these hard-core travelers who have been everywhere and done everything one-up your gift with something cooler brought back for you from one of their exotic trips. Remember that Masai beaded necklace from Tanzania you get so many compliments on?

FRAM--Audrey (nee Sandler), passed away in New York November 18. Born in Baltimore July 25, 1927, educated at Goucher College and Columbia University. Survived by her sons Robert (Jeanne) and Jonathan (Leslie) and her adored grandchildren, Nick, Sarah, Claire, Timothy and Stanford. Services will be held on Sunday, November 21 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 1:00.

One recent, drizzly Sunday, I met the artist Vik Muniz at his Ipanema home to drive from Zona Sul, the beachy, bathing-suited Rio of Copacabana lore, to the less renowned poorer part of the city in the north. As we whizzed up Avenida Brasil through an area called Mare, Muniz indicated a cluster of favelas arrayed around a public pool called Piscinão de Ramos and quipped, ''You have to think of Rio as St. Tropez -- surrounded by Mogadishu.'' Muniz, who splits his time between New York and Rio, sited his studio in a grim northern barrio called Parada de Lucas, in order to be next to the city's largest junkyard. The proximity allows Muniz, who creates work from found objects, to prowl the premises with abandon. His studio recently appeared in ''Waste Land,'' a documentary that charted his collaboration with a group of poor catadores, or garbage recyclers, from nearby Jardim Gramacho, Rio's biggest landfill. After drawing classically styled portraits of catadores, Muniz recruited them to help recreate the original drawings with enormous collages composed of painstakingly arranged buckets, nuts, bolts, old refrigeration units, tractor pieces, chunks of plastic and so on, spread out all over the studio floor. Shot from high above, the junk collages became a series of photographs in 2008 that traveled around the country and drew half a million visitors. The photographs were sold at auction and collected by museums around the world. The garbage pickers got to watch their bodies become art, then junk, then art, then money.
FARRLOW--Lucille, November 15. Devoted to Disabled American Veterans. May she rest in peace.

''We told children to think about how pictures tell a story like in fairy tales,'' says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni about the latest chapter in her ongoing project to help underprivileged children. ''We hoped to stimulate their creativity and make something that could be sold with the proceeds going back to bettering their hospitals and schools.'' The three resulting tote bags feature vintage Marni prints on one side and drawings by children from East Asia and South America on the other. Eighty percent of the proceeds will go to children's developmental programs geared toward learning and creativity. ''It seemed like the natural thing to do around the holidays,'' adds Castiglioni. ''To celebrate the innocence of a child's imagination.'' The bags are $175 at Marni boutiques and Marni.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

STELLA--Concetta (Connie, Etta) A. Passed away November 17th, 2010. Etta lost her battle with cancer quietly on Wednesday Morning, she was a former Hospital Administrator at NYU and later Corinthian Diagnostic Radiology. In her later years she was studying to become a Episcopalian Minister, her illness prevented her from completing her studies. She lived in Florida and New York and while in Florida volunteered at the Women's prison in Miami working with inmates. She is survived by Marie Stella, Fred and Roseanne Stella, Rochelle Stella, and JoAnn and Daniel Baldwin. Her nieces and nephews who she loved unconditionally, and the latest in a great star line up, her first Great Nephew. Etta will be missed, but her memory will always be alive in all of us. Services will be held on Monday, November 22nd at 2:00pm, The Little Church Around the Corner, One East 29th Street, New York City. Her ashes will be interned at the Church of Good Sheppard.

MANTON--A.J.F. (John). A global marketing executive for Avis Rent-A-Car from 1967 through 1982, died November 16th in New York from melanoma, according to his wife Ruth. He was 77 years old. Born in Abergele, North Wales, John Manton was schooled in the UK, joined the first class of the original Outward Bound, and was an Honors graduate from the Royal Naval College, HMS Conway, where he received the King's Gold Medal for Outstanding Achievement. In 1971 he was chosen as Class Valedictorian at Williams College in the US, where he did graduate work. Mr. Manton's work experience included positions at Nestle, Unilever, the Orient Line and the Royal Mail Line prior to his joining Avis, where he oversaw the company's global marketing initiatives in addition to serving as a member of the Office of the CEO. After leaving Avis, Mr. Manton started an international consulting business to establish and market foreign brands in the US. He also served on the Board of Directors, Travel Industry Association of America (USTA) and was a member of the American Society of Travel Agents (ASTA); the Pacific Area Travel Association (PATA); and the British Institute of Marketing. Following his retirement, Mr. Manton joined the US Coast Guard Auxiliary's Long Island division, where his contributions were recognized with citations, among them The Achievement Medal for Superior Performance of Duty, awarded in July 2007 when he rescued a man from drowning. John Manton is survived by his wife of 37 years, Ruth; her two children, Keith and Kyle McCarthy; a sister, Marjorie Sadler; three nephews; and a grandson.

There's no rest for the weary these days, at least if the number of spas offering ''guided sleep'' treatments is any indication. Yelo Spa (above; yelonyc.com) in New York City is adding targeted power naps to its menu for ailments like jet lag, stress and hangovers. The Desert Dreams Massage at Red Mountain Resort & Spa (redmountainspa.com) in Utah and the Dreamweaver Massage at the Hard Rock Hotel's Rock Spa (hardrockhotelsd.com) in San Diego both promise to bring you to a trancelike state. And for a holistic approach, the Lodge at Woodloch (thelodgeatwoodloch.com) in the Poconos will hold the Dreams as Oracle seminar from Jan. 28 to 30, in which participants are put through a regimen of sleep-inducing spa treatments, sessions with a dream coach, hydro-massage waterfalls and drumming. But then, if you're so sleep-deprived that ''you go spend $150 on a massage, you're pretty far along,'' says Dr. Bradly Jacobs, a director of the wellness program at the Cavallo Point Lodge spa (cavallopoint.com) outside San Francisco, which treats sleep problems with hypnotherapy and acupuncture. ''Go ahead and see a doctor anyway.'' HOLLY SIEGEL

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Image Rights vs. Free Speech in Video Game Suit,'' Nov. 16: It is true that tension exists between freedom of expression and a college athlete's desire to keep video game manufacturers from capitalizing on his or her image without permission or compensation.

Walter Isard, an economist who founded the field of regional science, inspiring social scientists to study the relationships between such factors as geography, migration and land use in local or regional economies, died on Saturday at his home in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 91. His death was confirmed by his son Peter.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, November 6th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. MUST YOU GO? My Life With Harold Pinter

Bucking the trend for rustic satchels, some luggage designers are boldly traveling forward. Delsey has developed a way to prevent surprise overweight charges: two bags in the company's Helium Fusion Lite 2.0 line ($120 and $130; delsey.com) have a built-in scale that triggers a red indicator when your luggage tops 50 pounds. At Tumi, where all-black Alpha rollers are standard business issue, innovation comes in a splash of color. The new Accent Your Alpha program ($50 at Tumi boutiques; tumi.com) lets road warriors distinguish their bags with monogram patches, zipper pulls and luggage tags in six punchy hues. And while you're waiting in baggage claim, you may wish you had Travelteq's Trip, a sit-on carry-on (below; about $1,100; travelteq.com). The aluminum frame has wheels that pivot outward to stabilize, the telescoping handle acts as a seat back, and an upholstered seat invites you to take a load off. Upgrade to the fully loaded model with battery-powered stereo speakers, and time will fly. JONATHAN S. PAUL
HARRIS--Irwin Yale, 86, November 14, 2010. Survived by wife of 65 years Sally and by children Gordon, Mark, Judy, Meryl, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

(13, 49) LENNON NAKED Christopher Eccleston (''Doctor Who''), above, summons the spirit of John Lennon and Naoko Mori (''Torchwood'') is Yoko Ono in this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' drama commemorating the 30th anniversary of Lennon's death on Dec. 8, 1980. Robert Jones wrote the script and Edmund Coulthard directed the production, which recreates scenes in Lennon's life from 1964 to 1971: the time his separated parents forced him to choose between them; his encounters with his absentee father (Christopher Fairbank); his arguments with Paul McCartney (Andrew Scott); the death of Brian Epstein (Rory Kinnear), the Beatles' manager, from a drug overdose in 1967; Ms. Ono's role in the breakup of the band; and the couple's subsequent self-imposed exile in New York City. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY In interviews here and on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC, Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, speaks about President Obama's Afghanistan war strategy; the discussion of that strategy by NATO leaders this weekend in Lisbon; and whether Afghan security forces will be ready to take control of their country by 2014. He also discusses the effect on national security of the stalled ratification of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.

''Western paper turns away the light, while our paper seems to take it in, to envelop it gently, like the soft surface of a first snowfall,'' wrote the Japanese author Jun'ichiro Tanizaki in ''In Praise of Shadows,'' his 1933 manifesto on the aesthetic differences between the East and West. His observations on subtlety, the play of light and dark, and, for that matter, all things Japanese, have lately been on the minds of Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the design duo behind the label Ohne Titel. ''While I was reading his work, I felt like I was experiencing this slice of traditional Japanese aesthetics visually,'' Adams says. Adds Gill, ''It's almost a goal toward perfect design, which as designers we're always searching for.'' In their spring 2011 collection, the pair softened their usual aggressive silhouettes with nods to the Orient: striped ribbed knitwear inspired by the Japanese woodblock print artist Utagawa Kuniyoshi, linen tie-front pants, jackets with kimono-style volume in the sleeves. The two recently made their inaugural trip to Japan, traveling to Kyoto to take in tea ceremonies, ancient temples and Noh theater. As Tanizaki saw it, the purity of great modern design comes, first, with an appreciation for the old. WHITNEY VARGAS

It's a splendid setting for a funeral. The turnip-domed Leksand Church sits in a sober three-quarter pose against the banks of Lake Siljan. Three hundred years of Leksand's citizens lie in the surrounding earth, their tombstones stitched into a crazy quilt that stretches to the water. Groves of spruce trees shade the churchyard. As mourners file out of the church, some lingering in the dimming afternoon light, the bell tower signals the passing with a long series of low, loud chimes. It rings out for nearly half an hour, pausing every few minutes, the sound echoing through the town and silencing everything in its path. On this day in Sweden, the past refuses to go quietly. Tradition has always hung on tight in Dalarna, the lower central part of the country, which encompasses the mammoth Lake Siljan along with Leksand, Rattvik, Mora and dozens of other villages. Much of the area, about three and a half hours north of Stockholm, feels like a remnant of the past. Horses graze in churchyards and roads meander through thickets of evergreens, from one homestead to another, then disappear into the lake. It is here that women wore 18th-century-style embroidered apron dresses until the 1960s; here that artisans started a craze for cheery, homespun textiles and ceramics a century before Ikea; and from here that the iconic red Dala horse was sent out into the world to be Sweden's tiny wooden ambassador.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''An N.B.A. Move That Crossed an Ocean,'' Nov. 18: I seem to remember Bob Cousy executing the Euro step with regularity when he played for Holy Cross in the 1940s. I also think it can be said that palming comes into play to make this move, a call that is rarely made today.

An article in some editions on Thursday about an annual report to Congress that raised speculation about possible meddling in the world's Web traffic by a Chinese Internet service provider last spring misstated the name of the group that issued the report. It is the United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission, not Revision Commission. The article also referred incorrectly to The Global Times, which quoted a top Chinese Internet researcher as saying such meddling was technically not feasible. It is a state-run English-language newspaper in China, not a Web site of the People's Daily, the newspaper of China's ruling Communist Party.

BOTTEGA VENETA has partnered with the Swiss watchmaker Girard-Perregaux to produce its first watch, the BVX. As elegant and subtle as the house's logo-free leather accessories, the unisex watch ($14,600) features a dark brushed-titanium curved case with a brown face and a cigar-colored crocodile strap. Inside lies an 18-karat rose gold automatic movement made expressly by Girard-Perregaux for Bottega Veneta. And this watch has a face even Dorian Gray could love, with nary a name or initial marring its smooth, lacquered surface, adhering to Bottega Veneta's motto: ''When your own initials are enough.'' BRUCE PASK

FRONT PAGE An article last Sunday about legal tactics that big tobacco companies are using globally to fight tough restrictions on cigarette marketing described incorrectly the total of goods and services produced by Uruguay, whose regulations have been challenged in court by Philip Morris International. Uruguay's gross domestic product -- not its gross domestic profit -- is half the size of the tobacco company's $66 billion in annual sales.

WEEKEND A report in the Inside Art column on Friday about the selection of curators for the 2012 Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennial misstated the time period when one, Jay Sanders, was a director at the Chelsea gallery Greene Naftali. It was from 2005 until recently; he did not leave in 2005. Another report in the column, about the California artist Chris Burden, misidentified the site where, by his calculation,100,000 cars circulate every hour. It is in his new work ''Metropolis II,'' not in Los Angeles. The report, using information from the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, misstated the time it will take to install the work at the museum after it is completed. It is 2 to 3 months, not 18 months.

A brief article on Nov. 7 with a chart showing how different groups voted in the 2010 midterm elections referred incorrectly to the overall vote. Experts said that ballots were cast by 42 percent of people eligible to vote -- defined as being at least 18, a citizen and not a felon in most states. They did not say that 42 percent of registered voters had gone to the polls.

At the government's request, the tribes that populate the remote Indonesian island of Sumba stopped hunting heads in the 1950s. Or at least that was what was supposed to happen. In reality, a head was lopped off in an intratribal war as recently as last March. ''We had to stop sending people on trips to the waterfall for months until things settled down,'' says Claude Graves, one of three Westerners living permanently on the island. Graves and his wife have spent the last 20 years building Nihiwatu, the most exclusive and lavish surf destination in the world. The hideaway resort draws ultrarich, über-athletic adventurers, who come to test themselves against a legendary wave and to be surrounded by one of the last Stone Age cultures on Earth. The Dutch, who opened the East Indies in the 1600s to the spice trade, called Sumba ''Sandalwood Island.'' They relinquished control of Indonesia after World War II, and Sumba, isolated on the far end of the archipelago, became Indonesia's wild wild west. Today its few towns are little more than dusty trading posts or missionary settlements, and the majority of the 600,000 citizens live as their ancestors did: in small, widely dispersed villages. When Graves first scouted the beaches, permission to explore came only after negotiation with tribal kings. ''We had an escort of a dozen barefoot porters carrying our equipment,'' Graves remembers. ''When we came to the edge of a tribal boundary, they'd melt back into the jungle and another crew would appear and continue on with their escort.''

At summer's end, for more than a century, a group of Americans have traveled to a hilltop in Rome. They are invariably an eclectic bunch -- scholars of antiquity, architects nursing ambitious projects, artists and designers of various disciplines -- who have each been selected to spend a year living at the American Academy in Rome, a lush compound overlooking the city's storied spires and ancient basilicas. Known as the Rome Prize, the fellowship is considered one of the most prestigious and envy-inducing within the world of the humanities and fine arts. And understandably so. To describe the academy, which was founded in 1894, as an idyllic incubation chamber for study and creative thinking would be something of an understatement. The Renaissance-inspired main building was designed by McKim, Mead and White and partly financed by J. P. Morgan, who helped find a site for the academy that stood higher above Rome than its French counterpart on the opposite side of the city. The building rises stoically around an interior courtyard, its plaster walls inlaid with lapidary from archaeological digs. Inside is a sitting room with a grand piano and a billiard room dominated by a black-and-white painting by Chuck Close, a trustee and former resident, as well as the library, which contains more than 140,000 volumes, from literary classics to rare books from the 16th century.

An article on Nov. 9 about a report on the achievement gap in schools between black male students and white male students in reading and math referred incorrectly to the gap in SAT scores. African-American boys scored, on average, 104 points lower in critical reasoning, not overall on all three components of the test. The gap is 120 points in mathematics and 99 points in writing.

THE NEWS The rock musician Patti Smith won the National Book Award for nonfiction for ''Just Kids,'' a memoir of her relationship with the artist Robert Mapplethorpe and of life in the bohemian New York of the 1960s and '70s. BEHIND THE NEWS Ms. Smith, who worked as a clerk in Scribner's bookstore in Manhattan before finding success as a singer and songwriter of jagged, beat-influenced punk rock music, told the audience at the awards ceremony, ''Please, no matter how we advance technologically, please don't abandon the book -- there is nothing in our material world more beautiful than the book.''

CHEW--Charles R.,died on November 18, 2010 at the Hospice Inn at St. Peter's Hospital, after a courageous two year battle with mesothlioma. He is survived by his wife of 56 years F. Joyce Chew, and seven children; Claudia, Eric (Susan), Kristopher (Marilyn), Adria, Philip (Jackie), Timothy (Mary Lynn) and Eliza, 14 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Charles was a Korean War Veteran serving in the U.S. Navy. He received a BA Degree from Rutgers University, a MA Degree from Montclair State College in New Jersey and a Doctorate of Education from SUNY Albany. Mr. Chew taught in New Jersey and New York. He was Bureau Chief of English for the New York State Education Department, where he retired in 1992 as the Division Director. He was a longtime communicant of St. Edward the Confessor Church. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Tuesday morning 10:00am, at St. Edward the Confessor Church 569 Clifton Park Center Road. Interment with full military honors will be in the Gerald B.H. Solomon Saratoga National Cemetery in Schuylerville. There will be no wake per the wishes of Mr. Chew. The family will receive friends at his home on Tuesday between the hours of 2 and 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jonesville Food Pantry, located at 963 Main Street, Clifton Park, NY 12065. The family would like to thank all of those involved in his care over the past two years for their tender loving compassion. Funeral services have been entrusted by the family to the Gordon C. Emerick Funeral Home, 1550 Route 9, Clifton Park, NY 12065. 518-371-5454.

Nobody who buys a Ralph Lauren prairie skirt or cowboy jacket really thinks a personal history of the West informs the clothes. Mr. Lauren grew up in the Bronx. The late Alexander McQueen loved Scottish history, but in practical terms, the links were as crumbly as an old castle. Even for the most sensitive of designers, fashion changes too often to supply a narrative of a single place or culture. It's astonishing, then, to realize how much one country shaped the ideas of Cristobal Balenciaga. The country, of course, is Spain, and the period of influence was from 1937, when he opened his Paris house, until he retired in 1968 and returned to Spain. That is the fascinating, single-minded focus of ''Balenciaga: Spanish Master,'' an exhibition that opens Friday at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute on Park Avenue.

On the eve of a Board of Education meeting in February where the death knell was to sound for five schools, Ron Huberman, the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools, granted an 11th-hour reprieve. The low enrollment and poor academic record at Paderewski Elementary had made the South Side school a target for closing, and its students were being sent to Mason Elementary, the only nearby school that had higher test scores. Mr. Huberman said he changed his mind after walking from Paderewski to Mason and discovering that students would have to cross a wide intersection of four streets, a situation he concluded was too dangerous.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

STEINHAUSER--Anthony Joseph, of Alexandria, Virginia born August 25, 1919 in Richmond Hill, New York passed away on Monday, November 8, 2010 at the age of 91. Beloved husband for sixty years to the late Ellen W. Steinhauser and adored brother of the late Rose C. Steinhauser. He is survived by his daughter, Lore C. Steinhauser; son, Peter A. Steinhauser and his wife, Barbara, and grandchildren, Elizabeth and Emily; sister-in-law, Lore W. McCarthy, and nieces and nephews, Monica, Christopher, Paul and Lorraine McCarthy; and brother-in-law, Peter Wallburg and his wife Catarina, and nephews Peter, Michael and Billy. A US Army combat veteran of WWII, he was re-activated for the Korean War to serve as an intelligence officer and then went on to become a successful oil industry executive followed by many years of faithful government service. He developed and maintained an interest in foreign affairs after his military service and private sector postings overseas in the Philippines and Europe for Caltex and other petroleum industry interests. Tony, as he was known to his family and friends, was a proud graduate of Richmond Hill High School and Fordham University where he was President of the Student Body and Captain of the Swim Teams. After graduation, he was drafted and then entered the executive training program at the Colgate-Palmolive Company but entered Officers Candidate School at the beginning of WWII. He served proudly with the 83rd Infantry "Thunderbolt" Division in the campaigns of Normandy, Northern France, Rhineland, Ardennes and Central Europe and served with distinction in ground combat in Northern France, in Belgium, the Hurtgen Forest, the Battle of the Bulge and the bridgehead over the Elbe River. The 83rd Infantry Division was recognized as a liberating unit by the US Army's Center of Military History and the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in 1993. Service to his country remained among Tony's proudest accomplishments and he exemplified the values of duty, honor, God and country that are hallmarks of "the Greatest Generation". A private service was held on November 19, 2010 at Demaine Funeral Home in Alexandria, VA. He will be buried with Full Military Honors at Arlington National Cemetery in the spring. In lieu of flowers, the family requests your thoughts and prayers for all members of the armed forces past and present and for our beloved husband, father and friend, Tony.

On his first visit home to Taiwan since Michelle Obama catapulted his name into the fashion stratosphere, the designerJason Wu was greeted by paparazzi, velvet ropes and tons of fans. Here, ''the glory of Taiwan,'' as Wu is now known in his birthplace, talks about his return to Taipei, where change is in the air but the old ways aren't forgotten. CHELSEA ZALOPANY The Museum of Contemporary Art Taipei (www.mocataipei.org.tw) is the center of the city's budding art scene (with a great design shop, where Wu picked up this T-shirt 1 .) Housed in a refurbished historic building, the museum has locals happily looking ahead. ''There are a lot of talented native artists now with their own space,'' Wu says.

Andrew Luck, left, threw two touchdown passes and led No. 7 Stanford to scores on all eight possessions he played in a 48-14 win over California. It was the most points Stanford has ever scored against Cal. The junior Mikel Leshoure rushed for 330 yards -- the highest total in the nation this season -- as Illinois beat Northwestern, 48-27. His two scores covered more modest distances: 1 and 4 yards.

OLIVEIRA--Nathan. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. He used the painter's rich art to depict the poverty of the individual soul, and did so in powerful ways that will haunt the memory for decades to come.

My wife and I are going to the British Virgin Islands in January for my 50th birthday. We're bare boating a '47 catamaran and have several couples onboard. What are the ''do not miss'' party spots around the islands as well as adventures that we must do? Bob Skubis, Capitola, Calif. A.Jeremy W. Peters, a reporter for The Times who lived in the U.S. Virgin Islands for two years, recommended several places to spend a celebratory evening. In the British Virgin Islands, ''Jost Van Dyke is an entire island practically devoted to partying,'' Mr. Peters wrote. Soggy Dollar Bar (soggydollar.com), he said, ''is the old standby,'' though he also recommends One Love Bar & Grill (onelovebar.com), ''and a host of other beach bars right in White Bay'' (above).

ONE of the first historic buildings to be awarded landmark status in the city, the Samuel Tredwell Skidmore House has been renovated and converted to 10 rental apartments. The house, at 37 East Fourth Street on the Bowery, was designed by T. Thomas & Son Architects and built in 1845 for Mr. Skidmore, a wholesale drug merchant with a wife and eight children.

It used to be much simpler to earn your environmental stripes, but these days anything short of brewing your own biodiesel gets you dirty looks in yoga class. At least Hertz is making things a little easier. Beginning in late December, customers in New York, Washington, D.C., and San Francisco, and on select college campuses, will be able to rent a Nissan Leaf, the first mass-market, zero-emissions electric car. The Leaf can go about 100 miles on a full charge, so if you're planning on roving into the wilderness of no charging stations (Hertz is working on building an infrastructure of stations nationwide), you're better off with the slightly less saintly hybrids, like Priuses and Volts, also available. Rest assured, for those vacationing without a vegan or a sense of environmental outrage, there is still fun to be had: Mustangs, Sebrings and Caddies galore. Go to hertz.com. ETHAN HAUSER
International ZAMBIA BALANCES AID

AT Eli Kapsack's bar mitzvah, he chanted in the ancient tones of the Hebrew Bible about a sorcerer named Balaam, the angel of the Lord descending to earth and a talking donkey who tries to clue her owner in to the miracle at hand. He read the prayers for the Saturday morning service, and took his place as a religious adult, as Jewish children generally do at 13. It was a ceremony steeped in tradition. Except that instead of attending Hebrew school two or three times a week, Eli prepared for his bar mitzvah using Skype and a Webcam, meeting virtually with Rabbi Yitzhak Miller, who lives an hour and a half away. To learn the melody for his Torah portion, he practiced on a computer program called TropeTrainer. And instead of carpooling to the synagogue, he did it all from his desk at home.

The Bloomberg administration wants to teach New Yorkers about the dangers of driving over the speed limit. Its latest weapon? Kids with radar guns. In an effort to promote safety among future drivers (and those they influence), officials from the city's Department of Transportation encouraged fourth graders at Public School 261 in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning to try out city-issued speed guns on the zipping traffic along Atlantic Avenue.

Google Chrome is providing free wireless Internet access on three airlines - AirTran, Delta and Virgin America - from Nov. 20 through Jan. 2 as part of a promotion for the browser. The carriers' passengers will be able to browse the Web via Gogo Inflight Internet, which allows users to go online midflight with Wi-Fi-enabled devices like laptops, iPads and smartphones. Passengers will be able to use any browser they wish while surfing the Web but will be invited to download Google Chrome upon landing.

JANOSKI--Janice Jean, of New York, NY died on October 25, 2010 at New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York from complications of severe rheumatoid arthritis. She was born on April 28, 1940 in Wilkes-Barre, PA, daughter of the late Clementine Janoski and Alfonso Janoski. She graduated from the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, NY with a Bachelor of Arts degree. She also earned an Associate's degree at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York, NY. Both degrees were in Fashion Design. She lived in New York City from 1963 to 2010, first at 1001 Park Avenue, then at the Trump Tower at 721 Fifth Avenue. She owned a Fashion Boutique in the Trump Tower. She leaves her husband, Dr. Rainer Mittl, Ophthalmologist at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York and her brother, Dr. Alfonso Janoski, retired Endocrinologist in Baltimore, Maryland. Funeral services were made by the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York and she was laid to rest at the Gate of Heaven Catholic Cemetery in East Hanover, NJ.

CALELLO--Paul. It is with profound sorrow that our family announces the death of Paul Calello on November 16, 2010, after a yearlong battle with cancer. Paul was the cherished father of Jin, David, James and Peter, adored husband of Jane DeBevoise, treasured son of Albert and Mary Calello, revered brother of Cathy Staples, Ann Groccia and Kristan Bishop, beloved brother-in-law of Alex Gibney and Anne DeBevoise, Charles and Andrea DeBevoise, Jim Staples, Al Groccia and Rick Bishop, idolized uncle of thirteen nieces and nephews, and deeply admired son-in-law of Lillie DeBevoise. A celebration of Paul's life will be held on December 18, 2010, at 3pm in the Sanctuary of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, 57 Orange Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets in Brooklyn Heights, New York. Please no flowers. Donation possibilities include Columbia Business School and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, but everyone should also feel free to give to the charity of their choice. We will miss Paul deeply, but his spirit will be with us forever.
Manhattan Hudson Heights ....... $335,000

Casual restaurants with rooms may be the newest fad, but big-league hotels and celebrity chefs are still the flavor of the month. Here are the latest toque-chasing properties. Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, London (mandarinoriental.com/london) is the word on everyone's lips, now that it can brag about Dinner by Heston Blumenthal (above left), the first London outpost of the chef whose restaurant Fat Duck in Bray, England, is a culinary mecca. Expect scallops with cucumber ketchup and peas, and bergamot-cured-mackerel salad (yum?). In Warwick, England, near Shakespeare's birthplace of Stratford, the Globe Hotel just reopened as the Lazy Cow (thelazycowwarwick.com), a 16-room bolthole that has take-home swag bags (robe-stealing encouraged) and, most notably, David Philpot, the chef who hails from London's Le Caprice and the Ivy, in the kitchen. After stints at Spain's renowned Quique Dacosta and the stunning restaurant at the Guggenheim Bilbao, the native son Hernán Gipponi takes over the kitchen at the just-opened Fierro Hotel (above center; fierrohotel.com) in Buenos Aires. His Med-inspired dishes are the big draw for lunch and dinner, but guests get a taste of his magic at breakfast (included in a room rate of $145). One of only two chefs to have earned a Michelin star for Thai food is testing the waters in the cuisine's home turf. At the new Siam Kempinski Hotel Bangkok (kempinski.com), Henrik Yde-Andersen, the man behind Copenhagen's masterful Kiin Kiin, creates authentic Thai dishes with a contemporary twist -- think frozen red curry with baby lobster salad and litchi foam.Pierre Gagnaire -- a demigod in certain foodie circles -- is dazzling the guests (summer only) at the Hotel Sezz St.-Tropez (hotelsezz.com). His Christophe Pillet-designed restaurant (above right) will have a modern-Med menu of dishes like lobster fricassee with basil, tomato purée and fresh gherkins.

Their brains are rewarded not for staying on task but for jumping to the next thing. The worry is we're raising a generation of kids in front of screens whose brains are going to be wired differently. MICHAEL RICH, executive director of the Center on Media and Child Health, on how digital technology affects children. [1]

''What a great country this is, God bless America,'' George Koikos said over and over as Georgio's, the restaurant he operates on the north side of Tallahassee, filled each night with lawyers and reporters. In one room you might find former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, the chief negotiator for Vice President Al Gore, sitting at a table filled with Democrats. Across the restaurant would be former Secretary of State James Baker dining with the Republican legal team representing Gov. George W. Bush. In between and all around the lawyers and politicians, reporters from all over the world gathered to eat and watch the show. Tallahassee was the center of the universe. The world was both making fun of us and waiting for us to announce who would be president.

We are a group of four Greeks (from Athens), who will visit Beirut Dec. 9 to 12 for the wedding of a friend's son. We'd like to take a walking tour of the city with a native, who would show us around. Perhaps a professional travel agent would be the right person? But we don't want big groups of people. Christina Houvarda, Athens, Greece

DWYER--Elizabeth Anne, on November 18, 2010. Beloved wife of Daniel, loving mother of Alexander and Nathaniel, devoted daughter of William and Barbara Deruiter. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call on Monday November 22, 3-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC with a service to follow on Tuesday 5:30pm at Frank E. Campbell.

STERNS--Harriette Beeson (Cis). Died November 10, 2010 at the age of 94 in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Adored wife of the late William S. Sterns Jr., loving mother of Harriette Luxner and William S. Sterns III, beloved by her grandchildren, Reed Merrill, Sara Shafer, William S. Sterns IV, Stefan Sterns, and Olivia Sterns, and by her great-grandchildren, Rebecca Merrill, Alexander Shafer and Catherine Shafer. A special person who made each person she touched feel special, who, by her own account, lived a wonderful life surrounded by countless friends, young and old. A fond farewell to Mom, Nan, Grammy. We will never forget your simple elegance and grace and your ability to forgive.

The height wars continue in Asia as, brick by brick, hotels compete for the title of world's highest. Currently taking the baton from the Park Hyatt Shanghai is the Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong. The International Commerce Center building, which houses the property -- 312 guest rooms on Floors 106 to 117 -- has a shingled facade that swoops into an elongated base, calling to mind a dragon's tail (and deflecting the wind during a typhoon). The money shot: a glass-enclosed tippy-top-level bar and swimming pool overlooking Victoria Harbor, Hong Kong Island and miles of mainland China.

'If you think big,'' says the tag line for the 1,000-acre Baha Mar resort about to break ground in the Bahamas, ''think bigger.'' Sound ridiculous in a recession? It's more of a harbinger than you'd imagine, at least in the travel world: led by Las Vegas's CityCenter and the Marina Bay Sands Singapore, a new wave of mega-scale complexes that were conceived during the boom have recently opened their doors, with several more in development, from the Alps to Abu Dhabi. ''I think it's the future,'' says Andy Cohen, executive director of the architecture firm Gensler, which worked on CityCenter and has a similar mixed-use project brewing in Shanghai. ''Whether it's sports, entertainment or retail, the ability to have all that variety in one place is key. People want choice.''

Spas are taking an eco-trip: go to any resort with a conscience and you'll find more alfresco treatment rooms, more locally sourced products, more carbon-neutral facilities. These four retreats are at the forefront of the green-spa movement, giving guests a chance to convene with nature sensibly while they slough off those old carbon footprints. Soneva Kiri This secluded island resort one hour from Bangkok has a spa in the jungle that uses only Thai ingredients in its therapies. When you're done with your four-hand massage, you can have lunch in a suspended bamboo pod, where food is delivered by waiters on zip lines. No footprint there. sixsenses.com/soneva-kiri; doubles from $1,200.

Jobs like stacking heavy boxes or fixing power lines can be dangerous, so why not give some of that work to robots? That's part of the motivation behind the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, known as Csail, at M.I.T. The lab's goal is to design robots that ''interact intelligently with people, the environment and each other'' and to create ''societal benefits through applications in homes, fields, oceans and outer space.'' Students and staff members of the Robot Locomotion Group, a part of Csail, use sophisticated formulas and materials, along with old-fashioned tools like pliers, wire and scissors, to create their robots -- which at times seem almost alive.
FEDER--Sylvia. Beloved wife, mother, step-mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and sister passed away this past Wednesday, November 10. Loved by all, she will be sorely missed.

EISENBERG--Florence, wife of the late Dr. Arthur Eisenberg, sister of the late Irving Reimer, died at home, Friday, November 12, 2010. Beloved mother of Arleen Sager, mother-in-law of Arthur. Loving grandmother of Marilynn and Richard, great-grandmother of Benjamin and Joseph. Private burial November 15, 2010.

It feels a little sacrilegious to call anything stamped Louis Vuitton a doorstop, but ''Louis Vuitton: 100 Legendary Trunks'' (Abrams; $170 for the deluxe edition, right) qualifies by heft alone -- it's nearly 500 pages and weighs about 10 pounds. The exhaustive, lushly illustrated book traces the history of Vuitton luggage; carry-ons these are not, either in spirit or in scale. There are engineering innovations (a bed that folds into a trunk, for the 19th-century explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza), concept-only wonders (the ''Jetsons''-esque Mars Trunk, which opens to reveal a mini cocktail bar and CD and book storage) and trunks customized to hold the inspirations and playthings of writers and artists (books for Ernest Hemingway, surgical knives for Damien Hirst). An accompanying exhibit is on view at the Carnavelet Museum in Paris until Feb. 27, 2011. ETHAN HAUSER

Zena Rommett, a ballet dancer and teacher who developed Floor-Barre, an influential training method promoting bodily alignment for both dancers and nondancers, and whose students included Tommy Tune, Patrick Swayze and Judith Jamison, died on Nov. 10 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 90. The cause was cancer, said her daughter Camille Mouquinho Rommett.

The Watchlist column last Sunday, about the growth of the online serial, referred incorrectly to the history of one such series, ''Riese,'' currently running on Syfy.com. Only 5 of the 10 episodes appeared last year on KoldCast.tv, not all 10.

Last week, news emerged of the Bloomberg administration's proposal to extend the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River to Secaucus, N.J. The idea has become an intriguing Plan B after Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey halted a new commuter rail to Midtown Manhattan because of rising costs. The latest proposal would extend the New York City subway outside the city for the first time, giving New Jersey commuters direct access to Times Square, Grand Central station and Queens, and to almost every line in the system. Several readers had strong opinions. Here are some of them:

HERE'S a twist for the holidays: your favorite new Céline accessories are wrapped up like candy. Leopard-print flats ($690 at Barneys New York) remind us of Tootsie Rolls, while the yellow sandals ($595 at the Webster, Miami) are as sweet -- and tart -- as lemon drops. RACHEL WALDMAN

A review on Nov. 7 about ''Scorpions: The Battles and Triumphs of FDR's Great Supreme Court Justices,'' by Noah Feldman, misstated the effect of a right-to-privacy ruling by the court in 1965. The ruling, in the case of Griswold v. Connecticut, prevented that state from banning the use of contraceptives, not their sale.

HONOLULU (AP) -- The former Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan, the N.C.A.A.'s career leader in touchdown passes, was upgraded to stable condition Saturday at Queen's Medical Center here after a two-car crash Friday. Brennan's father, Terry Brennan, told KHON-TV by telephone from California that his son had three or four broken ribs, a broken left collarbone and head injuries. The Honolulu Star-Advertiser reported on Saturday that Brennan's head injuries were ''favorable.'' He was in serious condition Friday.

It is confirmed now that I am a crazy person. I concluded this one April morning as I stood nearly naked in a temple in South India while a stranger in a loincloth hauled a bucket of water from a suspicious-looking well and poured it over my head. The water, I was assured, is holy. It comes from one of 22 theertha kundams, or wells, at the Sri Ramanathaswamy temple on Rameswaram island at the southern tip of the state of Tamil Nadu. The temple is famed for its sculptured pillar hall, said to be the longest in the world; its immense central tower, riotous with the usual celestial mob scene; and its associations with the Ramayana, the Hindu epic no one has ever been able to get all the way through. More than anything, though, it is known as a pilgrimage place, the only one in India where believers can participate in a particular sequence of purifying baths.

Happy birthday, Stan Musial. Stan the Man turns 90 on Sunday. Not every nonagenarian is named to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom, as Musial was on Wednesday. Then again, not every nonagenarian hit .331 in his career and is the most beloved citizen of his chosen town.

BERKSON--Roslyn. Died peacefully November 19, 2010, at the age of 74. She was the beloved daughter of Jack and Irene Weitzner, mother of Mitch and Steve, sister of Bern. Ros cherished being the grandmother to her eight grandchildren. She was a friend to many, and loved by all who knew her. She will be greatly missed for her generosity, spirit, good humor, and sweetness.

Don't be fooled by the name. Rhonda Drakeford and Lulu Roper-Caldbeck's design shop, in the storied Bloomsbury area of London, packs a colorful punch. ''No florals, no frills and no sparkles,'' says Drakeford (above, left). Instead you'll find bold home and fashion accessories in black and white, with vivid hits of Mondrianesque hues. Go to darkroomlondon.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE 1. Ilya Fleet, a former saddle maker, fashioned this bag (about $940) from saddle leather and brass equestrian fixtures. ''We gravitate toward impeccably crafted accessories with a masculine, almost hard-edged feel,'' Drakeford says.
iPad cases, from top: Hermès, $770. Go to hermes.com. Valextra, $740. Go to barneys.com. Want Les Essentiels de la Vie, $295. Go to lagarconne.com.

FARRLOW--Lucille (Fliegel), in Las Vegas, NV. Lucille joined her beloved parents Jerry and Frieda Fliegel on November 15, 2010. Heaven will never be the same! After a rewarding career in New York as an advertising executive, she retired in 1990 to Nevada. There at Adat Ari El, she honored her parents by endowing AAE's Sunday School with scholarships in their names. Lucille is a proud founding-member of Temple Sinai in Las Vegas. In the USA her poetry has been published by the International Library of Poetry, Eber & Wein Publishing and in England by Noble House. The epic poem "Ovens" is considered the quintessential work regarding the Holocaust. She attained the distinction of being named a Distinguished Member by the International Society of Poets. An avid supporter of our military, in 2006 she was presented with the Patriot Award from the Paralyzed Veterans of America. In 2007 the Help Hospitalized Veterans named her Donor of the Year. Lucille considered being called an "American chauvinist" a compliment. Her dearest friends work for veteran's organizations. Earn yourself a blessing-make a donation to any private USA Veterans firm that assists our heroes. Yo'll feel great!

It took the promise of freshly baked bread and recently laid eggs to drag Becky Eaton, 28, out of bed and all the way to Ocean Beach, on the far western edge of San Francisco. Outerlands hadn't opened yet, but she was first in a long line of hungry locals dressed in hoodies and flip-flops. ''This better be worth the half-hour on Muni,'' she said, referring to the often slow city transit system. She knew it would be. It's one of a few spots adding buzz to the Outer Sunset, a once bleak neighborhood home to surfers and families looking for affordable housing. Today, it hosts a cluster of arty shops and cafes covered in swirls of salvaged wood -- a sort of Driftwood Alley. RACHEL LEVIN

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel finds the best way to eat for a bargain in São Paulo: try lunch. He explores the all-you-can-eat specials, the restaurants where you pay by the kilo and bars that serve up much more than a liquid lunch. nytimes.com/frugaltraveler
