THE sunlight sliced through the clear glass of the gazebo-like restaurant at Familia Zuccardi, one of dozens of wineries located in the small town of Maipú, just outside the city of Mendoza, Argentina. The purple-red malbec and torrontés grapevines glistened in the early afternoon sun. Inside, a waitress poured us chardonnay as bread sticks and an appetizer of ham ravioli arrived. She brought a different chardonnay for the cannelloni filled with sweetbread. Then a hearty malbec, Argentina's signature wine, accompanied the main course of baby goat rolls filled with sun-dried tomatoes and aubergine. For the apple with cardamom soup, oak ice cream and goat cheese -- the ''pre-dessert'' on this tasting menu -- a sweet white wine cleared the palate. Then one more malbec appeared for the dessert of yerba mate foam with grapefruit and orange caviar.

ADAMS--Beth Van Hoesen. Peacefully in San Francisco, November 16, 2010. A prominent artist and acknowledged master of drawing and printmaking, Van Hoesen distinguished herself as a major figure in 20th century prints. Born 1926 in Boise, Idaho, to Enderse and Freda Van Hoesen. She was predeceased in 2006 by her husband of 52 years, Mark Adams. She is survived by many cousins, including Mary Jo Hossfeld, David Van Hoesen, Karen Olson, Phil Soulen, and predeceased by Norma Rich; also survived by nieces Judy Bailey and Barbara Nalli; by Mary N. Connors, devoted caregiver for 14 years, and numerous friends, colleagues, and admirers. Beth Van Hoesen studied art at Stanford University (BA 1948); at schools in Mexico City and Paris; California School of Fine Arts, San Francisco; and San Francisco State College. In 1953 she married artist and designer Mark Adams, and in 1959 they purchased a firehouse in San Francisco, where they established their studios and lived for the next 46 years. Throughout her career, Van Hoesen was honored for her artistic achievements, including a 1981 Award of Honor in Graphics from San Francisco Arts Commission, and 1993 Distinguished Artist Award from California Society of Printmakers. For 60 years, her works have been featured in numerous exhibitions and publications, and are in museum collections in the US and abroad, including her print archive at the Portland Art Museum, OR. An exhibition of Van Hoesen's paintings, drawings, and prints is currently touring U.S. museums. Services were held in San Francisco at Temple Emanu-El on November 19. An exhibition at the Sequoias Rotunda Gallery, 1400 Geary Street, San Francisco, concludes with a memorial reception on Sunday, November 21, 4:30-6pm. Donations may be made in her memory to Hospitality House, 290 Turk St., San Francisco CA 94102.

I have so many vivid memories of the 2000 recount frenzy that it is difficult to select from among them. One, certainly, is the extraordinary and exhausting pace at which the lawyers were working, nonstop, for the entire 36 days. My involvement began two days after Election Day with phone messages urgently summoning me to Tallahassee. I was on a flight to Los Angeles at the time (there were airplane phones in those days), so I had to disembark upon landing, march back onto the same plane, return to Washington, pack a bag, recruit colleagues for assistance and race to Florida.

At first blush, the meeting we were preparing for on the Thursday after Election Day was no different from countless others that I had attended as a lawyer: the top people from both sides were sitting down to talk about the dispute at hand. But as we gathered in a nondescript room in the Governors Inn in Tallahassee, it was clear that the usual tools of the legal trade would not be of much use. First, litigators know that the higher the stakes, the more likely it is that a case will settle: the more at risk, the less that anyone wants to take their chances with an unknown judge and an indeterminate appeal. But here, in the highest-stakes litigation ever, a negotiated settlement was not on the table. Only late-night comics believed that George W. Bush could be president on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, and Al Gore on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. This difference could not be split; there could not be a ''win-win.'' This dispute would have a winner and a loser, with historic consequences.

AVID travelers are notoriously hard to buy gifts for. They seem to want only things that will make their trips easier or their luggage lighter, even though they already have the perfect suitcase and the best noise-canceling headset. You can try finding something luxurious, but beware those Ghurka luggage tags for your backpacking sister-in-law or that elegant swivel-lid alarm clock that weighs a ton. It doesn't help that every holiday, these hard-core travelers who have been everywhere and done everything one-up your gift with something cooler brought back for you from one of their exotic trips. Remember that Masai beaded necklace from Tanzania you get so many compliments on?

Unlike Los Angeles neighborhoods whose names resonate worldwide as metaphors for glamour or the good life, the one in which the Peruvian restaurant Mo-Chica is located has no particular mythology and, really, no distinct identity. People refer to it alternately as ''south of downtown'' or ''near U.S.C.,'' meaning the University of Southern California. And the approach to Mo-Chica doesn't build confidence. You drive into a fenced lot, walk up to a squat orange building that looks as if it might house dental or car insurance offices and enter a space as vast as a hangar and as visually chaotic as a flea market. Mo-Chica is against the far right wall. It's a counter, more or less, with a menu board above it and plastic-covered tables scattered on the concrete floor in front. After you place your order, you're given a number on a stick, which you plant like a flag on one of those tables. Looking up, you see scores of athletic jerseys hanging above a patch of concrete where they're sold. In the opposite direction is an alcove with a bevy of untidily stacked computer equipment and a row of monitors: a technology repair shop, which also offers Internet access at hourly rates.

Nothing draws a crowd like a boldface designer. Yet these five high-style hotels have managed to fly under the radar -- until now. In Hokkaido, Japan, Alexandra Champalimaud is reimagining the European ski chalet for the Far East. Her 200-room Green Leaf Niseko Village has great views of Mount Yotei, is steps from the lifts and is filled with site-specific art by the Japanese artist Soichiro Tomioka. ytlhotels.com.

KAPLAN--Donald Barnard, 81, died peacefully on November 11, 2010 in New York City after a short illness. He is survived by his dearly loved two sons and their families, Tom and Liz, of Las Vegas, NV and John, Mimi, Avery, and Benjamin, of Mountain Lakes, NJ; beloved brother, Edgar, of Montclair, NJ; and dear friend, Bob Cosenza, of New York City. He is also predeceased by his beloved sister, Rosalie Kirsch. Don was an extraordinarily loving and compassionate father, granddad, brother, father-in-law, mentor and friend. Known for his impeccable manners, integrity, elegance, style, sense of humor, wisdom and intelligence, he was the consummate gentleman and the most honorable of men. He always wore a smile and brought great joy to all those around him during his wonderful life. Born December 30, 1928 in Newark, NJ to Ben and Katherine Kaplan, Don was a New York City resident since 1970. He graduated from Yale University in 1950 with a BA in Psychology where he played the clarinet in the marching band and was a member of the drama club. He served as a Captain in the US Marine Corps and saw active duty in Korea on the front line at the Yalu River. Don was a veteran of four decades in Manhattan real estate and served as general manager of the Empire State Building and the International Toy Center. He began his career in 1964 under the tutelage of real estate legends Peter L. Malkin, Lawrence A. Wien and Harry B. Helmsley, and went on to hold various executive positions. He retired in 2002 as an Executive Vice President of Malkin Properties, then W&M Properties. Don was a patron of the arts who frequented the theater and museums, especially MOMA and the Met. He had a passion for travel and genealogy. He loved his New York Times crosswords and gardening at his country homes in Sag Harbor and Spencertown, NY. Most of all, he cherished spending time with his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to the Friedman Brain Institute www.philanthropy.mountsinai.org. A Celebration is being planned for early 2011. Sweet dreams. Your loving family.

Survived by daughters Barbara Caress and Jane (Herb) Bardavid, grandchildren, Jessica (Steve) Graff, David, Josh and Lucas, great-grandchildren Samantha and Carter. An essay on Nov. 7 about the American dream misstated the first word of the title of a Norman Mailer novel about the same subject. It is ''An American Dream,'' not ''The.''

Comedy MASHANTUCKET Comix at Foxwoods Upright Citizens Brigade Touring Company, improvisation. Thursday through Nov. 27. $25 to $50. Michael Ian Black. Dec. 2 through Dec. 4. $45. Comix at Foxwoods, 240 MGM Grand Drive. comixatfoxwoods.com; (866) 646-0609.

Midtown Manhattan will get a brand-new hotel next spring when TRYP by Wyndham unveils its first property in North America. The TRYP New York City-Times Square South is scheduled to open in April at 345 West 35th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. The TRYP brand, which Wyndham acquired in June from the Spanish hotel company Sol Melia Hotels & Resorts, caters to both business and leisure travelers. The Manhattan property will have 173 guest rooms, including ''fitness rooms'' that include fitness machines and workout clothes and ''family rooms'' featuring bunk beds. Room rates are expected to be in the $200 to $300 range.

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Alastair Macaulay's article about the popularity of ''The Nutcracker'' in the United States: '' 'The Nutcracker' remains popular because the slipper-throwing Clara is plucky, and that kind of heroine has grown into quite an industry. American Girl and Disney princesses, anyone? Maybe our daughters beg to go see 'The Nutcracker' year after year because Clara always gets the ultimate tween holiday gift: a prince, a tiara and a kingdom full of candy. Who could ask for more?''

Adored father of Wendy, Michael and Peter. Cherished grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of one. You will be in "our hearts forever". Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel Boca Raton, FL. 800-992-9262.

With its food trucks, design collectives and rehabbed downtowns, the Research Triangle -- the patch of North Carolina that is home to Raleigh, Durham, Chapel Hill and 150,000 college students -- seems to be yet another hipster vibe factory. It's Silver Lake, you think, just with a few more ''yes, ma'ams.'' But then you taste the okra and sniff the heirloom tomatoes. You meet an ex-vegan who's smoking whole hogs and a church pastor who plays in a secular rock group. And speaking of music, it's everywhere -- beamed out from great college radio stations, seeping out of historic rock clubs and packaged by a growing local record industry. This is the kind of place where bands still play house shows, where a local will endorse a dingy club by telling you that, inside, it feels like you're at a Halo of Flies show in 1988. You don't really know what he's talking about, but you must find out. STEPHEN HEYMAN RALEIGH DENIM Victor Lytvinenko, 30, a former cook at Nobu in New York, and his wife Sarah, 29, who studied design at North Carolina State, began sewing selvage denim in their living room three years ago; now their jeans are on sale at Barneys for up to $300. Inside Raleigh Denim's new workshop (and small retail space), ambient music plays over the hum of vintage sewing machines, including one from 1921 that torques hemlines in a way that makes denim geeks freak. The staff of recent college grads and immigrants includes Christel Ellsberg, a feisty 76-year-old woman originally from East Prussia who was a patternmaker for Levi's in the 1960s. 319 West Martin Street, No. 100, Raleigh; (919) 274-5999; raleighdenim.com.

A picture credit last Sunday with an article about Oprah Winfrey misspelled the surname of the photographer who took the picture of Ms. Winfrey. He is Evan Sung, not Sing.

Every Thursday night at a single-family house in Bellerose, Queens, they file in the side door and down the stairs, men with ham-hock forearms, and a few sturdy women, too. They duck into a cramped basement room and gather around padded platforms equipped with handles for waging hand-to-hand combat. They greet by clapping together chalked-up palms, sending up little white clouds, and then face off across the tables. Often the hands are bound together in tight straps to avoid slipping. They joust for a powerful hand-clasp -- gripping, re-gripping -- and then position their elbows and shoulders for maximum power-pulling leverage.

While checking in at the hotel that first afternoon in the French Alps, I met a fine, terrier-like dog named Al Capone. He was admirably groomed, pearl coat nearly glowing, and he proceeded through the lobby with such aplomb -- did he realize that he stood only a foot and a half? -- that I was filled with immediate admiration for him, if not a scintilla of envy. Judging by the clientele here, his owner might have been a Russian oligarch, a Euro titan or a celebrity scion of some sort, and so could only offer me a wan smile and a few brief words. But that was to be expected. Women sashayed past in ski outfits that would have cost your average proletarian a month's wages; men sat by the fireplace drinking bottles of Cognac whose sticker price resembled that of a compact car. And Al Capone followed his curious nose, snuffling for nonexistent crumbs, until he bumped up against my alien, American shoe. If I'd landed at one of the ritziest hotels in one of the ritziest places on earth -- a place named Courchevel -- with an idea of settling in to ski the fabled slopes and cast a gimlet eye on the bread and circus of the rich and famous, well, dog or not, Al Capone embodied a message I could heed: act like you belong, take your Milk-Bones where you can, and try not to soil the Oriental carpet. Given my Communard instincts and lousy wardrobe, it was going to be hard. The five-star Hôtel de Charme Les Airelles is a stomping ground for the jet set and their kids, bodyguards and mistresses (oh-la-la!): it boasts of roughly three staff members for each of its 52 rooms and, on my visit, even had a palefrenier on property to care for the miniature Falabella horses.

WASHINGTON -- To Walter B. Slocombe, there was something hauntingly familiar about the political sinkhole President Obama found himself in last week. As a Pentagon official in the 1970s, Mr. Slocombe was part of President Jimmy Carter's team pushing the Senate to ratify an arms control treaty with Moscow. Skeptical of the Kremlin, worried about the impact on American security and sensing weakness in the White House, Republicans blocked the treaty.
Pop Jon Pareles

NEW lending guidelines being rolled out by Fannie Mae will make securing a mortgage a lot easier for some borrowers but harder for others. The rules, effective on Dec. 13, will allow buyers to use gifts and grants from nonprofit groups for their minimum 5 percent down payment, which is the threshold set by Fannie Mae, the government-owned company that sets lending standards and buys mortgages from lenders. (Freddie Mac is considering similar new guidelines, said Brad German, a spokesman.)

ZIELENZIGER--Eric W. A dealer in spices and eyewitness to the history of the Holocaust, who survived the war by living underground with a Dutch family, died Saturday after a short illness. Born in Berlin in 1920, Mr. Zielenziger arrived in New York in 1946 after living underground between September, 1943 and May, 1945 during the Nazi occupation of Holland. A member of the same Zionist Youth group in Amsterdam as Anne Frank, he came to New York with only a few dollars in his pocket and the promise of a job with a chemicals trading firm. Later in his career, he was a trader with Felix Kramarsky Corp., secretary-treasurer of the PEC Israel Economic Corporation, and a sales executive with Accurate Ingredients of Syosset, NY. A long-time resident of Great Neck, NY, he is survived by his wife, Ruth (Herrmann) a former professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America; two sons, David of Great Neck and Michael and Diane Abt of Oakland, Ca. Funeral services will be held Sunday, at a time to be arranged, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. For further details please call 516-487-9600.

Gone are the days when trains, planes and automobiles were all about speed. From skies to subways, these latest concepts -- some arriving shortly and others still en route -- will change the way we travel by eliminating frills and lightening the load. Recently, researchers in Finland made the discovery that some people's bodies do not respond as expected to weight training, others don't respond to endurance exercise and, in some lamentable cases, some don't respond to either. In other words, there are those who just do not become fitter or stronger, no matter what exercise they undertake. To reach this conclusion, the researchers enrolled 175 sedentary adults in a 21-week exercise program. Some lifted weights twice a week. Others jogged or walked. Some did both. Before and after the program, the volunteers' fitness and muscular strength were assessed. At the end of the 21 weeks, the results, published earlier this year in Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, were mixed. In the combined strength-and-endurance-exercise program, the volunteers' physiological improvement ranged from a negative 8 percent (meaning they became 8 percent less fit) to a positive 42 percent. The results were similar in the groups that undertook only strength or only endurance training. Some improved their strength enormously, some not at all. Others became aerobically fitter but not stronger, while still others showed no improvements in either area. Only a fortunate few became both fitter and more buff. As the researchers from the University of Jyvaskyla wrote with some understatement, ''large individual differences'' exist ''in the responses to both endurance and strength training.'' Hidden away in the results of almost any study of exercise programs is the fact that some people do not respond at all, while others respond at an unusually high rate. Averaged, the results may suggest that a certain exercise program reliably will produce certain results - that jogging, say, three times a week for a month will improve VO2max (maximal oxygen capacity) or reduce blood pressure; and for almost any given group of exercisers, those results are likely to hold true. But for outliers, the impacts can be quite different. Their VO2max won't budge, or it will fall, or it will soar.

One of the great legacies of the 2000 presidential election debacle was how it changed the way courts talk to you. I know, because I was the one talking for the Florida Supreme Court. By the time of the recount meltdown, the court was already posting court documents online and broadcasting live on the Web. Though such communications are now commonplace, back then the Florida court was a pioneer in so visibly using these new technologies to speak directly to the world.

Australian drinking culture took a serious hit during the temperance movement: for the better part of the 20th century, pubs were required to close by 6 p.m., a restriction that fostered binge drinking (the notorious ''six o'clock swill'') and dampened any creativity behind the bar. But an interest in cocktail craft has sprung up in cities down under, starting first in Melbourne's small, speakeasy-style laneway bars and taking hold most recently in Sydney. In 2007, new laws made it easier and cheaper to open bars here, resulting in an onslaught of pocket-size watering holes that are big on character, from buttoned-up boîtes to faux dives.

PINTO--Marion. 1935-2010. American artist Marion Pinto died peacefully on September 21st in the SoHo loft in which she had lived and worked for 42 years. An early pioneer of the SoHo artists' district, she created one of the first images of the coming of age of SoHo when she was commissioned to paint a large mural for The Ballroom restaurant depicting several SoHo art world figures. The painting is now in the permanent collection of The Museum of the City of New York. Always something of a feminist, Pinto had the first one-woman show ever mounted at SoHo's Leslie/ Lohman Gallery (1975) entitled "Man As A Sex Object." The models for the voluptuous male nudes, both straight and gay, were artist friends and young men she picked up at "The Firehouse" a disused fire house which had become the headquarters for an early gay rights organization, The Gay Activists Alliance, conveniently located just across the street from her loft. It was in that same period that she painted the dual nude of Fritz Lohman and Charles Leslie which later hung in Bologna's Museo d'Arte Moderna in the mammoth exhibition entitled "Il Nudo". Marion was an integral part of the early SoHo arts phenomenon and fully engaged in the fights to legalize loft living and to save the neighborhood from physical demolition. She traveled extensively covering wide swatches of Europe, Asia and North Africa. Each journey resulted in wonderful series of paintings such as the collection simply called "Egypt" and another called "Japan," where she spent a year in a visiting artist program. Marion is remembered by her many friends and lovers not only as a richly talented artist, but as a marvelously intelligent, witty and loyal friend, and as someone utterly devoted to the City of New York. There will be a memorial celebration of Marion's life and work at The Leslie/ Lohman Gallery, 26 Wooster Street in SoHo on Sunday, December 5th from 4-6pm.

LICHTENDORF--Arthur E. Everyone who knew and loved Arthur just found their lives a little smaller. He died Saturday, November 13, 2010, at six thirty in the evening after doing everything he could to stay alive. He was 74. Arthur was a graduate of The Wharton School and Columbia School of Business. A very complex person, he was exceptionally smart, kind, irascible, funny, and a dandy in his own way. He was madly in love with his grandson, Max Wolf Lichtendorf. He died holding little Max's picture. Arthur was a consummate traveler who visited all seven continents. He loved food, theater, and history in its big picture as well as the story of his ancestors and his Jewish faith. He loved his small extended family and life-long friends. Most of all, he adored his daughter, Victoria Lichtedorf, son-in-law, Harper Langston, his first wife who died before him after thirty years of marriage, his soul mate Susan, and his beloved wife Judith who only wishes they had had more time. The funeral was held at 1pm Tuesday, November 16, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue, and East 65th Street. Interment followed at Beth El Cemetery.

Chocolate lovers will soon find plenty to satisfy their sweet tooth on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia. In December, the upscale British chocolatier Hotel Chocolat (which has a Stateside flagship on Boston's Newbury Street) will make good on its name by opening a boutique resort on Rabot Estate, its 140-acre cocoa plantation in the shadow of the twin-peaked Pitons. The hotel will offer guests the full chocolate-making experience, including taking part in the cocoa harvest while learning about the company's philanthropic program to benefit local farmers. ''The idea is to let our customers have the same experience that we have every time we step onto the estate,'' says Angus Thirlwell, who co-founded the company 17 years ago with Peter Harris. Should chocolate-making wear thin, guests, who stay in contemporary West Indian-style cottages, can also hike Gros Piton, embark on a fruit-tasting safari and dine on dishes like sautéed prawns with chocolate tapenade. JILL FERGUS

I was among the trial lawyers who represented Gov. George W. Bush; however, I focused not on whether to recount ballots, but (if it became necessary) how to recount them. That question included the famous choice between Vice President Al Gore's desire to count ''dimpled chads'' and other arguable indicia of an intent to vote, and Governor Bush's desire to count only clear ballot punches. Though legal research at first revealed no compelling precedent, eventually we made a happy discovery: after a series of disputed local elections in California, the state's county clerks had come to a bipartisan consensus on this issue. Even better, from my perspective, was that their answer favored Mr. Bush. The trouble was getting a witness to say so.

Election night was followed by an ordinary business day at the Supreme Court, so I dragged myself out of bed to get to the court in time for morning arguments. On the plaza, I ran into Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who was out taking his customary stroll -- unrecognized, as usual, by the tourists wandering by. The chief justice was famous for organizing betting pools on the outcome of presidential elections. We greeted each other, and I said something like, Isn't it amazing that we still don't know who won the election? He agreed. We both shook our heads and went our separate ways.

My life from the start of the recount on Nov. 8 until the curtain fell on Dec. 12 was a fog of sleepless nights, bad pizza and mediocre wine. The Watergate suite that I was occupying had so many rooms filled with so many laptops that I kept forgetting which computer I was using to write which of the briefs I and the other Gore lawyers had to file almost daily. But those details are a meaningless blur. What has stuck with me from that period is a gut-wrenching sense of lasting injustice. Some wrongfully decided Supreme Court decisions can be belatedly righted. Bush v. Gore cannot. I had argued the first Bush v. Gore case in the Supreme Court, which the justices unanimously sent back to Florida's judiciary for an explanation of how its approach to the recount could be reconciled with the state's own law. I was then stunned when questions from the bench to my co-counsel David Boies, who argued the second and ultimate case, hinted that the court might make permanent its earlier decision to stop the recount temporarily.

Robin Day, perhaps Britain's most influential furniture designer since World War II, whose spare, practical and affordable inventions were exemplified by the now ubiquitous ''polyprop'' chair, died Nov. 9 at his home in Chichester, England. He was 95. The cause of death was colon cancer, said his daughter, Paula Day.

How safe are those full body scanners being used at airports? In response to a letter written in April by professors at the University of California, San Francisco, calling for independent evaluations of the X-ray scanners, the Food & Drug Administration and the Department of Homeland Security recently offered more details on the testing of the so-called backscatter devices.

SOHMER--Bernard. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of Mathematics Bernard Sohmer, former Chairperson of the University Faculty Senate and former Dean of Students at The City College. Dr. Sohmer, who began teaching at CCNY in 1952, was deeply committed to public higher education and the City University's founding mission of access to academic excellence. An outstanding teacher, administrator and advocate for students, faculty and staff, he combined a keen intellect with a superb sense of humor and personal warmth. Dr. Sohmer's impact was felt in endless positive ways within CUNY, the higher education community generally, and the external community during his many decades of exemplary service. With the support of CUNY and The City College, and with the encouragement of The University Faculty Senate, a student scholarship has been established in Dr. Sohmer's honor at CCNY. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Benno Schmidt, Chair, Board of Trustees; Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor.

Bustling with commerce, the design-savvy city of Porto, Portugal, plays a convincing Milan to Lisbon's Rome. (Its pristine beaches, 10 minutes from downtown, give it a touch of Malibu, too.) And suddenly the city's long-neglected downtown -- with its vertiginous hills and elegant spires towering over the Douro River -- is all the rage again. Sleek new galleries, restaurants and boutiques have the old cobblestone streets buzzing anew. TASTEMAKERS: Art galleries were the first to recolonize the once-derelict Bombarda area, and the pioneer dealer Fernando Santos (Rua Miguel Bombarda 526-536; 011-351-22-606-1090), who shows leading artists like Pedro Cabrita Reis, now has three spaces in the neighborhood. Following suit, the design darling Paulo Lobo has hung out a shingle, Lobo Taste (Largo de S. Domingos 20; 011-351-22-201-7102), offering a selection of handmade housewares and objects, some of which he designed himself. A Vida Portuguesa (Rua Galeria de Paris 20, first floor; 011-351-22-202-2105) is a gorgeously styled emporium of artisanal Portuguese products, from soap to nuts. And the Centro Comercial Bombarda (Rua Miguel Bombarda 285) is where hipsters pile into the 26 clothing stores and salons on Saturdays to fluff up their weekend looks.

An article on Nov. 7 about Caribbean islands where you can keep costs down located the Barceló Dominican Beach resort in the Dominican Republic incorrectly. It is in Punta Cana, not Puerto Plata. The article also included outdated information about discounts offered at the six all-inclusive Barceló Hotels and Resorts in the Dominican Republic. After the section had gone to press, a discount of 30 percent was extended for stays from Dec. 24 to April 30, if booked by Nov. 30.

TOMORROW evening, for the first time in more than 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera will unveil a new production of Verdi's ''Don Carlo.'' The director is Nicholas Hytner, working with designs by Bob Crowley, both in their Met debuts. Roberto Alagna leads a starry cast as Don Carlo, the unstable son of Spain's icy King Philip II. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducts. Long a rarity, ''Don Carlo'' has in recent decades established itself among the most indispensable of Verdi's creations. But Verdi reworked the opera off and on for nearly 20 years, and unlike others he subjected to heavy revision, this one never settled into a single, universally accepted form.

Bacon sh is the kind of dinner that doesn't lend itself to a recipe, but here's how I made it, more or less. Last Saturday, a friend from Oregon came to visit, and we served him bacon and eggs for lunch around noon, with a quince crisp after. The eggs were full of spinach with a flicker of nutmeg, and the bacon was roasted in the oven, just before the crisp went in. This was bacon from real pigs, old-fashioned pigs, and a pound gave off nearly a cup of grease, for which I said silent thanks. I poured it off into a dish, where it now sits in the refrigerator, white and waxy, until I call it up for corn bread. But I didn't wash the hotel pan I used because I thought it would come in handy for something. And it did when I found some glossy hake fillets for dinner. The oven went on low, the hotel pan went into the 325-degree heat just long enough to melt the bacon grease, the hake was swiped on each side in the slick of fat before going into the oven and 12 minutes later we were all eating bacon fish. The point here is not this nonrecipe, though I urge it on you as a cheap and easy knockoff of the halibut poached in goose fat that helped make Rocco DiSpirito's name many years ago. The point is that I made a dinner that my entire family ate. Pasta and pizza aside, that may be a first. Much more in the general line of things was last night's dinner, when I cooked lamb with eggplant and nobody touched the eggplant but me and my wife, Susan.

In their stampede for informality, many in the fashion world discarded a fashion foundation, the tailored jacket. Well, they were wrong. The jacket was back in force during last week's mild weather, proving yet again that it is the wearers who are the final arbiters of style, not the designers. Some men chose camel-color jackets, and they looked great with faded denim, as well as with the traditional gray flannel.

I remember fondly those weekly trips with my mother to the grocery store as a young boy. My father would drop us off, then wait in our black Chevy station wagon, reading the paper and smoking half a pack of Pall Malls. Supermarkets in those days were smaller and easier to navigate. They were not cluttered with giant pyramidal stacks of toilet paper or bottled water. Back then, we walked on the wild side, drinking the water that was actually piped into our homes. There were not 20 varieties of cereal to choose from, either. Nor did you have to maneuver around bins filled with can openers and measuring cups to get to the staples that sustained human life in those days: bacon, eggs, butter, steaks, chops, Twinkies and ice cream.

Almost two-thirds of a century before he died, on Nov. 4, Noel Taylor, then a young artist, faced a tough audition: Marc Chagall would judge his work. The occasion was a landmark 1945 production of Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' at the Metropolitan Opera House, for which Chagall created the look, from scenery to props to costumes. Chagall, declining to pick up his own brushes and palette, was looking for someone else to paint his vision.

Beloved mother of Rabbi Janet Roberts (Dr. Eric Stern). Adored, adoring and proud grandmother of Dr. Joanna Stern Loewenberger (Jeremy) and Jeremy Roberts Stern (Tracy Ogin). Devoted sister of Michael Roberts (Faline), their sons Lenny (Kim) and Marc (Cheryl) and families. Her legacy is a blessing. Service Friday 10am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

ISLAND LIFE Born in 1960s New York City to a TV producer father (Sy Kravitz) and an actress mother (Roxie Roker of the TV classic ''The Jeffersons''), the multiple Grammy winner Lenny Kravitz grew up on both the Upper East Side (''the Metropolitan Museum was my backyard,'' he says) and in his maternal grandmother's neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''I had a really great upbringing full of art and music and friends, surrounded by colorful people and artists who expressed their inner feelings through their clothes and their homes.'' Yet he reaches back even further for creative inspiration and replenishment: to the Bahamas, his mother's homeland, where he owns a bungalow on the island of Eleuthera. He calls life there ''very simple, not luxurious, not convenient. It's a place where you gotta be real and they don't care how much money you have.'' He grooves on the island's eye-popping colors, ''the most beautiful burnt orange and pink sunsets, white sands and turquoise waters.'' And he's a big fan of conch. ''You can do anything you want with it -- grill it, fry it.'' He washes it down with coconut water straight from the coconut, alongside his faithful companion he found in the nearby streets, Leroy, a nearly year-old ''potcake'' (Bahamian patois for a mutt). ''He's just the bomb,'' Kravitz says, ''the coolest cat to hang out with.''

Sometimes the most incongruous partnerships yield the most inspired results. Case in point: J. Press, known for its preppy sportswear for men, has teamed up with Urban Outfitters. While J. Press has a history steeped in Ivy League lore, its partnership with the hipster powerhouse might be just the thing to loosen up its staid image. Conversely, Urban Outfitters's disheveled-chic aesthetic could benefit from a bit of polishing. The J. Press designer Mikito Takeshima sprinkled some references to ''Happy Days'' and ''Animal House'' into its classics and, faster than you can say ''toga party,'' a pairing worthy of the coolest slacker at Yale was born: a collection of trim wool slacks, plaid bomber jackets, blazers with gold hardware, slim button-down oxfords in faded hues and plush crew necks. Add some WASP-y accessories (rep ties and nautical belts) and you'll be on your way to graduating with a major in style with a minor in effortless cool. J. Press for Urban Outfitters will be available starting Nov. 19. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

For months, psychologists struggled to reach the eight year old boy in the burn unit of the Pediatric Hospital of Tacubaya, in Mexico City. He had been discovered in the basement of a house, tied to a water tank after being burned along the backs of both legs with a clothes iron by his uncle and aunt, who were later arrested. "Soma," Carsten Höller's enormous installation at the Hamburger Bahnhof -- Museum für Gegenwart in Berlin, is quite a trip down the rabbit hole -- complete with a host of special psychedelic effects and strange supporting characters. The title refers to the drink central to Vedic and greater Persian religious rites, the active ingredient of which some scholars believe was Amanita muscaria, a kind of psychoactive mushroom. Höller has constructed two long, fenced-in corrals with hay-lined floors, gigantic sculptures of magic mushrooms and an elevated, cushioned platform on which a limited number of visitors can sign up to spend the night. There are also freezers stocked with actual -- enormous -- samples of Amanita muscaria.

Several readers commented that La Grande Dame's Web site contributed to its S.E.O. challenges and urged an overhaul to address that issue and improve the site's appearance and functionality. La Grande Dame took the comments -- and similar ones from its customers -- to heart, and unveiled its new site last week. "Our ultimate goal was to improve the user experience and make it easier for shoppers to find what they want," said Catherine Wood Hill, La Grande Dame's chief executive.

Last time in "Egg Drop Soup" we had a puzzle about a tall building and eggs. Well, we've dumped the eggs this week, but we're keeping the tall building theme with a couple of problems on elevators. Elevators form our "invisible vertical transport system" and are endlessly fascinating from the engineering, social, mathematical and psychological points of view. They make modern cities possible and are the second most common forms of transport, carrying an estimated 325 million passengers per day in the United States alone. Most of us are familiar with the psychological experience of stepping into these boxes, sometimes uncomfortably crowded with strangers, temporarily putting our lives on hold and activating our vacant stares and hyper-polite personae. In case you are nostalgic for this memorable experience, you can relive it by pressing the buttons Gary has provided on the right (like true elevator buttons, you cannot "undo" a button you've pressed!). Mathematically, elevators provide scope for all kinds of fascinating transport and scheduling algorithms. Here are a couple of puzzles from this realm. The first one features a new twist on a common favorite.

Glenn Branca's sound comes in two parts: the thing itself -- notes and chords and beats -- and the effect. A steady rhythm secures the pulse. (He likes two- and four-beat rhythms a lot, and makes them swing, in an early-60s rock 'n' roll kind of way.) Through notation and conducting he stirs the flow of music in several directions at once, forming stimulating dissonance and contrapuntal shapes between tidal currents of chords. When done with electric guitars -- whether four or a hundred -- the music becomes very loud, and you might find yourself listening by feel more than by thought. Not that you should expect a composer to reinvent himself every time out. Not that there haven't been different rhythmic and dynamic concerns in his work, especially when he's moved away from electric guitars and has used a full, traditional symphony orchestra. Not that he hasn't used structured improvisation as well as straight composition across the past 35 years or so, and written for nonmusicians as well as orchestra professionals. But for all this, generalizing about his music has been all too easy.

SPECTOR--E. Gladys, a rare book and antique dealer who became a leading authority on the artist Rockwell Kent, died Thursday, November 18 of cancer at home in Queens, NY. Mrs. Spector, with her husband George, was the founder and publisher of the Kent Collector, a quarterly publication that they began in 1974. Mrs. Spector started collecting antiques, books, prints, and other works of art in earnest in 1957 and specialized in the work of Rockwell Kent. Mrs. Spector was a member of the Long Island Book Dealers Association and the Long Island Book Collectors. She is survived by two sons, Charles Green of Vermont and James Driscoll of Long Island, six grandchildren and eight great--grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be announced in the Kent Collector.

Kyle Orton would make a great comeback player of the year award nominee if not for a minor problem: he never really went anywhere. Orton went 10-5 as a rookie starter for the Bears in 2005 before being banished to the third string for two seasons. He regained his starting job in 2008, moved to Denver in 2009, and has been steadily improving since. He's not Drew Brees, but a guy on pace to throw for 4,988 yards deserves better than to be overshadowed by his own backup. Philip Rivers is on pace to throw for 5,233 yards, but he has been overshadowed by his team's inability to kick straight. Between the back-and-forth passing and the potential for chaos on every punt, this game will be more fun to watch than last week's Vick Capades.

An obituary on Oct. 17 about the mathematician Benoît B. Mandelbrot referred incorrectly to his time at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. He did research there; he was not there ''for a postdoctoral degree.'' (The Institute for Advanced Study does not grant degrees.) This correction was delayed because the e-mail pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

LOS ANGELES -- The seventh Harry Potter movie opened to a jaw-dropping $330 million in global ticket sales over the weekend, underscoring the magical powers of the Warner Brothers marketing and distribution departments. That brawny total easily made ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1'' No. 1 in North America, where the boy wizard generated an estimated $125.1 million. It was the second-biggest domestic opening for the Harry Potter franchise; adjusting for higher ticket prices, ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' sold $127.4 million over its first three days in November 2005.

Even as developed countries close or limit the construction of coal-fired power plants out of concern over pollution and climate-warming emissions, coal has found a rapidly expanding market elsewhere: Asia, particularly China. At ports in Canada, Australia, Indonesia, Colombia and South Africa, ships are lining up to load coal for furnaces in China, which has evolved virtually overnight from a coal exporter to one of the world's leading purchasers.

6:47 p.m. | Updated The American International Group is shopping around its rail-car unit, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday. The move would be part of the insurer's plan to sell noncore businesses to pay down its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout. The unit, AIG Rail Services, is based in Chicago and has more than 10,000 rail cars and leases, said the person, who requested anonymity because of the confidential nature of the sales process. Potential buyers could include buyout firms.

Workers of the world unite and bemoan the end of the ''buddy punch.'' For the unfamiliar, a buddy punch occurs when someone clocks in at a job for a missing co-worker. It's a much-loved practice of workers who don't want their pay docked because some traffic or a boozy night out on the town caused them to run late. It's also a practice frowned upon by the business owners trying to keep track of their staff.

DWIGHT--Eleanor Collier, 72, died on November 16. Born September 5, 1938, in Boston, she attended St. Timothy's and Shipley schools and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1960. She earned a master's degree from Columbia University in 1964 and a Ph.D. in American literature from New York University in 1984. She lived all her adult life in New York City. An Edith Wharton scholar, she wrote an illustrated biography of Edith Wharton, published in 1994. Her other books portrayed Diana Vreeland, the Gilded Age in New York City, and tennis innovator James Van Alen. Her articles on gardens, travel, and literature appeared in Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful, and New York magazines, and the New York Times. She taught and lectured extensively on literature and gardens. She gardened with her husband at their summer home on Mount Desert Island, Maine. A formidable intellect, she served on the boards of Edith Wharton's estate "The Mount," the Colony Club, and the Garden Club of Mount Desert, and was a member of the Century Association. Married 34 years to George H.P. Dwight, who died in 2009, she is survived by her three children, Daphne Trotter, Willard Gardiner, and Sargent Gardiner; her five step-children, Lucinda Dwight, George Dwight, Margaret Dwight, Bradley Dwight, and Susannah Prout; eight grandchildren; and seven step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Tuesday, December 7, at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street, New York, NY. Donations to the George and Eleanor Dwight Memorial Fund at Groton School, Groton, MA, and The Mount, Lenox, MA, are welcome.

According to Activision, its publisher, just five days after its release the game has generated more than $650 million in worldwide sales, beating out Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, which smashed previous sale records when it was released last year.

The last two years haven't been easy on New York museums, but they've been particularly challenging for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. In a disastrous 2008, the museum's net assets declined by 25 percent. The latest tax filings show that 2009 was not nearly as bad, though the numbers still offer cause for concern. Despite a round of layoffs (completed midyear), expenses exceeded revenue by more than $12 million. Contributions were down from the previous year, to $20 million. The foundation's endowment decreased slightly, to $62.5 million from $64.4 million.

Mr. Li, speaking at the Web 2.0 conference in San Francisco Monday, was making his first public comments at an American industry conference. He spoke shortly after Eric E. Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, had taken the same stage.

9 P.M. (13, 49) LENNONYC Using unreleased recordings, rare concert footage and an emotional interview with Yoko Ono, ''American Masters'' chronicles the time John Lennon spent in New York City. The story begins with Lennon's arrival in 1971, as he sought freedom from his persona as a Beatle and escape from the public scorn he and Ms. Ono, above in the 1970s, faced in London. It continues with his persecution by the Nixon administration, which used the F.B.I. and the Immigration and Naturalization Service to tap his phone and put him under 24-hour surveillance with the purpose of deporting him; the 18 months after Ms. Ono had kicked him out of their apartment in the Dakota in Manhattan; and his return, after a five-year hiatus, to the recording studio in 1980, a few months before he was killed. 9 A.M. (FOX NEWS CHANNEL) AMERICA'S NEWSROOM Martha MacCallum interviews David Axelrod, White House senior adviser, and his wife, Susan, about the epilepsy of their daughter, Lauren, and their foundation, Citizens United for Research in Epilepsy. Ms. MacCallum also visits Lauren at Misericordia, a Chicago home and school for the developmentally disabled, which Mr. Axelrod credits with making his daughter happy, productive and independent.

When Oliver Kreylos, a computer scientist, heard about the capabilities of Microsoft's new Kinect gaming device, he couldn't wait to get his hands on it. ''I dropped everything, rode my bike to the closest game store and bought one,'' he said. But he had no interest in playing video games with the Kinect, which is meant to be plugged into an Xbox and allows players to control the action onscreen by moving their bodies.

It would not be the closest casino with table games to Manhattan; some casinos in Pennsylvania that recently added table games are slightly closer, though they are farther away from other parts of New York City.

STAMATIOU--Dorothy. Our beloved mother, Dorothy, passed away peacefully in her home on November 20th. She is survived by her two children Rina and Dean and her loving companion Margret, her sister Gloria, brother William and several extended family members. Born in Washington D.C. to Constantine and Athanasia Crassas on January 20th 1921, she served her country at the Pentagon during WWII. She later married her late husband, Evangelos Stamatiou. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. Visitation Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Wednesday. For further info call Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 212-288-3500.

An article on Thursday about how Wisconsin might change the way it implements the new federal health care law under a new Republican governor who opposes the law misstated the professional background of Florida's governor-elect, Rick Scott, another Republican who strongly opposes the law. He was an executive of a chain of hospitals, not an insurance executive.

CASTRONOVO--Professor David A.,65, of Manhattan died suddenly on November 19. The C. Richard Pace Professor at Pace University in New York City where he taught English literature and composition for more than 30 years, David was the author of a dozen books on literary subjects, including Blokes: The Bad Boys of British Literature (2009). His first book, Edmund Wilson, was named a New York Times Notable Book in 1985. The week he died his review of Christopher Hitchens' memoir Hitch-22 appeared in Commonweal and was billed on its cover. David attended Brooklyn College and received his Masters and Ph.D. in English from Columbia University. A specialist in Victorian studies, he wrote his dissertation on the English gentleman, a subject that he expanded upon and turned into a book in 1987. He is survived by his sister Val, his brother-in-law Alan Waxman, his niece Olivia, and a legion of friends, many of whom he mentored. David's kindness, erudition and rapier wit will be greatly missed. A funeral mass will be held Wednesday at 11:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 84th and Park Avenue. Please consider donations in David's memory to the English Department at Pace University or Columbia University's Graduate School of Arts & Sciences.

When the Los Angeles Dodgers were searching for a manager five years ago, Paul DePodesta was prepared to hire Terry Collins, the team's minor league field coordinator. DePodesta, then the general manager, loved Collins's passion and thought of him as a star of player development. Unfortunately for both men, DePodesta was fired by the Dodgers before he could make the move, and Grady Little was hired instead. But five years later, and now working as vice president for player development and amateur scouting for the Mets, DePodesta finally got his man.

Dallas IT was with great trepidation that I approached 3307 N Street in Washington on Nov. 10, 1960. I had just been given the assignment of providing protection for the wife of the newly elected president of the United States, and I was about to meet her for the first time.

It has been a whirlwind year for Clayton Kendrick-Holmes. His Maritime College team went 10-0 in the regular season. He was named the conference coach of the year. He became friendly with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell. But on Sunday, a day after Maritime's season ended with a 60-0 loss to Alfred University in the program's first appearance in the N.C.A.A. Division III playoffs, the reality of Kendrick-Holmes's situation became real. After he participated in the coin toss before the Jets' game against the Houston Texans in East Rutherford, N.J., he drove with his wife and their two sons to Norfolk, Va., where he will train before being deployed to Afghanistan. A member of the Navy Reserve, Kendrick-Holmes, a former linebacker at Navy who served a three-year tour aboard the U.S.S. Robert G. Bradley, was informed he would be mobilized in July. Since then he has been preparing for his tour, which he expected to last about a year.

ROSENBERG--Joan Levy, passed away in Atlanta, GA on Saturday November 20th 2010, after a brief illness. She was born in New York City on August 12, 1915. Graciela, Ofelia and Pedro from Patagonia stood around the counter with me in Buenos Aires, chomping on pizza slices and trying to explain  why Argentines dine so late. We were at Guerrin, an institution where you get to know the strangers standing next to you because you're in close quarters and there's nothing to do but talk. (My primary rule for lone travelers: always talk to strangers. At the very least you could end up with a bit of conversation over pizza. At best, you end up getting set up on a blind date. Back in September, Joshua Knobe of Yale University, writing here at The Stone, outlined a new experimental approach to doing philosophy in his post, "Experiments in Philosophy." Philosophers, he argued, have spent enough time cogitating in their armchairs. Knobe described how he and a group of like-minded colleagues in the discipline have undertaken a more engaged approach, working with cognitive scientists and designing experiments that will "test" people's intuitions about traditional philosophic puzzlers such as the existence of God, the objectivity of ethics and the possibility of free will. The result: new, empirically-grounded insights available to philosophers and psychologists.

For those not in the market for a million-dollar Warhol, there's Exhibition A, a new online art platform offering limited edition pieces by big-name artists - all in a nicely priced range from $100 to $500. Each week, the Web site's creators, Bill Powers, Cynthia Rowley, Laura Martin and Gabby Munoz, will offer new editions of work from the likes of Terence Koh, Richard Phillips, Geoff McFetridge and Rene Ricard. While some of the artists will offer a set number of signed works, others will offer open editions for a limited amount of time (usually between two and four weeks). Though the flash sales require budding art enthusiasts to think quickly on their feet, it allows "people new to collecting a point of entry that isn't super scary on the financial side," Powers said.

At the end of 2008, I was part of an NYTimes.com team that took structured data sets from many aspects of The Times and centralized them into one data repository. Last week, Google unveiled its e-commerce fashion venture, Boutiques.com, at the heart of which are online stores curated by celebrities and tastemakers. The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site. "The process was a ton of fun," Palermo said, "but I actually spent hours playing with it. It's quite addictive!" No stranger to online shopping, Palermo has mostly been browsing on net-a-porter.com and matchesfashion.com for Giambattista Valli, Christopher Kane and the French label Maje to feature in her boutique, her goal being to make scouring the racks easy and accessible for shoppers with similar taste. "Whether it's a Marchesa gown straight off the runway or a basic Topshop piece, everything is at your fingertips," she says. She appreciates Google's complex algorithms, which show browsers alternative items should the ones they want be unavailable or too pricey. The downside? "It's accessible and free - until you start buying all the items you find."

When short-term interest rates are up against the zero lower bound, whatever power the Fed has to influence the economy comes largely from its ability to affect expectations. This is true even for Bernanke-style quantitative easing: you can't really push down longer-term yields unless the market believes that you're going to keep buying until the rates are where you want them. It's even more true when it comes to credibly raising expected rates of inflation.

I have been reading with great interest (especially here) the stories of retailers sharing their experiences using Groupon. For those of you not familiar with Groupon, the company partners with local businesses to send a daily coupon e-blast to its members. The members who buy the coupon get 50 to 70 percent off on a product or service, and Groupon splits the proceeds with the retailer -- usually leaving the retailer with about 20 to 25 cents on the dollar of retail value.

DANER--Joel. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a highly beloved alumnus of Yeshiva College '60, Isaac Breuer College '61 and Wurzweiler School of Social Work '62 who had consecrated his life to serving the community as a social worker and mentor to hundreds of Jewish communal workers worldwide. A member of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work Board of Overseers, he and his wife Selma were Yeshiva University Guardians and established the Daner Family Scholarship Fund at the school. Heartfelt condolences to Selma and their daughters: Ellen and Linda. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Wurzweiler School of Social Work Dr. Robert Schwalbe, Chair Board of Overseers

Hollywood has waited many years to tell the story of the adult-film star Linda Lovelace, but it won't wait any longer to tell that story with Lindsay Lohan. The director of ''Inferno,'' a planned film about the life of Lovelace, who starred in ''Deep Throat'' and other pornographic movies, said he had parted ways with Ms. Lohan and was pursuing another actress to play the role, The Hollywood Reporter said. The part of Lovelace (nee Linda Boreman), who became a household - or at least a bedroom - name of sorts in the 1970s after the multimillion-dollar success of ''Deep Throat,'' had been mentioned as a comeback vehicle for Ms. Lohan, the ''Mean Girls'' star who in October was ordered back to rehab after failing a drug test. (The real-life Lovelace became an anti-pornography advocate before dying of injuries from a car accident in 2002.)

Quick: Who's the superhero with ticket-selling powers? Comic-Con is in need of some. Tickets for the 2011 edition of Comic-Con International, the annual convention in San Diego that celebrates comic books and related television shows and movies, were supposed to go on sale at 6 a.m. Pacific time on Monday. Crew, the clothier of choice for the likes of Michelle Obama, is near a deal to sell itself for about $2.8 billion to the buyout firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday. Under the terms of the proposed deal, TPG - a former owner of the retailer - and Leonard Green would work with the company's chairman and chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, these people said. The buyout firms are expected to pay about $43.50 a share, a 16 percent premium to Monday's closing price of $37.65.

The energy industry's love for shale gas has been in evidence in recent years. Companies like Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron have poured billions of dollars into deals to give them access to acreage in the Marcellus Shale and other shale formations. Alongside these global giants in oil and natural gas has been an investment bank that is only middling among merger advisers: Jefferies & Company. Yet the bank has managed to broker nearly every single major deal in shale.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Thursday about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the Charles Schwab YieldPlus mutual fund described some of its investments incorrectly in some editions. The fund was heavily composed of mortgage-related securities, but only about 5 percent of its holdings were riskier subprime investments; it was not ''packed with subprime investments.''

No turkeys were harmed in the writing of this column. For the past three weeks, The New York Times's Well blog has been collecting holiday vegetarian and vegan recipes from an all-star team of chefs and food writers. The haul has been mouthwatering: among other things, crisp low-fat zucchini cakes; avocado and grapefruit salad; honey-roasted acorn squash; chestnut and apple casserole; and a surprisingly easy chocolate-pumpkin bread pudding made with coconut milk instead of dairy products.

The teacher, Jake Ahern, works at the Spence School -- not at Collegiate School.

Novell, the software maker, said on Monday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Attachmate Corporation for $2.2 billion in cash. Novell also plans to sell some intellectual property assets like patents for $450 million to a consortium of technology companies led by Microsoft. Attachmate's takeover is contingent on the successful closing of that sale.

The independent company Energy XXI has agreed to buy $1 billion in oil and natural gas properties in the Gulf of Mexico from Exxon Mobil. The deal, announced on Sunday, includes nine shallow-water fields on the Gulf of Mexico shelf, located primarily between Energy XXI's two main drilling operations there. Energy XXI is the operator of 94 percent of the assets being acquired.

WEEKEND An art review on Friday about an exhibition of work by Marlene McCarty at New York University's 80WSE gallery misidentified a designer of the show's catalog. In addition to Ms. McCarty, it was designed by Jeremy Olson -- not by Michael Cohen, the organizer of the show.

It was utter euphoria for New York Jets fans after Mark Sanchez drove the team downfield with less than a minute remaining and pulled out a miraculous victory over the Houston Texans at the new Meadowlands Stadium on Sunday. But when cameras showed the cheering crowd, it seemed that most of the fans had already given up on the team. After all, the Jets had blown a big lead in the fourth quarter before snatching back victory with seconds remaining.

KAUFMAN--Stanley H.,passed away November 21, 2010 in his 92nd year. Loving and beloved husband of Tema for 60 years. A man of great integrity and intelligence, he was a scholar and army captain and always a consummate gentleman. His career was in men's clothing and he originated the Christian Dior license program in the US. Proud father of Julie (Walter Niemasik) and Dr. Peter (Marie Lurquin) and adoring grandfather to James and Thomas Niemasik and Benjamin Kaufman. Services will be held on Wednesday, November 24 at Congregation Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains at 11am.

THE ARTS A film review on Wednesday about ''William S. Burroughs: A Man Within'' misstated the given name of a poet whom Burroughs quotes at one point in the film. He was Edwin Arlington Robinson, not Edward.

HOROWITZ--Joseph, 83, died peacefully on November 21, 2010, in Nassau County, New York after a brief illness. Having worked in the textile industry for over 50 years, his passion, intensity and skill as a deal-maker was known by those who worked with him in the Garment Center. Joe was a great cook and loved the New York Giants, but his love for them did not compare for what he felt for his wife Elaine, and daughters and sons-in-law, Linda and David Freedman and Nancy and David Slavin. As the definitive grandfather, however, his greatest affection was reserved for his grandchildren, Samantha, Suzanna, Zach, and Max. He will be remembered fondly and greatly missed.

IXTLÁN de JUÁREZ, Mexico -- As an unforgiving midday sun bore down on the pine-forested mountains here, a half-dozen men perched across a steep hillside wrestled back mounds of weeds to uncover wisps of knee-high seedlings. Freeing the tiny pines that were planted last year is only one step of many the town takes to nurture the trees until they grow tall, ready for harvesting in half a century. But the people of Ixtlán take the long view.

Shakira Castronovo stood in a classroom at the Manhattan School for Children on West 93rd Street on a recent afternoon and hushed a squirming group of kindergartners perched around a blue carpet. ''Where do you think I picked this?'' she asked, pinching a leafy-looking thing between her index finger and thumb. ''It was picked fresh just few minutes ago.''

HAMILTON--Ian Morgan, 1923-2010. Died November 14, 2010, peacefully at home in England. Much loved father of Amanda Hamilton, stepfather of Alexandra Woods, younger brother of David Hamilton. Cherished by his devoted friends and community. Predeceased by his wife, Anina Paepcke Hamilton. Funeral to be held at St. Mary's Church, Offham, E. Sussex, UK, 2nd December, 2010. All enquiries to RA Brooks & Sons, Funeral Directors, Haywards Heath, W. Sussex. UK.

Once again, what's good for banks -- and their shareholders -- may not be so great for consumers. The Federal Reserve's new stress tests, along with the new Basel III international rules on capital requirements, are aimed at ensuring that big banks are well capitalized and, in the United States, finally allowing them to raise dividends to shareholders. But according to banking experts, one big result is likely to be that those banks will also raise the costs of loans of all kinds, including corporate loans, mortgages and credit cards.

Michael Savage, the combative talk radio host, has signed a deal to write two thrillers for St. Martin's Press, the publisher said on Monday. Until now Mr. Savage has stuck to nonfiction, with books like ''Liberalism Is a Mental Disorder,'' ''The Savage Nation'' and ''The Enemy Within.'' Mr. Savage, whose personal ''manifesto'' on his Web site calls for closing the United States' borders, ending affirmative action and instituting a flat tax, attracts more than nine million weekly listeners to his syndicated radio show, according to Talkers magazine. His first novel, ''Abuse of Power,'' is set in San Francisco and tells the story of a failed carjacking that reveals a government coverup, a sinister plot involving British officials and a terrorist group known as the Hand of Allah ''that will make 9/11 look like child's play,'' the publisher said in a statement. It is scheduled for publication next summer.

An obituary on Friday about W. Howard Lester, the owner of the housewares retailer Williams-Sonoma, misstated the given name of the author of the book ''How They Achieved,'' in which he was quoted. She is Lucinda Watson, not Linda. The obituary also misstated Joanne Parrent's connection to the book. She was the editor, not the co-author.

GROVER--Inez L. (nee Learner), 83, passed away on November 17 at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair NJ, after a long illness. Inez was a UCLA graduate in Fine Arts - a great joy was in visiting art museums around the world - and on her retirement in 1993. She had been employed as the graphic artist at the Montclair Board of Education. Inez was born in Jersey City, NJ; spent her early years in Los Angeles and had resided for the past 50 years in Montclair, NJ. She is survived by her loving family: husband, Martin; son Andrew; daughter Laura and by her beloved granddaughter, Esther Rose. Inez will be cremated. Her friends and loved ones will be advised concerning her Memorial Service in due course. Please make any donations in Inez's memory to your own favorite charity.

SPINGARN--Edward, passed away on November 21, 2010. He was a wonderful and caring person. Survived his wife Suzanne Spingarn and his nieces and nephews. Services will be held November 23 at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Nov. 16 about the Spanish filmmaker Luis García Berlanga referred incorrectly to the village in which his film ''Bienvenido, Mr. Marshall!'' was set. It was a Castilian village that took on Andalusian trappings to impress a visiting American delegation; it was not an Andalusian village. The error also appeared on Nov. 19, 1993, in an article about the movie and on April 5, 1953, in an article about the making of the movie.
F.B.I. agents raided the offices of three hedge funds on Monday, the government's latest salvo in an escalating investigation into insider trading on Wall Street.

FLASTERSTEIN--Shirley, 89, passed away peacefully at home on November 21, 2010. A woman of striking beauty, intelligence and grace, she was inseparable from husband Alexander, who recently predeceased her. Cherished mother of Lee and son-in-law Donald, adored grandmother of Paul, Joyce and granddaughter-in-law Lisa, she warmed all our lives with her love and caring.

CASTRONOVO--Professor David A.,65, of Manhattan died suddenly on November 19. The C. Richard Pace Professor at Pace University in New York City where he taught English literature and composition for more than 30 years, David was the author of a dozen books on literary subjects, including Blokes: The Bad Boys of British Literature (2009). His first book, Edmund Wilson, was named a New York Times Notable Book in 1985. The week he died his review of Christopher Hitchens' memoir Hitch-22 appeared in Commonweal and was billed on its cover. David attended Brooklyn College and received his Masters and Ph.D. in English from Columbia University. A specialist in Victorian studies, he wrote his dissertation on the English gentleman, a subject that he expanded upon and turned into a book in 1987. He is survived by his sister Val, his brother-in-law Alan Waxman, his niece Olivia, and a legion of friends, many of whom he mentored. David's kindness, erudition and rapier wit will be greatly missed. A funeral mass will be held Wednesday at 11:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 84th and Park Avenue. Please consider donations in David's memory to the English Department at Pace University or Columbia University's Graduate School of Arts & Sciences.

DWYER--Elizabeth Anne. The Browning School community notes with sadness the death of Elizabeth Dwyer, mother of Alex and Nate. Our thoughts are with the boys, and their father Dan. The Dwyer family is a key part of our school, and Elizabeth will be deeply missed. James S. Chanos President, Board of Trustees Stephen M. Clement, III Headmaster Susan A. Grimbalas President, Parents Association

Part of the disconnect some fans feel with sportswriters is that we don't understand their perspective. How could we, without rooting for teams we cover? Yet almost all of us started as fans, and recalling those days can be instructive. Growing up, I rooted for the Philadelphia teams. When the Eagles played on ''Monday Night Football,'' we growled that the announcer Dan Dierdorf simply hated our team. When writers annually predicted a gloomy year for the Phillies, we howled that they were biased. They were usually right, but that was beside the point.

Since she joined the Azzaro French luxury brand as artistic director eight years ago, Vanessa Seward has brought it out of the exclusive realm of fancy-wear and into every-wear -- pieces that meet the sundry needs of the everywoman. Not that she is opposed to the glamour. "It was an unconscious move for the line," says the designer and new mom. "I think having a baby brought a youthfulness, freshness and versatility to the collection." As she revisited the generations of inspirational women before her, photographs from the 1930s of her grandmother and friends vacationing along the Tigre River in Argentina resurfaced. "Their clothing were all the things I wanted: timeless, comfortable and pretty," she says. The Voyage capsule collection, Azzaro's latest diffusion line, is designed with comfort and a more carefree agenda in mind. It includes wrinkle-free materials like jerseys, knits and cashmere, introduced in sophisticated separates (think playsuits and pantsuits) and dresses, like a wrap model with embroidered cord detail. "The Azzaro woman is a woman that shows her femininity," Seward says. "Nowadays women don't have to be in a power suit to be in power."

A distinct gloom has descended upon conversations among those of us whose business it is to attend the theater as often as some people turn on the television set. By which I mostly mean critics, although I do number among my friends a few obsessive civilians who see almost as much as I do. Everyone wants a piece of Kate Moss. A kitten heel short of most modern glamazons, Moss has been one of the most in-demand fashion models for two decades - and one of the most talked about. Now there's a bit more of her to go around. For the past year and a half, Moss has been collaborating with James Danziger, of Danziger Projects, on curating a portfolio of 11 images of her by 11 of her favorite photographers. The result, a limited edition of 30 portfolios designed by Ruth Ansel and priced from $75,000 each (the figure is expected to go up as the series sells out), is being exhibited for the first time at the Pulse art fair in Miami Dec. 2 to 5. The images, by a stellar lineup of fashion and art world luminaries, including Chuck Close, Juergen Teller and Annie Leibovitz, showcase not only Moss's preternatural beauty but also her undeniable versatility. The Moment recently phoned Moss at her country home in England.

A woman's work is definitely never done in a Mika Rottenberg video. I mean really never. The women in her latest, "Squeeze" -- one of the bigger attractions in Chelsea right now -- submit to the drudgery of their assembly-line labors without a peep, as if that were all life was about. Seen in Arizona and India and confined to a spa-from-hell in Rottenberg's Harlem studio, they pick lettuce, collect rubber sap, stretch it into latex, massage sore hands and manufacture blush from the scrapings of their own reddened cheeks. And all they get out of it is more work.

"I was conditioned to try to become a doctor just as my father - I even majored in Political Science in college," said the jewelry designer Hirotaka Inoue during a visit to T's offices. The transition from political theorist to jeweler started in Paris where Inoue studied how to select and set stones before returning to Japan working for a jewelry firm. Designing his own line in 2009, Inoue's first collection, available at the Nolita boutique Eva (355A Bowery, between Third and Fourth Streets, (212) 925-3890), showcases his intricate craftsmanship and his whimsical nature. One of his creations is a new beige-colored gold. "It's not flashy but a very chic choice of metal - it took six months to get the right percentage of silver, copper and some platinum to make the sand gold color," he says. More playful designs include the Vanité collection of skull charms ($477 and up), some with black diamond teeth accents, to the classic Serpent and Naja rings (starting at $550), featuring intricate scaling detailwork. Inoue says, "My jewelry can change its color like a chameleon - classic to funny to cool to chic."

Thanksgiving is Thursday, but the real holiday for college football fans comes on Friday. The day's slate features three games (Auburn at Alabama, Arizona at Oregon, Boise State at Nevada) that have the potential to seismically shift the national championship race. Even if the Auburn, Oregon and Boise State win on Friday, Saturday offers plenty of intrigue. The Big Ten and Big 12 South have plenty of meaningful football left to play, with Michigan State at Penn State, and Oklahoma at Oklahoma State headlining the action in their respective conferences. And will also be plenty of interest in games that involve ranked teams that don't have a chance to win their conference (Louisiana State at Arkansas), in-state rivals (Florida at Florida State) and long-time foes who have seen better days (Notre Dame at Southern California). It's a holiday week, so take time to celebrate with perhaps the best weekend of the college football season.

The Winter 2010 issue of T Design & Living contained a preview of the exhibition "How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now" at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition opened last weekend, and while drinking wine in museum galleries is strictly prohibited, the design of the show brings wine into the galleries in other, ingenious ways. The museum's architecture curator, Henry Urbach, collaborated on the installation with the New York architecture firm Diller Scofidio and Renfro, whose design for "The American Lawn: Surface of Everyday Life," a 1998 exhibition at the Canadian Center for Architecture, convinced him that the architects would help bring something "as banal as fermented grapes" to life. For their part, the architects were intrigued by the idea of tackling a subject that's not traditional museum fare. Elizabeth Diller, one of the firm's partners, said, "Certain aspects of the story of wine's transformation were more obvious - the branding of wineries with star architecture, design of stemware, labels, etc. -- while it was less apparent how to present the experiential aspects of wine."

Not all flower arrangements need a vase - especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap fall's bounty for a cool still life. It could be arranged on your mantel, or a maybe a sideboard, or even a centerpiece for your dining table (if there's room). I can arrive at my friends'  house with a bag of produce from the market and a few items from my garden and do up an arrangement quickly and easily while sipping a drink. Here's how you can, too.In the example here, I'm using white pumpkins - one big, several small - plus bittersweet vine, lady apples, small pears and a few  leaves. Persimmons and quince would have made this grouping that much better, for the fuzz and color they bring. Ultimately, it's all about the mix, the color palette and a balance of big and small, linear and round.

Back in the 1970s, researchers in Japan studied child laborers and discovered that, among their many misfortunes, the juvenile workers tended to be abnormally short. Physical labor, the researchers concluded, with its hours of lifting and moving heavy weights, had stunted the children's growth. Somewhat improbably, from that scientific finding and other similar reports, as well as from anecdotes and accreting myth, many people came to believe "that children and adolescents should not" practice weight training, said Avery Faigenbaum, a professor of exercise science at the College of New Jersey. That idea retains a sturdy hold in the popular imagination. As a recent position paper on the topic of children and resistance training points out, many parents, coaches and pediatricians remain convinced that weight training by children will "result in short stature, epiphyseal plate" - or growth plate - "damage, lack of strength increases due to a lack of testosterone and a variety of safety issues."
