Over the past four years, New York City has dedicated more than 250 miles of traffic lanes to bicycles, and has passed several laws intended to promote cycling. Yet a backlash has taken hold in various neighborhoods, from Staten Island -- where the city removed a 2.35-mile painted bike lane along Father Capodanno Boulevard -- to Brooklyn -- where opponents protested last month alongside supporters of the lanes on Prospect Park West. The City Council will hold a hearing on Dec. 9 to address balancing the needs of cyclists with those of other road users. Last week, City Room asked readers to weigh in, and hundreds responded. Here are some of their thoughts:

Joe Klecko, a member of the New York Sack Exchange defense in the 1980s, was among the first six inducted into the Jets' Ring of Honor at New Meadowlands Stadium. He was the first player to be selected for the Pro Bowl at three positions-- defensive end, defensive tackle and nose tackle -- and has been nominated for the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Klecko, 57, is a Jets analyst on SNY and a consultant for Trinity Solar, a designer and integrator of solar electric systems in Freehold, N.J. Q. How does Rex Ryan's defense compare with the Jets' defense when you played?

Some of the top performances in Saturday's games: TYLER BRAY Tennessee's quarterback, left, threw for 354 yards and 2 touchdowns as the Volunteers became eligible for a bowl by beating Kentucky, 24-14, their 26th consecutive victory over the Wildcats.

A listing of place names on the Nov. 14 cover, referring to articles inside, misstated the name of the country in which Kutna Hora, a medieval town near Prague that makes an interesting overnight destination, is located. As the map indicated, the listing should have placed Kutna Hora in the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia. (Czechoslovakia was split into the Czech and Slovak Republics on Jan. 1, 1993, at which point Czechoslovakia ceased to exist.)

The Gaylord Opryland hotel in Nashville celebrated its reopening last weekend with three days of events that included country music concerts, a Christmas tree lighting and indoor fireworks at its Delta Atrium. The scale of the celebration matched the scale of the Gaylord (gaylordhotels.com), which with more than 2,800 rooms, bills itself as the largest nongaming hotel in the United States. It had been closed since being damaged by flooding in early May. The hotel said that 70 percent of the common areas and all of the subterranean areas were underwater.

BLACK FRIDAY'S starting gun may have already sounded, but for thousands of immigrants in New York, this week is the final, breathless stretch of a holiday shopping season that began with August clearance sales and ends when freighters departing the Port of Miami for the Caribbean can no longer guarantee Christmas delivery. For local shipping companies that need to factor semitrailers and the I-95 corridor into the equation, that cutoff is fast approaching: The first week in December is their busiest of the year. These immigrants fill the 70-gallon-plus fiber barrels not just with gifts for relatives and friends but with everyday items that are much less expensive to obtain in the United States. Some people also use smaller barrels, boxes or crates; others prefer longer-lasting blue plastic barrels that can be used for storage or, when cut in half, as watering troughs for livestock at the destination.

WHEN Tucker, a romantic collection of drapey classics, discontinues a print, people react as though their favorite flavor of ice cream were being taken out of production. ''We receive so many e-mails and calls about prints that got away,'' said Gaby Basora, the designer behind Tucker. She is bowing to public demand and re-releasing 20 vintage styles, like this red and pink rose number called Whistle Print, $275. At tuckerbygabybasora.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

A question in the 30-Minute Interview last Sunday about Douglas C. Steiner, the president of Steiner Equities Group, misstated the amount per square foot that the store Value City was paying at a Steiner mall. It was $3 a square foot, not $3 more a square foot.
An Oct. 23 article on the Wirtz family misspelled the name of the company owned by Peter Wirtz. It is Bismarck Enterprises, not Bismark Enterprises. Editors were notified of the error on Monday.

Q.My wife, grown daughter and I will be traveling to Africa over the holidays - our first trip there. We will be spending Christmas in Zanzibar and New Year's in Cape Town. Do you have recommendations for any special activities or holiday dinners for those occasions? Are there any local customs for those holidays? David L. Powell, Tallahassee, Fla.A.For tips on Zanzibar, an island off the coast of Tanzania, of which it is a part, I turned to Tim Hendriks, owner of the Web site Zanzibar.NET, which promotes Zanzibar and offers information about the island's attractions, history and culture. In an e-mail, he wrote the following: ''Zanzibar is a predominantly Islamic island so Christmas isn't celebrated much locally, although the main Christmas days are taken as public holidays.'' He added that most of the hotels on Zanzibar offer Christmas celebrations, as they cater to an international clientele. Mr. Hendriks also owns a boutique hotel, Ras Nungwi (rasnungwi.com), on Zanzibar's northern peninsula; it will host traditional dinners on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, as well as live music and entertainment, decorations and a Christmas tree. Zanzibar Serena Inn (serenahotels.com), a resort hotel in Stone Town overlooking the ocean, will also host dinners on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, at $55 a person.

PARIS -- International fisheries negotiators agreed Saturday to maintain the 2011 catch of endangered Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna at essentially the same level as in 2010, eliciting a stinging rebuke from conservationists, who had been calling for a fishing moratorium. The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, or Iccat, meeting here, voted to reduce the total allowable bluefin catch next year to 12,900 tons from 13,500 tons. That decrease will have little effect in practice, because of rampant illegal fishing and the inability or unwillingness of fishing and consuming nations to track trade in the species accurately.

The trustee seeking to recover money for people who were defrauded by Bernard L. Madoff filed lawsuits Friday against investors, employees and Madoff family members. Irving H. Picard, appointed trustee by a federal bankruptcy court, filed 40 lawsuits seeking $69 million against people who he said had invested with Mr. Madoff and withdrawn more money than they contributed. The filings are the latest in a series of ''clawback suits'' filed by Mr. Picard, a New York lawyer, attempting to obtain as much as $17.5 billion total for victims of the largest Ponzi scheme in American history.

MARANDINO--Yvonne Marie Brulatour. Passed away peacefully on November 18, 2010 from dementia-related complications. Born in New York on June 2, 1936, Yvonne Marie was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Jules Brulatour and granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Healy, Claire Isabelle Brulatour and Jules Ernest Brulatour, film pioneer and co-founder of Universal Pictures and president of Eastman Kodak. Yvonne received a Bachelor of Arts degree in Sociology from Rosemont College in 1957 and a Masters degree in Psychiatric Social Work from Fordham University Graduate School of Social Services in 1959, and spent several years helping the underprivileged. After raising four children, Yvonne became a Realtor for Coldwell Banker in Stamford, CT, but continued to fulfill her passion for helping others as a committed volunteer for the Den for Grieving Kids. Yvonne's generosity of spirit and strength of character will forever be held in the hearts of her family and friends. She was predeceased by her sister Mimi and brother Jules. Yvonne is survived by her sisters Denise and Andree, children Missy, Rob, Kim and Cristin as well as the grandchildren she so adored, Connor, Aidan, Caroline, Kaitlyn and Ryan. It is with a heavy heart but extreme gratitude for all she gave that her family says we love you and good-bye. Visitation will be held at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT on Wednesday, December 1 from 4pm-8pm (phone: 203 869-1513). Funeral will be held at St. Catherine of Sienna, 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT on Thursday, December 2, 2010 at 12:00pm. Luncheon reception immediately following funeral services at Riverside Yacht Club, 102 Club Rd., Greenwich, CT. Entombment to be held at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

Not the tippy-top, where the paid ads are found, but under those, on Google's version of the gold-medal podium, where the most relevant and popular site is displayed.

Jazmine Sullivan Jazmine Sullivan gets straight to the point, often in pithy one-syllable words, on her second album, ''Love Me Back'' (J Records). In ''Good Enough,'' one of the many songs in her repertory aimed at some unappreciative jerk, she sings, ''If I'm not good enough, then baby, there's the door.'' The album also has some amorous songs, but they're outnumbered by breakups that let her fully unleash her wrath. Her voice is narrow and jagged, with more grain and more tears as she applies gospel dynamics to her venting; the productions use hip-hop programming but aim for soul. While Ms. Sullivan revels in drama, she still has a sense of humor. In ''U Get On My Nerves,'' a sequel to her vengeful hit ''Bust Your Windows,'' exes briefly consider reuniting, then realize it would be a bad idea. The guy -- Ne-Yo -- is every bit as persuasive as she is about who gets the blame: ''Any time I think about missing you/I remember the stress you put me through.''

Midcentury Scandinavian food never had the second life that Scandinavian furniture did. And if you'd like to know why, imagine the opposite -- a world in which we savor salted herring and forget about Saarinen tables. No! But if we were to bring back just one worthy dish, I'd vote for fyrstekake, also known as royal cake. Fyrstekake's buttery dough sandwiches a layer of cardamom-scented almond paste. The effect is something between a cake and a bar cookie. It's so fragrant and chewy that it begs for an accompanying cup of tea. Craig Claiborne wrote about it in 1963, when he was deep in his infatuation with dill and meatballs and all things Nordic.

Colleagues at Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. are shocked and saddened at the sudden passing of our dear friend and general counsel, who with his acumen and dedication contributed to the growth and success of our company over the last decade. Stuart joined Regeneron in 2000 as General Counsel and was named a Senior Vice President in 2007. Those who worked with Stuart professionally know that he was bright, capable, dedicated, hardworking, and an outstanding attorney. Those of us who knew him well personally also know that he was kind, funny, and comfortable with himself and with anyone he met and had a humility that only truly extraordinary people can attain. We will miss his wise counsel, good humor, legal expertise, and, above all, his warmth and friendship. Our hearts go out to his many friends and to his family, especially to his wife, Ellen, and his three children, Benjamin, Lev, and Julia. COLONEL ROOSEVELT By Edmund Morris

DAWEI, MYANMAR -- The vast, pristine stretch of coastline here is almost deserted, save for fishermen hauling their bountiful catches onto white-sand beaches. But a deal signed this month would transform these placid waters into a seaport for giant cargo ships. Cashew nut groves and rice fields would be plowed under and replaced with a warren of factories, refineries and an expansive coal-burning power plant. Myanmar, which is run by a repressive military regime that controls both economic and political life, recently captured the world's attention with its first elections in two decades and the release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's leading dissident, from house arrest.

Michael R. Bloomberg, in his successful bid to become mayor, sold himself as an expert manager, a businessman who had made a fortune in private industry. He has now named Cathleen P. Black, a magazine executive, to be the next chancellor of New York City's public schools. Why? ''Cathie Black is a superstar manager who has succeeded spectacularly in the private sector,'' Mayor Bloomberg said this month. ''She is brilliant, she is innovative, she is driven -- and there is virtually nobody who knows more about the needs of the 21st-century work force for which we need to prepare our kids.''

SMITH--Michael M. Died November 21st from complications due to prostate cancer at his home, the historic Lent-Riker-Smith Homestead, with his wife, Marion, by his side. Born July 22, 1935 in Paris, France of Russian decent (nee Matveyev) Mr. Smith was educated in the United States and an Alumnus of the Millbrook School. Founder of Larimi Communications, publisher of Contacts Newsletter, Radio Contacts, Cable Contacts and T.V. News founded in 1970. Larimi was later sold to Billboard Publications. Mr. Smith also founded the National Media Conference featuring such motivational speakers as Oprah Winfrey, Barbara Walters, Ralph Nader and countless others. Along with his beloved wife of 27 years, photographer Marion Duckworth Smith, they lovingly restored the 1654 farmhouse which is on the National Register of Historic Places. (See New York Times October 11, 2006). The Homestead was open for tours thru local historical societies and for local school children. He is also survived by a daughter, Laurel K. Vouvray of Austin, TX and a step-daughter, Leslie Granger of San Jose, CA. A wake will be held at Quinn Funeral Home, 35-20 Broadway, Astoria, NY, 718-721-9200, Monday evening, November 29th, 69pm. Burial will be private and take place in the Riker Cemetery on the grounds of the historic farmhouse. He always wore a smile and was the consummate gentlemen to the very end.

GOLDBERGER--Mike. In memory of Mike Goldberger, who died one year ago in New York City, surrounded by his loving family. Born in Hungary in 1921, he emerged from the Holocaust with his will to live undiminished. Against the century's darkness, with his wife Lilly, he transmitted to his family the ineradicable moral foundations of Jewish tradition and labored selflessly and unceasingly to provide. He was a powerhouse, larger than life, and inspired us all. He is sorely missed, but his memory and example live on in those of us who remember him today. Love you, Pop. Evelyn and Salomon Sassoon, Nina, Danielle and Lily

A review on Nov. 7 about Joseph J. Ellis's ''First Family,'' an account of the marriage of Abigail and John Adams, referred incorrectly to a passage from a letter in which Abigail told her sister that after half a century, her choice to marry her husband ''would be the same'' if she once again had the ''youth and opportunity to make it.'' This part of the letter is indeed cited in the book; it is not a passage that the author ''neglects to quote.''

DWIGHT--Eleanor Collier, 72, died on November 16. Born September 5, 1938, in Boston, she attended St. Timothy's and Shipley schools and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1960. She earned a master's degree from Columbia University in 1964 and a Ph.D. in American literature from New York University in 1984. She lived all her adult life in New York City. An Edith Wharton scholar, she wrote an illustrated biography of Edith Wharton, published in 1994. Her other books portrayed Diana Vreeland, the Gilded Age in New York City, and tennis innovator James Van Alen. Her articles on gardens, travel, and literature appeared in Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful, and New York magazines, and the New York Times. She taught and lectured extensively on literature and gardens. She gardened with her husband at their summer home on Mount Desert Island, Maine. A formidable intellect, she served on the boards of Edith Wharton's estate "The Mount," the Colony Club, and the Garden Club of Mount Desert, and was a member of the Century Association. Married 34 years to George H.P. Dwight, who died in 2009, she is survived by her three children, Daphne Trotter, Willard Gardiner, and Sargent Gardiner; her five step-children, Lucinda Dwight, George Dwight, Margaret Dwight, Bradley Dwight, and Susannah Prout; eight grandchildren; and seven step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Tuesday, December 7, at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street, New York, NY. Donations to the George and Eleanor Dwight Memorial Fund at Groton School, Groton, MA, and The Mount, Lenox, MA, are welcome.

Packers (7-3) at Falcons (8-2)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Falcons by 2 1/2 Labeling a game as a preview of the N.F.C. championship is like calling a young singer-songwriter the ''next Bob Dylan.'' It sets the bar too high: you expect Cowboys versus 49ers circa 1992, but instead you get welterweight-caliber matchups. The season opener between the Vikings and Saints, both a conference championship preview and a rematch, devolved into a sloppy punter's duel. Sunday night's Eagles-Giants game, while close, was marred by dropped passes and inexcusable turnovers. The latest would-be championship preview pits the Packers, who have spent three seasons on the brink of breaking out, against the Other Leading Brand.

Two federal agencies say they know how far the new Nissan Leaf will go on a fully charged battery. They just don't agree. A few weeks before the Nissan Leaf is delivered to buyers, the Environmental Protection Agency, which approves the fuel economy stickers that go in the window of every new car, says it will go 73 miles. The Federal Trade Commission says the correct number is 96 to 110. (These range numbers, it's worth pointing out, are distinct from the fuel economy numbers that Nick Bunkley recently wrote about in The New York Times.)

This Thanksgiving was a particularly special one for the Vanderbilt basketball team. It marked the first time in four years that we were actually able to spend Thanksgiving in Nashville and enjoy a traditional home-cooked holiday meal. We've had dinners on Thanksgiving before, but none like this. We starved ourselves for 24 hours beforehand and showed up to Coach's house Joey Tribbiani style, in our maternity elastic-waistband pants. Then, of course, as we lay on the couch in a food coma, we reflected on the great things in our lives that we were thankful for.

This is a story about a courageous policy in an unexpected place. In this place homeless shelters have vending machines selling clean syringes for injecting drugs.  Drug users are not prosecuted as long as they are in treatment programs.  Drug addicts are given clean needles and methadone maintenance therapy ─ available on a widespread basis even in prison.  These tactics have worked to reduce crime, lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep AIDS from spreading out into the general population.  The place is not Amsterdam.  It is Tehran.

This week, A. O. Scott looks at one of the high points in the revenge film genre, 1967's "Point Blank," directed by John Boorman. Though many films have focused on a wronged character seeking payback, "there aren't many characters who embody vengeance as forcefully, as purely, as nastily as Lee Marvin's Walker," he says. The film fills the screen with enemies for Walker to confront and take down on his way to retribution, but Mr. Scott sees a deeper side too, calling it "an allegory about the fate of the individual in a world dominated by corporate power." Have you seen "Point Blank?" Please share your thoughts.

Come gather 'round, people: if your cash to you is worth spending on a one-of-a-kind piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia, you might consider saving the date of Dec. 10. That's when Sotheby's plans to auction Mr. Dylan's handwritten lyrics to "The Times They Are a-Changin'" as part of a larger sale of books and manuscripts, the auction house said on Monday. In a catalog listing, Sotheby's described the item as "a sheet of unruled three-hole notebook paper" on which Mr. Dylan wrote four verses of the famous protest song in simple block lettering (which you can see in closer detail here). He later recorded it for his 1964 album of the same title. (The verse that begins, "Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen," does not appear in the document, though a fragment of lyrics from Mr. Dylan's song "North Country Blues" can be seen on the reverse side.)

Weeks ago, Justin Kubatko noted the rebounding excellence of the Toronto Raptors' Reggie Evans in this space, as Evans' rebounding ethic is obscured by more conventional rebounding measures, but is resplendent under the light of more detailed statistics. Evans is still third in the league in rebounds per game, even though rebound percentage -- a percentage estimate of the rebounds a player grabbed while they were on the floor -- shows the Raptors' forward to be far and away the most efficient rebounder in the league. When the noise from pace factors and varying opportunities are wiped clean, Evans is the league's indisputable best on the boards.

Skye Parrott, the photographer, curator and one half of the duo behind the art and fashion journal Dossier, regularly shoots for the likes of Dazed and Confused and Vogue. "First Love, Last Rites," now on view at Capricious space in Brooklyn, however, finds Parrott operating on a more personal level. Recreating events from her drug-fueled teens, Parrott has tried to dive headlong into her own blurry history -- something more difficult than you might imagine. "In doing this work, I was keenly aware that what I remembered might not be 'real,' " she says. Curious about what actually happened, after making the photographs she interviewed her boyfriend from that period to see what he remembered. "There was a lot of overlap," she says, "but there were huge discrepancies, too. I think it points to the way that memories form us, and as we form, we reshape them to fit."

Priests and nuns are not the most likely fashion inspirations, but the first hint that I remember of the clerical collar as a subversive take on the prim and the perverse was at the Prada men's collection in January 2008. I remember watching the guys, in their streamlined tailoring, walk a weird cat's cradle of a wooden runway. They were close enough for the audience to spot chests covered with what resembled pastors' bibs, tied over bared shirt backs. Other looks, as if of a priest defrocking himself, were neckties used as nooses and visible underpants rising from trousers. But it was the abstract collars - and the sly sexuality that the enigmatic Miuccia Prada drew from them - that stayed in my mind.

It's at least as responsible as any of the other plans being advanced, with a very different emphasis: more reliance on revenue, no attack on Social Security. Some of the revenue comes from indirect taxes -- green taxes and fuel taxes -- but the rest comes from measures that would raise taxes mainly on upper-income Americans.

At a time when e-readers may be displacing the good, old-fashioned print book, an effort to revive interest in the art of the book cover is taking place in London. The gallery StolenSpace gave a simple task to a group of more than 30 artists, designers, ceramic artists and photographers: design a cover for your favorite book. Participants were free to paint, print, etch, sculpt, photograph, or use any medium of their choice, as long as the result was in the size of an average book (defined as 198mm by 129mm).

INTERNATIONAL The Hanoi Journal article on Thursday, about Nguyen Phuong Hung, the last blacksmith working in Hanoi, on Blacksmith Street, misstated the time period in which Blacksmith Street got its name. It was at the end of the 19th century, when Vietnam's French colonial administrators recruited metal workers to help build the Long Bien Bridge over the Red River; it did not get its name at the beginning of the 19th century. (The bridge was built from 1898 to 1902.)

One great and glorious advantage that the theater used to have over the movies was the third dimension. You knew that when you watched actors on stage that they were just as fully rounded - physically, I mean - as the people in the lobby at intermission. Actors on film, no matter how big they looked in 10-foot close-ups, were as hopelessly flat as the screens on which their images flickered. In the past few years, though, filmmakers have been co-opting the third dimension for themselves. Once James Cameron's ''Avatar'' broke box office records with the help of silly-looking 3-D glasses, what had been a novelty (and a punch line) in the 1950s started to be taken very seriously. And now moviegoers can regularly see blue-skinned freedom fighters, green-skinned ogres and even flesh-colored human beings who seem to break through the screen and reach right into your theater or living room.

For the magazine business, 2011 will be a year to watch -- and not just because it could hold answers to lingering questions about the financial health of the industry. Or, if not, whether the problems run deeper than they now appear.

SCHAFFER--Franklin Edwin. 86, a resident of Greenwich, CT since 1956, passed away November 11th of cardiac arrest. He was born in New Rochelle, NY, January 1, 1924. Frank retired in 1985 as Chairman and CEO of Doremus & Co. where he had worked since 1954. Among the accounts Frank handled, were Heineken, Casio and PR for foreign governments including Spain, Japan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. Frank served as a governor of the New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies 1973-75. A summa cum laude graduate of Princeton University Class of 1945, he was elected to the Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi Societies and from 1980-82 served as national chairman of the Princeton Alumni Council. He served in the US Army from 1942-46, rising to first lieutenant field artillery, served in the Pacific Theater and was awarded the Army Commendation Medal for outstanding service in the 33rd Infantry Division. He was inducted into the Who's Who in America in 1980. Since his retirement, Frank was involved in numerous charitable organizations, including President of Blueberry Treatment Center; advisory council member of Covenant House, New York; and board of directors member at Silver Hill, New Canaan, CT. Frank will be remembered for his love and knowledge of poetry, his humor, intellect, vast network of friends, and his passion for his family. Frank leaves behind his beloved wife Joan (Fitzgerald Gardner) Schaffer, his three children, by his former wife Diane (Wormser) Burke; Quentin Schaffer of New Canaan, CT, Darcy Hadjipateras of Greenwich, CT and Jocelyn Donaghue of Jamestown, RI; eight grandchildren: Cameron, Kylie and Charlotte Schaffer, Sophie, Costas, Peter, Marina, and Alex Hadjipateras, and beloved nieces, nephews, step children and grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to Covenant House, New York or Silver Hill, New Canaan, CT.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) RESTREPO: AFGHAN OUTPOST In this 90-minute documentary, filmed from May 2007 to July 2008, Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington focus their cameras on the 15 men of a remote outpost in the Korangal Valley of Afghanistan, named after Pfc. Juan S. Restrepo, a medic who was killed early in the deployment. The film, which records firefights, reconnaissance missions, rounds of horseplay and tedium, ''is an impressive, even heroic feat of journalism,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times when the film had its theatrical release in June. ''There is nothing especially fancy or innovative here, just a blunt, sympathetic, thorough accounting of the daily struggle to stay alive and accomplish something constructive.'' What distinguishes the film, Mr. Scott said, ''is not only its uniquely intensive focus on a small group of men in a particular time and place, but also its relentless attention to the lethal difficulty of their work.'' 8 P.M. (ABC) SKATING WITH THE STARS In Week 2 of this competition series the six celebrities -- the actors Rebecca Budig (who leads with 45 points out of a possible 60), Brandon Mychal Smith and Sean Young; the reality-show fixture Bethenny Frankel; the Olympic skier Jonny Moseley; and Vince Neil, the Mötley Crüe front man (in last place with 28 points, but first in number of falls) -- return to the ice with the help of professional skaters and face their first elimination. The judges are Dick Button, the two-time Olympic gold medalist known as the voice of figure skating; the Olympian Johnny Weir; and Laurieann Gibson, a choreographer for Lady Gaga.

This month, I wrote about an Apple-1 computer that was set to be auctioned for $150,000 by the auctioneer Christie's. The bidding is now closed, and the computer that debuted in 1976, for $666.66, built by Steven P. Jobs and Steve Wozniak, Apple's co-founders, sold for $213,600. Not a bad return on investment, especially considering most technologies decrease in value as they age.

STRONG--Lynn St. Clair, 72, of Manhattan, died on November 4th. Friend, colleague, copyeditor extraordinaire. Lynn began her career at Random House, where she brought her love of language, attention to detail, and respect for writers to books by Woody Allen, E.L. Doctorow, Frederick Exley, Pete Hamill, Peter Matthiessen, James Michener (who bought her a round-trip ticket to Paris as an expression of gratitude), George Plimpton, Philip Roth, James Salter, Bobby Seale, Gore Vidal, Robert Penn Warren, Geoffrey Wolff, many others. Her interests were broad, her tastes catholic: She edited dictionaries, women's magazines, medical textbooks, legal briefs, and, in the last decades of her life, books and calendars at Workman Publishing. Her craft is evident on the pages of books by Joseph C. Piscatella, Henry Lodge, M.D., and Chris Crowley, among many others, as well as on every card in the Brain Quest series. The list goes on and on. We can't believe that she isn't here to argue the evils of the serial comma. Her fans at Workman Publishing

SAN JOSE, Calif. -- When Scott Thompson, the president of PayPal, chats with executives at its parent, eBay, he is diplomatic about the size of his business compared with eBay's marketplace. ''I hope -- honestly, genuinely -- that we never get bigger than you,'' he tells them.

During the first 30 minutes of ''Tron: Legacy,'' the forthcoming science fiction film from Walt Disney Studios, the hunky computer whiz at the center of the action struts to his refrigerator and pulls out a Coors. Yes, a Coors. Cynical moviegoers may think the screen time is a case of product placement, where marketers pay Hollywood to embed their wares into the action. Perhaps Coors - pretty much as far from futuristic as they come - was hoping the movie's cool vibe would rub off.

Arizona Coach Ken Whisenhunt wants you to know that even though the Cardinals have no prospects of getting better in the near future, everything is just fine because they were good two years ago. ''I don't think you can look at our team over the last two years and what we have done in the playoffs and be ashamed about anything with that or feel like we've lost anything from that,'' he told the team's Web site. Over the last two years, the Cardinals lost Kurt Warner, Anquan Boldin, Karlos Dansby and Bertrand Berry from a 9-7 team that improbably reached the Super Bowl. Those players were replaced by the likes of Derek Anderson and Joey Porter, and prospects like Beanie Wells are not developing. Erosion? Coach, this is disintegration.

IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture. Did the executives at HSBC who approved posters for lobbies that read ''This city never sleeps, neither do we'' remember the campaigns for Citicorp and Citigroup that carried the themes ''The Citi never sleeps'' and ''Citi never sleeps''?

SCAPIN--Daniel, died on November 26, 2010. He died in his sleep, at home with his family beside him. Dan was 52. Professionally Dan had 30 years experience in the logistics industry improving operations and building companies. Dan served as President of both Premedia and Logistics Divisions for Worldcolor. Throughout his career he served as President of Logistics at RR Donneley and Moore Wallace. Dan advised the Royal mail (UK) logistics/ digital printing in it's operations redesign as well as multiple groups in the US postal industry. Dan served on the board of the Classic Stage Company. Dan loved his work. He loved his wife more than words can express. He loved his life and his home. Dan leaves behind his loving wife and best friend Janet and their dog Poppy. Dan's mother-in-law loved him and will miss him. Dan was a happy, generous, good and honest man. The loss of his tender heart is simply unbearable. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

LEIGHTON--Norman, 82, on November 24, 2010. Son of late Abrahm and Fannie, he was born and raised in Jersey City, and lived in Manhattan before retiring to Oceanside, CA. Avid golfer and successful builder, he created the well liked restaurant Federico's and Alligator Alley. He is survived by his beloved wife, Selma, children Audrey (Rick) Cole and Michael, brother Saul and grandchildren Barrie, Adam, Daniel, Matthew and Sara. A strong man, his strength inspired many others and he was a firm supporter of civil and human rights. As he said at the racetrack "Don't Stop Now". Services Tuesday, 1pm at Eden Memorial chapels, Fort Lee, NJ (201) 947-3336.

GOLUB--Richard E. Died November 27 at 86. Adored husband of Rena, beloved father of Peter and Jimmy and daughters-in-law Cristina and Janine. Special grandfather to Natalie, Ginger, Phillip and Alejandro. Devoted brother to Jackie Cooper and husband Harvey and special closeness to brother-in-law Charles Greenhouse and cousin Naomi Adelman. Attended the University of Virginia. Served in the Navy in WWII in the Pacific. Great love for music, particularly jazz. Service at Campbells, 81st and Madison, November 30 at 11am. Interment private. He will be with us always.

KURZ--Max. November 27, 2010, age 93 years, of Waukesha, WI. Beloved husband of Kay Kurz. Dear father of Robert (Pamela Alexander) Kurz and Mark (Barbara Haskell Kurz) Kurz. Fond brother of the late Ruth Klein. Loving grandfather of Rebecca and David Alexander Kurz; Nellie and Olivia Kurz. Cherished uncle of Marilyn Klein-Larson. Max was Professor Emeritus at UWM. Graveside Services November 29, 2010 at Mound Zion Cemetery, Brookfield, WI. Memorial gifts to the UWM School of Social Welfare, Retzer Nature Center, or Lad Lake are appreciated.

BRILL--Allen. With great sadness, Tourneau mourns the passing and loss of our friend and colleague, Allen Brill, President and CEO of Rolex Watch USA. We extend our deepest condolences and sympathies to the Brill family during this most difficult time and to Allen's extended family at Rolex, including the countless associates and colleagues whose lives he touched.

President Obama's relationship with Republican Congressional leaders begins a less predictable phase this week that confronts each side with a new political calculus. When the House speaker-to-be, John A. Boehner, and the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, visit the White House on Tuesday, their political momentum will be leavened with increased governing responsibility. The thoroughgoing opposition that benefited them in the first half of Mr. Obama's term will carry an offsetting price in the second half.

SAMUELS--Barbara C. The word spunky was created to describe Barbara Christie Samuels who recently died at the age of 91 on November 17th. She passed away in West Palm Beach, Florida at the Noreen Mckean nursing home. Bobbi, as she was known to all, grew up a tomboy (see delete) able to throw fastballs and willing to fight bullies. The depression couldn't stop Bobbi from pursuing her dreams. Earning an acting scholarship to Boston's Emerson College, she served food to fellow students in her homemade dresses to earn her keep, while modeling in the garment district to earn her spending money. At night, utilizing her acting skills and her chutzpah, Bobbi would bluff her way into Broadway theaters, pretending to be an actor's relative. Against her friends' admonitions, this beauty, never lacking for suitors, went out with a notorious MIT "playboy" named Howard Samuels. After taming him, Bobbi, raised Christian, courageously defied her parents and 1940's societal taboos by marrying Samuels, who was Jewish. During WWII, while her husband was fighting overseas under Gen. Patton, Bobbi was fighting all alone for her son's life. The enemy at home was spinal meningitis from which no child had ever survived. Bobbi's son Bill was one of the first in medical history to do so, all because of Bobbi's determination not to give up. When the war ended, Bobbi helped her husband make history. Howard Samuels, during his college years, had created a thesis for the first plastic clothes line. Upon his return home, Bobbi and Howard rented an old school house, and with practically no money, started manufacturing the clothesline. Under the name Kordite. Then, with Bobbi coming up with some of the ideas, they created the first of many other plastic products: the plastic bag, the plastic egg carton, plastic for dry cleaning., Baggies, and Hefty garbage bags. At first they settled in Rochester, New York where Howard had grown up. She and her husband moved in 1949 to Canandaigua, New York which she dearly loved and only reluctantly sold their home there where Howard joined the Johnston administration as Undersecretary of Commerce in 1963. When her husband decided to run for Governor of New York in the 62, Bobbi then became an astute political strategist and an engaging campaigner. Always ahead of her time, Bobbi, like her husband, fervently supported equal rights for blacks, gays, and women before many other liberal democrats. And through-out all these years, Bobbi also kept having children. Eight in all, which she considered her greatest achievement. She never failed to believe equally in each and every one of them...in their hidden talents and their secret dreams. Her eight children and 12 grandchildren will always remember her strength of spirit, her sense of style, and her passionate enthusiasm for life. When recalling these attributes in the future, we will smile, realizing we've each inherited the best of our Mom. We are lucky. Our mother's highest compliment about another woman was to say, "She's a great Dame". Well, Bobbi Samuels, our mother, was a Great Dame: Truly one of a kind. Born June 4, 1919 in Detroit Michigan. She grew up in Hempstead, Long Island as the only child of Fred Christie and Ruth Rogers Christie who taught 6th grade for 30 years. She is survived by William of New York City, Howard of Los Angeles, CA, Catherine Samuels of Larchmont, NY, Victoria Samuels of Valley Cottage, NY, Carey Samuels Hochberg of New Rochelle, NY, Barbara Samuels of Millbrook, NY, Jacqui Samuels of New York City, Janine Samuels of New York. She was laid to rest Saturday, November 20th in Southhampton, NY along side her husband, Howard.

''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 1,'' above, with Bonnie Wright and Daniel Radcliffe, opened on Nov. 19 and took in $125 million during its first weekend. That puts it in sixth place in an all-time ranking of opening-weekend totals, tied with ''Shrek 2.'' The take for ''Hallows'' from Friday to Sunday, $50.3 million, puts it at No. 15 in a box-office ranking of second weekends. Longevity rules at the box office: ''E.T.: The Extraterrestrial'' (1982) was tops for 16 weeks and among the top 10 for 44 weeks, putting it at No. 4 in an all-time revenue ranking, after adjusting for inflation. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GENEVA -- Switzerland's voters approved a referendum on Sunday calling for the automatic deportation of foreigners who are convicted of serious crimes, but they rejected an initiative to set a minimum national tax rate for the wealthy that opponents asserted would have prompted an exodus by many wealthy Swiss and foreigners. A total of 52.9 percent of voters and a majority of Switzerland's cantons supported the initiative of the right-wing Swiss People's Party calling for the automatic expulsion of foreigners convicted of crimes ranging from murder, rape and drug dealing to social security fraud, according to the Federal Statistics Office Web site.

MARANDINO--Yvonne Marie Brulatour. Passed away peacefully on November 18, 2010 from dementia-related complications. Born in New York on June 2, 1936, Yvonne Marie was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Jules Brulatour and granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Healy, Claire Isabelle Brulatour and Jules Ernest Brulatour, film pioneer and co-founder of Universal Pictures and president of Eastman Kodak. Yvonne received a Bachelor of Arts degree in Sociology from Rosemont College in 1957 and a Masters degree in Psychiatric Social Work from Fordham University Graduate School of Social Services in 1959, and spent several years helping the underprivileged. After raising four children, Yvonne became a Realtor for Coldwell Banker in Stamford, CT, but continued to fulfill her passion for helping others as a committed volunteer for the Den for Grieving Kids. Yvonne's generosity of spirit and strength of character will forever be held in the hearts of her family and friends. She was predeceased by her sister Mimi and brother Jules. Yvonne is survived by her sisters Denise and Andree, children Missy, Rob, Kim and Cristin as well as the grandchildren she so adored, Connor, Aidan, Caroline, Kaitlyn and Ryan. It is with a heavy heart but extreme gratitude for all she gave that her family says we love you and good-bye. Visitation will be held at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT on Wednesday, December 1 from 4pm-8pm (phone: 203 869-1513). Funeral will be held at St. Catherine of Sienna, 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT on Thursday, December 2, 2010 at 12:00pm. Luncheon reception immediately following funeral services at Riverside Yacht Club, 102 Club Rd., Greenwich, CT. Entombment to be held at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

Despite the slew of peripheral events on Tuesday's calendar (don't forget to R.S.V.P. for tonight's Gaetano Pesce for Melissa shoes launch), the day before the official vernissage for Art Basel Miami Beach is relatively calm. For the last few years, it's also been the day for early out-of-towners (Jane Holzer, Adam Lindemann) and locals (Tiqui Atencio, Ella Cisneros) to attend a preview hosted by Sotheby's at Miami's Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden. This year's show, "Les Lalanne at Fairchild," is the largest outdoor exhibition of works by the French sculptors Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne. The display includes over 20 sculptures dotted throughout the 83-acre sylvan paradise, including the couple's well-known flock of epoxystone and bronze sheep and lambs. Claude's favorite, however, is "Dimetrodon II" (1998), a copper and steel topiary dinosaur, which spouts water through its teeth. "How can you not love it?" asked Claude, whose husband died in 2008. "It's a prehistoric monster who somehow finds himself in a big modern grotto.""Les Lalanne at Fairchild" runs through April 1, 2011.

It seems as if men can get their work wear from any mall that has a J. Crew these days, but it turns out that the best of that lot has been hiding in plain sight for a year and a half on the expertly curated, under-the-radar menswear Web shop C.H.C.M. The owner, Sweetu Patel, knows a little something about timeless design after putting in five years on the floor of Cappellini, the SoHo Italian design emporium; for C.H.C.M. -- which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear --  he has carved a niche with classic American and European brands as well as hard-to-find Japanese ones. Last week, he brought those labels even closer within reach when he opened a fashionably minimalist, brick-and-mortar shop in NoHo. The store shares its raw, slightly underground space with the fashion designer Tunji Dada and the curator-about-town Josee Lepage, who was setting up her creative consultancy within plain view of the merchandise on Friday, opening day. "I wanted a nice space, good music, nothing pretentious - like the stores I grew up around in Northampton, England, in the late '80s and early '90s," says Patel.

It's official: royal fever is in full swing. QVC and the supermarket chain Tesco are selling synthetic versions of Catherine Middleton's engagement ring from Wednesday and Sotheby's London is auctioning the jewels of the Duchess of Windsor on Tuesday. "It is still the highest valued private jewelry collection ever sold," said David Bennett, Sotheby's chairman of Europe and the Middle East for International Jewelry. The last sale of the Duchess of Windsor's jewelry was held in Geneva nearly a quarter of a century ago in 1987. The treasures include a 1935 gold Cartier cigarette case with gems denoting the royals' exotic destination spots and the 1957 emerald, ruby and diamond 20th anniversary brooch. Now is a chance to buy a piece of eternal style. Lucky ones may get a chance to pair it with an invite to next year's eagerly anticipated nuptials.

The Pentagon on Tuesday released its long-awaited report on "don't ask, don't tell," the policy that allows gay men and women to serve in the military as long as they keep their sexual orientation quiet. The report, the result of a nine-month study, said that repealing the law would present a low risk to military effectiveness. It also found that 70 percent of service members believe that the impact of repealing the law would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

When utilized to its full potential, the pick-and-roll is not only among the most fluid and glorious displays of coordinated movement that the game of basketball has to offer, but also among the most potent. When operated by skilled practitioners, the pick-and-roll is a simple sequence with seemingly unlimited potential, so much so that defenders versed in limiting the pick-and-roll's options are worth their weight in gold in today's N.B.A. The various offensive systems in the league may stem from vastly different philosophies, but the pick-and-roll is something of a universal -- a commonality too obvious, accessible, and useful for any scheme to ignore.

Remember the old slogan for Clairol hair coloring, "Only her hairdresser knows for sure"? A campaign to help fight AIDS, which is to get under way on Tuesday, is based on the idea of hairdressers imparting to customers their knowledge of preventing the spread of H.I.V., which causes AIDS.

I don't like losing things. I keep a list of books I know I once had, and know I've read, that I have somehow misplaced; "The Magic Mountain," Loren Eiseley's "The Star Thrower," "The Complete Claudine" by Colette are on it, along with at least 40 other titles. Even when I lose a pair of pants, a sense of vexation, a confusion arises in me that seems out of all proportion to the loss, and if the pants are suddenly presented to me apologetically at the dry cleaners I feel a strange giddiness, a tincture of the kind of joy displayed by reunited families in movies about Mormon heaven. It is strange that in this world in which everything is sooner or later lost, where losing is the only certainty, one gets attached to even the smallest things and wants to be able to say goodbye even to a pair of pants, rather than have it simply disappear. One wants to see a logic in disappearances, and to know when one is losing things. Even if, in the end, we get to keep nothing.

"The Scottsboro Boys" has become the first new commercial musical of the Broadway season to fall at the box office. The producers said on Tuesday that "Scottsboro," which set the infamous 1930s Alabama rape trials to music and presented them subversively in the form of a minstrel show, would close on Sunday, Dec. 12, after 29 previews and 49 regular performances.

Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the chamber's No. 4 Democrat, will become chairwoman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee for the 2012 elections, taking on a steep challenge as her party seeks to defend more than twice as many seats as Republicans‬.‪‪Democrats face an extremely tough map in 2012 as they try to hold on to what will be a 53 to 47 majority. That number includes two independents -- Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Bernard Sanders of Vermont -- who align with the Democrats.‬‪ ‬‪The Democrats must defend 23 seats, while just 10 Republicans are up for re-election. It is also a presidential election year, which will drive up turnout and puts added pressure on Congressional candidates as their fate can often hinge on the higher-profile race for the White House, while also making it harder for them to draw attention.‬‪ ‬‪Ms. Murray led the campaign committee in the 2002 elections, when Republicans picked up two seats and reclaimed a narrow 51-to-49 majority.‬‪ ‬‪Many Democrats viewed the post as a thankless job with little upside, and the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, reportedly struggled to find someone who would take it on. Ms. Murray's willingness to step up only further cements her position as the most prominent woman in the Senate Democratic caucus.‬‪ ‬‪Ms. Murray just survived her own tough re-election fight, a race that ended up far closer than many Democrats had expected.‬

The New York State Assembly voted 93 to 43 Monday night to place a temporary moratorium on a controversial type of natural gas exploration that combines hydraulic fracturing with horizontal drilling. The goal is to give the state more time to address safety and environmental concerns.

Last year, Google filled in the big blue blank spot on its online replica of the Earth with three-dimensional oceans. Whether they'll help inspire people to take care of the real oceans remains unclear, but it can't hurt. Now the company, in the latest iteration of Google Earth, is filling in some of the vast green blotches with three-dimensional trees.

DENVER -- The Colorado Ballet program has a "Did You Know?" checklist of five points about "The Nutcracker." I was aware of only two. Well, I wish I'd known when I was in Washington State that the "Bavarian Village" of Leavenworth there has a Nutcracker Museum with a collection of thousands. It's also good to learn that the ability of nutcrackers to crack nuts is based on the physics of Archimedes' lever and "moments of force." And I'm happy to discover that the nutcracker is also a bird related to the jay and the crow, known in America as Clark's Nutcracker.

"Winter's Bone," "Black Swan," "127 Hours" and "The Kids Are All Right" were the big names recognized by Film Independent's Spirit Awards, which announced their nominees today. Each got nods for best feature, best director, and some acting categories. "Greenberg" rounded out the list of best features, while John Cameron Mitchell earned a best director spot for "Rabbit Hole," a wrenching story of a couple - Aaron Eckhart and Nicole Kidman -- trying to cope after the death of their child. Ms. Kidman and Mr. Eckhart were also nominated as featured actors.

Ms. Hathaway has a longer shot for playing a lusty Parkinson's patient in "Love and Other Drugs," an Edward Zwick dramedy which performed poorly at the box office in its opening weekend.

Of all the shiny objects I saw at WTF Espresso Bar, a tricked-out coffee shop that opened last month in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the gadget that caught my eye was a filter cone made out of perforated stainless steel. It was sitting in a Chemex brewer, which looked significantly more awesome when equipped with a metal filter that could draw blood. It was a Kone, a reusable filter developed by Keith Gehrke of Coava, a small-batch coffee roaster in Portland, Ore.

A group of 26 senators have called for the extension of a renewable power grant program created by the 2009 stimulus law, which they describe as an effective job-creation tool. SEATTLE -- One artificial Christmas tree, in lights, beams from the top of the Space Needle here; a real one stands in the foyer of the nearby Marion Oliver McCaw Hall, where Pacific Northwest Ballet's "Nutcracker" is playing. There's snow on the Cascade Mountains, and apparently the city ground to a halt last week with three inches of snow, now vanished. You don't need to know much about "The Nutcracker" to know that these things are fitting.

Looking for a new single taxi design to replace the jumble of models now on the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commission's "Taxi of Tomorrow" competition is down to three finalists chosen from a larger group of contenders. In the last few years, the Karolinenviertel neighborhood has gone the way of many other former industrial enclaves - the meatpacking plant has morphed into galleries and cafes and the front windows of old tenement buildings now gleam with merchandise. But this being a microhood within the city's scruffy St. Pauli district (home also to one of Europe's legendary red-light districts), Karolinen's new coffee bars and design studios are cheek by jowl with punk hangouts and anarchist graffiti. It may be gentrified but it's not glossed over.

Independent film as salvation: that was the message of the annual Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night. Patricia Clarkson, a host, called out the director Lisa Cholodenko ("The Kids Are All Right") for saving her from a lifetime of playing plucky friends and long-suffering girlfriends and mothers. "She cast me as a German lesbian heroin addict" in "High Art," Ms. Clarkson said. Anne Hathaway, presenting an award to James Schamus, the chief executive of Focus Features, thanked him for changing her career path via "Brokeback Mountain." "Don't get me wrong, I loved playing princesses," she added, before praising Mr. Schamus for running a studio with spine, although she used a different, rather unprincessy anatomical word. (Mr. Schamus, a professor as well as a film executive, used a dry erase board and a philosophical metaphor during his acceptance speech.)

This week marks the start of a six-week program in New York that celebrates Italian design and culture.  I Saloni Milano, or the Milan Furniture Fair -- sponsored by Federlegno Arredo, an Italian federation of wood and cork furnishings manufacturers; Cosmit, the fair organizer; the Italian Trade Commission; and the Italian Ministry of Economic Development --  includes events at 20 Italian furniture showrooms until Jan. 8, as well as two special installations. On Monday night, "Perchance to Dream," an exhibition by the artist and director Robert Wilson, opens at Center 548 in Chelsea, where it will run through Dec. 18. In the exhibition, Wilson has installed his video portrait of the Italian ballet star Roberto Bolle on 31 screens in seven different rooms, through which are interspersed pieces of Italian furniture that Wilson chose for their form, shape, color and shadows.

When employers first introduced H.M.O. plans to their workers in the early 1990s, the plans were considered bargains. Companies paid much less for these plans because patients were sharply limited in where they could go for care, and medical expenses were tightly managed. Today, these plans are no longer a best buy, according to an analysis released Monday by consultants Aon Hewitt.

Tuesday, Nov. 23 After 12 hours of driving from Ambalavao on the High Plateau we reach the Mangoky River at Berokoha, which is full with the recent rains. We are pleased to see that there is a raft (''ferry'') to transport the car. The captain of the raft won't attempt the crossing, however, with the fast-moving high water. With the river still rising, we are anxious to find a way across before we get stuck for a few days. We agreed to pay 10 strong guys from the village to help pole.

LANDEY--Toby Gindes, died Saturday, November 27 in Manhattan after a heroic battle against pancreatic cancer. She was a daughter of Minna and Robert Gindes of Brooklyn, NY. If you wish to make a memorial gift in her name, the family would appreciate a donation to The Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research (www.lustgarten.org/) or the charity of your choice.

Brian Snyder/ReutersLoch Capital Management, a hedge fund in Boston, was raided on Nov. 22 as part of an insider trading inquiry.WASHINGTON - Secret, court-approved wiretaps put in place more than two years ago are now being used by prosecutors in a widening inquiry of securities fraud and insider trading involving hedge funds and consultants that provide industry research, according to court documents and interviews with people close to the investigations. The wiretaps were originally part of an insider trading investigation of the New York hedge fund Galleon Group. Those wiretaps, which involved the phones of at least seven individuals, potentially provided prosecutors with a vast array of new evidence for use in the latest investigations. Only four of the seven wiretap targets have been identified in court papers that have been made public so far in the Galleon case.

CUDDIHY--Harriet DeHaven (Heidi), 73, of New York City, died suddenly on Saturday, November 27th, after celebrating the most wonderful Thanksgiving surrounded by her beloved family. Born on September 6th, 1937 in Ashland, WI, to Robert (Bob) DeHaven a venerable broadcaster, and his wife Harriet Pray Dehaven, Heidi was a graduate of Northrop Collegiate School for Girls in Minneapolis, MN, and the University of Wisconsin at Madison. After graduation she moved to New York City, and held various positions in the art and business worlds, but her true passion was helping her husband in his life's work as a professor of sociology at Hunter College and a scholar of religion. Her family and friends cherished her pearls of wisdom, plucky sense of humor, selflessness and genuine interest in both people and the world. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, November 30th at 10am at St. John's in the Village, 224 Waverly Place, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to Clearwater Camp Foundation, PO Box 152, Minocqua, WI 54548-0152 or The Memorial Fund at St. John's in the Village Church, 224 Waverly Place, NYC 10014.

Rick Maiman/Bloomberg NewsRaj Rajaratnam, Galleon Group's founder, has been accused of earning money from stock trades made with inside information.On Wall Street, it is called the ''mosaic theory.'' Every day, professional investors and research analysts work the phones to ferret out information about companies that can't be found by simply reading news releases. Some will walk through shopping malls interviewing store managers at the Gap, for example, to gauge how sales are going. Others might monitor sales of certain component parts in Asia to determine how many iPads Apple might sell this quarter.

In a strongly worded, previously undisclosed correspondence, a lawyer for Steven L. Rattner, the financier ensnared in a wide-ranging investigation of suspected kickbacks, described a proposed payment of at least $20 million to the New York attorney general office as excessive, ''misconceived'' and ''wholly untethered from the facts'' in the case. The late October letter offers a glimpse into what has since become a bitter showdown between two of the state's most powerful, highly connected men: Mr. Rattner, the longtime financial adviser to New York City's billionaire mayor, and Andrew M. Cuomo, the governor-elect.

You'd think a movie project whose roster of characters runs from dwarves to dragons would need to be as inclusive as possible in its casting. But on Monday a casting agent was let go from Peter Jackson's planned film adaptations of ''The Hobbit,'' after placing newspaper advertisements seeking extras with ''light skin tones'' and a prospective performer said she was told she was too dark to appear in the movies, Agence France-Presse reported. A spokesman for Wingnut Films, the production company of Mr. Jackson, the ''Hobbit'' producer and director, told Agence France-Presse that the casting director, who was not named, was not directed by the company to make these restrictions. ''No such instructions were given,'' the spokesman said. ''The crew member in question took it upon themselves to do that and it's not something we instructed or condoned.'' In addition to an ad that appeared in The Bay of Plenty Times, a regional New Zealand newspaper, Naz Humphreys, an actor who attended a casting meeting, told The Waikato Times, ''The casting manager basically said they weren't having anybody who wasn't pale-skinned.''

The Delaware Supreme Court's opinion in favor of Airgas in its battle with Air Products and Chemicals is notable for what it does not say or do. The court finds that Delaware's staggered board statute is ambiguous; so the court looks to see what Airgas's certificate of incorporation states. The court then finds that the certificate is also ambiguous. This is where the Supreme Court opinion begins to differ from most Delaware decisions. In other cases on this issue, Delaware courts would typically follow the practice used by Chancellor William B. Chandler III in his lower court opinion: interpret the ambiguity against the company and in favor of the shareholder's because of Delaware's preference for empowering shareholders in their voting decisions.

Is the Foxwoods Theater already giving up on the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark''? The $65 million musical began preview performances at the theater on Sunday night, and by now you may have read that the first outing got snarled at times in its own technically ambitious web. Monday was a day off for the show's creators and cast; they are set to return to the Foxwoods Theater on Tuesday to start working on the physical kinks and to further shape the production, which is scheduled to open on Jan. 11.

Come gather 'round, people: if your cash to you is worth spending on a one-of-a-kind piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia, you might consider saving the date of Dec. 10. That's when Sotheby's plans to auction Mr. Dylan's handwritten lyrics to ''The Times They Are a-Changin''' as part of a larger sale of books and manuscripts, the auction house said on Monday. In a catalog listing, Sotheby's described the item as ''a sheet of unruled three-hole notebook paper'' on which Mr. Dylan wrote four verses of the famous protest song in simple block lettering (which you can see in closer detail here). He later recorded it for his 1964 album of the same title. (The verse that begins, ''Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen,'' does not appear in the document, though a fragment of lyrics from Mr. Dylan's song ''North Country Blues'' can be seen on the reverse side.) Selby Kiffer, a senior vice president in Sotheby's books and manuscripts department, said the document was originally given to Kevin Krown, a fellow folk singer, by Mr. Dylan, who had a tendency to toss away his lyric sheets once he'd committed his songs to memory. When Mr. Krown died in the 1990s, the lyrics were passed along to Mac and Eve MacKenzie, who hosted Mr. Dylan in their Manhattan home on some of his earliest visits to New York.

Sometimes a role is just a role, but not if you're an actor playing Sigmund Freud.That is especially so for Martin Rayner, 61, who plays a dying Freud in the Off Broadway play ''Freud's Last Session.'' The role has converged with his own life in a way that has left him in a psychoanalytic hall of mirrors, which became evident Saturday afternoon when Mr. Rayner collapsed onstage at the theater and had to be hospitalized. At first, many audience members believed the collapse was part of the drama, since Freud is dying of cancer in the play. What those in attendance did not know - besides several colleagues in the production - is that Mr. Rayner has prostate cancer that has spread to his lymph system, and he has been given a grim prognosis by his doctors.

Apollo Global Management has named Marc Spilker, a former Goldman Sachs Group executive, to the new position of president, as the private equity firm bolsters its management ranks to ready itself for life as a publicly traded company. Mr. Spilker, who joins Apollo on Wednesday, will run the day-to-day operations of Apollo and sit on the firm's executive committee, according to a statement issued by the firm late Monday. The 46-year-old Mr. Spilker previously co-headed Goldman's money-management unit. He retired from Goldman in February after 20 years at the firm. Apollo, based in New York and run by billionaire investor Leon Black, owns a portfolio of companies including Harrah's Entertainment and Claire's Stores. Apollo is expected to start trading on the New York Stock Exchange sometime early next year. Its currently trades on a private exchange run by Goldman Sachs. Mr. Black and his two co-founders, Josh Harris and Marc Rowan, have gone on something of a hiring spree the last couple of years. In early 2009, the firm brought on the financier Henry Silverman as chief operating officer. The firm also hired a Citigroup executive, Joe Azrack, to head up a new real-estate investment business. Not all of Apollo's high-level hires have worked out. Neal Shear, a longtime senior executive at Morgan Stanley, joined the firm to start a commodities investment business but lasted just over a year. Mr. Shear now works at UBS. Mr. Spilker made headlines over a battle with the hedge fund manager Jim Chanos. The two men, neighbors in East Hampton, N.Y., had a boundary dispute over a common path -- bordered by 6-foot-high hedges -- that led to the beach. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CBS is not giving up on the daytime soap entirely. The network announced Monday that it had renewed ''The Young and the Restless'' for three more seasons, keeping the daily drama on the network through 2014. The 38-year-old series is the highest-rated soap opera on network television, so its renewal is not necessarily surprising on its own. But other soaps have not been so lucky lately: last year CBS canceled the soap opera ''Guiding Light,'' and this year it canceled ''As The World Turns.'' The former was effectively replaced by the game show ''Let's Make a Deal,'' and the latter by ''The Talk.''

Diamondback Capital Management and Level Global, two of three hedge funds raided by federal authorities last week in a widening investigation of insider trading on Wall Street, say the firms are not the target of the government's inquiry, according to letters that the firms sent to investors on Monday. Though Diamondback was also served with a grand jury subpoena ''seeking a broad range of information in connection with the firm's trading and research activities,'' its co-chief investment officers, Richard Schimel and Lawrence Sapanski, said in the letter that the inquiry was focused on one portfolio manager at the firm and a former employee who reported to the manager.

The United States, which faced an uncharacteristic struggle to qualify for soccer's 2011 Women's World Cup, was drawn into a first-round group with North Korea, Colombia and Sweden in Frankfurt, Germany on Monday. The tournament, which will be played in nine cities around Germany, will open on June 26 in Berlin with the hosts playing Canada. The United States begins play in Dresden, in the eastern part of the country, against North Korea on June 28, then travels west to play Colombia in Sinsheim on July 2. It finally heads north to face Sweden in Wolfsburg on July 6.The United States was the final qualifier in the 16-team field.

Two prominent authors of a 1999 book teaching family doctors how to treat psychiatric disorders provided acknowledgment in the preface for an ''unrestricted educational grant'' from a major pharmaceutical company. But the drug maker, then known as SmithKline Beecham, actually had much more involvement than the book described, newly disclosed documents show. The grant paid for a writing company to develop the outline and text for the two named authors, the documents show, and then the writing company said it planned to show three drafts directly to the pharmaceutical company for comments and proposed a timeline for the writing company to furnish the doctors and SmithKline with draft text and final page proofs for approval.
International WOMEN FACE CHALLENGES

SPORTS An article on Friday about the history of the Floyd of Rosedale Trophy, given annually to the winner of the football game between the universities of Iowa and Minnesota, misspelled the given name of a woman who wrote a paper about the trophy's history and gave an outdated reference to her academic affiliation. She is Jaime Schultz, not Jamie, and she is an assistant professor at Penn State; she is no longer at Maryland. The article also misidentified the city near Rosedale Farm, where Floyd of Rosedale, a prize hog and the basis for the trophy, once lived. It is Fort Dodge, Iowa -- not Dodge City, which is in Kansas. (Go to Article)

I recently had the opportunity to spend a week as the doctor at the Imus Ranch for Kids With Cancer in Ribera, N. M., founded by radio personality Don Imus and his wife, Deirdre Imus. Camps for children with cancer have been around since the mid-1970s. Thanks in part to Betty Ford's courageous public discussion of her breast cancer diagnosis in 1974, people with cancer had begun to talk more openly about their disease. Although children with cancer had always met on the wards, and social workers talked with them and their families about their cancer, these encounters only scratched at the surface of these life-changing experiences. Today there are over 70 such camps worldwide.

KAY--Helen. 88, of Lake Worth, FL. Passed peacefully on November 26. Admired for her independence, generosity and lengthy career as an interior decorator. Survived by sons Richard and Jonathan, brother Milton Malkin, grandchildren David, Jana, Jeffrey, Michael and Melanie and five great-grandchildren.

SCHWARZ--Steven, 73, of South Orange, NJ died November 28, 2010. Born in Newark and long-time resident of Wilkes-Barre, PA, he is survived by his wife, Karen Schwarz; his children, Erica and Andy Furman; Joanie and Don Rosenthal; grandchildren, Ariel and Frances Furman; Lee and Dean Rosenthal; and his brothers James and Sharon Schwarz of South Orange, NJ and Roger and Barbara Schwarz of Silver Spring, MD. He was respected, loved and admired by all who knew him. Funeral at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ, 800-938-6372 on Tuesday, November 30, 2010 at 10am. Donations to Oheb Shalom Cong., South Orange or St. Barnabas Hospice.

SPIGA--Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony Spiga, associated with The New York Times from March 1, 1979 until retiring on December 1, 1992.

KOMAR--Herman, 99, co-chairman of the board of Charles Komar and Sons, a 102-year-old intimate apparel company, died in his home in Shrewsbury, NJ, on November 26, 2010. He was a beloved father, grandfather and patriarch. A man of unparalleled integrity, he lived by his father's words, "You only have one reputation." Mr. Komar was a no-nonsense business man and semi-pro athlete. He worked his entire career at Charles Komar and Sons, which was founded by his father in 1908. Mr. Komar ran the company as president from 1952 to 1985 and subsequently served as co-chairman of the board until his death. One of his proudest moments was attending the 100th anniversary party for the family business at the New York Public Library in 2008. As an athlete, he was an all-scholastic lacrosse and football player; he played professional football for the Perth Amboy team in the early 1920s and later was a nationally-ranked handball player. He was predeceased by his first wife Margaret in 1952 and his second wife Hermie, who died in 1998. He is survived by his children and their spouses: Charles and Liz Komar of Rumson, NJ; Leah Komar Harris and Jay Harris of Breckenridge, CO; Donna and Victor Laurie of Princeton, NJ; brother Harold and sister in-law Adelaide of Little Silver, NJ; sister, Madeline Levin, Palm Beach, FL; eight grandchildren; and five great-grandchildren. Mr. Komar was a member of Congregation B'nai Israel in Rumson. He was 75-year member of the Masons.

In a case study we've just published, Dalia Fahmy writes about OfficeDrop, a two-year-old document-scanning company based in Boston. Prasad Thammineni, chief executive, knew he would have to check employee backgrounds before giving them access to sensitive client documents, but it took him a while to find the right solution. He eventually settled on a customized bundle offered by Kroll Background Screening, which reviews a variety of federal and local criminal records, as well driving histories and credit reports (Mr. Thammineni decided against requiring drug tests). Now, every new employee undergoes a background check after accepting a conditional job offer.

With the Chinese buying cars by the tens of thousands every week - big cars, too - and throwing up new buildings, driving in Beijing is no lark. It was an hour before Guo Pei and her husband, Cao Bao Jie, reached the headquarters of Rose Studio, their fashion company, on the city's north side. The October sun was blazing pale when their Mercedes pulled up to a low-rise office complex, its white brick rendered shabby by newer developments. Cao, a stocky, good-looking Taiwanese man who goes by the name Jack, had been kneeling the whole time next to the driver; facing his wife, who sat in the back; and translating from Chinese into English. Now he sort of backed out of the car. Guo Pei, whose career as a fashion designer began when there was no fashion in her country, remained a study in Asian poise and etiquette. In addition to large eyes and delicate features, enhanced by careful makeup, she has a gentleness unmarred by circumstance. These circumstances include wealth and a list of clients in Beijing's highest political, media and social circles. But as Jack said proudly, ''Guo Pei is a very traditional lady - a wonderful wife and daughter and mother who always cares more about her family than the attention she receives.''

"Freaking Ziegfeld!" Darren Aronofsky, Coney Island boy made good, shouted at the premiere of his film "Black Swan" on Tuesday night, although he used a more Brooklyn-y word. Mr. Aronofsky could be forgiven for crowing. "Black Swan," the dark, fantastical story of a perfectionist ballerina, was, by his own admission, a difficult film to make, and his first to have its premiere at the Ziegfeld, the grand movie palace in Midtown Manahattan which he frequented while growing up. ("Mom, I have a confession - I cut out of high school to see 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' in this theater," he said from the front, and later confided to the Bagger that it wasn't a one-time thing.) "Black Swan" felt and played big to its hometown crowd, who could be heard shrieking and shuddering at the more macabre moments. "The Red Shoes" it's not.

Royal Caribbean's newest cruise ship, the Allure of the Seas, is not just big. It is the biggest cruise ship in the world, and as such it crashes magnificently against the tide of the zeitgeist: There is very little sustainable, small-batch, or boutique about it. The ship weighs 225,000 gross tons, consumes 4.7 million pounds of fresh water per day, and enjoys 1.6 million square feet of air conditioned space. At 1,187 feet long, the Allure of the Seas is precisely five centimeters longer than its sister ship, launched in 2009, the paradoxically-named Oasis of the Seas.

For those of you who have considered hoarding incandescent light bulbs before they're phased out for good in 2014, you might want to hold off on renting that storage space. General Electric's Energy Smart LED bulb goes on sale on Wednesday on the company's Web site. The nine-watt bulb is not only energy-efficient - it produces the same amount of light as a 40-watt incandescent bulb (higher-wattage models are in the works) with 77 percent less power - but is also omnidirectional, unlike earlier generations of LED bulbs, which shed light in one direction only. Its 22,500-hour life span is twice that of a compact fluorescent bulb, and it contains no mercury. GE claims that one bulb will last 22.8 years, and GE's  Energy Smart microsite, designed by the New York firm Doyle Partners, makes the point by following a girl from infancy to her wedding day, with the same light illuminating each scene. The bulb's $50 price tag may give sticker shock to all but early adopters. But considering its long life and its incandescent-quality white light - not to mention GE's assertion that if every American household bought just one, we'd save almost $400 million in energy costs and prevent five billion pounds of greenhouse gas emissions in one year - the bulb could turn out to be a good investment in more ways than one.

With the Christmas video-game-buying season in full swing, now seems the right time to ask, Are active video games being aimed, at least in part, at the wrong audience? Active video games refer, of course, to games that require you to be active. Often also called exergames, they include the Wii Fit, Dance Dance Revolution from Konami and the new Microsoft Xbox Kinect and Sony PlayStation Move systems, among others. Depending on the game, they exhort players to hop, wriggle, serve and volley, left-hook a virtual boxing opponent or, in some other fashion, move. The underlying premise of these games is that, unlike Madden NFL 11 or Super Street Fighter IV, playing them should improve people’s fitness and health.

HOFMANN--Peter. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of tenor Peter Hofmann. He made his debut here as Lohengrin in 1980, and sang several leading Wagnerian roles culminating in his unforgettable Siegmund in the new production of Otto Schenk's Die Walkure in 1986. We offer our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, did not spend a lot of time during his recent re-election campaign talking up the McCain-Feingold Act. The tough campaign finance legislation, which he sponsored in 2002 with a Democratic colleague, Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, is unpopular with many conservative Republicans, and they have heaped scorn on Mr. McCain for his role in it ever since. But Mr. McCain took time on the Senate floor on Tuesday morning to profusely praise Mr. Feingold, who lost his bid for a fourth term this month to Ron Johnson, a Republican businessman. ''The Senate will be a much poorer place without Russ Feingold in it,'' said Mr. McCain, who detailed their disagreements - specifically over the war in Iraq - and the civility with which they debated them.

An article on Thursday about a move by Netflix away from DVD by mail and onto the Web misstated, in two instances, the service the company is providing via the Internet. Netflix streams movies and television shows for viewing over an active Internet connection; it does not permit downloads of content.

LORBERBAUM--Donald. In loving memory, died peacefully after a long and heroic battle with pancreatic cancer.
