A loving husband, devoted father to Steve, Gregg and Neal, grandfather to eight grandchildren and loving partner to Beth. With his quick wit, insightful guidance, and care for others, he inspired us with a life beautifully lived. Services Thursday, 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The federal government's crackdown against what it considers illegal insider trading advanced on Tuesday with one arrest and a lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against a husband and wife formerly employed by the consulting firm Deloitte Tax. The S.E.C. is seeking financial penalties and the disgorgement of illicit profits.

Joan Rosenbaum, who has led the Jewish Museum since 1981, will step down as director at the end of June, the museum plans to announce on Wednesday. ''Thirty years is a very good run,'' Ms. Rosenbaum, 67, said in an interview. ''The museum is well-positioned now to take on the next stage of its life.'' The board of the museum, which is on Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street, has formed a search committee to find a successor. Under Ms. Rosenbaum the museum's collection has grown to 26,000 objects, its endowment to more than $92 million and its annual operating budget to $15 million from $1 million in 1981.

She was a theatrical lighting designer in her early years and then became a Systems Programmer. In addition to her love for the opera and theatre, Carol was an avid bridge player and participated in many tournaments throughout the United States. She is survived by her loving companion, James Sampson, her brother, Giles Hoover, her cat, Misty, and a multitude of loving family and friends who will greatly miss her. In lieu of flowers, Carol, being the animal lover that she was, would have preferred any donations be made in her name to any animal rescue or humane society of your choosing.

Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the chamber's No. 4 Democrat, will become chairwoman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee for the 2012 elections, taking on a steep challenge as her party seeks to defend more than twice as many seats as Republicans. Democrats face an extremely tough map in 2012 as they try to hold on to what will be a 53 to 47 majority. That number includes two independents -- Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Bernard Sanders of Vermont -- who align with the Democrats. The Democrats must defend 23 seats, while just 10 Republicans are up for re-election. It is also a presidential election year, which will drive up turnout and puts added pressure on Congressional candidates as their fate can often hinge on the higher-profile race for the White House, while also making it harder for them to draw attention. Ms. Murray led the campaign committee in the 2002 elections, when Republicans picked up two seats and reclaimed a narrow 51-to-49 majority. Many Democrats viewed the post as a thankless job with little upside, and the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, reportedly struggled to find someone who would take it on. Ms. Murray's willingness to step up only further cements her position as the most prominent woman in the Senate Democratic caucus. Ms. Murray just survived her own tough re-election fight, a race that ended up far closer than many Democrats had expected. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Bella Akhmadulina, a poet whose startling images and intensely personal style, couched in classical verse forms, established her as one of the Soviet Union's leading literary talents, died on Monday at her home in Peredelkino, outside Moscow. She was 73. Her death was reported by the Russian news agency Itar-Tass, which quoted her husband, Boris Messerer, as saying that she had had a heart attack.

NEW DELHI -- Mahitosh Sarkar came here from his distant village in West Bengal 12 years ago looking for a better life, and he found it. He abandoned the penniless existence of a subsistence fisherman to become a big-city vegetable seller. His wife found work as a maid. Their four children went to school. Their tiny household, a grim but weather-tight room in a dilapidated tenement, had a color TV and a satellite dish. But these days Mr. Sarkar is counting losses, not blessings. His 10-year-old son died along with more than 70 others when their tenement collapsed on Nov. 15. His wife is in the hospital with a broken leg. All of their possessions, including that color TV, are gone.

Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon, an online coupon start-up, is an aggressive move by the company to dominate local online advertising and help with its long-sought move into social networking. Google has offered Groupon $5.3 billion, with the promise of $700 million in performance bonuses for management, according to a person knowledgeable about the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Several people close to the deal said Groupon, which is based in Chicago, was expected to approve the acquisition and an agreement could be signed as early as this week.

BOUMA--Robert E. 72, lost his fight with uveal melanoma on November 24, 2010, in the presence of his loving family at his home in John's Island, FL. At the time of his death, Mr. Bouma was Senior Counsel at the Chicago-based law firm McDermott Will & Emery LLP, where he had served on the Management Committee and chaired the Litigation department. He was born the son of Jack and Gladys Cooper Bouma on July 19, 1938, and grew up in Pocahontas, IA. Mr. Bouma, an outstanding high school athlete, was selected All-State in both football and basketball. He went on to Coe College, where he excelled in both sports, and on whose Board of Trustees he later served for many years. At the University of Iowa Law School, he was an editor of the Iowa Law Review. Upon graduation in 1962, he joined Cravath, Swaine and Moore in New York as an associate, during which time he also served as a Lieutenant in the JAG Corp. of the United States Naval Reserve. Before joining McDermott as a partner in 1984, Mr. Bouma was Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Household International, Associate General Counsel of Monsanto Co., Senior Group Counsel at Xerox Corporation, and Vice President and General Counsel of Systematic Data Systems. Mr. Bouma was a past chairman of the Illinois Institute of Continuing Legal Education and a past president of The Legal Club of Chicago. He previously was a co-chair of the American Bar Association Litigation Section's Corporate Counsel Committee and a founder and active emeriti member of the Chicago North Shore General Counsel Association. Mr Bouma served as President of the Iowa Law School Board of Trustees and was awarded the Iowa Law School Alumni Achievement Award in February 2010. Mr. Bouma loved art, especially the American realist Marvin Cone. He assembled a diverse collection of Canton porcelain and was an avid reader of art and antique magazines. His greatest loves were playing tennis with his family and spending time at his cabin near Pocahontas hunting pheasants with his son Jim and his brother John, a leading Arizona attorney. Mr. Bouma, together with his wife Susan, raised his family in Lake Forest, IL. He was a most loving and caring father and an inspiration and guide to not just his children, but to many in his personal and professional life. He is survived by the love of his life, Susan Lawson Bouma, son Jim, daughter Whitley Clare, son-in-law David Donnelly Herbert, and grandson, Lawson. Robert and Susan Bouma were to celebrate their 47th wedding anniversary on November 26. He was a member of the John's Island Club and the Onwentsia Club. "Bob was a vibrant leader of McDermott and part of our backbone for the many years he was our friend and colleague," said Jeffrey E. Stone, Co-Chair of McDermott Will & Emery. "Our lives were made better because Bob's irrepressible spirit and unlimited vitality touched and inspired all of us. He pushed us all to be better - and because of him we were. He will be greatly missed by all in the McDermott family." A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, December 3, at 3pm at The First Presbyterian Church of Lake Forest, 700 North Sheridan Rd, Lake Forest, IL. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Uveal Melanoma Fund KCC and sent to Dr. Sato, Kimmel Cancer Center, 1015 Walnut St., Room 1024, Philadelphia, PA 19107. Please reference Robert Bouma in the memo.

ROME -- Less than a month after Pompeii's so-called House of Gladiators collapsed into rubble, portions of a garden wall at the nearby House of the Moralist fell down on Tuesday, prompting new calls to better safeguard the city buried by an eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. Antonio Varone, Pompeii's director of excavations, said the house - which actually consists of two adjacent abodes that belonged to two families - was in no danger.

The Swiss group ABB is set to buy the Baldor Electric Company, an American motor manufacturer, for $3.1 billion, the companies said on Tuesday in a joint statement ABB, which specializes in automation, has offered $63.50 a Baldor share as it makes a push into North America. The deal will also give Baldor access to global markets for its industrial electric motors.

To those who know their vodka, zubrowka (pronounced zu-BROV-ka) is legendary. It's a Polish vodka, said to have been made since the Middle Ages, seasoned with bison grass, or zubrowka, a plant that grows in a northern region of Poland where the now-endangered European bison graze. But the federal Food and Drug Administration does not allow authentic zubrowka to be imported because bison grass contains a blood thinner. Now, the experts at Polmos Bialystok in Poland, the only distillery permitted to make vodka called zubrowka, have assembled other herbs and seasonings from the bison-grass area and come up with a very close approximation of authentic zubrowka. The vodka, distilled from rye, has just been introduced in the United States. Its herbaceous aroma suggests chamomile, and the flavor is grassy and fruity, with hints of coconut. It is delicious served well chilled, rocks optional, and is a superb partner for nutty, fruity osetra caviar.
An article on Nov. 13 about twin brothers who had been sleeping in a tree in Central Park misidentified the type of tree. It is a European beech, not an American elm.

An article on Tuesday about life expectancy in the United States misstated the name of the journal in which researchers reported that inefficiencies in the health care system were to blame for the country's poor ranking compared with other industrialized nations. It is Health Affairs, not Health Services. The article also misspelled the surname of one of the researchers. She is Sherry A. Glied, not Gleid.

It seems that few celebrities in the mid-20th century escaped the lens of Alfred Eisenstaedt. Yet his most famous image depicts people whose identities are not known for sure: the sailor and nurse kissing in Times Square on Aug. 14, 1945, the day that Japan's surrender was announced, ending World War II. In June, I tried to photograph Mr. Eisenstaedt's picture in Times Square. It was the day that an obituary for Edith Shain, who claimed to be the recipient of the kiss, was published. As I held up the clipping, a stranger asked if I needed help. The man called over his bride (of 26 years), and they spontaneously recreated the scene. Mr. Eisenstaedt never named his subjects. But the romance of Conny and Austin McCormack of Whittier, Calif., is no secret.

A.I.G. will sell about $2 billion worth of bonds in its first debt offering since the financial crisis. The insurer will sell bonds in two tranches: a $500 million issue of bonds that mature in January of 2014 and a $1.5 billion issue of bonds that mature in December of 2020. The former carries a yield of about 3.7 percent, while the latter carries a yield of about 6.4 percent.

SIMON--Helene, 94, on November 30, 2010. Born in Baghdad, Iraq, loving and devoted daughter of Khedouri and Louise Zilkha. Beloved wife of the late David Simon. She is survived by her four sons, Ronald (Anne), Edwin (Argie), Jamil (Yolanta), and Victor, eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren, sister Hanina Shasha and brothers Ezra Zilkha and Selim Zilkha. Helene was educated in France and England, married in Beirut, Lebanon in 1937, and emigrated to the US in 1942. She traveled extensively throughout the world exercising her passion for learning and her deep interest in art and art history. In middle age she developed a career as a sculptor and achieved remarkable success. Her work is represented in museums and private collections in North America, Europe and the Middle East. A loyal and loving friend to many, she endeared herself with her boundless optimism, insatiable curiosity, enormous energy, and her warm and caring disposition. Rather than mourn her passing, we celebrate the long and rich life she lived as wife, mother, artist and friend. Services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 11am, Friday, December 3rd.

Kenneth C. Frazier, the president of Merck, is to become chief executive of the pharmaceutical giant at the beginning of next year, the company said Tuesday. Mr. Frazier, 55, a lawyer by training who graduated from Harvard Law School, is believed to be the first African-American tapped to run a global drug powerhouse. Merck, which merged last year with Schering-Plough in a deal worth $49 billion, is the world's largest drug maker after Pfizer.

LEIPZIG--Lloyd, was born in New York City in 1922. He enlisted in the US Army Air Force in 1942 and subsequently flew 78 combat missions in B-25's in the China-Burma-India and European theatres. His many decorations included the Air Medal with four Oak Leaf clusters and the Distinguished Flying Cross and he was honorably discharged as a Captain. When he returned to civilian life, he worked as a publicist for Loew's Theatres, Columbia Records and United Artists Records. In 1970, he relocated to Hollywood, California, and eventually became Senior Vice-President of Advertising and Publicity for both the United Artists Corporation and then Orion Pictures. In these posts and as an independent, he attained an international reputation as a master strategist of Academy Award campaigns, among which were the Oscar-winning films, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," "Rocky," "Annie Hall," "Amadeus," and "My Left Foot." In 1996, Leipzig returned to his native New York, but continued his Academy Award consultancies. Among the award winning motion pictures he represented were "All About My Mother," "Indochine," "Talk to Her," "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," and "Fog of War." He is a long-time member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences and is survived by two brothers, Jay of Santa Fe, New Mexico and Stanley of Lake Worth, Florida. Services will be held at the Plaza Memorial Chapel on Thursday, December 2, 2010 at 2:00pm.

The housing market just earned a much-needed moral victory. Although more than 4 percent of loans held by Fannie Mae are still delinquent, the rate declined recently as banks and the government refined their foreclosure prevention programs, Fannie's monthly housing summary showed. The rate of single-family mortgages that are more than three months past due -- loans that Fannie calls ''seriously delinquent'' -- has fallen every month since March, the report said. And for the first time since 2007, the rate experienced a yearly decline when it dropped to 4.56 percent in September, the most recent month for which data was available, from 4.72 percent in September 2009.

(Showtime) THE OTHER CITY (2010) According to recent figures from the Epidemiology Annual Report for Washington, at least 3 percent of the residents of that city are living with H.I.V. or AIDS -- the highest rate in the nation, rivaling that of some African countries. The crisis, some say, is fueled by a volatile combination of politics, ideology, corruption and bureaucracy that is affecting treatment. In honor of World AIDS Day, this documentary, left, from Susan Koch interviews citizens who have not allowed a lack of government assistance to stand in the way of pursuing effective treatment -- like J'Mia Edwards, a mother of three who is fighting to keep her family housed; Jose Ramirez, who has devoted his life to promoting H.I.V. awareness among Hispanic teenagers; Ron Daniels, who provides clean needles and medical information to drug users; and the staff members of Joseph's House, who comfort terminally ill patients. 6 P.M. (Fox News Channel) SPECIAL REPORT WITH BRET BAIER Because Wednesday is World AIDS Day, Mr. Baier interviews Bono and former President George W. Bush about the One Campaign, an advocacy organization that fights extreme poverty and preventable disease, particularly in Africa; global fund-raising; and bipartisan initiatives for research. President Obama and AIDS workers in Africa will send messages of support.

The Ixtlán de Juárez Journal article on Nov. 23, about successful forest conservation by the Zapotec Indians in the mountains around Ixtlán de Juárez in southern Mexico's Oaxaca state, misattributed the source of a study that reported local communities like the Zapotec are now managing more than a quarter of the forests in developing countries. The study was done by the Rights and Resources Initiative, a nonprofit advocacy group based in Washington that promotes increased community ownership of forests in developing countries; it was not by the Center for International Forestry Research, a nonprofit conservation group based in Bogor, Indonesia.

An article on Monday about extensive leadership changes in the largest American magazine companies referred incorrectly to the revenue that the publisher Meredith derives from products marketed at Wal-Mart stores under the name of Better Homes and Gardens magazine. While the total sale of such products is indeed about $1 billion, Meredith itself does not receive that amount. (Meredith does not release figures on how much licensing revenue those sales generate.)

This year's soccer World Cup in South Africa, in the end, yielded relatively few surprises. Seven of the eight quarterfinalists hailed from either Europe or South America, soccer's traditional power continents. The tournament was won by Spain, which was ranked as one of the two strongest teams heading into the competition. Sure, the 2006 finalists, Italy and France, performed poorly. But that should not have shocked anyone who watched these countries' tepid performances in the qualifying stages.

LONDON - As a trader at JPMorganChase in London, Ashish Goyal helps manage billions of dollars of the bank's exposure to risks like foreign exchange fluctuations. In his spare time, he takes tango lessons, plays cricket and goes clubbing with friends. Mr. Goyal is also blind.

Yesterday's four consecutive openings of Art Basel Miami Beach - a ten-hour delight for jet-lagged, untanned dealers minding their booths - yielded an overall quiet turnout. On Thursday the fair opened to the public, and beyond the bottleneck at the gates things were ... even quieter. Which is not to say dead, or even grim; the mood at Art Basel this year so far has merely been sober. The work is selling. The $20 Champagne is selling. You might say things have been laid back ... is that OK? Why not. I even saw an errant Eames chair extrude beyond the limits of a booth, and it was not instantly destroyed by Swiss authorities.

The secretary of homeland security, Janet Napolitano, called on Congress to pass a bill granting legal status to many thousands of illegal immigrant students, saying it would help immigration authorities focus their resources on deporting dangerous criminals.

The NBC singing competition returns for another season.

A study by a group of biologists, ecologists and medical researchers casts new light on a phenomenon farmers have known for years: the less the genetic variety in a crop or a herd, the greater the risk that disease will decimate it. The presence of many species in ecosystems, the scientists report in  Thursday's issue of the journal Nature, damps a pathogen's ability to spread among humans.

Whether it's designing the Design Miami exhibition tent (in 2008, 2009, and 2010), showing their work at the Johnson Trading Gallery booth, or conceiving the fair's floor plan (2010), Ben Aranda and Chris Lasch of the New York architecture firm Aranda\Lasch have been a consistent presence at the fair. This year, they added another arrow to their quiver: a Fendi-sponsored booth that showcases Modern Primitives, a collection of objects that are the product of the firm's research into developing crystalline shapes into building systems. Despite the name, the concept behind their latest venture is anything but primitive, including references to the revolutionary 17th-century mathematician Johannes Kepler and a special app the duo devised to generate different formations. But the end results are beautiful sculptural pieces that fulfill both a function (in this case, mostly seating) and offer the possibility of being developed into a full-fledged architectural system. The Moment sat down with Ben and Chris to discuss the process behind the project, and how the storied Roman luxury house became part of the equation.

"The Social Network" was a big hit with the National Board of Review, which on Thursday awarded it several top prizes, including best feature, best director (David Fincher), best actor (Jesse Eisenberg) and best adapted screenplay (Aaron Sorkin). The group's president, Annie Schulhof, lauded the truthy drama for being a timeless story that will "appeal to many generations," especially if or when Facebook takes over the world.

When Nina Garduno opened Free City Supershop in 2005, in a strip mall in Malibu, Calif., it was hard to describe the place. It wasn't a boutique, exactly, though she sold clothes and jewelry. It wasn't a "concept store," though it offered a genuine sense of discovery rare in the world of retail. And you hesitated to lump it with the deadly term "lifestyle," though she sold refurbished bicycles, custom turntables and teepees.

In the summer of 1970, President Richard M. Nixon consolidated the anti-pollution enforcement powers of 15 federal departments into a single new entity, the Environmental Protection Agency. "We're going after the polluters," William D. Ruckelshaus, the agency's first director, said after his nomination to the post. "All of them."

Ruba Katrib has been organizing some of the freshest and smartest museum shows anywhere - in Miami. As the associate curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) in North Miami, Katrib - a West Virginia native with a master's degree from Bard College's renowned Center for Curatorial Studies - has been responsible for recent surveys of Cory Arcangel and Claire Fontaine, and sprawling, international concept shows like last year's "The Reach of Realism." The Moment caught up with the creative force who helps to keep the city on the map all those other 51 weeks of the year.

Lots of smart economists and policy makers have been debating whether the problems in the job market are primarily cyclical (that is, temporary, and related to slack demand) or primarily structural (that is, reflecting a deeper problem in the economy, such as a tougher mismatch between the skills employers want and the skills workers have).

Christopher Crawford and Jayzel Samonte started Company of We a little over a year ago from their downtown Manhattan apartment. Launched initially as an online-only boutique, the boys, 30 and 28 respectively, watched as their playful toggle coats and double-breasted captain's jackets gained a virtual following, only to be later snatched up by the likes of Saks Fifth Avenue. This month, the designers opened up a pop-up shop in the West Village, where they are manning the registers, meeting their customers face to face for the first time. "It breathes life into our digital roots," Crawford said of the earthy, masculine space. The shop also serves as a platform to introduce the Company of We's women's capsule collection, featuring easy, ladylike confections like an elongated dinner jacket with metallic detailing and a pastel pleated skirt. The couple's first foray into women's wear channels both the interior designer Kelly Wearstler ("She was a Playboy Playmate, has impeccable taste and is now filthy rich," says Samonte) as well as friend and fashion journalist, Meenal Mistry, ("Stylish, slightly mysterious, intelligent and aspirational," says Crawford). And as for sharing a life as well as a business? "The New Yorker and Bravo's 'Real Housewives' can be the perfect high-low distraction," Samonte says with a laugh.

Overview | How can using writer's notebooks and practicing the use of literary elements help writers develop ideas? In this lesson, students examine the lyrics of rap artist Jay-Z for literary elements including rhyme, metaphor, puns and allusions, then consider what he says about his own writing process. Finally, they analyze additional lyrics and apply lessons from Jay-Z's process to their own reading and writing.

Visitors to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington will no longer be able to find the David Wojnarowicz video "A Fire in My Belly" there, but they will not have to travel far to see it. "I saw God today," Javier Bardem said Wednesday night, having a smoke outside the party for "Biutiful," the Alejandro González Iñárritu movie in which he stars. "I saw God and God talked to me, and I'm actually amazed by his grace." God, for Mr. Bardem, is Al Pacino, who made a surprise visit to the celeb-stocked party, after his performance in "The Merchant of Venice" on Broadway. Mr. Pacino, his hair in a messy little ponytail, chatted with Mr. Bardem, who eagerly introduced him to Penélope Cruz, his very pregnant wife. Mr. Pacino promptly touched her belly. ("He touched the baby!" Mr. Bardem gushed later.) They all talked and laughed in a tight circle for a few moments.

MIAMI BEACH - The crowds that used to form more than an hour before the opening of the "First Choice" portion of Art Basel Miami Beach-the four-hour window between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. when only elite collectors can enter and browse the fair-are gone. Gone too are the speculators who before the financial crisis used to race down the aisles as soon as the doors opened in order to snag a work that they thought they could flip at a profit a few months later. Indeed, on Wednesday during "First Choice" things seemed sedate compared to the years before 2008. Some described the giant convention hall as "empty."

"Biutiful," written and directed by Alejandro González Iñárritu ("Babel"), is the dark story of a struggling father of two, played by Javier Bardem, who is barely getting by in Barcelona, hustling even more struggling people - illegal Chinese and African immigrants - while dealing with a troubled ex-wife and his own life-threatening health problems. Mr. Bardem's character lives on the margins in a world that rarely has time for pleasure and seems encircled by death. He won a best actor prize at the Cannes Film Festival for his performance in the movie, which opens on Dec. 29.

It was the Triangle Waist Company, not the Triangle Shirtwaist Company.

Gardner is expected to be ready for spring training, the Yankees said. The tendinitis emerged as an issue after he was hit by a pitch June 27 in Los Angeles. It flared up from time to time, and in September he received an injection of anti-inflammatory medication.

An article on Nov. 22 about a surge in coal imports to China misidentified the entity that recently rejected proposals for adding a coal export terminal in the Tacoma, Wash., area. It was the Port of Tacoma, an independent municipal corporation, not the city of Tacoma. The article also misstated the time frame in which the decision not to add a terminal was made. According to a port spokeswoman, officials decided not to pursue terminal proposals advanced by coal companies over a period of several weeks, ending in early November; she said they did not make the decision on Nov. 19. (That was the date on which the port first informed a publication that the terminal would not be built.)

Yamaha's one of those fun Japanese conglomerates that makes things as diverse as baby grand pianos and motorcycles. But music and audio is where the company had its start (its logo is three tuning forks arranged in a circle), and those remain a core competency. The latest product to come out of the multifarious company is the TSX-140, a $400 speaker dock for iPods or iPhones that also functions as an alarm clock.The TSX-140 uses Yamaha digital signal processing to eliminate noise and make the tabletop unit sound larger than it actually is. In addition to playing an iPhone or iPod, it has an AM-FM tuner.

SIMON--Helene, 94, on November 30, 2010. Born in Baghdad, Iraq, loving and devoted daughter of Khedouri and Louise Zilkha. Beloved wife of the late David Simon. She is survived by her four sons, Ronald (Anne), Edwin (Argie), Jamil (Yolanta), and Victor, eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren, sister Hanina Shasha and brothers Ezra Zilkha and Selim Zilkha. Helene was educated in France and England, married in Beirut, Lebanon in 1937, and emigrated to the US in 1942. She traveled extensively throughout the world exercising her passion for learning and her deep interest in art and art history. In middle age she developed a career as a sculptor and achieved remarkable success. Her work is represented in museums and private collections in North America, Europe and the Middle East. A loyal and loving friend to many, she endeared herself with her boundless optimism, insatiable curiosity, enormous energy, and her warm and caring disposition. Rather than mourn her passing, we celebrate the long and rich life she lived as wife, mother, artist and friend. Services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 11am, Friday, December 3rd.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about China's proposal for emergency consultations to defuse the crisis on the Korean peninsula erroneously attributed a distinction to the catalyst for the crisis, North Korea's deadly Nov. 23 artillery shelling of an island occupied by South Korea. That shelling was the first attack on civilian areas since the armistice that halted the 1950-53 Korean War; it was not the first time that South Korean civilians have been killed by North Korean weaponry since then.
An obituary on Wednesday about the Italian filmmaker Mario Monicelli referred incorrectly to his daughters Ottavia and Martina, who survive him. They are from his second marriage, not his first.

The Front Row column last Thursday, about which designer Kate Middleton, Prince William's fiancée, might use for her wedding gown, misattributed a statement about Issa, a fashion label that is one of her favorites. Janet Ozzard of New York Magazine called Issa ''something a well-bred and not terribly adventurous woman can reliably wear to polo matches or garden parties (or a really big press conference).'' The comment was not written by Hadley Freeman, a fashion writer for The Guardian, who did, as the article noted, call it ''truly the Diane Von Furstenberg of the Sloaney set.''

The executive producer of AMC's ''The Walking Dead,'' Frank Darabont, is shaking up his writing staff as he prepares for a second season of the post-apocalyptic zombie series. Some fans fretted about a report on Deadline.com Tuesday evening that Mr. Darabont had dismissed all of the writers of the series, which has enjoyed a ratings surge this fall. The series has its first season finale on Sunday night. The Web site said that Mr. Darabont, a veteran of feature film, was thinking about forgoing a writers' room entirely for season two, relying on freelance writers instead.

Steven N. Posner, who with his father, Victor, was caught up in a major corporate raiding case that led to the convictions of Ivan F. Boesky and Michael R. Milken, died Monday in a high-speed boat collision on Biscayne Bay, Fla. He was 67 and lived in Miami. His wife confirmed the death.

The new Broadway musical ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,'' a favorite of critics that has had trouble catching on with theatergoers, will close on Jan. 2 after three and a half months of performances, the producers said on Wednesday. It is the second new musical in two days to announce a closing notice; ''The Scottsboro Boys'' will end its run on Dec. 12 after just two months. The production, which cost $4.5 million to mount, will close at a loss to investors, as will ''Scottsboro'' - 2 of the 10 big-budget new musicals with original scores that are taking a chance on Broadway this season.

By ELLEN BARRY MOSCOW -- Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin responded on Wednesday to criticism of Russia revealed in United States diplomatic cables published by the whistle-blowing Web site WikiLeaks, warning Washington not to interfere in Russian domestic affairs.

Bondi Digital - the company that took more than 80 years of New Yorker issues and converted them into a browsable, searchable, full-page archive on CD-ROM and a portable hard drive-has added a new magazine title to its list of clients. Playboy Cover to Cover is a portable hard drive that contains every issue from the first, in 1953, to December 2009. It costs $300. Once the drive is connected, a viewing application is downloaded and installed on a PC. The interface is clean and simple - readers can browse by issue, read table of contents and search for keywords across all issues. Each month's copy of Playboy is displayed in its entirety - including the advertisements that ran in each issue.

LORBERBAUM--Donald. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and long-time member Donald Lorberbaum. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club

Three designers had a month and $5,000 to design a studio or one-bedroom apartment in 99 John Deco Lofts, a 442-unit condo built in 1933 as the Insurance Company of North America Building. The competition was sponsored by TF Cornerstone, the condominium's developer. Their designs were judged by potential buyers at the condo's sales office and by other interested parties who voted on a Facebook page. The winner, to be announced at a reception hosted by the interior designer Jamie Drake, is Jacquelyn Moore-Hill, above right.

''Our political sky still continues to grow more and more dark and threatening,'' the elderly statesman John Jay wrote in 1810. ''Whether the clouds will quietly disperse and disappear, or whether they portend a storm, is uncertain. The present tempestuous state of the world does not encourage us to expect a long season of uninterrupted fair weather.'' Even as war with Britain seemed more and more inevitable, however, New York spent much of 1810 - boisterously and confidently - developing into the American metropolis. New York, just as I pictured it.

STRIDER--Robert E.L. II. The President and Trustees of Colby College mourn the loss and celebrate the wonderful life of Robert E.L. Strider II, Litt.D. '79, 17th president and life trustee. Died November 28, in Boston, MA, at 93. Scholar, educator, leader, and friend to Colby for more than five decades. Memorial: Sunday, December 5, 2pm, The Episcopal Church of Our Saviour, 25 Monmouth Street., Brookline, MA.

The recent expansion of federal insider trading investigations has placed networks of outside experts at the center of the inquiry. But the experts' motivation for disclosing nonpublic material isn't clear, and prosecutors may have a hard time proving the experts received any benefit or breached their fiduciary duty. Many experts believe they simply provided an informed understanding of an industry. John Kincunnan, a principal at Broadband Research who was asked by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents to record conversations with clients, wrote in DealBook that ''the type of research I provide to clients is pervasive in the financial community, the same kind of analysis provided not only by all investment banks, large and small, but by an ever-expanding group of research boutiques, virtually all larger than mine.''

TAKING inspiration from the architecture of India, the designer Roberta Freymann has revamped a two-story Upper East Side town house, transforming it into Ro's Market. The bazaar has chunky rings, bangles and scarves displayed in fruit crates and on drum tables, and the walls are rich bright pinks, accented by hanging bamboo curtains and stenciled lanterns. The finds, sourced by Ms. Freymann, come from Latin America, India and Vietnam. The tapestry tote (pictured, $250) is from Thailand. 153 East 70th Street, (212) 585-3767; robertafreymann.com.

Tuesday's meeting in Tampa, Fla., between the Yankees, Derek Jeter and his agent was set in motion when the agent, Casey Close, called Hal Steinbrenner, the team's managing partner, and suggested that the sides get together in an attempt to break Jeter's contract stalemate. So for several hours on Tuesday evening, Jeter, Close and a lawyer working for the agent met with a Yankees contingent that included Steinbrenner, General Manager Brian Cashman and the team's president, Randy Levine, said a person in baseball with knowledge of the meeting.

A press representative for the R&B group Boyz II Men said that a technical glitch was to blame for one of the group's songs being played twice during an NBC Christmas special -- once when the band wasn't on stage -- and that the band was not lip-syncing during its performance.

6 A.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: MICKEY ROONEYTurner Classic Movies pays tribute each Thursday in December to Mr. Rooney, a larger-than-life 5-foot-2-inch package who married eight times, made and lost millions and has enjoyed a career spanning more than 80 years. The salute begins with his uncredited role in ''The Beast of the City'' (1932), about a police captain (Walter Huston) who leads the fight against a brutal gangland chief (Jean Hersholt) and finds himself embroiled in an affair with the gangster's stenographer (Jean Harlow). At 8 p.m. Mr. Rooney takes on the impish Puck, above, in William Dieterle and Max Reinhardt's adaptation of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' (1935), with Ian Hunter as Theseus, Verree Teasdale as Hippolyta, Dick Powell as Lysander and Olivia de Havilland as Hermia. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES After a burned corpse is found in a truck, Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) are led to a high school, where they uncover a relationship between a teacher and a student. Meanwhile Hannah (Katheryn Winnick) tries to bond with Booth's son. In ''Fringe,'' at 9, the team discovers a device that can facilitate communication between universes.

The question before the Food and Drug Administration advisory committee on Tuesday was path-breaking: Would it recommend that the labels of two drugs be changed to say that they can reduce a man's risk of getting prostate cancer? If the drugs were approved for that purpose, they would be only the second class of cancer-prevention drugs on the market -- the first being drugs like tamoxifen that block estrogen and reduce the risk of breast cancer.

Most pop stars don't go on the record the day after their album is released with specific sales projections. But most aren't Kanye West. Onstage at the Bowery Ballroom last week, as part of a wide-ranging speech on fame, Mr. West bragged that his new album, ''My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy'' (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam), was on track to sell 600,000 copies in its first week.

WARD--Jane Barber, 94, passed away peacefully at the Shady Grove Adventist Hospital in Rockville, MD on November 26. She leaves two sons, Tom (Towers of New Canaan, CT) and John (Towers of Englewood, FL), a daughter, Dr. Jane Ballard (Ward of Washington, D.C.), seven grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren. Daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Barber of Richmond Hill, Queens, NY, she was a graduate of Richmond Hill High School, Wellesley College and received her Masters degree from Columbia University. She taught school in Valley Stream, LI, and English as a second language in Jakarta, Indonesia, and also lived in Manhasset, NY, Ridgewood, NJ, Centerville, MA, Englewood, FL, San Antonio, TX, and Washington DC. A memorial service will be held next May in Baiting Hollow, LI, where she spent summers growing up and was married to Ballard in 1950. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to UNICEF or the Sierra Club.

FISHER--Margaret M.,of Manhattan, died in a tragic automobile accident on November 26th. For over 40 years, she devoted her nursing career to advocacy for patient care and was a leader at the Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was revered as a leader and acted as a role model for the psychiatric interdisciplinary team at the hospital; her impact was profound. Her commitment to service was not limited to her profession. Margaret was an active member of the Park Avenue United Methodist Church, and was involved in their various volunteer initiatives. She ran marathons, helped to rebuild homes in Louisiana, traveled much of the world, was a voracious leader, and loved her family and friends. She was preceded in death by her parents, Clyde and Georgia Fisher of Spencer, Nebraska. Margaret's passing will be mourned by brothers Stanley of Waldport, OR, Philip of Evansville, IN, Lowell of Spencer, NE, Roger of Acworth, GA, and many nieces, nephews and friends. She will be sorely missed. Memorial services will be held Friday at 10am on December 3, at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86 Street, New York City.

Two ancient walls fell in different areas of Pompeii, left, on Wednesday, probably the casualties of heavy rains. The collapses were the third and fourth in less than a month. A staff member at the site said that the walls, a combination of ancient stone and mortar, did not contain frescoes. The interim Pompeii superintendent, Jeanne Papadopoulus, played down the latest collapses, saying in a statement that such occurrences were ''possible in the life span of a vast, 2,000-year-old archaeological site, especially considering the weather conditions of recent days.'' These new incidents ''should not generate any alarmism or sensationalism,'' the statement said. But Wednesday's collapses at the ancient city engulfed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79 are likely to fuel the polemics that have raged over the upkeep of the site since the so-called House of Gladiators crumbled in early November. The debate grew on Tuesday after a nearby wall fell. Critics say that the Italian government has been remiss in overseeing and financing basic maintenance at the fragile site.

MACKAGE, the Montreal-based label primarily known for outerwear, is opening its first stand-alone store in the United States in SoHo. The 2,000-square-foot-store, which opens this Friday, will have an exclusive collection of shearling jackets (right, $950) and mink accessories. The line is designed by its founders, Elisa Dahan and Eran Elfassy, childhood friends who went to fashion school together. They have just introduced a ready-to-wear collection, and opened a store in Paris last year; 123 Mercer Street, (212) 925-1455; mackage.com.

As investors fret that Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon is too high a price to pay, new details about the company's sales and growth suggest that it might be more like one of Groupon's cut-rate deals. An individual close to Groupon, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the company's annual revenue is running in excess of $1 billion a year and its subscriber base tripled this summer to 35 million users.

For the fourth year in a row, the number of players who had a diagnosis of attention deficit disorder and were allowed by Major League Baseball to use stimulants to treat the disorder exceeded the national average. In a report issued Wednesday, baseball's drug administrator, Dr. Bryan W. Smith, said 105 players were given exemptions for the 2010 season, enabling them to use stimulants to treat attention deficit disorder. That number was 108 in 2009, 106 in 2008 and 103 in 2007.

Syracuse said on Thursday that it had accepted an invitation to play in the inaugural New Era Pinstripe Bowl on Dec. 30 in Yankee Stadium. Its Big 12 opponent is likely to be Kansas State. ''This is a fabulous opportunity for our institution, as many alums live in the area and our fans can descend upon New York City for the holidays,'' Dr. Daryl Gross, Syracuse's athletics director, said in a statement. ''We continue to want to represent as New York's college team as we are the only B.C.S. school in the state of New York and plan to paint the city orange.''

Iran: Holidays Declared for Pollution Iran has declared public holidays in the capital, Tehran, on Wednesday for the second time in two weeks after air pollution reached dangerous levels. Schools, government offices and public facilities were closed for two days starting Wednesday. Many private businesses stayed open, and hospitals and health centers remained open to handle an expected increase in patients with breathing difficulties. On Saturday, Health Minister Marzeh Vahid-Dastjerdi reported a 30 percent increase in health problems related to the recent increase in air pollution. A one-day holiday was also called in the central city of Isfahan on Tuesday. WILLIAM YONG

It has been a rainy week in Philadelphia, and Michael Vick is about as effective on a soggy surface as a dinosaur in a tar pit. What looked like a charmed season for the Eagles a week ago now looks like just another cut 'n' paste Andy Reid campaign. Hope for a quick rebound rests with a Texans team with an awful pass defense and a knack for losing nationally televised games.

The government's widening investigation of suspected insider trading is shaking up Wall Street and the hedge fund industry. The investigation accelerated this fall, more than a year after the arrest of the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group. In November, a French doctor and a consulting firm executive were arrested, three hedge funds were raided by F.B.I. agents and federal subpoenas were issued to several funds, including the giant SAC Capital Advisors. As we wait for the government's next moves, DealBook spoke with a former prosecutor and a former Wall Street executive, both with many years of experience, to put the investigation into perspective. The former prosecutor is Jay Fahy, who now specializes in white-collar crime at the law firm Fahy Choi. We asked Mr. Fahy what the inquiry represented:

An article on Nov. 18 about the use of nutria pelts in fashion misidentified the conservation group in Thibodaux, La., that was the main sponsor of a nutria fashion show on Nov. 21. It is the Barataria-Terrebonne National Estuary Program -- not the Barataria-Terrebonne Estuary Foundation, a separate group.

An article on Wednesday about the Air Force's efforts to counter a mix-up in which rival bidders on an aerial tanker contract were inadvertently sent data on each other's proposals quoted incorrectly from comments by Sean O'Keefe, the chief executive of EADS North America, on how the company treated data it received about Boeing's proposal. He said the disc ''was packed up and returned to the Air Force,'' not ''backed up'' and then returned.

Last week Dell released its new Inspiron Duo, a hybrid device that, through the cunning use of hinges, can go from a tablet to a keyboarded portable in a short flip. The Inspiron Duo ($549) is a portable computer with a 10.1-inch display. It features a 1.5 GHzIntel Atom processor and 2GB of RAM. Storage can be as much as 320GB. A webcam is built in and the computer ships with Windows 7 Home Premium.

It was just a little bantering between friends, but the text messages Cliff Lee exchanged Tuesday with Ian Kinsler provided a glimpse into the bidding for his services, which are set to intensify next week at baseball's winter meetings. Kinsler, who was Lee's teammate on the Texas Rangers for the final four months of last season, told a Dallas radio station that he exchanged text messages with Lee while a contingent of Rangers executives was visiting Lee at his Arkansas home.

Google has finally set a date - or at least a ballpark one - for its long-awaited foray into electronic books, Google Editions. The company will introduce Google Editions by the end of the year, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday night, a delay of several months from the original timeline. Google had said that the venture would be ready by the end of the summer.

No department store in the 1990s had the cool factor of Barneys New York. It had the edgiest designers (Martin Margiela, Helmut Lang, Comme des Garcons), the kookiest windows and a team of buyers and merchandisers that made the store something of a hip event. Even when the store filed for bankruptcy protection, in 1996, it kept its cool. But a lot has changed in the post-recession world, challenging Barneys' authority. On Monday, the store announced that two of its longtime buying executives, Judy Collinson, the general merchandising manager for women's fashion, and Julie Gilhart, its fashion director, had been let go. Daniella Vitale, a former Gucci executive, was named Barneys chief merchant and would be responsible for women's fashion, as well as the retailer's online operations. Tom Kalenderian, the store's top men's wear executive, will stay.

He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to Autism Speaks.

The Federal Reserve's data dump of more than 21,000 loan documents from the financial crisis provides a vivid reminder of how ugly it can get when the credit markets freeze up. In order to get crucial overnight loans, hundreds of banks had nothing else to give the Fed as collateral except junk-rated loans and bonds -- valued at $1.3 trillion. Securities rated that low are risky because no one wants to buy them when the markets freeze up. As a result, many banks could not push these junk securities off their balance sheets by selling them.

IT doesn't really matter whether Serendipity, the restaurant on East 60th Street in Manhattan, was already serving footlong hot dogs in 1975, or its frozen hot chocolate. Neither Nan Talese nor Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis would have ordered them anyway. ''I don't think I noticed what either of us had,'' Ms. Talese, the longtime editor, said there recently -- the first time she had returned since that long-ago meeting. ''We were there to talk about books.''

HONG KONG - A bank whose customer base is larger than the population of the United States, a French cosmetics maker, a microlender and a Chinese pharmaceutical company that makes an anticoagulant derived from pigs' guts: Asian stock exchanges have seen it all this year. And it is not just the variety of stocks on offer. It is the sheer number of companies rushing to market in Asia, and the huge amounts they are raising. General Motors may have raised $23.1 billion in its initial public offering - but it is fast-growing Asia, not Wall Street, that has had most of the world's new listings this year.

Fisk University in Nashville, which wants to sell a $30 million ownership stake in its Stieglitz art collection to raise money, plans to appeal a court decision that set limits on the sale, the university announced on Wednesday. The ownership stake is going to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., but the sale has raised concerns among those who question the university's need to sell items given to it as a public trust by the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, who married the photographer Alfred Stieglitz.

Greg Lawrence's ''Jackie as Editor'' (St. Martin's/Thomas Dunne Books, $26) is the first biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis dedicated to her 19-year publishing career, which began in 1975 with a $200-a-week editorial job at Viking. (A head honcho at Random House had politely turned her down.) Lawrence credits Kennedy with publishing 97 books, including many on dance - memoirs by Martha Graham and Gelsey Kirkland, and a collection of Pushkin fairy tales prefaced by Rudolf Nureyev. ''If you produce one book,'' she said, ''you will have done something wonderful in your life.''

As an Irish-American, I don't usually trumpet the work of a nation that kept my ancestors under its boot heel for nearly 300 years. But having just finished the memoirs of two great exports of Britain, I rise to praise a pair of Brits in the season of book-buying.

If such a thing were possible, it would be nice to have red flags warning us of the difficulties lurking in a puzzle. Today, I ran into trouble in the lower right, then upper right, middle, lower left and finally in the red-flag-worthiest upper left.

In a memorable scene in the "The Social Network," the actor Justin Timberlake, who portrays the Silicon Valley investor Sean Parker in the movie, leans over the table and tells the founders of Facebook in a conspiratorial tone: "A million dollars isn't cool. You know what's cool? A billion dollars."

So how did Iran do it?   How did a conservative theocracy decide to deal with its drug addicts as if it were Canada?  In Tuesday's column, I wrote that Iran is treating its massive epidemic of injecting drug use mainly as a health problem.  With this strategy, it has effectively managed to lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep the disease from spreading.  It has taken an approach to drugs known as harm reduction, which includes the provision of methadone maintenance therapy and clean needles to drug users.
Melanie Lefkowitz’s family has had an enduring presence in Brooklyn since the early 20th century. She chronicles their lives in words and pictures.

11:37 p.m. | Updated Groupon has walked away from Google's $6 billion takeover offer, according to a person close to Groupon. The rejection at least temporarily thwarts Google's efforts to buy the social buying site, which would have been its largest acquisition to date.

In the current college football era, where strength of schedule is just one of the factors determining where a team stands in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, those at the top can often find themselves rooting for already defeated opponents, hoping a win here or there will convince the computers' metrics that their schedule is indeed stout. Well, on Saturday, none of that will matter. The equation will be much simpler for most teams: win a game and win a title. Oregon is an exception. If the Ducks beat Oregon State in the rivalry known as the Civil War, then they will merely secure a chance to win a title. Of course, it will be the B.C.S. championship. Auburn is hoping to join Oregon in that game, but first the Tigers will have to beat South Carolina and win the Southeastern Conference. Florida State and Virginia Tech, two teams that have improved as the season has gone on, will fight it out for the A.C.C. title, while the old foes Oklahoma and Nebraska will meet for one last time as members of the same conference, a fitting end to the Cornhuskers' time in the Big 12. Connecticut will be looking to wrap up the most improbable B.C.S. berth in the country. If the Huskies beat South Florida, they will be Big East champions. Even without mathematical formulas, there is plenty at stake on Saturday.
One big lesson from the WikiLeaks dump of state department documents: Weddings in Dagestan are insanely awesome.

A new poll from Public Policy Polling in Massachusetts suggests that Republican Senator Scott Brown -- who represents one of the Democrats' few opportunities to play offense in a cycle in which they hold more than two-thirds of the Senate seats that will be contested in 2012 -- is in relatively good shape for re-election. Against a series of potential Democratic opponents, he holds leads by margins ranging between 7 and 19 points, according to the survey.

Dec. 4, 7:34 p.m. | Updated CANCÚN, Mexico -- At almost every negotiation in recent years aimed at building a new international climate agreement, a batch of delegates and United Nations officials huddle at the end of the first week to start framing some kind of text. The diplomatic term of art for such documents is "non-paper." The idea is to have something ready for high-level officials to firm up before the meeting ends a week later.

In this week's Travel section, Gregory Dicum explores San Francisco's literary scene, which remains robust despite dire warnings of the publishing industry's demise. He writes that "on almost any day or night in San Francisco, there is likely to be something for the literary inclined -- a poetry reading at a bar, a book swap in a cafe or a reading in the book-lined lobby of the Rex Hotel."

Lotus Cars announced two new high-level executive hirings. The news confirms a widespread impression that the sports car company is making an aggressive effort to expand sales -- an effort signaled by the hiring of a new design chief, Donato Coco, roughly a year ago and the unveiling of multiple new models -- Elise, Elan, Esprit, Elite, and Eterne -- at the Paris auto show in September.

Well, after 20 blog posts, a dozen interviews, five movies, three red carpets, two video tapings and one instance of slipping into a party to which we weren't technically invited, we've made it through the first week of award season more or less intact. Hurrah! Only 12 more weeks to go!

Most computer database searches - where you use key words to retrieve documents - are based on something called Boolean logic. What you may not know is that the term refers to a 19th century mathematician named George Boole, who developed his now indispensable theory in the 1854 book "The Laws of Thought."
Four nonprofit groups are trying to attract $25 gifts through text messages this holiday season, an experiment that may increase the popularity of giving via mobile phones among charities.

A few weeks ago, Van Leeuwen Artisanal Ice Cream added a new truck to its expanding buttercup-yellow fleet. Called "Turtle" (all six trucks are named for animals: Kangaroo, Panda, Rattlesnake, Bobcat, Eagle), it's as focused on coffee as it is on ice cream.

Todd Stern, the chief American climate change negotiator, arrived on Friday in the Mexican resort town of Cancún, where the annual two-week United Nations climate extravaganza has been under way since Monday.
A federal advisory panel on Friday endorsed an expansion of the use of Allergan's Lap-Band stomach restricting device to patients who are less than severely obese.

With all the fairs opened and all the weather-delayed New Yorkers safely deposited in Miami, Thursday was primed to kick the party circuit into high gear. Despite a Swiss Institute/Bally party in Wynwood rumored to have cost half a million dollars (presumably spent on the laser show and on Peaches, who performed on the shoulders of a naked transvestite), the cab ride across the causeway was out of the question for most partygoers. This was more a matter of practicality than anything else, considering the door hell promised by the evening's most buzzed about event: the MOMA PS1/Interview magazine pool spectacular at the Delano. Ninety minutes before the performance, conceived by Mariah Robertson, was scheduled to begin, the receiving area behind the hotel's shrubbery resembled a military state. For a moment even MOMA's Klaus Biesenbach was stranded on the other side.
Kiya Horace stood in front of a microphone at Avatar Studios on West 53rd Street on Wednesday afternoon and waited for directions.

New York made $16.9 million in the latest auction of carbon dioxide credits, held this week under the cap-and-trade system known as Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. But it remains to be seen whether the money will go to the energy efficiency programs it is intended for.

Although the Christmas shopping season is off to a strong start, some surveys of consumers are flashing red lights rather than green ones as to what the mood among retailers and marketers might be on Dec. 26.

A project that began with an iPod Nano and an experimental wristwatch design has quickly exploded online, receiving over $540,000 in funding through Kickstarter, a Web site that helps people find support for projects.

Both the main Democratic and Republican campaign committees ended the 2010 political season with roughly $15 million in debt from their final attempts to sway voters in the days before the midterm elections, according to financial disclosure reports filed late Thursday night that track the period between Oct. 14 and Nov. 22.

The awards campaigning for Lesley Manville seems to be working just fine so far. Ms. Manville, who plays Mary, a needy middle-aged women with a touch of a drinking problem in Mike Leigh's "Another Year," took home the best actress award from the National Board of Review on Thursday. Michael Kors may not like the term "Pre-Fall" but he embraces the concept. As he pointed out at his, er, Pre-Fall presentation on Thursday, the day after Labor Day is a little early to be busting out the triple ply cashmere, tweed and fur. "These are the pieces you want to be wearing in September," he said of the graphic sweaters, narrow pants and day dresses in royal blue, red, white and black. When it comes to this voluminous coat in particular -- and also the sharp, zip-back flats -- we have to agree.

Political downfall, military heroism, the educational system, the financial crisis, Rwandan genocide and the paparazzi are the subjects addressed by the films nominated for the year's best documentary by the Producers Guild of America. "Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer," from Alex Gibney; "Inside Job," by Charles Ferguson; "The Tillman Story," about Pat Tillman, the football player turned Afghanistan war casualty; "Waiting for 'Superman,'" Davis Guggenheim's attention-getting look at the country's schools; "Earth Made of Glass," which centers on the Rwandan president and a citizen dealing with the aftermath of the genocide there; and "Smash His Camera," about the pioneering celebrity photographer Ron Galella, were all chosen.

This is it. The last weekend of college football. It seems as if we're getting used to the idea of Oregon playing Auburn in Glendale, but I think that we're forgetting that sometimes that last win is the hardest to get. Remember unranked (and sub .500) Pittsburgh shocking No. 2 West Virginia in 2007? What about No. 2 U.C.L.A. losing to Miami in 1998? No. 2 U.S.C. losing to U.C.L.A. in 2006? Those were the last games of the season and games that those teams were all favored in. Then you have the championship games, where teams have lost the chance to play for national titles in the past. Tennessee in 2001 and Kansas State in 1998 are two examples from the B.C.S. era.

A major group representing Iraq and Afghanistan veterans announced on Friday morning that it supports repealing the military's ban on openly gay men and women service members. The announcement by the group, Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America, comes as the Senate is considering legislation to rescind the 17-year-old law, popularly known as "don't ask, don't tell."

The hardcover list this week shows the diversity of graphic novels. Witness: Book Two of "Troublemaker" (at No. 2), in which the novelist Janet Evanovich takes characters from her prose novels and brings them, in a new adventure, to the graphic novel format. The book is co-written by the author's daughter, Alex, and illustrated by Joelle Jones, and it follows the story of a Nascar driver named Sam Hooker and Alexandra Barnaby, a mechanic. The first volume of the graphic novel hit the No. 1 spot of the hardcover list in July.

Pete Peterson, the former cabinet secretary turned private equity billionaire, has been the No. 1 crusader against deficit spending. The fact that there seems to be a political consensus to cut spending when the economy is weak is a testament to his success.

At the party after the New York premiere on Tuesday, the Bagger spoke with Mila Kunis, who plays Natalie Portman's ballet frenemy, the dancing free spirit to her prima ballerina. Like Ms. Portman, Ms. Kunis trained rigorously for the movie, spending months working with Alexandra Blacker, a member of the Los Angeles Ballet. ("Blacker!" Ms. Kunis called, when she spotted her at the party; they have become friends.) On the red carpet, Ms. Portman wore a black gown and Ms. Kunis a cream one, with a heavily-shouldered jacket and Christian Louboutin stilletos. But at the party, she unself-consciously shuffled around in a pair of black hotel slippers, her dress puddling around her feet and trailing behind her. Toe shoes are likely not in her future.

This one he calls "Under the Sea," Little Mermaid not included. See it for yourself until January 5th.

The coming Off Broadway production of Chekhov's "Three Sisters" has become a who's who of young acting elite in New York theater. Marin Ireland, a Tony Award nominee for "Reasons to Be Pretty," will play the insecure and cruel Natasha, and Juliet Rylance, an Obie Award winner for the Bridge Project's "As You Like It," will play Irina, the youngest of the title trio, Classic Stage Company announced on Friday. Written in 1900, the play depicts the decline of Russia's privileged class through the lives of three sisters who grew up in sophisticated circles in Moscow and dream of returning there from their home in a provincial town.

Schools, universities, banks and government offices were closed again in Tehran on Thursday as a result of heavy air pollution, the second citywide shutdown in two weeks. The thick haze, blamed on a weather inversion that has trapped automotive and industrial emissions over the city, has lead to a 30 percent spike in hospitalizations from respiratory illness in recent days, health officials said. According to a recent World Bank study, heavy pollution has cost the Iranian economy $3.3 billion since March. [National Public Radio]

Today's jobs report is disappointing. The private sector added only 50,000 jobs in November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. Even with upward revisions to prior months, that is below what most economists expected and provides more reason to think targeted fiscal stimulus is needed.

Now it appears to be moving sideways again, as it did last summer. Whenever it does turn up again, it will have a long way to go.

By now, many people with even a casual interest in automobiles have heard of Jay Lamm's hoopty racing fever-dream, the 24 Hours of LeMons. The fun-first race series for $500 cars has made real road racing more accessible than perhaps ever before. To quote Mr. Lamm, "At LeMons, racing isn't just for rich idiots, it's for all idiots." LeMons is, and always has been, about fielding a more terrible and ridiculous car than the team in the next pit. As I am one to revel in the irrational and idiotic aspects of car culture, I had to have a truly hateful car.

For years, it seemed as if precision lighting was a fundamental element of retail design. Stores had the perfect amount of soft, incandescent light with a touch of track lighting to highlight a featured ensemble, akin to the way museums focus light on fabulous works of art. Unfortunately, those days are over. A new and incredibly irritating trend has sprung up in retail design: dark, darker and nocturnal.

The suspects were small and furry and elusive, as mice tend to be. They were scurrying around Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan. Janitors were put on the case. Traps were set - glue traps, to be exact. We wrote about them. But not everyone was happy: someone complained to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. PETA proposed alternatives: traps of the neck-snapping variety. They are more humane, after all - no frustrating struggle for the desperate, confused, snared animals; no long, slow slide toward inevitable death. Just one spring-loaded thwack! and it's all over. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, in command of the nation's largest municipal police force, listened to the recommendations. He mulled them. He accepted and improved upon them.

GAREEN--Paul Shelomo. Born in the shtetl Horodecz, Poland, on July 6, 1921, passed away at home in New York, November 27, 2010. Son of Rabbi Mordechai and Feigl Greenberg. Cherished husband of Diane Brody Gareen. Beloved father of Ilana F. Gareen and the late Ahri L. Gareen. He will be lovingly remembered by his granddaughters Shelly, Yael, Arielle, and Jessica, by his son-in-law, Andy, and his beloved sisters-in-law Clair Brody and Feige Brody and daughter-in-law, Kahal. Donations may be made to Ansche Chesed Synagogue, 251 West 100th Street, Manhattan, 10025, and to Dorot, 171 West 85th Street, New York, New York, 10024.

Video games and the people who play them are now so diverse that buying games for others, and perhaps even for yourself, has actually become a bit more confusing. For me, the key to a great game is the interplay between the freedom to do what I want in an interesting game world and the sets of rules, constraints and specific goals that give the experience direction and purpose. Of course, a great game for children will rarely do that in the same way as an engrossing experience for adults. So to be clear, these are some of my favorite games of 2010. I'm an adult, so most of these games are for adults. They generally contain violence and are at times profane. They are also a ton of fun and each is engrossing in its own way. If you're looking for excellent games for children and the whole family, please see my gift guide for the Arts section of The New York Times. Grown-ups, step forth.

Chicago has been home to far bigger transactions than the one being discussed between Google and Groupon. But few, if any, have had as much riding on it for the city as this $6 billion deal does. Groupon, a Chicago company coveted for its ability to mobilize millions of people online to buy local products, offers steep daily discounts to consumers on an array of products and services. If the Google-Groupon deal is completed, Groupon will be one of the country's biggest start-up success stories and one likely to spur a frenzy of new investment in Internet-based companies, including more in sometimes-overlooked Chicago.

ALONSO--Oscar. Dr. Joseph Masci, Director of Medicine at Elmhurst Hospital Center and entire Department of Medicine extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. George Alonso, Director Infection Control and his family for the loss of his father, Oscar Alonso.

Talks between the Yankees and Derek Jeter appear to be slowly moving forward, and the team now appears willing to offer its captain and shortstop a contract of three or four years at $16 million to $18 million a year, according to two people in baseball briefed on the status of the negotiations. The Yankees' offer to Jeter had stood at three years at $15 million a year. They have improved those terms, but the two people who disclosed them said there was still substantial ground to be bridged with Jeter and his agent before an agreement is reached and that a deal is not close.

WHEN Gordon Moore predicted 45 years ago that the number of transistors in a chip would double about every two years, he probably wasn't thinking about toys. But there's no better evidence of the accuracy of Moore's Law than the toys on this list. Here are 10 Gadgetwise selections culled from the last year. You'll find something for each age and budget. SING-A-MA-JIGS (Mattel, $13 each, ages 3-up) are hand-held plush toys that emit a musical pitch each time they are squeezed. When two or more are squeezed simultaneously, their specially tuned voices make a song, allowing children to play with chord structure. The noisy creatures serve another function: grown-up repellent.

COOPER--Margaret Rice. Born January 19, 1920, Los Angeles, CA, died December 2, 2010, New York City. Daughter of Elmer and Hazel Rice, mother of Richard and the late Ann Cooper, sister of the late Robert Rice, half sister of Paul, Katya and the late John Rice, aunt to Josh and Susan Rice. A lifelong resident of Manhattan, she attended the Horace Mann School, the University of Chicago, and the Art Students League. Author of books for children and young adults, including "The Inventions of Leonardo Da Vinci", "The Ice Palace" and "The Great Bone Hunt." Founder of Faces magazine for children. Longtime employee of The American Museum of Natural History in the exhibition department. Word traveler, lover of theater and art. She will be greatly missed by her family and many friends.

President Obama hosted a luncheon on Thursday for newly elected governors across the street from the White House at Blair House, where he promised to work closely with them to fix the economy and improve education over the next two years. But while Ohio's incoming Republican governor, John Kasich, was among the nearly two dozen state chief executives at the lunch, the Democrat he beat in November, Gov. Ted Strickland, was not left out in the cold. In fact, he got a personal visit with the president hours earlier in the Oval Office, the only governor singled out for such special attention.

LEVINE--Max Henry, age 70, died suddenly December 1, 2010. He was born to Antonina Monocco and Milton Levine in New York, May 13th, 1940 and raised in Mahopac, NY. He graduated from Mahopac High School and Colgate University. He served in the US Marines from 1962-1965, retiring as a first lieutenant. He was married to Judy Wright in 1963. He was the co-founder of Hoenig and Company and head of institutional sales trading from 1967 until the firm was sold. He remained an active trader until his untimely death. He was partners with his son Michael for the past 18 years. Among his numerous charitable and civic contributions were co-founder of The St. Jude's Wall Street Committee, The New York State Trooper's Signal 30 Fund, Member of the board of trustees for Ithaca College and numerous Catholic charities. He is survived by his wife Judy, his daughter and son-in-law Donna and Donald Takash, their three children Daniel, Elizabeth, and Sarah, his son Michael and Michael's son, Max Henry Levine II. Visiting Sunday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road Larchmont, NY 10538, (914)834-0144. Funeral Mass: Monday 10am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Ronald McDonald House would be appreciated.

LEHRMAN--Theodore H. passed away December 1, 2010. He is survived by devoted wife of 60 years, Barbara, beloved children Woody and Laurie, and five grandchildren. As a man passionate about music, film, and theater, he dedicated himself to the careers of aspiring actors. He cared deeply for those he guided and held them very close to his heart. Earlier in life he co-wrote well-known songs such as "No Man is an Island," and was the lyricist for the Soupy Sales albums. He loved people and touched everyone, whether they were family, friends, actors, students, or people on the street. We loved him dearly. Services will be held Sunday, December 5, 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City. Donations honoring his memory can be made to The Actors Equity Foundation, 165 West 46th St. NY, NY 10036.

She may not sing, but the ''CBS Evening News'' anchor, Katie Couric, will at least make a cameo on Fox's special episode of ''Glee'' after the Super Bowl on Feb. 6. A spokesman for Ms. Couric confirmed Thursday that she had been booked by the show but shared no further information. The studio that produces ''Glee,'' 20th Century Fox, declined to comment.

MIAMI BEACH - The crowds that used to form more than an hour before the opening of the ''First Choice'' portion of Art Basel Miami Beach-the four-hour window between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. when only elite collectors can enter and browse the fair-are gone. Gone too are the speculators who before the financial crisis used to race down the aisles as soon as the doors opened in order to snag a work that they thought they could flip at a profit a few months later. Indeed, on Wednesday during ''First Choice'' things seemed sedate compared to the years before 2008. Some described the giant convention hall as ''empty.'' That doesn't mean that things didn't sell. The extreme caution and modesty of 2008 and 2009, the hesitation to be seen spending, is gone, too. Pay in the financial world is roaring back to pre-crisis levels, and art is increasingly seen as a safe place to park money, like gold. So galleries including Gagosian, David Zwirner, Pace and Andrea Rosen all reported making several sales, and major collectors like Steven A. Cohen, Peter Brant, and David Tieger wandered around the fair, often being stalked by journalists hoping to catch them in the act of closing a deal. (The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. Cohen bought Adel Abdessemad's ''Mappemonde'' for approximately $300,000 at Zwirner and a work by Tim Hawkinson for $180,000 from the gallery Blum & Poe.) But although many dealers and collectors cited a renewed optimism and exuberance-''I guess maybe the art world hasn't heard about the recession,'' said Don Rubell, the major Miami collector-later in the evening a more cynical European collector described the fair as relatively anemic. He recalled how, in earlier years, he had to arrive by 9:30 a.m. to have a chance of getting through the doors by 11:30. This year, he arrived at 10:45 and was the first in line. It worked out well for him: He walked right in and bought a piece.
