Angelina Jolie defended a film she is directing about a love story set during the 1990s Bosnian war from a fresh round of criticism, saying she did not intend to cause controversy and that most Bosnians supported the project, Reuters reported. Ms. Jolie, who is making her directorial debut on the film, about a romance between a Serbian man and a Bosnian woman, recently shot portions in Bosnia. Her permit to film there was briefly canceled amid an outcry from residents including the Bosnia's Women Victims of War association, whose president, Bakira Hasecic, said the film depicted its female character ''falling in love with her torturer,'' a claim Ms. Jolie denied.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer neared an exit from bankruptcy protection on Thursday after a federal judge approved its reorganization plan, less than a month after it filed for Chapter 11. Under the plan approved by Judge Stuart Bernstein of the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan, M.G.M.'s creditors will take over the film studio in exchange for forgiving more than $5 billion in claims.

Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Thursday about the Afghanistan parliamentary election results misstated the earliest date that the new parliament could begin its work. It is Jan. 21, not Jan. 2, and therefore is roughly seven weeks away, not four and a half weeks.

For more than six decades, Frank W. Lewis mesmerized, mystified and miffed a circle of obsessed people by writing a devilishly quirky cryptic crossword puzzle for The Nation. But there were some bridges even he would not cross. If the clue ''BEFORE FALL'' led to the answer ''PRIDE,'' for example, drawing from the Bible, he conceded that it would be ''carrying things a trifle too far,'' as he wrote in an essay, to use the clue ''SUMMER.''
Room for Debate: What is a college degree worth in China? Experts discuss why many Chinese graduates are unable to capitalize on their advanced education. nytimes.com/roomfordebate.

Visitors to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington will no longer be able to find the David Wojnarowicz video ''A Fire in My Belly'' there, but they will not have to travel far to see it. Transformer, a Washington-based arts organization, has been playing it in the front window of its gallery on P Street NW, near Logan Circle, and says it will continue to do so on a 24-hour loop until the National Portrait Gallery reinstates it. The National Portrait Gallery, which is part of the Smithsonian, took the video out of an exhibition called ''Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture'' after the Catholic League and members of the House of Representatives said the work was offensive to Christians. Among the imagery that Mr. Wojnarowicz, who died of AIDS in 1992, uses in the video to depict the suffering of an AIDS patient is a scene of ants crawling on a crucifix.

LASKIN--Meyer. In grief and love, the Laskin family remembers Meyer Laskin, who died on November 30, 2010, at the age of 84. A child of immigrants, Meyer lived out an American success story, forging an impressive business career. Associates valued his intelligence and integrity. To friends, he embodied the ideal of an ethical, caring life. For his wife of 63 years, Leona, he was a lifetime companion in all the adventures of marriage. For his four sons Robert, Daniel, David, and Jonathan he was the Dad who read to them, coached their teams, skied and hiked with them, imparted a love of the Adirondack Mountains, gave them wise advise, and showed them, by example, that success in life is measured by morals, not money. His seven grandchildren discovered, with their Papa, the tang of a mountain morning, the glory of a summit view, and the meaning of the word mensch. The family asks that memorial contributions be made to the Adirondack Chapter of the Nature Conservancy, Adirondack Land Trust, PO Box 65, Keene Valley, NY 12943; or to Penn Hospice at Rittenhouse, 1800 Lombard Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19146.

An article on Friday about the reaction of Auburn University football fans to the team's success amid controversy surrounding its starting quarterback misidentified the Apollo mission that Ken Mattingly, an astronaut and noted Auburn alumnus, participated in. It was Apollo 16 -- not Apollo 13, which he missed because of health concerns. The article also referred incorrectly to several Auburn flags that Mattingly carried with him on the mission. He never planted one of them on the moon. (As command module pilot of Apollo 16, he did not set foot on the moon.)

An article on Nov. 24 about the controversy surrounding the recruitment of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton and N.C.A.A. investigators' interest in one of his father's churches referred incorrectly to $50,000 in repairs to the church, which the city of Newnan, Ga., closed in 2008. That was the cost for all projects, including some that had not been completed before the church closed; that amount was not the cost for just repairs that had been completed.

Madoff's Ponzi scheme sued JPMorgan Chase for $6.4 billion on Thursday, contending that the bank bears some responsibility for the losses of victims because it continued to serve as Mr. Madoff's primary banker despite growing evidence that he was running an enormous fraud.

Fisk University in Nashville, which wants to sell a $30 million ownership stake in its Stieglitz art collection to raise money, plans to appeal a court decision that set limits on the sale, the university announced on Wednesday. The ownership stake is going to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., but the sale has raised concerns among those who question the university's need to sell items given to it as a public trust by the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, who married the photographer Alfred Stieglitz.

Boehner of Ohio, the soon-to-be speaker of the House, and two other Republican lawmakers on Thursday laid out proposed rule changes for the next Congress - which include mandating that spending on new programs be offset by budget cuts and changing how more ceremonial measures are dealt with.

LONDON - As a trader at JPMorgan Chase in London, Ashish Goyal helps manage billions of dollars of the bank's exposure to risks like foreign exchange fluctuations. In his spare time, he takes tango lessons, plays cricket and goes clubbing with friends. Mr. Goyal is also blind. Watching him in the middle of the trading floor as he switches back and forth between computer screens, that is not apparent at all. But to check his e-mail, read research reports and look at presentations, Mr. Goyal uses a screen-reading software whose speed is so high that it sounds like gibberish to the untrained ear. When he needs to read graphs, which the software cannot do, Mr. Goyal goes through the data and tries to imagine the graph in his head.

JACOBS--Richard A. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare deeply mourn the passing of our longtime trustee and supporter Richard (Dick) Jacobs. A trustee since 1985, he served as Board Chair from 1989-1993. He was also the founding chair and a trustee of Jewish Home Lifecare's Westchester Division, the Sarah Neuman Center. Throughout his tenure, Dick made numerous contributions to Jewish Home's growth and expansion. In 1991, he led the initiative to purchase the Sarah R. Neuman Nursing Home and reopen it as a not-for-profit skilled nursing center. He spearheaded a capital campaign that raised $47 million, funded building improvements and provided countless programs and services to benefit residents. Under his leadership, Sarah Neuman added a new wing, a short-stay rehabilitation program and an adult day care program. Dick also played a key role in developing the Fund for the Aged, the philanthropic arm of Jewish Home Lifecare. He chaired the Board Marketing Committee and was a member of the Healthcare Committee. Dick and his wife Pat were actively involved in daily life and activities at Sarah Neuman. They established the Jacobs Rose Garden which provides a beautiful oasis for residents, families and staff to enjoy. Pat is the founder of the Friends of Sarah Neuman, an auxiliary dedicated to ensuring the highest quality of resident life. Together, Dick and Pat were honored as 2005 Trustees of the Year by the Association of Jewish Aging Services. Over the years, Dick provided exceptional leadership and gave tirelessly to the residents, many of whom knew him personally. His years of dedicated service and good fellowship earned him the highest respect and regard from all who had the pleasure to know and work with him. We will miss him deeply. Our thoughts are with Pat, daughters Suzanne and Diane, and grandchildren Masha and Jake during their time of loss. Stanley H. Pantowich Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

An article on Monday about classified State Department cables obtained by WikiLeaks, an organization devoted to revealing secret documents, misstated the most recent year covered by the department's unclassified history series, titled ''Foreign Relations of the United States.'' It is 1976, not 1972. The article also referred incorrectly to Ahmed Zia Massoud, an Afghan official who, a secret cable reported, visited the United Arab Emirates last year carrying $52 million in cash, described as a ''significant amount.'' Mr. Massoud, who has denied the report, was one of Afghanistan's two vice presidents; he was not the lone vice president. And the article also referred incorrectly to an unidentified Yemeni official who, according to another secret cable, had joked about lying to Yemen's parliament by saying that Yemeni forces, not American forces, had carried out missile strikes in Yemen against Al Qaeda targets. The unidentified official was one of Yemen's two deputy prime ministers, not the only one.

JACOBS--Richard Alan. It is with profound sorrow that our family announces the death of Richard Alan Jacobs at his home in Rye Brook, NY on December 2, 2010. He was a man of integrity, loyalty, curiosity, and great sense of humor. His devotion to family was unsurpassed. The son of Joseph and Millicent, sister of Madeleine Goldfarb (all deceased), he was adored by and adored his wife of sixty-five years Pat, daughters Diane Jacobs and Suzanne Davidson, and grandchildren Masha Rabkin and Jake Davidson. Dick graduated from the Franklin School and the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School. A lieutenant in the Navy during World War II, he was assigned to the USS Arkansas and fought at DDay, Iwo Jima and Okinawa. He was President of the first Jewish advertising agency, Joseph Jacobs Organization, which he inherited from his father, but he made his own. Dick was a truly giving man: past President of his temple, past Chairman of the Board of Jewish Home Lifecare and its Westchester division Sarah Neuman Center. During his retirement he devoted his time to a new career as an arbitrator for FINRA, to volunteering in his community and to his favorite sport, Golf. As a family man, friend and patriot, no finer human being ever lived. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Richard A. Jacobs may be made to Jewish Home Lifecare, or its subsidiary Sarah Neuman Center, 120 West 106th Street, New York, NY. 10025. Funeral service December 5, 2pm, Temple Emanuel of Westchester. Entombment immediate family.

An article on Thursday about the Food and Drug Administration's decision not to approve two prostate drugs for use in reducing cancer risk misstated the academic affiliation of Dr. Ian Thompson, a urologist who led a study of one of the drugs, finasteride. The main question they consider: Is legitimate research being cast as insider trading by regulators, or is there evidence of actual criminal wrongdoing? nytimes.com/dealbook

While the IFC cable channel stakes its future on a slate of original comedies aimed at young male viewers who like to stay up until the wee hours, it is also looking to the recent past to help build its library. On Thursday IFC said it had acquired the rights to four breakthrough comedy shows from the 1990s, a not-too-long-ago era when David Cross and Bob Odenkirk were wide-eyed newcomers looking for things to be cynical about, and Judd Apatow produced everything but nobody realized it yet. The vintage series that IFC will present as part of a nightly 90-minute comedy block are ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' the HBO series about a self-loathing late-night host played by Garry Shandling; ''The Ben Stiller Show,'' a short-lived but influential Fox sketch show that helped introduce viewers to Mr. Stiller and pals like Janeane Garofalo and Andy Dick; and ''Mr. Show With Bob and David,'' a slightly longer-lived HBO sketch show created by Mr. Odenkirk and Mr. Cross, both ''Ben Stiller'' veterans.

TAKAHASHI to ANGELS Hisanori Takahashi, who was one of the most valuable pitchers on the Mets' 2010 staff and one of the most versatile in the team's history, agreed to a two-year deal with the Los Angeles Angels, the team announced. Takahashi, a 35-year-old left-hander, has been working out in Yokohama, Japan, for the past few weeks but was headed to California to take a physical for the Angels, the last step before the contract can be completed.

VIDEO games and the people who play them are now so diverse that buying games for others, and perhaps even for yourself, has actually become a bit more confusing. For me, the key to a great game is the interplay between the freedom to do what I want in an interesting game world and the sets of rules, constraints and specific goals that give the experience direction and purpose. Of course a great game for children will rarely do that in the same way as an engrossing experience for adults. So to be clear, these are some of my favorite games of 2010. I'm an adult, so most of these games are for adults. They generally contain violence and are at times profane. They are also a ton of fun and each is engrossing in its own way. If you're looking for excellent games for children and the whole family, please see my gift guide for the Arts section of The Times. Grown-ups, step forth.

After an election cycle in which the Republicans picked up nearly two-dozen additional seats in the State Legislature, a new endangered political species has been identified at the Capitol: the white Democratic woman. State Representative Donna Howard of Austin is the lone remaining Anglo female Democrat in the Texas House, having watched four of her kind be defeated on Nov. 2: Valinda Bolton of Austin, Carol Kent of Dallas and Kristi Thibaut and Ellen Cohen, both of Houston. In the Senate -- where men hold 25 of 31 seats -- Wendy Davis, Democrat of Fort Worth, is, like Ms. Howard, the single white female.

10 P.M. (NBC) WINDS OF WAR: GEORGE CLOONEY IN SUDAN In this ''Dateline NBC'' report, Ann Curry joins Mr. Clooney (above left, with Ms. Curry, center), the actor and human-rights advocate, on a fact-finding mission in southern Sudan. A referendum is planned there for Jan. 9 on whether the region should secede from the north and form its own country after decades of war and marginalization, threatening to throw the nation further into chaos. The two are joined in Sudan, and on a whistle-stop tour of the United States, by John Prendergast, who served as director of African affairs at the National Security Council during the Clinton administration and is a founder of the Enough Project, an antigenocide organization. Mr. Clooney also speaks about working with impoverished people who are struggling for peace. Ms. Curry interviews Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, about what a secession could mean, and how the Obama administration might react if unrest descends into genocide. 7 P.M. (National Geographic) CROCODILE KING With a typical adult male measuring 20 feet long and weighing 2,900 pounds, the salt-water crocodile is the world's largest reptile. This program uses high-speed cameras and infrared technology to travel into the Northern Territory of Australia, where the crocodile rules rivers and estuaries while battling the extremes of nature for its own kind of dominance. In ''Dog Whisperer,'' at 8, Cesar Millan comes to the rescue of Donna Kronenfeld and her Australian shepherd, Snickers, who was attacked by two off-leash boxers and now has the urge to bite dogs and humans.

A picture caption on Nov. 17 with an article about Phillies pitcher Roy Halladay, who faced 993 batters and walked only 30 last season in winning the National League Cy Young Award, erroneously attributed a distinction to Grover Cleveland Alexander in some editions. As the article noted, Alexander, who faced 1,246 batters in 1923 and walked 30, was the last player to face so many batters while walking so few; he was not the last pitcher to match Halladay's walks-to-batters ratio. (Cliff Lee walked 18 of the 843 batters he faced in 2010, for a better ratio than Halladay's.)

MOCH--Joan K.,83, died November 30, 2010 in White Plains. A daughter of Alfred and Geraldine Kahn, she was a graduate of the Julliard School and also an accomplished ceramist. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Gerald M. Moch, children Susan A. Moch (Roland Poirier) and Kenneth I. Moch (Ellen Stolzman), grandchildren Marc and Alison Poirier and Jonathan and Stephen Moch, sister Bunny Marks, brother-in-law Irving Moch, Jr. and many loving nieces, nephews and friends. Funeral services will be held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY, Friday, December 3, 2010 at 9:15am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the Julliard School of Music.

Naomi Campbell's been accused of many things, but crimes against hair? The beehive she sported on the stand at the United Nations war-crimes trial of Charles Taylor at The Hague last summer garnered a lot of buzz, but the buzz was tinged with ridicule - a clear indication that while the style possessed a lot of pins, it didn't have real legs. The staid, sculptured bumps of hair looked painfully anachronistic, and just like that, a trend that seemed fresh on Prada's fall runway came tumbling down. ''For all the talk of the beehive this fall, no one's really wearing it,'' says Orlando Pita, who created the edgy style on the previous page. ''The big editorial up-do doesn't translate into real life.'' Accordingly, at the spring shows, hair started to come undone. There were long, partial plaits at Givenchy, sex-kitten tousles at Isabel Marant and half-up-half-down dos at Miu Miu and Christopher Kane, while the rocker chicks at Balmain looked like they had just rolled out of bed. For Pita, the new down-do is all about texture. ''We've seen perfectly blown out, silicone-sleek hair for so long,'' he says. ''The new texture doesn't look so worked on. It's all in the brushing and the products you use.'' Pita sprays Elevate, a texturizer from his own line, into wet hair and dries it using his fingers to encourage the natural wave. (Everyone has one.) Next, he sprays dry shampoo (his version is called Refresh) onto the roots (avoiding the top of the head) in one-inch sections. Finally, he gently brushes it out with a Mason Pearson brush, fluffing the hair so ''it feels soft, not tacky with product. I call it the anti-blow dry.''

As the ocean liner steamed in from the open sea and approached the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the boy worried that the ship's superstructure would not clear. ''It was a cold, sunny winter day, Wednesday, the 22nd of December, 1965,'' he said. ''There are certain dates etched in your memory.'' His journey to America had begun in Egypt, where his father was a leading religious figure. ''The image of the Statue of Liberty came into view slowly . . . such majesty and beauty. It was a life-changing moment in my life. I was 17 years old.'' That Feisal Abdul Rauf's American story began off the southern tip of Manhattan can seem foreordained, in light of the controversy that consumed him 45 years later. At his first glimpse of his new world, he told me, ''I had an intuition that my work would involve introducing Islam to America.'' Yet at that point, young Rauf was himself in the throes of typical adolescent questioning. ''In such a free society - it was the '60s! - religion had become a matter of choice.'' Not so in Kuwait, where he was born, and where religion was inherited. In America, ''religion was passé. I was bewildered by all that. I was asking, 'Does God exist? What is the meaning of life?' And I found the answers to my religious questions as a matter of choice. I could choose to embrace my Muslim faith - and I did.'' That simply, Feisal Abdul Rauf glimpsed the meaning of the nation's defining freedom. ''America made it possible for me to freely and deliberately choose to be religious and Muslim.'' Rauf would become an American citizen in 1979.

Complete the following sentence by the photographer Walker Evans: ''All my life I've wanted nothing so much as. . . .'' Freedom to pursue my work? The respect of my peers? A retrospective at MoMA? It's actually none of the above (all of which he either already had or would eventually have). No, what Evans wanted was leisure. And he had it - this was in 1947 - in the form of an unbelievably cushy job at Fortune magazine. We often hear of artists going into decline, but by the 1960s, Evans seemed to have fallen into terminal recline.

Julian Assange and WikiLeaks have been jettisoned to fame or notoriety (choose your noun, please) not because of a passing political battle but for reasons much deeper: the desire to possess, distribute and devour information. Ever since the release in July this year of some 92,000 documents relating to America's involvement in Afghanistan, an old joke from Communist times keeps spinning around my head. ''We cannot predict the future,'' announces the newsreader of Soviet radio reporting on the Politburo's deliberations, ''but the past is changing before our very eyes.'' Now our understanding of the nature of the intervention in Iraq has also changed radically with the publication of a still more astonishing collection of 391,832 secret United States military field reports from the kaleidoscopic theaters of battle.

The London restaurant, which opens next month in the Mandarin Oriental overlooking Hyde Park, will champion British food from Tudor times up through that 20th-century invention, the ploughman's lunch. The coming Off Broadway production of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' has become a who's who of young acting elite in New York theater. Marin Ireland, a Tony Award nominee for ''Reasons to Be Pretty,'' will play the insecure and cruel Natasha, and Juliet Rylance, an Obie Award winner for the Bridge Project's ''As You Like It,'' will play Irina, the youngest of the title trio, Classic Stage Company announced on Friday. Written in 1900, the play depicts the decline of Russia's privileged class through the lives of three sisters who grew up in sophisticated circles in Moscow and dream of returning there from their home in a provincial town. Ms. Rylance joins the previously cast Maggie Gyllenhaal (an Academy Award nominee for last year's ''Crazy Heart''), as the blunt, temperamental middle sister Masha, and Jessica Hecht (a Tony nominee in June for ''A View From the Bridge''), as the motherly elder sister Olga. Josh Hamilton (''A Lie of the Mind'') will play their brother Andrey, who suffers humiliation at the hands of his manipulative wife Natasha. Peter Sarsgaard will play Vershinin, one of Russian soldiers who befriends the sisters - and who begins an affair with Masha. (Offstage, Ms. Gyllenhaal and Mr. Sarsgaard married in 2009.)

LEHRMAN--Theodore H. passed away December 1, 2010. He is survived by devoted wife of 60 years, Barbara, beloved children Woody and Laurie, and five grandchildren. As a man passionate about music, film, and theater, he dedicated himself to the careers of aspiring actors. He cared deeply for those he guided and held them very close to his heart. Earlier in life he co-wrote well-known songs such as "No Man is an Island," and was the lyricist for the Soupy Sales albums. He loved people and touched everyone, whether they were family, friends, actors, students, or people on the street. We loved him dearly. Services will be held Sunday, December 5, 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City. Richard N. Goldman, a San Francisco civic leader and philanthropist best known for co-founding the Goldman Environmental Prize, which is given to six grass-roots environmental activists every year, died Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 90. His son John confirmed his death.

Virginia Thomas is stepping aside as chief executive of the conservative organization she founded, but intends to keep ties to a new alliance between that group, Liberty Central, and the Patrick Henry Center for Individual Liberty. Ms. Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, will be a consultant to Liberty Central, according to a statement released Friday. Gary Aldrich, the founder of the Patrick Henry Center and a former F.B.I. agent, will be in charge of day-to-day operations of the partnership.

If you're curious how your political beliefs line up with those of the businesses you shop at, a new online tool can help you. The tool, called Checking Influence, is a downloadable browser bookmark that analyzes your online credit card or bank account statement and presents you with a summary of the lobbying activities and campaign contributions of the companies you do business with, noting how much is going to Democrats versus Republicans.

YOUNG--Abraham R.,beloved son of Rose Tatz passed away suddenly on December 1, 2010. Born on July 12, 1926, he was 84 years old. Known affectionately as Abe to his friends and family, he was a beloved husband, brother and father to Sharon, Jeff, Ben, Stacy and Karen; loving grandfather to Jordyn and Alison, and Uncle "Abe" to so many. Known by all as loving, smart, funny and most of all having the sweetest soul. He will be missed by all. The funeral will be held this Sunday, December 5, Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 West Broad Street Mount Vernon, NY 10552 (914)664-6800. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla.

Speculation that Roger C. Altman, a prominent Wall Street investment banker and former Treasury deputy secretary, is a leading candidate to become the next director of President Obama's National Economic Council reignited on Friday when he was seen at the White House for a second time in recent weeks. Administration officials said Mr. Altman met with members of the economic team; Mr. Obama was away in Afghanistan on a surprise visit, but Mr. Altman had met with the president at the White House in mid-November.

After an eight-year dispute the Court of Appeals in Paris has ordered the estate of Aime Maeght, the Paris dealer who represented the sculptor Alexander Calder during his lifetime, to return seven sculptures to the artist's estate. ''In 2007 the Paris court ordered the gallery to return three other works that were in dispute,'' Mr. Rower said. He added that there are still three sculptures that the Maeght Gallery sold after Calder's death in 1976 but never paid the estate for. The court still has to determine whether the gallery will reimburse the estate for these works as well.

In a memorable scene in the movie ''The Social Network,'' Sean Parker, the investor played by Justin Timberlake, leans over the table and tells the founders of Facebook in a conspiratorial tone: ''A million dollars isn't cool. You know what's cool? A billion dollars.'' These days in Silicon Valley, a billion dollars seems downright quaint. The enthusiasm for social networking and mobile apps has venture capitalists clamoring to give money to young companies.

John Kinnucan, the research analyst who refused a request by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to wear a wire, has received a subpoena. In an interview with DealBook, Mr. Kinnucan said that an F.B.I. agent showed up at his front door in Portland, Ore., at 7:30 on Friday morning and served him with a subpoena, just as his children were leaving for school. ''These guys have a knack -- they must have a policy -- for showing up only when my wife and kids are home,'' Mr. Kinnucan said. The subpoena requests all of the records for him and his firm, Broadband Research, going back to 2008. Mr. Kinnucan said it was signed by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, whose office is spearheading a sprawling investigation into insider trading on Wall Street. ''I'm not worried,'' said Mr. Kinnucan, who has not been accused of any wrongdoing and plans to respond to the subpoena. ''Call me crazy. I know I'm the biggest whack job on the planet, but I feel fine.'' Mr. Kinnucan, 53, first appeared on the business press radar two weeks ago when The Wall Street Journal reported that in late October the F.B.I. had attempted to persuade him to wear a wire and record his calls with people at the hedge fund giant SAC Capital Advisors. He described the two agents who showed up at his front door as ''fresh-faced eager beavers.'' He later appeared on CNBC and wrote a commentary for DealBook, titled ''Why I Chose Not to Wear a Wire.'' News of the subpoena was earlier reported by Business Insider.

SILVERMAN--J. Herbert, noted travel and wine writer, passed on November 24, 2010. A veteran of WWII, he leaves his beloved wife Betty, and children Braden Silverman and Nora Kinne. He was predeceased by a son, Wiley. A memorial service will be held at a future date. View obituary and share memories at: www.edwardsanddowdle.com

Garry Trudeau has criticized many people and institutions in the 40 years since he first started drawing Doonesbury, the Pulitzer-Prize winning comic strip. But his latest cause is a personal one: he has come to the defense of two of his more colorful characters who've been banished from a Connecticut college campus. Since Tuesday, Doonesbury has focused on a 2008 decision by Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., to force students to rename two campus festivals that had been named for the characters Zonker Harris and Uncle Duke. The festivals - one in the fall and one in the spring - were held every year for more than 30 years.

Saddened though we are by recent developments in the extracurricular life of Jennifer Jason Leigh (who, it was reported, is divorcing her husband, the filmmaker Noah Baumbach), we take heart that she has new work to devote herself to, and continue to hope she'll find happiness with a nice movie-theater usher from the local mall. On Friday, press representatives for the coming Broadway revival of ''The House of Blue Leaves'' said Ms. Leigh, a star of films like ''Single White Female'' and ''Greenberg'' (and, lest we forget, ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High''), had joined this production. The previously announced cast for the revival of John Guare's dark comedy about a zookeeper with Hollywood ambitions includes Ben Stiller as Artie Shaughnessy, the zookeeper, and Edie Falco as his wife, Bananas. Ms. Leigh, who made her Broadway debut in ''Cabaret,'' will play Artie's mistress, Bunny Flingus.

TAMKIN--S. Jerome. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Dr. S. Jerome Tamkin of Pacific Palisades, California, a steadfast supporter of the Technion for many years. He was a member of the ATS Southern California Chapter Board. Together with his wife Judith, Dr. Tamkin funded projects he felt would benefit future generations, including the Dr. S. Jerome and Judith D. Tamkin Molecular Human Genetics Research Facility. The Tamkins were Technion Guardians, having achieved the highest level of commitment. They also received the Albert Einstein Award, the ATS' highest honor, in 1998. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Judith, brother Jack Tamkin, sons Steven Tamkin and Dr. Gary Tamkin, daughters Sherry Catlett and Windy Litvak, and the entire Tamkin family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

JACOBS--Richard Alan. It is with profound sorrow that our family announces the death of Richard Alan Jacobs at his home in Rye Brook, NY on December 2, 2010. He was a man of integrity, loyalty, curiosity, and great sense of humor. His devotion to family was unsurpassed. The son of Joseph and Millicent, sister of Madeleine Goldfarb (all deceased), he was adored by and adored his wife of sixty-five years Pat, daughters Diane Jacobs and Suzanne Davidson, and grandchildren Masha Rabkin and Jake Davidson. Dick graduated from the Franklin School and the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School. A lieutenant in the Navy during World War II, he was assigned to the USS Arkansas and fought at DDay, Iwo Jima and Okinawa. He was President of the first Jewish advertising agency, Joseph Jacobs Organization, which he inherited from his father, but he made his own. Dick was a truly giving man: past President of his temple, past Chairman of the Board of Jewish Home Lifecare and its Westchester division Sarah Neuman Center. During his retirement he devoted his time to a new career as an arbitrator for FINRA, to volunteering in his community and to his favorite sport, Golf. As a family man, friend and patriot, no finer human being ever lived. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Richard A. Jacobs may be made to Jewish Home Lifecare, or its subsidiary Sarah Neuman Center, 120 West 106th Street, New York, NY. 10025. Funeral service December 5, 2pm, Temple Emanuel of Westchester. Entombment immediate family.

ABC announced on Friday that it had appointed Ben Sherwood, a former executive producer of its ''Good Morning America'' program, as the next president of its news division. He will succeed David Westin, the longtime president of ABC News, who announced in September that he would step down at the end of the year. ABC is owned by the Walt Disney Company.

MANDELL--Shirley, passed away on December 3, 2010 at the age of 87. She was born Shirley Korentar to Annie and Mitchell on December 27, 1922 in the Bronx, NY. Mrs. Mandell was the youngest of three children. She had two older sisters, Florence Eisman and Katie Saed who both pre-deceased her. Mrs. Mandell married her beloved husband Sam, who also predeceased her on August 26, 1970. Mrs. Mandell spent many years as an administrative assistant at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in the Bronx. At the age of 68, she proudly received her college degree, graduating Suma cum laude from Lehman College in the Bronx. She had a love of learning and continued to take college courses into her 80's. She is survived by her devoted and loving nieces and nephews and their families. Services will be held on Sunday, December 5th at 10:30am at Gutterman's Funeral Home 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. 718-896-5252

One Saturday night this spring, a limber woman eating dinner at Elaine's walked up to Table 4, bent very low, and reached out her hand to pay her respects to the imposing woman seated there. The limber woman was Jane Fonda; the imposing one, Elaine Kaufman.

In a film career that some part of us still has difficulty accepting spans 35 years, Susan Sarandon has played the sexy prisoner of an interstellar transvestite; the sexy muse of a minor-league baseball team; a sexy outlaw on the run from phallocentric American society; and a nun; won an Academy Award and somehow become Ping-Pong's ambassador to the world. To celebrate most of these accomplishments (except for the Ping-Pong) the Brooklyn Academy of Music's BAMcinematek will present a four-day-long, 13-film tribute to Ms. Sarandon in February, the academy said on Friday. ''The Susan Sarandon Picture Show'' - come on, that's what you'd call it, too - will be presented from Feb. 10 through 13 at the BAM Rose Cinemas, and will include films like ''Dead Man Walking,'' ''Pretty Baby,'' ''Light Sleeper,'' ''Bull Durham,'' ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' and ''Thelma and Louise.'' Ms. Sarandon is expected to appear at a question-and-answer session during the festival, as are Paul Schrader (the writer and director of ''Light Sleeper'') and John Turturro (who directed Ms. Sarandon in ''Romance & Cigarettes''). The academy will announce additional guests and other details for the retrospective, which, as a great actress once said, will repair our losses and be a blessing to us. (You could look it up.)

SIMS--Franklin S.,on December 2, 2010. Beloved husband of June (nee Diedrich). Loving father of David (Lisa), Matthew and Lynne. Adored grandfather of Franklyn and Keira. Graduate of Fordham University, Class of 1961. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue, New York City, Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. There will be a Funeral Service at the funeral home starting at 7:30pm.

WALSH--Annie, 97, died November 2, 2010, having lived nearly a century in the pursuit and appreciation of art. Her zeal, her profound love of language and her heart are sorely missed by her two grandchildren, Sam and Molly Walsh, and her daughter-in-law, Susan. We invite you to remember her with donations to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in lieu of cards or flowers.

LimeWire, the popular music file-sharing service that ran afoul of the music industry, has reached its end. The company said on Friday that it would be shutting down by the end of the year and closing its sole office in New York. ''As a result of our current legal situation, we have no choice but to wind down LimeWire Store operations,'' LimeWire said in a statement. ''Despite our dedication and efforts, Dec. 31, 2010, will mark the day when LimeWire Store shuts its virtual doors.''

Investors have flocked to the ''set it and forget it'' style of mutual funds known as target-date funds, where the mix of investments automatically becomes more conservative as the retirement date approaches. But when the markets plunged, it became readily apparent that some funds did a better job of protecting investors than others. What was most surprising, however, was the wide variation in performance among funds with the same target date. And most alarmingly, some 2010 funds lost more than the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.

An article last Saturday about a flurry of diplomatic activity by China three days after a North Korean artillery attack on a South Korean garrison island misstated the island's civilian population at one point. As the article noted elsewhere, Yeonpyeong Island has about 1,350 civilians, not 1,600.

As an Irish-American, I don't usually trumpet the work of a nation that kept my ancestors under its boot heel for nearly 300 years. But having just finished the memoirs of two great exports of Britain, I rise to praise a pair of Brits in the season of book-buying. Christopher Hitchens, the polemical polymath, is to modern American discourse what Lenny Bruce was to comedy. He changed the game, and in so doing forced us to examine our core beliefs. His story, ''Hitch-22,'' was hitting the best-seller lists this year just as he was diagnosed with a killer type of esophageal cancer. He has vowed to go to his grave as an intellectually curious atheist.The beautiful ruin that is Keith Richards, guitarist and guiding musical force behind the Rolling Stones, is best known for being a living cadaver. A heroin addict during his most productive years, Richards the author is now competing with former President George W. Bush for bragging rights to the most popular nonfiction book in this country. In his story, ''Life,'' the United States and its black music saved him as a man and an artist.

WARSHAUER--Ruth. Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Jerusalem mourns the passing of Ruth Warshauer, Mother of our devoted Board Member Sivia Loria. Our thoughts are with the Warshauer family at this difficult time. Ilan Kaufthal, Chairman Bathsheva Rifkin, President

STEINBERG--Meyer. Dad, so many great-grandchildren - Isabelle, Macklin, Ryder, Charlotte, Avery, Edie and Macy - you would be so proud. Girl genes still stronger! Dad, love you and miss you. You are in my heart and thoughts every day. Lovingly, Susan

Next month, 11 Times Square, a new, glassy 40-story office tower at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, will formally open with its first tenant. Compared with the metamorphosis that has occurred around it, there is nothing extraordinary about the building except for this: Its completion officially marks the end of the long and tortuous redevelopment of Times Square, an effort that began 30 years ago. The plan, to radically make over 13 acres, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, primarily fronting 42nd Street, outlived three mayors, four governors, two real estate booms and two recessions. It faced widespread derision in the beginning from jaded New Yorkers who were wise to grand plans. It faces occasional derision today from New Yorkers who speak of the old Times Square with newfound fondness.

A potentially embarrassing lawsuit brought against Nickelodeon by a former star of its hit animated series ''Dora the Explorer'' is now off the table, and without any intervention from Swiper the Fox, the THR, Esq. blog of The Hollywood Reporter said. In October, Caitlin Sanchez, a voice actress who was hired at the age of 12 to portray the bilingual title character of ''Dora the Explorer,'' filed a suit that portrayed Nickelodeon less as a colorful factory of childhood dreams than a Dickensian sweatshop. The suit said Ms. Sanchez was forced to sign an ''unconscionable'' contract that required her ''to work hundreds of hours marketing the Dora Brand for free'' and prevented her from being paid residuals on her work and royalties from ''Dora'' merchandise. She also said she was dismissed from the job after her voice changed when she hit puberty.

Beatrice Kahn, Co-President Karol Todrys, Co-President Joan Shapiro Green, Exec Dir

LONDON - UBS, Switzerland's largest bank, appointed an executive at its American wealth management unit as the bank's next chief financial officer, the company said Friday. The executive, Thomas C. Naratil, will succeed John Cryan, who will leave UBS in May after nearly three years in the job. In some underground New York, Tokyo or London club, Shannon Funchess's powerful contralto punches through the fog-filled stage - as does the spread of green laser light emanating from behind her. Funchess, the Light Asylum frontwoman, drums and sings, pogoing around in a mix of black leather and new-wave neon, like a punker, harder-edged Grace Jones possessed by the sensibilities of Ian Curtis. Her voice has appeared on tracks by bands like Telepathe and TV on the Radio, but it's with this latest project (a duo, with Bruno Coviello on synth) that she has come into her own. Light Asylum is catchy but raw, music you can lose yourself in.

Forecasters whose predictions for advertising spending are closely watched are projecting better results for 2010 than initially expected. And they are mostly seeing better days ahead, spending-wise, for next year as well.

At a time when the weight of scientific evidence would seem to call into question the Bible's account of history and the God who set it in motion, the Virgin Mary enjoys a kind of free pass. As the third-century Christian theologian Tertullian wrote of the Resurrection, "It is certain because it is impossible" - a notion that might well apply to the virgin birth; such a conundrum that it elevates Mary to a safe place, beyond logic.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Almost everyone adores alliteration. Richard Chisholm likes it so much that, sure as shootin', he built a Monday theme around it. Along the way, and probably without even trying, he manages to include 16 H's, which ties the record for the most in a 15x15 grid.

"Nihilism stands at the door," wrote Nietzsche.  "Whence comes this uncanniest of all guests?"  The year was 1885 or 1886, and Nietzsche was writing in a notebook whose contents were not intended for publication.  The discussion of nihilism ─ the sense that it is no longer obvious what our most fundamental commitments are, or what matters in a life of distinction and worth, the sense that the world is an abyss of meaning rather than its God-given preserve ─ finds no sustained treatment in the works that Nietzsche prepared for publication during his lifetime.  But a few years earlier, in 1882, the German philosopher had already published a possible answer to the question of nihilism's ultimate source.  "God is dead," Nietzsche wrote in a famous passage from "The Gay Science."  "God remains dead.  And we have killed him."

It was a dark December, decades ago, a beastly night of sleet and hail, a night to ruin your favorite boots. Needing gifts and needing them in a hurry, I dashed from drugstore to thrift shop to the fresh hell that is Macy's at holiday time, in search of something that might slake the peculiar appetites of my peculiar circle. How pleasant to remember those desperate hours as I sit under an afghan, laptop on my knees! A few clicks are all it takes to find that for $150 bottegaveneta.com offers a woven-leather money clip, usa.hermes.com a ladybug key ring. What's that - you hate obvious labels? Perhaps an exception can be made for a Lanvin Cabas tote that resembles a laundry bag, if that item were made of marine blue nylon and cost $840 at barneys.com? Or even a graffiti-bespeckled motorcycle helmet by Martin Margiela at aloharag.com? If you insist that your gang's predilections swerve away from capitalist exccess, send Walter Benjamin's ''Arcades Project,'' 1,088 pages for $31 at www.hup.harvard.edu. But Americans defy categorization, and that same person enjoying Benjamin may be a defender of the Second Amendment, pouring port from a crystal decanter decorated with a shotgun-toting hunter from the old Park Avenue emporium scullyandscully.com. Or, if your posse prefers ''The Simpsons'' to Schopenhauer, try a pair of Bécassine plastic servant-girl earrings, invariably available on ebay.com. Don't think you know anyone who wants a pair of ear bobs based on a circa-1905 French comic-book scullery maid? Guess you haven't peeked inside my jewelry box lately.

The awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar is certain to change the way the world views the sport of soccer. These days, that metamorphosis is not limited to play on the field. In today's graphical world, computers and the human imagination have added a new dimension to objects as prosaic as the plain-vanilla tournament draw sheet.

Karl Smith sort of takes issue with my point about how Social Security is a favorite target of the Beltway crowd, because it's not important to anyone they know. "I doubt anyone thinks about it in such crass terms," he writes.

A dark and stormy night: the cliché has come to life, zombielike, and is clutching the party island of Bali in an intense and unseasonable monsoon. I've had to bribe my cabby to get him to take me to a spooky gate on a lonely country road. ''You can't miss it,'' Bickerton, a reclusive artist, had assured me. I don't. Set into twin niches chiseled into the stelae that serve as gateposts are two severed heads. Gene Simmons-caliber tongues writhe from mouths agape in midscream, and only their neon complexions give them away as sculptures.

One of the things you often hear is the claim that statistics showing falling inflation are just about housing. Via Mark Thoma, the San Francisco Fed has done the homework: the same downward trend is there if you purge housing from the core index:

Jessica Kerwin Jenkins's ''Encyclopedia of the Exquisite'" (Doubleday, $28) collects history's most reverie-inducing marginalia - on subjects like milk baths, italic typefaces and blancmange, a silky almond pudding name-dropped by Chaucer. The same sun-baked optimism that sent ''The Girl From Ipanema''into the stratosphere also spawned some of the best album art ever, now compiled in ''Bossa Nova and the Rise of Brazilian Music in the 1960s'' (Soul Jazz Books, $40). Punta Arenas, Abomey, Alice Springs: the postmarks in ''Under the Sun: The Letters of Bruce Chatwin'' (Viking, $35) betray an epic case of wanderlust. When good triumphs over evil, the comic-book heroes of Marc Guggenheim and Tara Butters's ''Halcyon'' (Image Comics, $3.50) face an uncommon enemy: ennui. A monograph on the man who made Marilyn's skirt billow: ''Sam Shaw'' (Hatje Cantz, $75). ''The Victorian hoop skirt, the Gibson Girl coif, the plume hat slouching over one winking eye'' - these and every other part of Gypsy Rose Lee are examined afresh by Karen Abbott in ''American Rose: A Nation Laid Bare'' (Random House, $26). And in ''We Have Met the Enemy: Self-Control in an Age of Excess'' (The Penguin Press, $27), Daniel Akst explains why there's a glut of everything these days - except willpower.

Updated, Tuesday, Dec. 7 | Six months or so ago, Jeffrey Ruhalter was a butcher in a deep funk, grappling with a sinking family business that dated back to his German great-great-grandfather in 1870. Jeffrey's Meat Market is, he says, the last original tenant at the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, opened by his grandfather in 1940. The dynamics of change, along with the global economic downturn, had blindsided him.

The latest holiday issue of T makes its debut this weekend with Mick Jagger on the cover. At 67, Jagger, the iconic rocker/style-setter/knight of the cultural realm, shows no interest in raking over the past - a fitting idea for a newly redesigned T. Along with several retooled features, you'll see plenty of fresh faces, among them Nicki Minaj, Reeve Carney, Sasha Pivovarova, Todd Selby and a full cast of up-and-comers in music, fashion, film and art. They're all gifted in some way, and they're our holiday gifts, along with other offerings both ruminative - the Icelandic volcano's surprise gift of time, Wikilieak's not-always-welcome gift of information - and retail: There's an eye-popping preview of the spring collection's boldest moments; a portfolio of languid, ladylike dresses worn by fierce modern beauties like Maggie Gyllenhaal and Mila Kunis; and a guide to gifts so good you can't give just one.

Eleven years ago, Donna and Philip Berber had a Texas-size life - a booming tech company in Austin (Cybercorp), three sons and, "you know, flowers in my garden," says Donna, who started A Glimmer of Hope, a foundation to help the rural poor in Ethiopia. Then, after seeing a video of his wife handing out bread to the hungry in Addis Ababa, Philip made a trip there himself and decided to "turn my back on my commercial career." With $60 million from the recent sale of Cybercorp to Charles Schwab (for $488 million), he joined the foundation full time, and the couple (he's Irish, she's English) became pioneers of philanthro-capitalism. The Berbers' endowment covers all of Glimmer's operating costs, which has allowed the foundation to spend $40 million and counting to help alleviate poverty in Ethiopia. "One hundred percent of the money, not 50 or 80 percent, needed to get to the people," says Philip, comparing Glimmer's business model with that of other charities. "We had to start with a clean piece of paper."

Suddenly everyone is talking about Thomas Tait, 23, the London-based Central Saint Martins graduate who in October, with barely two collections to his name, won the first-ever Dorchester Collection Fashion Prize. The Montreal-born Tait has yet to sell a single dress outside of private orders (some accessories are available through a project with Asos.com), but he says the prize money will enable him to begin proper production and retail sales. However, it's his new friends, famous for their taste, who are likely to move his business along the most. Giles Deacon, Daphne Guinness, Stephen Jones and others selected him for the award; another judge, Manolo Blahnik, has been widely quoted gushing over Tait's ''incredible couture mind.''

Sharon Wauchob just presented her first collection as creative director for Edun, the socially conscious line founded by Bono and Ali Hewson and now partially owned by LVMH. The Madagascar-made organic poplin cotton dresses and Kenyan beadwork found in a number of her clothes made us think: who better to advise on greening up holiday packaging supplies? Wauchob suggests recycled tissues from Calligrane ($14 per sheet, 6 Rue du Pont Louis Philippe) and, for ribbons, old ripped T-shirts strung with locally produced African beads (beadsofparadisenyc.com). ''Recycling should be impulsive,'' she says, ''an intimate way to give a little bit more.''
